=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At the very least: The best board game I played in 2010. Currently my favourite board game.

This game takes civilization building to a whole new level and plays in 30 minutes no matter how many people are playing (from 2 to 7).

Players only directly interact with their immediate neighbours and everyone selects and plays cards all at once. These two mechanics keep the game very fast-paced and fun!

Players can also choose different paths to victory: You can go military and try to beat up on your neighbours, go for science and try to get massive points in the final turns, go for wonders for unique benefits... so much more. No two games will be exactly the same. The same strategy will not always work.

The only thing I dislike about this game is the make-shift two-player variant, but the box does not even advertise that it can be played with two players so I'm fine with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game with any number of players 4-7. Really good for new people to board gaming even with the large amount of rules. Very easy to learn and to play. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Quick fun card drafting game with amazing artwork and a cool theme. Multiple ways to earn points lends itself to replayability. Initially disliked it because I was expecting to game to have more of a civ building feel but once I figured out that the game wasn't trying to be that it became great. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I admit this one is growing on me. I wasn't sure what to think of it the first dozen or so times we played it. I guess I expected more than a card game - more chits, more stuff to move. But there are a lot of things to like here. The downtime is zero; everyone plays at the same time. This also means the game can scale between 2 players and 7-8 players easily without increasing the game time much, if at all. Also, the game does not outstay its welcome. It never lasts longer than 30-45 minutes, which allows you to play through multiple games in an evening.

We introduced the Leaders expansion recently and think it is a great addition to the base game.

6-1-14: Bumped it up to an 8. Easy to teach, quick to play, and scales up very well from 2 to 7 players.

10-3-14: 18 months ago when we first bought this game, I rated it as a 7. After playing it a few more times, I bumped it up to a 7.5. Then after a few more plays, bumped it to an 8. Then an 8.5. And now I've increased the rating to a 9. I can't think of another game I've increased its rating after playing it so many times. I've played lots of 2, 3 and 4 players games, as well as a few with 6 or 7. When everyone has had a few plays under their belt this is a very competitive, tight game.

7-13-16: Bumped to a 10. This is one of my favorite games.

RATING: 9.3
My personal gateway game, 7 Wonders is amazing, yet very difficult to teach. The reliance on symbolism, as well as the way production and trade function seems to be esoteric to most, but I find 7 Wonders an amazingly elegant, deep and engaging game. One I almost always lose.

RATING: 7

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Card-drafting civilization building that scales very well and plays quickly.

I can see why people love this game; it plays quick, it has replayability, and it can accomodate 2-7 players (!), plus the theme "fits".  I'm not sure it has much in the way of strategy or control, but again because of the short playtime this is tolerable I guess (any game with card-drafting as the central mechanic seems tactical at best).

Setup/space is a bit of a pain in the ass, considering its a quick card game, so you almost have to have a big table and play several games back-to-back for it to be worth it.  2-player is a bit annoying for this very reason(s); that said, the "dummy" mechanic, which I usually do not enjoy at all, is implemented pretty well.  The cost and box-size/shelf-space is a bit absurd, when you compare it to say, oh Dominion.  This game also seems very expandable, and the Leaders expansion seems to be a must buy for me.  And oh, this is really a very very simple game to jump in and play, despite what the simpleton SdJ jury voters might lead you to believe.

Own the [boardgame=92539]Leaders[/boardgame], [boardgame=111661]Cities[/boardgame], [boardgame=154638]Babel[/boardgame] and [boardgame=133993]Wonder Pack[/boardgame] expansions, as well as the [boardgame=110308]Catan[/boardgame], [boardgame=83445]Manneken Pis[/boardgame], [boardgame=99315]Stevie[/boardgame], [boardgame=127838]Louis[/boardgame], [boardgame=156119]Wil[/boardgame], [boardgame=166329]Nimrod[/boardgame], [boardgame=231167]Leaders Anniversary pack[/boardgame] and [boardgame=231168]Cities Anniversary pack[/boardgame] promos.  This expansion (Leaders) adds another round of drafting, which leaves you with a hand of 4 leaders, 3 of which can be played during the course of the game.  The leaders allow for specialization/ways to score points/quick money etc., and add to the gameplay.  Really a simple addition and a must-have expansion for fans of 7 Wonders.

RATING: 10
Highly competetive card game with simple rules but complex strategy. Rarely used draft mechanics allows for a lot of player interaction. Randomness vs. skill is well balanced.  Definitely many skill levels exist.

Plays fast (7-14 minutes online, 25-40 minutes in real life), with simple set up and clean up. Strategy and experience depends on number of players (personally prefer 2-4 players).

Still feels fun and fresh after 5000 games.

Amazing art on the cards. Highly recommend sleeving cards due to barely acceptable durability.

A masterpiece.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like 7 Wonders more every time I play it. At our last play, we finished a quick three-player game and immediately turned around to play again. I love games that hit that under half hour mark and still leave you hungry to try to improve on your previous performance. 

It offers more flexibility beyond Sushi Go and is kind of like a +1 step to it, though some people in my game group seem to think that it's wildly more complicated. It's really not, but perhaps I overcomplicate it when I explain it -- need to work on that. 

It's nice that it plays 3-7 players, though -- we are always on the lookout for games that are good at 5, 6, or even 7 players.

7 Wonders is really close to my ideal light game. It takes a while to explain (for newbs, I prefer [thing=192291][/thing]), but when you sit down with people who know how to play, no other game plays so smoothly, accommodates such a flexible player count, and providers such a satisfying experience. One of my favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Growing on me slowly but surely. Add the expansions for a bit more flavor. Without the Leaders expansion, my rating of the base game would be a bit lower.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of my favorite newer strategy games.  

For me, the elements of a great strategy game include: 

(1) More skill-based than luck-based,
(2) Winning strategies change with circumstances,
(3) Straightforward / simple set-up, 
(4) Balanced gameplay,
(5) Does not drag on after one side has a decisive advantage, 
(6) Entertaining theme

7 Wonders scores high on all of these attributes.  There is a slight learning curve in 7 Wonders and it might take a round before the rules become clear to new players, but once everyone knows the rules, it's a a simple game that can be played in about 30 - 45 minutes, while also packing in a lot of strategy.

RATING: 5
A big beautiful game that is right in the Euro game wheel house.  It's simple and it exploits modern tastes in drafting and card combos so it's no suprise it's popular.  But it's not any better than Ticket to Ride, Carcassonne, or Settlers of Catan and it doesn't do anything that Race for the Galaxy or Fairy Tale don't already do.  I have no need of it, but I'll play someone else's copy.  I'm repulsed by the publishing company's use of hard to acquire promotional items to sell the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I tried hard to like 7 wonders, and it's ok, but not great, imho.  

For me the issue is that I feel like I would need pretty detailed knowledge about the cards to able to access its strategic depth. 

You buy your resources and economy stuff in Ages 1 and 2, while you're going to score a big chunk of your victory points from cars bought in Age 3. Obviously you can't see the Age 3 cards in ages 1 and 2, so unless you've memorised how much they're going to cost, all of your resource purchasing just feels like guesswork to me.

I'm fine for games to have a learning curve, but I want to feel like I can at least _access_ the puzzle within my first few plays, even if I need more practice to solve it or beat experienced players. I've played probably 10 times now and I still mostly feel like I'm making educated guesses in Ages 1 and 2, and then being constrained by those guesses in Age 3.

In terms of positives, 7 wonders is good to have around because it's so flexible in terms of player count, it has cool art, it's quick to play and it's a plausible option for non-gamers (as long as you have time for two games, and assure them that by the second game they will understand).

Sushi Go Party, however, checks all of these boxes as well. Having recently acquired SGP it remains to be seen how often 7W will come off the shelf now....

RATING: 8
11+ plays, 4,6,7 players.

LIKE: The card draft is fun and the table talk when someone passes you a great card, or pointing out someone has an edge. Fun and relatively quick, great game. (We usually play with expansions.) I enjoy the small amount of engine building.

DISLIKE: Shallow theme and the strategy is not deep either. Cards are iconified, so looking up what effect every card does is a drag.

OVERALL: Fun game. Great for larger groups. Not sure if the leaders expansion is necessary as it adds to game length.

RATING: 7
3 plays in a row in the first outing. I've now played with 3, 4, 5 and 6 players. Initially, we were all very confused about the game (and none of us are slouches at gamin') having no idea on strategy. It's clear the first game will end with many cards unable to be played or not helpful at all - e.g. learning that new resources really *can't* be added by the third age is extremely important. Combination are really confusing at first. You have to keep in mind several things: your resources, your neighbors resources, cards that produce other cards, and then evaluate each card based on cost - i.e. can you pay for it with your own resources or do you have to buy from a neighbor? Do you take this opportunity to build your Wonder? There are many variables - it results in a bit of AP as you trim the possible cards down to the few that produce sufficient benefit for the cost.

Given all this, I don't think this is a gateway game at all - it's more a filler for gamers. Speed of play is definitely a huge bonus here since you can dismiss the first game as a learning experience and give it another go without pause.

One key we discovered was using the included scoring pad. It's *far* easier to score everyone card type by card type - with one person recording the values for each: "Ok. What did you get for purple cards?" I'll be sure to do this from now on.

In the end, this game is fine and certainly fits a niche - those times you're waiting for others to arrive or filling time between things. But is it a game I'm anxious to play? Not really. It isn't terribly interesting. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Filler entretenido, entre familiar y juego de cartas... No está mal, pero prefiero otros juegos y me cansé de él jugando online.

RATING: 7
2010-12
A game that hit me seriously already at the first play. Plays fast and has many alternative strategies. 


2013-01-16
7 Wonders didn't stand the test of time since it has become a little monotonous. I'd like to see more variance from game to game. It's still a good game but there are times I do not fancy it.
8->7

2016-04-11
7 Wonders satisfies one of the most primitive human needs, that is accomplishing something. In every game you can see the progress you make right in front of your own eyes. You may miss a turn or two but your achievements last. On the first plays this is what gets you hooked. 

A few plays later you start to worry about your neighbours, and yet another layer of the game unfolds. Now you are not only trying to play your own game but also hinder your opponents'. This is what satisfies gamers' needs. Every turn you are facing trade offs between the best card for you and the best card for the next player.

However, just like I wrote before, it does not take too long until you have been in almost every conceivable situation and the game becomes a bit repetitive. Your decisions become obvious and the game reduces closer to what it was on the first plays, i.e., the satisfaction comes from building the civilisation not from competition.

I also have to say that the resource mechanics and especially how you pay for the cards is rather counter intuitive. New players have needed quite a bit of explaining and some practical examples to learn how the game plays. Personally I do not like teaching 7 Wonders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
A classic civilization building game that scales elegantly and will take just as long to play at 3 or 7 players (though 5 is probably optimal). This was one of the first modern games I got into with a card drafting mechanic and tableau building mechanic. It has withstood the test of time and will likely be a staple in my game library for many years to come. The only drawbacks in my opinion are that the iconography can present a steep learning curve for new players and since you can only directly influence the play of those to your immediate left and right, certain people in the right position in the turn can benefit wildly from being next to novice players and others just the opposite by being next to experienced ones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
As I play more games I am slowly realizing that drafting cards (and building decks for that matter) are not my preferred game mechanisms.

In this game one has to continually examine cards, keep one, and pass along the others until everyone has kept a certain amount of cards. Then points are tallied up based on the cards drafted as they fall into "families" (military, science, etc.).

There is a bit of a leaching aspect of your neighbour's cards which I liked.

Familiarity with the type of cards in the game and their function is needed to succeed. 

Its simplicity is its brilliance but it's simply not something I want to play over and over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Zee - 8
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Euro to the core.  It is an optimization exercise that is prevalent in the genre.  You are trying balance a whole lot of doo-hickies:  some give you instant gratification (victory points) while others get you nothing now, but may get you more future gratification (bigger victory points).  Some doo-hickies in combination won't score you VPs until the end of the game, while others keep you from losing VPs during the course of the game.  If you overload in one area, you lose, so you have to balance and optimize.  (I asked on more than one occasion, "Are you SURE Knizia didn't design this?")  It's a common mechanic, but by selecting a card to play from a hand of cards and passing the rest around can keep cards out of the hands of those who may benefit more from them.  It is like [thing=13823][/thing] with more doo-hickies and a [thing=12][/thing]-like scoring system.

If you flip for Euros, you probably own it, and if you don't and this type of optimizing/puzzle-solving is your thing, then why heck don't you already own this?  Don't you know this won a whole bunch of awards that I cannot even pronounce?  

If this isn't your thing, then run far and fast.  Me?  I'm indifferent.  I like optimization puzzles for a couple of tries, but they get old pretty quickly (which is why I'm happy to let others buy them and play their copies).  I'll play it, and for a short filler for 3, I may even [i]recommend[/i] it, but it's not one that I would run out and buy, nor is it one that I'm going to center my game-playing night around ("Sorry, I can't play [thing=91][/thing] right now.  I've been waiting all night to get into this game of 7 Wonders.  Can I take a rain check?")

But in defense of it, it's one of the better Euros that I don't own and maybe the best 3+ player Euro that plays in about 20 minutes.  It's not worthy of "game of the year" hype, since it's really just another Euro, but folks who vote on this probably never played anything but Euros.  For instance, I watched the BGG-produced video in which the lady said, "Don't be intimidated by the complexity."  10 minutes later, when I finally stopped laughing, I commented that she's obviously never played a wargame or anything by Fantasy Flight.  Hint: it ain't complicated. As a matter of fact, it's greatest charm is the combination of its simplicity, it plays in less than 15 minutes, has more choices in it than its peers, and that after about 5 games you should be ready to play with anybody, and because of that, I kind of like it: it's a filler that doesn't [i]feel[/i] like a filler.

If I were rating it against other Euros, it would probably be an 8, but compared to a world of awesome wargames and Ameri-Trash, it gets a 6, but that's how I roll.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
after one play: so and so. quite random and you only care for your left and right neighbour. everybody kind of plays for himself as everybody resolves his card simultanously. You don't have any influence on other players except (very limited) on your direct neighbours. The scores are only calculated at the end, so that you don't really know how well you or other players are doing (except you spend a lot of time calculating the score for them in your head each turn).
It's not a bad game, but I just wanted to list a few concerns from my side.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Absolutely wonderful game!  Easy to play, easy to teach, easy to grasp, difficult to succeed (and there are different paths to consider).  Very well done!

So why a '9' and not a '10'?  Well...  It gets stale.  The replay value isn't off the charts, or at least it's not high enough.  I have +30 plays of this (guesstimating, probably more) and it's gotten stale.  Also, while fast for a multiplayer game (very fast), AP can set in and stall everyone while one person puzzles it out.

But really, play this!  It's very, *very* good!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
$5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A simple mechanic, extraordinary graphics and a nice idea for this strong filler. The wide player range and the short playing time make this game hit the table very often. Without expansions it gets repetitive after a while and it would be a little too simple. Fortunately Leaders and Cities really enhanced the potential of this game.

The gameplay is simple, but it also comes with very interesting choices to make. I don't understand, why so many people complain about the low interaction. Now this is true with too many players around the table and it's also true that all you can do to damage your opponents is to pick cards that would be too powerful for their strategy... but this what draft is all about! It DOESN'T mean that there's no interaction, because you have to foresee what your opponents want to do. What cards have the chance to come back? What card do I need to pick right away? Choosing the right card at the right time is crucial to win the game.

What do I need to get during this age to score the most points? Which card from this hand can come back in 4 turns? Is it better to pick this card that gives me a lot of points or this one that gives me less, but it would be too good for her/him? This is of course indirect interaction, but does the game really need some "take that" to be better? For sure not for me! 7 Wonders is great as it is.

Rating without the expansions: 7.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
The best card development game until now. For first timers it is hard to grasp the end scoring, but after a few plays everything settles.

RATING: 7
7 Wonders takes up a lot of table space - as soon as the fourth player. The fiddliness is a dealbreaker; icons and tokens litter the playing space and scoring is byzantine. This inability to track the game state means the game is pointless as a competitive pursuit, yet there is too much going on for this to be a casual game. 

I'll play it if you want, but I'd rather play Race For The Galaxy as a competitive many-playered card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
The first time I played this game, I was underwhelmed.  It was short and ended abruptly.  We played again, and then again, and by the time we played the 4th game, everything started to click.  Every game, and we've played tons now, feels different.  There are limited choices, but you have to make your strategy as you go.  If you try to stick to one strategy, others will block you easily, and the cards will not come to you the way you need them to every time.  The game has gotten longer because we all think a little bit more each time we draft a card.  I love this game, and I will play it any time with any player count.  

My only wish is that there was a better symbol system for building chains of buildings.  It's too easy to overlook or just miss that you have build a preliminary building.  Sure, as time goes on, you begin to memorize them.  Also, some more randomness in the cards, so your unsure which ones will be in the game.  That would be nice.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
v
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.85
This is what user scud-o (I think that was his name) described it as: a "second-step" game. The iconography is a tad bit complex for anyone who has had no experience of designer games. If a player has played at least gateways, it won't be a problem, and will be an ideal game that will appeal to all sorts of gamers, ranging from novices to Martin Wallace fans.

It is a weird game: it is a filler, and yet, at the same time, it is a very deep game. It is multi-player solitaire, and at the same time, is highly interactive. One MUST constantly be aware of what their opponents are doing, and play one's cards accordingly, or you WILL lose! This results in an extremely tense game after the first few rounds. There are also two interesting ways in which a player can get rid of cards that they don't want, and (even more so) don't want their opponents to have, which strikes me as remarkably similar to the Space Race Track in Twilight Struggle!

The artwork in 7 Wonders is gorgeous! And, while the game's not "dripping" with theme, it is nevertheless very well themed indeed! An excellent civ-building game that I enjoy even more than Francis Tresham's Civilization.

My only significant criticism is the size of the player boards: it is fairly difficult keeping your played cards neat and organized. That wouldn't be a big issue for me, except given the ridiculously high price that is charged for what is essentially just a card game, the buyer should be given more.

7 Wonders definitely will be a Hall of Fame sort of game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Gorgeous game, with many clever mechanics. As with a lot of euros, the theme is kinda pasted-on (it feels more like card-collecting than civilization-building), and conflict is kept to a minimum, but it plays fast with no downtime. However, scoring is a pain in the ass (way too long and complicated). I have recently lowered my rating for this game because in the end, its success in my house was really a big flash in the pan. Now that we've stopped playing it, no one wants to pick it up again. Like this chewing gum that tastes great for a few seconds, then loses its flavor...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Set collection and drafting with some asymmetrical positioning to make it interesting.  I'm not sold on the need for the leaders expansion, but the cities adds some new elements.  This game moves quickly and can grab players who aren't into heavy games, although the scoring at the end is a little awkward.  If everyone playing is familiar with the game, there are a lot of second-order strategies to pursue.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The theme translates surprisingly well since all you're really doing is choosing cards. I love the ancient civ setting.

The various routes to build up your tableau are well designed. Unfortunately, the symbology is a bit idiosyncratic. It can be quite mystifying at times for new players. 

But it's fun! 7 Wonders has set the bar for strategic card drafting games these days. It's not incredibly deep, but it is a very enjoyable game. Probably more of a '7' for me without expansions. But Cities and Leaders keep it pretty fresh. And occasionally playing with Babel is nice too.

Cons

- Hard to game to teach for what kind of game it is
- Setup is rather annoying 
- Easy for someone to make a mistake and nobody catches it, especially in larger games

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Some people love drafting in and of itself. I'm fine with it as a mechanism for balancing starting positions and/or for letting people target a particular strategy. But, always, I want that to be a preparatory step for -the game-. Here, that is the game. There's no further game. Pick out items from a menu, pick out more items from the menu, and then...pick out more. For me, it ends before I ever actually got anything I ordered. It ends with a big pile of things I wanted in front of me, all unfulfilled.

No theme. No interaction between players. All you do is sit and stare at your hand and shuffle some things around in front of yourself, and try to organize them in a way that the game makers decided was more-or-less score-worthy.

If I'm going to play a game with no theme, I'd rather play Sushi Go. It's the same game, but with less pomposity, and whimsy and light enough that you can chat with the other players. But, really, I'd rather play Shadow Throne. Theme, bluffing, strategy, and interaction. Most importantly, it's actually a game. Set collection just really isn't. It's a cheap cheat to make it seem like there's more depth to your game than there really is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Astonishingly easy to get even for casual players, while at the same time quite complex enough to make winning it very rewarding.

RATING: 6
2-7(4)

As a multiplayer this is ... not bad. I'll give it a bonus for quickly handling lots of players. I find that, not intuitively, building your wonder actually doesn't seem all that powerful, whereas it feels like it should be a major focus. I do think it plays best with four or so in that you still want to be aware of everybody's tableau (e.g. ensuring somebody doesn't get too many science points). The balance at this point feels okay. Some good ways to score with military, science, trade buildings, and sometimes guilds. It can get awfully crowded and be awfully hard to keep track of your resources (sometimes people don't realize the goods they have available, or which buildings they can build for free).

I don't think I'll be playing the 2p variant any time soon. It's just additionally wonky to me with the neutral city, and it loses much of its pace there.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders combines card drafting with some light engine building, leeching off your neighbours (you can purchase resources that only they produce and several cards will score you points for their buildings), and an arms race. For a quick, simple game, it gives you quite a few things to consider. 

The most interesting decisions are about how much of a production engine you need and what it should produce.  Those decisions are less straightforward than in many efficiency games because of the ability to make use of what your neighbours produce - provided that you have money.  There is also some balancing of present versus potential reward in your card choices.  

Rather less interesting is that the game offers but three main ways of scoring victory points (military dominance or collecting science or civil cards)and a winning strategy will probably pursue two of those routes. The individual wonders and how you tailor your play to make the most of their rewards are almost all the game offers by way of strategic variation.  Certainly, after 10 or so plays it feels tapped out to me.

The artwork and production quality are both good.  I found the plentiful icons rather easier to grasp than in many other games. My one gripe is with the out-sized box and the inflated price that goes with it.

RATING: 7
When you strip it down to its essence, it's a card drafting game, with the attendant benefits and drawbacks (one new or weak player at the table can really hand victory to his or her neighbors). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast paced with everyone taking terms simultaneously while "drafting" cards for their civilization. The entire game is just drafting cards, but there are so many options on how to build up your city and other players' choices will effect you. The game is a little difficult to teach someone, but after one 30 minute play-through they will understand. 

Great balance of german-style building, and player interaction.

My only concern is long-term replay-ability, after 20+ games it's still the same small set of cards.

RATING: 8

But the funny thing is, everyone is on a pretty much level playing field.  I'm sure some really smart folks could count cards and do some crazy probabilities, but I don't think it would help that much.  although it is a bit of a pasted on theme, i like it better than puerto rico's.  you just try and get as many VP as you can and every round is kinda exciting to see what you will be passed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Well, this is a nice filler(ish) game. It plays fast, it's fun and even non-gamers can enjoy it. There is little to no downtime and always tough decision to do with the cards. Of course luck of the draw plays a big part in the game and it can be a bit random, so tactical decisions usually outweigh strategic ones. I love the art and the quality of components. I'd also say that this needs at least 4 players to be interesting. Overall a game that is never boring and the winner is surprisingly hard to detect before counting up the scores.

Fun factor: 4/5
Strategy vs. luck: 2/5
Mechanics/gameplay tied to the theme: 2/5
Component/art quality: 5/5
Replayability: 4/5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.02
I enjoy the drafting, and very little downtime for a lot of players while still having some depth

RATING: 7
Well, this is way more fun than last year's hot game [thing=36218][/thing].  The passing-hands-around is an excellent mechanic that makes sure everyone has something to do all the time and that the game scales well.  And the brightly-coloured oversize cards are attractive.

I think the strategy may not be all that interesting though.  In fact I'm kind of hoping someone comes out with a more interesting game with the passing-hands mechanic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This works well with up to seven people because everyone plays simultaneously, so you don't have to wait for six other people to take their turns. The downside is that your neighbours don't affect you much, so it sometimes feels like seven people playing solitaire together.

I like that it allows several different ways to win, so if you are behind, you usually have ways of catching up. The downside is that it doesn't allow for much long-term strategy, you just have to make plays one at a time.

It has some good features and some flaws, but overall I have fun playing it.

RATING: N/A
No rating here because no full play through. We really wanted to like this one since it is so popular. But it just did not work. 1st of all it is a drafting game and those types of games need more than two players to make them work as good as they can. 7 Wonders comes with a 2-player variant but it is a dummy player called the Free-City where players take turns controlling it to assign cards to build it up. That isn't a "dummy player." It is a part of players' strategies. Plus that is so fiddly. It's just one more thing to have to keep up with. So with more than 2 we are sure it works very well. But as with most other drafting games it doesn't do 2 very well.

RATING: 9
Практически идеальная игра на разноколичественную компанию. Очень хорошо реализована механика драфта. Легко обучить новичков.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very cool filler. It plays really well from 4 to 7 players, without increasing playtime.

I think the drafting mechanics is brilliant and everyone I present this game to seems to agree with it.

But I get the feeling that it doesn't matter how many players you're playing this game with, it always seems like a 3-player game, for you only get affected by what your right and left neighbors do.

In that sense, when you're playing with many players, it seems to me that victory is much more a matter of circumstance than of smart playing, because in order to win, you're gonna have to be the top scorer on the two or three different 3-player games happening simultaneously around the table.

In other words, 7 Wonders with many players is a game with quite a lot of chaos going on, over which your control is pretty limited. That is why I'd rather play it with only 3 or 4 players.

RATING: 7
I can see the appeal, but I don't think card drafting is my forte.  My biggest issue with this game is how unbalanced it can be when playing with multiple skill levels.  New person doesn't understand to not pass all the science to one person?  Game over.  A game can also be ruined if you are the one sitting next to someone who is collecting science, because you are forced to take their science cards, often at the expense of your own game.

Overall, I think this is a good game, and I am happy to play it.  But I'm not sure it deserves quite as much praise as it gets.

RATING: 6
Pleasant game that I can repeatedly play in spite of it being more pastime than a compelling game.  It is mostly saved by very good production quality, short tight game time, and accommodation of a large number of players without getting slow.

The ironic thing is that while this game has many layers and lots of detailed balanced interaction, it turns out to be quite shallow.  Normally this dooms a game to low replay value.  In the case of 7W, the investment to a play is so low, and the gameplay so tight, that I still do not mind replays.

In other words, it is a tasty little candy, not a satisfying meal.

RATING: 10
My friends and I thoroughly enjoyed this game once we got over some initial frustration learning the rules.  There's a 1/2 hour YouTube video which explained the mechanics extremely well.   The things I liked about this game were the quality components, the ease of play, the good mix of strategy and luck, the fast pace, the short duration, and the Euro style (which I'm new to), while maintaining a military aspect.   I'm a wargamer who so far has only been able to get new gamers to play Risk, cos it's most familiar.   But it can get cutthroat and can leave bad feelings.  I love that everyone stays in the game until the very end.  And I didn't even mind that I lost both times!  There seems to be endless replayability.   It played well with 5, but I can see how it would play just as well with 3-7, which is another really nice thing about this game, since many other games have a much narrower range of "optimal number of players".   

2-7, best 4, rec 3-7, solo variant

RATING: 8

This is one of the games to pull out when you've got 30 minutes and a flexible number of people.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
The initial reason for this high rating was that after the first game, everyone immediately wanted to play again. The game feels _fun_ (and retains that feel after playing more). The game also has longevity, and a subtlety which you only slowly learn to appreciate. I'm much more excited about playing the game now, after 30+ plays, than I was after 5 plays. (Was in fact nearly uninterested in the game after 10 plays.)

Plays very swift, but is not as light / devoid of meaningful choices as one might expect based on other comments, particularly in a 4-player game. There's several opportunities per game of screwing over your neighbours by handing them only bad choices (which can include gleeful taunting), and the different strategies you can follow in the game do each have their own distinct feel. Paying attention to your neighbours is important, but in the end you're going to have to accept that no matter how well you play, luck will remain a factor in this game. As you play the game more often, though, and play with a table of equally experienced players, you'll learn that the choices that lead to a win are subtle and very fine indeed, and the game becomes a very careful balancing act in building up your resources (or ways to acquire them) _just_ far enough to enable to you to more efficiently build a better mix of point-scoring cards. Yet add a single inexperienced player to the table, and it's all thrown out of whack again.

The 2-player version works surprisingly well, and I'd rate that a 7.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For me, the biggest negative about this game is how having a weak player to the left/right of you is one of the best assets in this game. Simply put, this game is all about evaluating the best VP-return for yourself and your opponents. Thus, a card that gives you the most VP may actually be a bad decision if taking another card would create a bigger VP-spread between you and your opponent. 

That being said, the game plays a large number of players very quickly and is filled with interesting decisions. I never feel bored with this game and I never feel like decisions are too obvious. I wouldn't call it a deep game but there is certainly has enough interesting decisions to entertain most gamers. Overall, a great design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is probably the closest thing to gateway game for me (with Betrayal on the House on the Hill). It's quick and fairly simple to play once you learn the iconography, and it plays with wide-range of people.

RATING: 8
PERFECTO. Para lo que está diseñado es perfecto: para personas que lo mas parecido que han visto a un juego de mesa es el Monopoly, este juego es perfecto. Permite jugar un grupo generoso (7), componentes super atractivos, temática estupenda y una mecanica sencilla que lo unico que se la puede achacar es más falta de interacción entre los jugadores alejados... Un exito de momento en todas las partidas que he jugado... Si estás esperando algo más duro juega al Peloponnes y luego un Civilization y por último un Through the Ages... pero empieza por la base...de la piramide ;oP
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Loads of fun
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sleeved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It feels forever since the last time I awarded a perffect 10 score to a board game. My first impressions of this little gem were a bit negative; I just didn't get what all the fuzz was about after a couple online plays.

And then, it clicked. And how. This game gives the initial impression of being yet another exercise in multiplayer solitaire, and with little control to top it all out. Instead, there are myriads of fways you interact with others, from the outright commerce and military issues, to the more subtle interception of highly needed cards by your neighbours. And the "control" issue? It's just nonsense; the game has so varied uses for each card, you can almost always adapt what you've got to what you need.

A great game I can't wait to buy and play it over and over again.

Update (July 25th 2011): I bought it, and played it face to face. It's even better. Great, great game.

UPDATE: I still love it, but it's no longer amongst my favorites. Perhaps I've played it a bit too much? Down to a 9.

UPDATE: Still great, but no longer one I'll try to push into my friends' faces all the time. Down to an 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2
Best card game I have to play with lots of people

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 7.5
7 Wonders fills an unusual void in my collection.  Plays up to 7 (but not a party game) and the game lasts 30 minutes.  

It's got a fair amount of satisfying tactical gameplay.  I suppose it's what people call a "super filler"  

I dont know anyone who loves it, but everyone seems to like it and thats pretty much how I feel.  I like how it plays, but I love what it can do for a large group of gamers who all want to sit at the same table together.

It's a solid game and a perfect '7' on the BGG scale (go figure!)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A civ game in 30 minutes, well kind of...

On your turn you play 1 of your 7 cards, then pass the rest of your cards to another player, you receive 6 cards, play another card and so on, until you are passed 2 cards, at that time play one and discard the other. That comprises an age, play through 3 ages and finish the game and count points... It's that easy.

Let's see how this game holds up with more plays.

Seems that the most viable option for scoring a lot of points is through green cards (science points) and through purple cards (guild cards). Improving your Wonder is probably a good ideia since you can get rid of a useless card or, even better, a powerful card that one of your opponents wants.

Plays from 2 to 7 with no extra time loss. Since everyone plays simultaneously.

Edit: It has been holding up pretty well, this game is very addictive! But after adding 1 or 2 expansions and then going back to the basic game it feels too simple, but still this is a must have.

RATING: 9
Hand-drafting and per-round simultaneous play means no downtime. And because the game hinges on making tough (or, sometimes, obvious) choices about what is in front of you, it never feels like you know exactly what is going on in the game world at large, and thus are in the dark about the ultimate victor until the points are tallied at the end. Everyone is fully involved at every stage. Just great! (And all the expansions just make things better).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nagyon jó! Gyanús, hogy meg kell venni... Szabályok nem túl bonyolultak, és a hossza is meglepően rövid (max. 1 óra), pedig elég soktényezős, jópár út vezethet a nyeréshez! Kiegyenlített is, volt olyan 5 személyes játék, ahol hárman azonos ponttal végeztünk. A kártyaleosztás mechanizmusa hasonlít az Agricola haladó kártyaelosztásához, meg a Fairy tale alapmechanizmusához.
---
Na megvettem. Amilyen jó maga a játék, olyan siralmas a minőség:( Az egyik csoda pl. durván el volt szakadva, a felső dobozrésznél a ragasztás semmit sem fog.
---
Kár a kivitelezési hibákért, mert maga a játék ma is meggyőzött: ez az a kategória, amivel bármikor játszanék, főleg hogy ilyen rövid.
---
Kipróbáltuk ketten is, így kvázi háromszemélyes, mert van egy fiktív játékos. Meglepően jól működik, kifejezetten élvezetes így is!! Nagyon sok olyan taktikai lehetőség bukkan fel, ami a többi létszámnál nem. A harmadik csodát felváltva irányítjuk, ezen keresztül kihatással lehetünk a pénzáramlásra, a harci erőviszonyokra, a másiknak nagyon fontos lapoktól tudunk megszabadulni, stb. Vigyázni kell, hogy nehogy végül a fiktív játékos nyerjen:)
---
Elsőre is tetszett, de csak 40-50 parti után kezdtem el igazán megszeretni! Fantasztikus, hogy a jól kitalált alapmechanizmusból mennyit ki lehet hozni. Szinte korlátlan mennyiségben vannak új csodák a neten, amik nem nehezítik a játékot, csak a varianciát növelik. Az egyik legnagyobb újrajátszhatósági faktorú játék szerintem, ha valaki nem riad vissza a sok kiegtől. A félhivatalos paklikkal együtt eddig 5 kieg pakli van a játékhoz, mindegyik egy új színt (szó szerint is) visz bele, persze mind együtt már talán túl bonyolult, de lehet válogatni...
Még ha a gyerekkoromban gyakran játszott játékokat (Snapszer, römi, amőba) számoljuk is, akkor is az 5-6 leggyakrabban játszott játékom közt van, nem véletlenül. Fel is nyomom 9 pontra:)
---
Nem hiszem, hogy volt már olyan játék életemben, amivel 50 nap alatt 70 partit játszottam, a 7 Wonders az első ilyen. És még nincs vége a házi bajnokságunknak, de már így is elmondhatom, hogy ez a játék a kiegekkel együtt gyakorlatilag megunhatatlan. Már az alapban is sok játék van, de ha váltogatjuk a Bábelt, Leaderst, Citiest, vagy akár kombináljuk ezeket, mindig annyira más-más élményt kapunk, nem is beszélve a sok csodáról, hogy simán lenyomható folyamatos alkalmakon akár 50-100 parti is. Mi még pár hétig nyomjuk, aztán félretesszük egy évre, de tuti elő fog még kerülni hasonló maratoni játékfolyamokra, mert nagyon szeretjük az alapot is és az összes kieget. A házi bajnokságunk egyébként nem elsősorban egyének közti verseny (bár az is), inkább azt próbáltuk letesztelni, melyik csodák az erősebbek. Az eddig megjelent 15 gyári csoda mellett 24 rajongói csodát is versenyeztettünk. Sokkal több van fenn a neten, ez a 24 már egy 2013-as szűrésünk eredménye, akkor kiválasztottuk és legyártattuk a legötletesebb, legleteszteltebbnek tűnt csodákat. Így tehát 39 csoda versenyzett, és mivel 3-an voltunk, hármasával küzdöttek meg egymással a csodák, mindegyiknek 3 parti jutott, hogy mindenki minden csodával pontosan egyszer játsszon. A 13 győztes csoda és még a 2 legjobb második továbbment a rájátszásba, onnan hasonló módszerrel továbbment a legjobb 6, majd a legjobb 3 került a döntőbe. Itt tartunk most. A döntőben egy gyári csoda lesz, a Manneken Pis (mellette a Persepolis és Atlantis nevű rajongói csodák). Általános tapasztalat, hogy nagyon jól szerepelnek a kevés szintes csodák (ami logikus is, hiszen akciókat spórolunk velük), pl. Manneken Pisnek az 1 szintű oldala volt nagyon erős. Másik tapasztalat, hogy általában a viszonylag egyszerű csodák a jobbak: semmi varázslat, egyszerűen pénzt és pontot adnak meg esetleg fegyvert. Jellemzően a 10 pont + 5 pénz meg még valami kis extra kedvezményt adó csodák számítanak nyerőnek, de pl. Manneken 1 szintre ad 7 pontot 7 pénzt és 1 fegyvert. Kivétel pl. Róma, amelyiknek az egyik oldala teljesen speciális, de nagyon jól szerepelt (Róma 7. lett). Általában kevés az olyan csoda, mint Róma, amelynek mindkét oldala versenyképes. Volt olyan csoda, amelyiknek az egyik oldalával szinte mindig nyertünk, a másik oldalával meg szinte sosem. De a verseny szempontjából ez nem számít, mivel mi döntjük el, melyik oldalt választjuk, így egy jó oldal elég lehet a legjobb csoda házi címhez:)
Kíváncsian várjuk az újabb kieget, bár nekünk már az eddigiek is szinte kimeríthetetlen újrajátszást adnak. Hogy mást ne mondjak, pl. a Bábel totál más játékélmény, mint bármelyik másik kieg vagy az alap.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
So far this has been the default game when hosting gatherings, after a couple rounds most people get the hang of it and are typically eager to play a second game.

As someone who is more interested in heavier games I'm always pleasantly surprised by 7 Wonders. It is just a great card game.  The game length is perfect and it scales well from 4 to 7 players.  The two player variant is flawed, but that's what 7 Wonders Duel is for.  Playing with 3 leaves a little to be desired but is still fun.

It's no wonder this game is ranked so high!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the landmark for future card-game fillers! It is FAST, it accomodates up to 7 players, it is elegantly designed, and it is easily taught to everyone who has at least played a couple of other games.
It is almost tactical, with very little chance to plan a strategy, and I don't know if it will stand the test of hundreds plays, but it is definitely engaging and worth exploring!
A note on pruction quality: artwork is gorgeous, cardboard is thick and durable, but the cards are very thin and show signs of being worn out after the first couple of games... Hopefully adequate sleeves will become available soon!
Update may 21st, 2011: after 15 plays, I am still not sure about the game. The random element is high, but in such a fast paced game this is not a great problem... Nevertheless, I would lower the initial rating (8) to a 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.1
Excellent game... quite unlike anything else in my collection. Only 2 downsides; 1) While the game is actually quite simple, the first teaching game for new players is often difficult, due in part to the bunch of (very well designed) symbols you need to understand, and also to the multi-faceted end game scoring which you need to experience once to know what to aim for in the future. 2) Not a huge amount of obvious interaction, limited mostly to denying cards to neighbours. Both minor problems with a game I've taught and enjoyed with gamers and non-gamers alike.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

With expansions: they do add the meat :) Especially Leaders are a must have if you own 7 Wonders - they force you to play each game differently.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a game that manages to play 3 to 7 (maybe more with expansions) players within the same timeframe and the same amount of tension (regardless of player-count).
This game's design is just a brilliant piece of work!

The game itself is themed around being a mayor of an antique city and building and improving that city (and it's wonder) through 3 ages (an age lasts for 6 rounds).

Each round you have to use one card of your small deck of cards (starting with 7) and giving the rest to your neighbour on the left.
This is another marvellous design that generates a decision making conflict right from the start of the game:
"I could really use card A, but I can't give my neighbour card B nor card C - What should I do?!?"
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Not normally a card game lover but this is a nice little card draughting game that is fun for even none card game players. The math at can be a little annoying for scoring but also quite educational if that is what you want

RATING: 7
This basic mechanism for this game, card drafting, is pretty simple, making it easy to learn.  Simultaneous actions also allows it to scale up well.  Once you know the cards, you can work out your strategies in the first era.  However, you never know whether you’ll ever see the cards you need to execute that strategy.  So even the most skilled player can’t guarantee a win.  However, there are few enough basic strategies that replayability isn’t infinite.  It will probably get boring after a few dozen plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It has a hard time living up to the hype though, and the criticism it gets for lack of variety and strategy is probably deserved as well.  Overall though I like it and will play it a lot.

RATING: 9
Despite the fact that I've lost 70% of the games I've played (are there times when one just has to accept that he's really bad at a game and can't hope to win?), I think 7 Wonders is really solid.  Maybe because I've lost so many times I like it all the more.  

Lately I've played with the same people a few times, and it's been very interesting to try to balance the need for subverting someone else's building potentials while trying to simultaneously construct a solid of my own infrastructure.  This constant tension ... and seeming simplicity of choices in front of someone at any given time, makes the game beautiful.  Shoot ... I think I just talked myself into upping my rating of this game as I wrote my comments.  That's what tells you this is a solid game.

RATING: 7

Pros are quick playtime, and easy to learn. Almost everyone I've taught it to picked up exactly how to play it after the second game. Strategic play comes quickly after that.

Cons are it seems a bit repetitive once you're familiar with all the cards although the varied cards from the drafting mechanic mitigates this a bit. Sometimes bad results can't be avoided due to what's handed to you or lack of a required resource
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
(3-8 Players, 30 min, CLASSIC) A civilization-building game featuring nations from across the globe in a contest of drafting. Each turn, players choose one development card from their hand to play, in order to acquire natural resources, build buildings, raise military, or develop sciences. The remaining cards are passed to their neighbor! What you choose is as important as what you give away!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great option. 30 min a game, easy to learn but not easy enought to bore
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
7 Wonders is a very 'attractive' game for a variety of reasons. The symbology gives an appearance of complexity, depth and 'geek cred', the game has at least the impression of 'building a civilization', there are unique 'powers' (civilizations) to play with, and it accommodates up to seven players in roughly the same amount of time (which, admittedly, is pretty impressive). Of course, everything comes with a cost, and 7 Wonders is no exception. 

In 7 Wonders' case, the downside comes mainly in the form of [i]interaction[/i] -- or more accurately, the lack thereof. It is difficult to imagine why I would want to play a game with six other players when I only have the ability to interact with the two players adjacent to me. And that interaction is often overly subtle for my tastes. Burying a card in your Wonder to deny it to an opponent is a good strategic play, but it happens so quietly that it simply isn't [i]fun[/i]. And when the player count is >4, any ability to play strategically is also dramatically reduced, making each decision less meaningful.

Furthermore, every decision in 7 Wonders feels essentially the same and [i]feels like it carries the same weight[/i]. It is exceedingly rare, if it ever happens at all, that a turn poses a very difficult, fun decision -- a problem which is exacerbated when the player count reduces the ability to play with any semblance of strategy. Some games offer limited victory points, while others are classified as 'victory point buffet' games. 7 Wonders is an 'action buffet' game -- except all of the courses are the same. Compare this to Settlers of Catan, which offers the same choices every turn, but adds [i]noticeable tension[/i] because you are trying to make that key trade with another player that will help you advance your game. In 7 Wonders, your opponent just silently hands you some cards with an implied "Eh, just take one. I may have taken the one you need, but you'll never even know until the end."

Like Agricola, scoring is also a huge letdown, and is quite anticlimactic. Surely a ~30-minute game could have employed a scoring system that doesn't require a pencil-and-paper version of Excel. The scoring is balanced (perhaps overly so, to the point of being artificial), but uninspired and negative fun.

[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/811970/theres-gotta-be-a-better-way]This review[/url] is an excellent summary of much of my feelings about 7 Wonders: [i][7 Wonders] fills a need that it had to create. ... Nothing about 7 Wonders serves any reasonable game function. Instead of a fun social experience, it offers a way to sit around a table of seven people and never have to speak to them. I can live with that in a game with fewer people, or a game that just felt more satisfying.[/i]

I don't mind playing 7 Wonders a bit, but I don't enjoy it as much as other games, and don't consider it to be nearly as good of a game as it gets credit for.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Card drafting for up to 7 players. A 30 minute forgettable filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game that plays as fast with 3 players as it plays with 7 (which is very rare). Probably the best drafting game out there and one of the better entry-level ones. I dislike the iconography a bit, it can seem scary for newer players. It's fine when you finnaly grasp it but it can be a pain at the start. Second thing, the cards that you build could be a little bit more complex (for example, green cards are pretty much the same in all three eras, red cards are just "+1 more sword" each era, blue cards are "more points than before" etc). the Guild purple cards are very interesting and I would like to see more of that, the gold ones are nice too. The game should be fine with the Cities expansion tho. It adds exactly what I think it needs.
Beside those 2 things I loved the game. It's fun, has a lot of ways to win, plays fast and has more theme that I gave it credit at the start (tho not as much as I would like). A very easy purchase in my opinion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
First play. Suprised at how fast it plays. I felt pretty swamped by the options and didn't see the gobal picture at all. I'd be happy to play again but I really don't see what all the raving is about. Not sure I'd want to buy this.

Second play and I am left utterly cold by the experience. Its clear that its a game where success comes with knowing the decks and what is coming up. However the decisions are formulaic and limited and I felt bored by the lack of depth and non existant meaningful interaction between players. Rating dropped to a 4 for what is for me a soulless experience that I really do not want to repeat again.

Third Play: Struggling to find a filler for 6 at evening end I found myself at the table with this again. What I said after second play x 4. There are no informed decisions. You just decide whther a card gives you more points or stops your neighbour getting more. Just a really trivial numbing experience that I progressively dislike and down grade with each unpleasant outing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
What's great about 7 Wonders is it's so simple to learn and takes almost no time to play. The more you become familiar with it, the faster the game goes, and you'll end up playing several rounds a night. However, my issue with the game is simple. You could change the theme of 7 Wonders, name it anything else, and it would be the exact same gaming experience. Breeds of cats, ball clubs, auto manufacturers, etc. Completing your wonder, is so unfulfilling. And even with 7 different wonders available with slightly different modifiers, they somehow manage to give you the exact same experience, and won't change how you play the game. Honestly, nobody remembers the name of this game. It's simply referred to as "that quick one." But, like I said, that's exactly why this game's a winner. You don't have to invest a lot of time, thought or energy. And, with a little luck, you'll have several winners throughout the night. Not a bad thing, and keeps me reaching for it.

RATING: 9
Fantastic, most likely deserving of a much better write up than I can muster here, exhausted from this years TN Game days, but I had to get this in the list and extol its virtues as best I could. This is without a doubt one to chase down and pay retail for if you have to in order to own it. from artwork to mechanics it all comes together and delivers a very satisfying experience. Building wonders, buying from your neighbor, even the way combat is not ignored,but not a major focus of this game, gives one a lot of of the sense of scale its trying to convey. Clever card passing mechanics are not new, but they are executed very nicely here, and for me at least, are a part of the draw of the game. Each decision is fraught with internal hand wringing as every great choice for this card has at least two others, and then that many that are bad. This process continues until just about the time to see where your neighbors really fit in, and then it all kicks it up a notch. It is an excellent way to spend time among friends, give it a try you will not be sorry!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a a solid game with a multitude of fairly balanced paths to victory. I have seen players win with a strong focus on either science, military, or victory point cards. A mix of card types also seems to work, but diversifying does not seem to be as strong as specializing.

The wonders seem fairly balanced, and very rarely does one player take a run-away victory. The beauty of this game is that there is literally no down-time. Everyone plays at the same time. Occasionally one has to wait on other players to make a card choice, but this is minimal.

The biggest con to this game is the lack of player interaction. Very rarely does a player actively change his/her card choice based on other players's cards. Another small downside is that it takes some time to sort the cards at the beginning of the game when there is a different number of players between play sessions; however, compared to other games, setup time is still fairly short.

I look forward to trying the expansions that bring new mechanics into play. Overall, if I am looking for a quick game that accommodates up to 7 players, this is currently my game of choice.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Complexity overhead to game depth seems off. Iconography can be intimidating to new players but the game plays smoothly and pretty quick with high player counts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[url=http://ballearicus.blogspot.com/2012/01/7-wonders.html]7 Wonders[/url] es de esos juegos que cuando lo juego y a medida que la partida avanza, me empieza a dar un poco lo mismo lo que hagan los demás. Al principio miras un poco lo que se está bajando a la mesa, sobre todo tus vecinos. A medida que avanza la partida, la mesa empieza a llenarse de de cartas y la información te satura un poco. Cartas y cartas se apelotonan pese a intentos vanales de los jugadores por ser ordenados en la ubicación de las mismas. Siempre tengo la sensación de estar perdiéndome algo en alguna parte de la zona de juego. La sensación de “me da lo mismo lo que hagan” se agudiza a medida que avanza la partida, toda la atención se centra en que carta voy a bajar en este momento y como consigo los recursos necesarios para financiarla. 

Para el que suscribe, la perdida de interés por jugar a 7 wonders se intensifica en cada partida que juego. Esto no quiere decir que sea un mal juego. Solo quiere decir que no es un juego para mi. Me niego a pensar que uno de los juegos que ha estado en todas las quinielas, de todos los concursos del mundo, que es uno de los mas jugados y que mayores alabanzas a obtenido por la comunidad lúdica mundial en general hasta la fecha, pueda ser malo. Simplemente no es un juego para mi. Seguramente el no saber apreciar las deidades del juego es culpa mía.

RATING: 8.5
Interesting and very quick drafting game. Very good and flexible filler as it can be played with up to 7. There are some interesting decisions to be made in the game, but mostly the choices are pretty straightforward once you've chosen your strategy. Artwork and overall look of the game are superb. Quality of the components is lacking to put it mildly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Hype is a strange thing.  Sometimes it blows my expectations way too high, and other times it makes me dislike a game without even trying it.  In the case of 7 Wonders I think my expectations got a little out of control.  I love the drafting mechanism in Fairy Tale, and I love civilization-building games as well.  Then people talked about how it was easy to teach and could play with up to 7 players and I was absolutely chomping at the bit, expecting the next great game for my family.  So when I finally played it, unfortunately the only way for my excitement to go was down.

Now, don't get me wrong, it's a really fun little game.  However I didn't really feel the theme at all when playing.  It just kind of felt like we were playing cards.  And I didn't like that you have to have a significant amount of trust in the other players, not just that they're being honest, but that they understand when they can and cannot play a card.  I'm concerned that this will bog down with non-gamers and I'll spend a lot of time checking other peoples work.  Still, I want to get the game and try it with my family, but my excitement has dropped off significantly from where it was.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The big trend since Dominion has been "Deck-Building Games", which try to evoke the fond memories of MtG drafts, but have all been missing another important aspect - the drafting of cards.

7 Wonders brings back that wonderful feeling of card drafting that I enjoyed so much, as you pick a direction and try to bend your strategy that way.  And, much like MtG drafting, there are clearly superiour strategies (build up a solid resource base, or militia), but an inferior strategy (science) can win if it is under-drafted.  The "pick-and-play" mechanic means you can see everybody's strategies in action, making it much easier to decide your path, which makes the game very accessible.  I love the resource buying mechanic and the "competing only against your neighbour" simplifies a game that could get very complex with large numbers of players.  For such an intelligent mechanic, I'm surprised how simple it is to teach and learn.

Another thing I like - building on your wonder lets you hate draft and "bury" cards instead of passing them on, even if you can't use them, which is a lot of fun.  However, you can only do this a limited # of times and have to do some leg work first, or pitch it for a very small reward (3 coins).

Finally, the player boards allow some customization and encourage different players to pursue varied strategies.

I've played this with 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6 players.  The game sings on 3-4, where you can apply some drafting strategy and reasonably expect to get cards back.  I enjoyed 5 as well.  6 was a bit of a luckfest, but still ok, and 2 was not worth your time.

7 Wonders is just a very intelligent game, with a lot of great ideas put together in an intuitive package, that furthermore plays quickly and isn't too heavy.  Thumbs up from me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 4
A game I pass gladly over: it’s boring and usually played at hysterical speed, with no time to think about the card you’re to play.

Interaction is almost nonexistent: you just get some cards from the player before you, draw one of them and pass the remaining ones to the next player. Even trades (to be made with both said players only) don't require any talk but are performed quickly and silently, every player on his own: you need it, you pay it, you take it.

Finally, don’t even think the themed Wonders are central to the game: you usually finish to build them early in the game, the bad cards you received from the player before you being the only motivation.

Edit: after a few more plays, rating lowered from 5 to 4.

RATING: 6

Picking a strategy or two is uncomplicated but if one hand happens to contain several of the cards you want, nothing can save you. Reversely, if 'your' cards are evenly spaced out among all hands, you will win the game easy. This is partly because you effectively have to live with your choices at the beginning of the game with little to no option to change your strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Played once so far and loved it. I'm a huge fan of the card game Fairy Tale, especially the card drafting element. This is Fairy Tale+++ with a re-theme. There's more to keep track of, more choices to be made, and a small economic factor to keep track of.
 That re-theme is also important to me, because I've always had a hard time getting a game in a pink box called Fairy Tale to the table.
Love how this can be played in 25-35 minutes no matter how many you are playing with. 
Simple to teach and easy to understand. 
There are multiple paths to victory, and things get interesting when two or more players choose to go the same route. Can be played cutthroat, looking at what your neighbors are building and trying to deny them what they need, or can be played casually, with every player minding his own business.
Good for hardcore gamers, gateway gaming families, and even very casual game players.
With some more play I'll probably bump up the rating.  

Edit: Okay, I've played this a whole buncha times now, and my thoughts on the game have changed. I still think it's a fantastic game, and all the pros I mentioned in my original comment still hold true, but there is definitely some overhype here. It's fun to watch the game shoot up through the BGG rankings, but #1 family game and 14th overall? I don't think so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A modern classic of drafting games. It's easy after so many plays to become disenchanted with 7 Wonders but it's still one of the absolute best games to introduce newer players to modern card game mechanics. You can always count on Antoine Bauza to deliver a solid, above-average gameplay experience and this game is no exception. 7 Wonders will never be my favorite game but I doubt I'll see it leave my collection anytime soon.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Good go-to for gaming newbies with good theme, simple mechanics, and a relatively quick game. "Point salad" scoring method may turn off hard-core gamers that relish deep strategy, but this always provides a fun experience in putting together building combos that result in a lot of points. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I have played this one a lot. It's a great game that really defined the deck drafting mechanic.

// Certainly my favorite game with the drafting mechanic.

civ/city-building theme of 7 Wonders more than, say, eating
Sushi. This is one of those games that may seem a little
overwhelming to a new gamer mostly due to the iconography,
but typically they'll have most of it figured out within
just a few rounds. Overall, this game is fast, has
interesting decisions, and is approachable for new gamers,
all of which are good qualities to have.

RATING: 7.3
Ever wondered how its like to game with 7 people all at once? Give 7 wonders a try!

Little downtime with the card-drafting mechanic, lots of decisions and multiple victory paths. Although the only interaction is only with your neighbours, its still a race to see who has the best combination for their wonder!

Also, the game has good sturdy components with fantastic artwork!

Would like to get this to the table more frequently.

RATING: 5.5
A fun game of card drafting and interacting with your "right and left" neighbors (ala Scream Machine).  The fact that it holds 7p and plays fairly fast (45 min) is great too!!

UPDATE: A good (not great) light-weight game that is almost entirely based on card-drafting (others in the genre are Notre Dame & Fairy Tale).  I would argue that it is not multiplayer solitaire because you can impact almost anyone at the table by denying them a card (e.g., burying it to build your Wonder)... but the game does feel a bit solitaire-ish since you can only have significant interactions with your immediate (left + right) neighbors.  I think the game would benefit from some kind of central competition like the national customers in the game Scream Machine (which has the same immediate neighbor interaction mechanic)... and it wouldn't surprise me if an expansion is in the works that fills this gap (perhaps a gladiator showdown or some kind of commerce goal cards?).

The fact that it holds 7 and plays fast is a big plus because it is a good game for bridging gaps during game days/nights when you are waiting for more people to arrive.

UPDATE #2: still my favorite card drafting game so far, but it's feeling more solitaire-ish than I would like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Whoops. I think this is a game where it can be pretty uncompromising if played against experienced players, but I did enjoy it. I didn't *love* it, but it's something I'm interested in trying a few more times.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game absolutely deserves the praise for what it is. I can't think of any games that can play with such scalability, such a short playtime and such ease of learning while simultaneously packing so much in. It doesn't have the complex theme or epic quality of some games because no game that is played in 30 minutes by up to seven players will. What it is able to give you with so little cost is something that no other game I know can give you for the same investment. It is not likely ever to be the main attraction of a game day, but it probably the best filler game I've ever seen.

Edit: I've downgraded to an eight. I haven't been as enthusiastic to get this title out as I once was. I still think it's an outstanding game, but I am less convinced now that there is as much to explore as I once thought. This is quibbling, though. It's still a classic and I'm happy to play it, especially when I have four or more players in need of a filler.

Edit: It's now a seven. It occurs to me that every time there is the perfect time to get this game out I just don't want to do so. There seems to be more fussiness than actual decisions. It's not so much scaling as facilitating several three player games as much. It's still enjoyable, but the shine has worn off. It's a lesson for me, I think.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Beautiful visual design and concept. It feels great to build up your city. 

Similar to Dominion in the central mechanic of "play cards that use my resources to either build more resource capacity, or cash in on my existing resource capacity". But unlike Dominion, the theme and card names make coherent sense, and there's some satisfaction in playing an impressive card with a cool design.

Excellent core game mechanic where everyone plays simultaneously. There is no negotiation, and all of this makes the game go quickly but always play a bit differently. 

I wish the player interaction were a greater part of the game, though; you don't have the same kind of "DDAAAAMMMNNN YYYOOOUUUU" moment you can have in Catan when someone blocks your growth. Decisions seem relatively easy each turn.

Winning depends on who has accumulated points in half a dozen different ways by the end, which is the way some other games, like Smallworld, work too. This preserves the sense that anyone might win, but it's anticlimactic and it means strategic decisions never feel high stakes.

So it's a great looking, accessible family game, if a little intimidating at first with its seeming complexity; it's really a very simple game. Fun and light, and a real challenge to beat a clever player.

Of course, the real test is how often my kids ask to play it, which is often!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
One of the best card driven games I've played.

7 player game: Won with military might and Strategist's Guild which gave me 11 victory points with my neighbors having 11 -1 tokens

5 player game: Alexandria. Won with Science and Civilian buildings. +10 point guild for grey cards to the sides.

4 player game: Won with 15 civilian + 14 guild pts.

3 player game. 51 pts. Mostly Civilian. came in 2nd to guy who did Science with 53 pts.

3 player game: 67 pts. Rhodes. Won with mostly Military and guild cards.

4 player game: 52 pts. Alexandria. Won with balanced approach.

5 player game. 79 points. Gizah. Won mostly with Military 12 points, Guilds 17 points, and the Wonder 20 points. Second place through 5th place had 51 points to 48 points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Card drafting, set collection and tableau building card game. Players choose a card from a starting hand to play and pass the rest to the right (or left depending on the round). After picking up the hand you've been passed, you select another card to play and keep passing until you've played six cards for the round. There are several ways to concentrate points, and tracking the cards as they progress about the table is a skill that will have to be developed to do consistently well. Ideally you are pursuing a line of play different from your neighbors so as to avoid trying to collect the same types of cards.  

I very much like the card drafting mechanic and see a possible application of it to Agricola for the Occupation and Minor Improvement cards at the beginning of the game. Another big plus is the low downtime and how well the game scales from two to seven players. Amazingly (baring players with a bad case of AP), the overall playing time is relatively unaffected by the number of players!

The swiftness of the play, yet with decent depth, makes this game an awesome filler. Definitely a keeper - I think this is going to be hard to displace from the top of the list of our filler favorites.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

We played this one about 5 times before it was played out.  At this point, I would play it if others wanted to, but would not ask for it or recommend it myself.

RATING: 8
Es un juego de cartas en el que debemos desarrollar una civilizacion a lo largo de tres eras.  Utiliza un sistema de draft para distribuir las cartas. En cada era, cada jugador dispondrá de 6 posibles acciones. Un acción consiste en poner en juego una carta (desarrollar alguna faceta de la civilización), usarla para desarrollar la maravilla, o conseguir dinero. Incluye interacción con los jugadores adyacentes, a través del comercio y los conflictos bélicos. Admite de 2 a 7 jugadores. 

Es sencillo, rápido y muy entretenido. Ha tenido un éxito que recuerda un poco al caso dominion.

RATING: 10

In my first play, I didn't think the choices were too difficult, but the selection of card play is interesting, as one has to consider his two neighbors in both what he plays and what he passes to his right or left neighbor. UPDATE: Already upgrading to a 9 with my second play. The boys enjoyed this as much as myself on their first play - quite an accomplishment. High hopes for this now. UPDATE: Now a 10, with both the Cities and Leaders expansions, with a medium/heavy rating due to the plethora of card icons to learn.

RATING: 5
