=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
7 Wonders is a fun card drafting, tableau building game. Probably the biggest selling point is that if everyone knows how to play the game, you can easily play in 30 minutes (even with the full 7 players).

BUT it is not the gateway game I was hoping it to be. It can be a bear to teach because of all the symbols. My friend who plays games at my place and has played complex games like War of the Ring and A Game of Thrones Board Game struggled immensely with 7 Wonders.

But overall 7 Wonders is a fun game that I don't see ever leaving my collection. Every turn is packed with meaningful decisions and it is not as multiplayer solitaire as a game like Dominion; you really need to look at your neighbors and pay attention to what they may pass you, what you don't want to pass to them, and what resources they have.

I highly recommend 7 Wonders, but not as a gateway game. Play Sushi Go! first with non-gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After my first play, this game continued to grow on me.  I found the player interaction and resource management fascinating.  There is a learning curve for new players due to all the symbols, but once that's mastered the game plays very fast.  I would have enjoyed it more if I had some time to explore the cards, instead of being thrust into the game by other players.  The different paths to victory (military, scientific, buildings) keep the strategy interesting, as well as the the numerous leaders and the 7 different wonders themselves.  I may have to pick this one up.

RATING: 10
   7 Wonders is a great game in terms of its presentation, playability, and scalability.  Easily the top ranked game in our household, my only regret is that we do not play it as much as we should.

   The deployment of cards on the basis of inherent resource values attributed to other cards / civilizations is a great alternative to exchanging physical tokens for resources - something that new players might struggle a bit with, but that an introduction to a lighter game like Splendor might alleviate.

RATING: 9
Played 7 times.  I'm getting the hang of this more and more, starting to make decisions based on what's going on with my opponents.  I really like the booster draft mechanic in this game.  It manages to provide a rich game experience in building up your civilization in just 20 or 30 minutes, tops.

My rating of 9 corresponds to play with 4 or 5 players.  With 3, 6, or 7 players I rate it an 8.

I get that this is something of a puzzle and after a while it's likely to be optimized and not as much fun, but I predict that getting to that point will be a blast.  Plus there is the Leaders expansion out now, which I will get if the base game ever starts to get stale.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The drafting mechanic makes a great game for up to 7 players (or 8 with the City expansion.) All players can act in parallel which keeps the downtime minimal. The downside is that there is almost no direct interaction with the other players, except for war with your neighbors.

I prefer the game with 3-5 players, because with more players you cannot observe what all of the other players are doing, you cannot take into account all the cards that are in play and the other players' strategies. And you basically only get to see each hand once, so you cannot hope for a card to wheel. With 6-8 it feels much more luck-driven and multi-player solitaire than with less players.

[microbadge=29032][microbadge=40] BSW

# of players: [bgcolor=#99FFFF]2[/bgcolor][bgcolor=#00CC00] 3 [b]4[/b] 5 6 7[/bgcolor]

RATING: 8
I like it.  The rules are clean and simple, the play is fairly quick.  It's a nice light game.

I think the hype is a little unusual though, because there really isn't a whole lot to this game.  There are limited paths to victory (greens are all or nothing, for example), and games seem to get a little boring.   It feels like a game badly in need of expansions.

Appropriately 7 Wonders gets a 7.

Jan 2011:  Upped to an 8, after it plays far better than I thought with a larger number of players.  Still enjoying it and would like to add this to my collection.

RATING: 7
Surprisingly engaging.  Easy to learn, lightning quick, but decidedly more strategy than might be expected.  Plays well, but quite differently, with different player numbers.  Even the two-player variant keeps the same feel.  (Nonetheless, kudos to the publisher for listing it as 3-7.)  I do wish the cards were a bit sturdier, but they're really beautiful.

Update 2/2012: I may have overplayed this a bit.  I still like it, but I'm almost never the one suggesting it now.  It's still an awesome achievement -- easy to teach, works with a wide range of player numbers, and plays incredibly quickly.  But there are a lot of games I'd rather play.

RATING: 9
This is the game I always play with my French friends whenever I get to meet with them. They love the game even more than I do, and play even more, I never seem to be so victorious with them! The theme is not really important but the gameplay is super fun! I love the drafting. I love the set collection aspect. I love building those wonders. The game really shines with all the extensions in my opinion: yes even with the rage-inducing Babel. Love it!! Keep in mind it might be a bit tricky to teach, beginner usually don't pay attention to 'playing twice the same card' on their tableau, and there are TONS of symbols to remember, but I think the iconography is good enough it is reasonably manageable.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
With 2, the game has the most control, as the hands move back and forth, so you see the "other" hand every other turn.  What complicates this is the dummy player - unlike with 3 or more, he doesn't have a hand that rotates, but one that comes out a card at a time.  Thus, you'll know what cards are where, but there is a small amount of doubt as to when those cards you haven't seen will show (one of them won't).  You can use the dummy player to enrich yourself and/or screw your opponent, so there's more strategy than with 3+.  This is a fun, fast game, but no matter how you play, no terribly deep.  Great filler, sadly at non-filler prices.  If you pick this one up, be sure to get some sleeves - every Repos game I've owned has had cards that show wear after only a few plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Nice and simple to teach, 7 Wonders is a family game and a gamer's game, which is a rarity. It's hard not to recommend it to a lot of people, and it would be a great place to start.

RATING: 7.5

The real bonus is the number of players supported. Since everyone takes their turn at the same time, the game takes ever-so-slightly longer with more players as there is typically at least one player with AP in the group. But with people who know the game, it's a 30 minute party-game-for-gamers.

* [thing=92539]7 Wonders: Leaders[/thing] (2011) :star::star::star:
* [thing=111661]7 Wonders: Cities[/thing] (2012) :star::nostar::nostar:

(9.0) GAME LENGTH      (x2): TOO SHORT/LONG :star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::nostar: JUST PERFECT

[/c]
[b]TOTAL = 452.0/50 = 9.04[/b]


:thumbsup: [b]POSITIVE POINTS:[/b]

++ Great, light-medium weight strategic engine-building card drafting game, with smooth gameplay, with many paths to victory.
++ Great scaling between all player counts, by adding more cards. The official "expert 2-players" variant works very well and makes the game more strategic in my opinion (but takes longer to play and affect the gameplay smoothness). 
++ Great replayability from the variable card draft mechanism, the variable player's Wonder Board used (plus side used, A or B), the limited number of Guild used in the last Age (purple cards), the number of players and your neighbors strategy used during the games.
++ Easy to teach, fast to set-up and fast to play (even at high player's count when players know how to play).
++ Great game insert which hold everything in an orderly fashion (base game and expansions, but to put everything in the core game box, you'll need to get rid of it unfortunately).
++ Great card graphic design, that is clean and clear.
++ There are expansions available for this game (which is useful to refresh the game when we have overplayed it).
++ The Leaders expansion really add a layer of depth and possible long-term strategy without adding bulk to the base game, as it's essentially just a pre-game draft (to choose our leaders) and then, just one more action per age to do (recruit a leader).
++ The Leaders expansion is also the best kind of expansion in the sense that you can easily decide to play with it (or not), with minimal setup and take-down time.
++ The Cities expansion add more interaction between all the players around the table (and not just your neighbors anymore) by including the black cards. This add a 7th round in each Age, which does add some variability to the game when you have played it a lot (This expansion is best with more players).


:thumbsdown: [b]NEGATIVE POINTS:[/b]

-- Take a lot of table space (beyond 5 players, a normal kitchen table may be not enough!).
-- The replayability in 2-players game can be a bit lower (for the base game only), but is still really high with expansions (especially Leaders).
-- Even though the official "expert 2-players" variant work well and is more strategic, it take longer to play it than a 3+ players game.
-- The components between the base game and the expansions (and between the expansions themselves) have slight color mismatch, thus it easy to know that some cards are from an expansion or not.
-- It seems like the expansions are a bit expensive for what we get (especially the Wonder Pack), but if you really like the base game, they are still worth it.
-- Using the Cities expansion add a bit of setup time as we now need to include black cards equal to the number of players for each Age deck.
-- Using the Cities expansion also add too much randomness and chaos to this well balance game (for low player counts). The 7th round also lengthen the game. 


:arrowE: [b]OTHER GAME INFO:[/b]
[b]
Game Weight = 2.3/5
Release Date = 2010
Number of Player = 2-7(8)
2-player length (Base game only) = 45 min.
2-player length (With expansions) = 60 min.
Player Count Preference = Best at 3 and 4, great at 2, 5 and 6, recommended at 7 and 8! :thumbsup::thumbsdown:

NOTE: Should have been sleeved because not all the cards are played all the time.
[/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
The complicated scoring makes it hard to parse the good plays from the better plays.  The tight scoring at the end makes it critical to eke out that extra point or two, but it's hard to tell early on exactly what will do that.  If this game were more like Dominion, merely an efficiency race for simple VPs, I would rate it higher.  No game should take longer to score than to play.

RATING: 7
14 plays - not bad - but I think I've hit that point where I'm not enjoying it that much anymore. Apart from the niggling issues of balance and control, I think probably 7 Wonders biggest problem is that the pacing and narrative are wrong. High-stakes decisions are made early with inadequate information, and rather than build to a conclusion 7 Wonders actually becomes less and less interesting, and the game drains tension, with each passing age, until the 3rd Age when almost all the decisions are automatic and little you do matters. Which is a shame. There are of course reasons to break the rules of narrative structure, but you need to really know what you're doing if you want to change things up. I don't think 7 Wonders does.
---
Having now gotten a significant number of plays of this under my belt, I like it. It's great that it packs a fair amount of interest into a 30-minute game that easily scales to 7. But ... I can't shake the feeling that there is less here than meets the eye. Once people get the hang of the game it seems like scores become very clustered (a recent game was 52-51-49-48), which is not really  a good sign. Or, the game can be decided by some guy who never builds any Military and allows a neighbor to score a ton of points off of a single 1-point military card. Given there isn't much depth the underlying game here, it's rather chromy, and it feels like your fate is as much in the hands of others as it is your own - Military and Science can both be swingy. Still, it has many good qualities as well, it's clever and fast and fun and flavorful and colorful, and I expect to be enjoying it for a while.
---
Played twice at BGG.con, fun, but a bit over-hyped. It's a nice medium-weight that plays very fast but doesn't pack the punch of, say, a Beowulf, Blue Moon City, San Juan, Race for the Galaxy, or even Small World. It seems clear that it's going to become pretty samey pretty fast. But it does play fast, and does cleanly support 6-7 players, which is huge - nothing else in my collection keeps 6 or 7 players as engaged and moving as quickly on a game with some substance. This alone will assure it a spot in my collection for some time, I imagine.

I'm really curious as to whether there is a "life extension" plan for expansions for the game. Clearly it'll need something if it's to rise above disposability. Also clearly, new player mats aren't going to do it; we'll ultimately need more variety and range in the decks. The path forward is not entirely clear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As Modern Art is a distillation of auctions and Can't Stop is a distillation of push your luck, 7 Wonders is a distillation of take-and-pass drafting. I'm always surprised it gets so much love for being original since Fairy Tale did a lot of the same things. That said, I think 7 Wonders is a better game, especially with the expansions.

RATING: 9
PL, niezależna językowo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Definitely one of those "let's play one more time!" games, which is actually fairly rare in our group.  A lot of that is simply because the entire game takes 20 minutes, but within that 20 minutes is a very interesting game!

7 Wonders reminds me a lot of Fairly Tale, with the "play a card and pass the rest" mechanism.  However, 7 Wonders adds quite a bit of depth to the system, as you now have to pay even more attention to your neighbors and how you interact with them.  And this added depth doesn't come at the expense of much added complexity, which is great!

I also enjoy how each player starts with a different wonder, which will sometimes slightly drive your game strategy.  I actually wish they drove your strategy a little more heavily, but it's a nice touch as it is.

Overall, a great little filler that feels like a full game, and plays 7 to boot which covers a hard to fill niche!  My only concern is with staying power, as games start to feel very same-y a few plays in.  For a "one more time" type game, it really needs to feel different from game to game, which I hope future expansions address.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
An ok game that is way overrated and doesn't quite work for me.

I dislike 7 Wonders for several reasons, but one thing which really bugs me about the game is that it doesn't teach me how to get better, rather, it obfuscates strong play. Not that I've played the game a huge amount, but in my few plays I never felt like I was developing skill or understanding what the game really wants me to do. It's kind of point-salady but because it's simultaneous and disconnected and I can't quite figure out what decisions my opponent's made and can't understand how they built up more points than me. Sure, someone may have some awesome combo but how did they get to that point, what thought processes went into what resources they took, etc. 

It also suffers from very little and localized player interaction.  In a 7 player game it doesn't feel like you're playing with the majority of players.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This is a nice enough game when you want something quick that doesn't involve TOO much thought. This gets a lot of play with us for the simple reason that it scales really, really well. And even though I'm sort of played-out of the game by this point, I'm still up to play just because it's so fast.

Even though it scales well, I think I prefer this game with a lower player count (three is my favorite). There's a little more strategy involved when you know you're passing the same decks back and forth, and it makes for some tenser choices.

I have a problem with this game, though, and that's that it's quite difficult to interfere with other players. I enjoy plenty of low-interaction games, but the drafting makes it feel like you should be able to stop someone who's running away with the win, but unless everyone is cooperating it's really hard to do and often doesn't feel worth it.

Luck of the draw is obviously a big factor as well. You only win if you pick a plan early game and stick to it, and that's hard to do when you might just get bad pass after bad pass. But in a light, breezy game like this it's not really a big deal. Don't treat this like the serious game it isn't and it's fun enough.

Update: I really don't care for this game anymore. What was once a middling experience is now irritating. If someone goes uncontested Sciences, they win. So someone always has to fall on the sword and contest Sciences - usually letting another player just play for points and sneak in a win. I will play it when everyone wants to play because it's so short, but I'd be more than happy to never play again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a great game. It plays extremely fast (around half an hour) and plays 3-7 player in ALMOST exactly the same way - and in the same time!

It's a good light civilization card game which I think fills a unique niche; I cannot really compare 7 Wonders to many other games. The symbols and how the ressources work can be hard for newcomers to figure out at first, but once they have tried a game, they know what to do the next time - which will probably be right after the first game as it's such a fast game! 

Even though it's a fast game, you actually feel that you are building your own small civilization, especially because of your own unique wonder (which are all pretty well balanced, and I like how there are 2 different sides to choose from). 

When playing with 3 players there is much less luck as you will get your starting hand back and everybody have access to the same starting ressources and influence each other militaristic. If you are playing with 6 or 7 players, there is more luck involved as you never know which cards will be passed to you by your neighbour, but I don't mind this aspect. 

Regarding strategy, I think that the different paths are pretty balanced though it does seem that, in our games, the blue civil cards have been granting the most VPs, but the green scientific cards and red military cards have won their fair share of games too. A good mix of the different cards can be okay too sometimes, but it really depends on how many players you are, which wonder you have and which cards you are dealt etc., so you cannot declare a superior strategy... I also like the guild cards and how they are mixed into the deck randomly.

The expansion adds a little something different to the game and I can't wait to see the rest of the expansions. The promo wonders Manneken Pis and Catan are okay wonders but not some I use when playing with fewer than 5 players.

This is one of those games you want to have in your collection. I recommended it a lot - not many games can play 7 players like this in 30 minutes!

My recommended number of players: 3, 4, 5
Best with: 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really don't think there's another civilization type game out there that can accomplish what this game offers in the 30 minute time frame, especially with a high player count. RATING: 7.5
A very quick and well designed card game.  Definitely NOT a multi-player solitaire as a lot of card-based board games tend to be (I am thinking of you Dominion, and you, London) as much of your scoring throughout the game is dependent on what others are doing.  

My wife claims the Wonders are unbalanced, but I don't know if I agree.  Some are better than others, but I think you have to cater your strategy to the Wonder that you get at the beginning of the game, rather than being stuck with one particular strategy.

RATING: 9
A very fun game, and my favorite of the drafting games.  It can be a challenge to learn and teach (it takes about 15 minutes), but it is straightforward and intuitive once you pick it up.  It scales nicely to bigger groups, meaning it doesn't take much more time to play with six people than it does with four.

Is more fun with expansions; I have tried the "Babel," "Cities," and "Leaders" expansions.  I do not recommend teaching the game with the expansions, but they are worth it for experienced players.  I love the Babel and Cities expansions; I am just so so on the Leaders expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
7 Wonders is one of the most versatile games that I have in my collection. It plays from 3 up to 7 players with no issues, it  makes great use of the drafting mechanic, and it typically plays in about 30 minutes. It is… “The Superfiller!”

And that’s a key point. This game does not offer the substance of, say, Puerto Rico, or Agricola, or etc. etc. And I’m OK with that. Every time I’ve sat down to play this game, I’ve enjoyed it. Waiting for others to show up? Bust out a game of 7 Wonders. Have 30 minutes to squeak in one last game? Bust out 7 Wonders. The only issue with the game is teaching “newbies” the iconography on the cards. But once they overcome that initial barrier, the game flows very smoothly.

A couple notes--I actually prefer playing this with less players, as you can see the hands of cards twice in a phase and try to anticipate what you will see again. Also, with groups larger than 4, you really need to police everyone’s turn. Otherwise, a few get ahead of themselves and then it’s a mild train wreck to fix. It's a 7 rating for 6 or 7 players, but an 8 at anything less.

Update: I ultimately ended up trading this one away. My resistance to playing with more than 5 players, coupled with the fact that I can think of more enjoyable "superfillers" for 3 to 5 players meant this just wasn't hitting the table. Too many times I felt victim to simply not getting a critical card because it was never passed my way. It just wasn't fun!

RATING: 5
:indigo: :( :what: :D :D :) :) :) This is a good game, and it's a worthy addition to any strategy gamer's arsenal -- it plays quick and it's relatively easy to grasp if you put in the effort (but it's not strictly a gateway game, there's a few too many things to explain to people not used to this sort of thing), it's capable of playing any number of players from 3 to 7, you can play it light if everyone's doing so or you can really dig into the strategy and make it a deeper experience, and the whole thing is done in less than an hour, much less than an hour if everyone's played a few times before. It's unlikely to be my first choice unless time is a serious factor but it's usually fun.

Best with: 3-4. Playable with: 3-7. Probably fine with 2, but why bother?

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
In my opinion 7 wonders is very close to the perfect type of game I want to play. 

1) It accommodates a broad variety of player groups, from 2-8, so it's almost always an option depending on the party
2) There are a variety of ways to win, and you can't be so self-centered to ignore what your opponents are doing, you often have to react to what they play (and don't play)
3) Everyone takes their turn at the same time.  This mechanic can be rare to find in games but I absolutely love it, because you're almost never waiting very long for other players to finish their turns.  
4) The game has a huge variety in terms of how it can unfold, you'll never play the same game twice. 
5)The learning curve is about mid-range, you can understand all the basic mechanics of the game in a few minutes, but it takes some time to familiarize yourself with all the cards.  You may not truly understand the impact of scoring until you finish your first game and see it for yourself
6) Once everyone knows what they're doing, the game is a short enough length that you'll often want to play multiple times in one sitting.    
7) I like the art style quite a bit!

There are a few shortcomings that I find mostly dismissable, like the fact that being randomly assigned a civilization can force you to adopt one strategy over another, but these are smoothed over by house rules and in later expansions.  I'd recommend 7 wonders to any of my friends, and if you haven't played it at least try it once.

RATING: 7.5

update: Part of me is sick of this game but it's enduring popularity in my game group is undeniable. Always easily playable, fun, breezy. The end scoring always brings groans and laughter. It's a game we can always pull out that everyone agrees on. Like many of us, I grew up playing classic card games (for me Crib, Canasta, Hearts etc) and 7W is the one designer boardgame that gives me the same feeling as those card games of my childhood. That pefect blend of strategy, tactics, and luck where if you win, you accomplished something and if you lose the cards were against you:)

Also for some reason I have often thought 'shrug' about 7W when not playing it but when I am playing it I always think 'this game is amazing'..

RATING: 8.1
Cracking game that delivers some very important game design lessons. Turning each player into nodal resources is a wonderful way to supply interaction without supplying interaction (?). It is very easy to get on the table, plays up to 7 (8 with expansion) and does not run into any substantial amount of "dead time" what so ever. For newer players this game is wonderful and one of those games you can always rely on as a fall back. This will stand a very long test of time.

RATING: 9
a very fun & fast game that scales well even with 6 & 7 players.

it can be a touch challenging to teach ( particularly with expansions ) but one of its best aspects is that once everyone knows it, you can knock games out in 15 to 20 minutes.

despite the games being so short, you do feel like you are generally building towards something and over time you learn that to win consistently at the game you cannot play solitaire and need to balance being reactive to some long range planning.

each expansion added more swinginess & a larger luck factor. the game is still fun with expansions but going back and playing just base, I find this is when the game was best balanced.

RATING: 8
Very impressive.  I have only played this twice...one 3 player and one 2 player game.  The game is easy to teach (especially if one is familiar with resource management) and easy to learn. And now after several 4 and 5 player games it shines even more.  It's a great little game.

RATING: 8.5
An enjoyable game, It's reasonably complex yet still easy enough to teach new players in a short amount of time. Gameplay is a little dry as you are basically taking a card and passing your hand to the next player. However, there is enough variety in the cards (and wonders), and in what you can do with them, that I don't mind it too much. I love games with good artwork and 7 Wonders has great artwork. Quite honestly this games biggest plus is the short amount of time it takes to play. I tend to like longer, more strategic games, and was pleased to find that 7 Wonders was a short, fast paced game that has a good amount of strategy.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the "have to play" games of modern board gaming and I have yet to meet anyone what didn't enjoy it. For the uninitiated, it's a quick card game that feels very much like Sid Meier's Civilization series. You can win through military, science, culture and the like. Super quick if everyone has already learned how to play. Perhaps a little too much to teach someone totally new to gaming, but anyone with some XP under their belt won't have any trouble picking it up. (A science victory is the only complicated part to learn, since its scoring is exponential.) All in all, a fantastic game that's also great to fill in short gaps of time while you're waiting for a friend to finish another game. Great on its own, though all of the expansions are very worthwhile.

RATING: 10
This is a great game to serve as an introduction to friends and family who aren't hardcore boardgamers. Also own Palace promo card, Art Pack, and 2016 playmat
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
7 Wonders is yet another titles in the card drafting filler to super filler category that has been popular for the past few years. It basically gives players a Fairy Tale type draft where they take turns placing cards to produce resources which can then be used to erect military, science and VP cards. As is usual for these types of games, specialization is usually much better than the smorgasbord, which limits the strategic space of the game, and its ultimate variability. In a decent twist, there is also the ability to use resources from your neighbours for a cost, a bit of interaction that is often absent from these types of games.

As with any drafting game, there are some tough decisions to be made in terms of the pass, but honestly, it's not all that difficult (read: interesting) to play, and there doesn't seem to be a lot of variation in the cards. I don't expect this to have much in the way of legs. Vis a vis its most obvious competitor in Fairy Tale, I think it's a touch worse, as it has a much larger space requirement and set-up/tear-down/play time. Not a bad game, but not a particularly great one either. Unnecessary given the existence of FT, which distills the same basic concept down into a 10 minute, small box title versus a 25-30 minute one in a huge box.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Simply amazing. The hand rotation and the people directly next to you really changes your in-game decisions.

On top of that, you need to weigh every pickup for its value. Do you take the 8 point VP card, knowing next guy in line can build the 7 pointer in the same hand you're about to give him? Or do you try to get rid of it and hope that 8 point card makes it back around for you?

I haven't played the 7 player version yet (where you only see every hand once).

Plus, the scaling adds no more time than it takes for the players to make their decisions as the game is always 18 plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
I really feel that the game is stuck between worlds. It is WAY too complex for a quick gateway game but too simple for a light weight strategy game. I'm sure I could become better at the game if I understood all the building chains but the question is WHY. Why would I sink in so much effort to mastering a game that gives me so little control. Sometimes it is easy to pick the best card but other time YOU HAVE NO IDEA. Plus the game is nearly impossible to play well the first time. Sushi Go's simplicity actually makes me feel that my decisions are more meaningful as I can actually weigh the importance of the cards I choose.

That being said, the game isn't bad. I actually enjoy it a lot at 3 players because you can keep track of your opponents which informs your decisions more.

RATING: 9

Update 2/2311

Maybe I have just not played it enough to tire me out of it, but I am finding that I am really digging this game. It is still multiplayer solitaire, but it is quite fun. It is not a really deep game, but who cares.

RATING: 10
Jogo maravilhoso. Leve, rápido, simples, com o grau ideal de intervenção no jogo dos oponentes, e uma boa gama de decisões para tomar na escolha de cada carta! Sempre no clima para mais uma partida :) 
Cada jogador tem uma Maravilha para aprimorar, e tem 3 eras para fazer isso, o que restringe a duração do jogo. Precisamos de matérias primas e manufaturas para baixar cartas de desenvolvimento em ciências, militarismo, pontos de vitória e comércio, bem como para construir as etapas da Maravilha. Balancear seu jogo é essencial. (Ainda não testei a variante para 2 jogadores).

RATING: 9
This is a good game requiring a balance of building for the future and taking opportunities to score points. I need to play it more to be able to speak with any credibility on its replayability and variety of strategies. Responding to what other people are building makes this game far more interactive than it seems.

There are different ways to go about balancing your play to get a win. In one game I thought I had done poorly by going for far too many resources and goods at the start but the last round was incredible and I ended up with my highest ever score. 
Scratch that new highest score 84. 4 of each science (16x3+28=76). Blue = 1st round 2point and 3rd round 4 point I think. Military = -6. and mined a guild in the last turn for opponents blue cards (8 points!)

2nd copy pretrade deal 2013 maths trade

RATING: 7
Kicsit bajban vagyok az értékeléssel, mert nagyon ritkán kerül elő a 7 csoda, pedig alapvetően egy nagyon jó játéknak tartom. 

A gyűjteményem első card drafting játéka volt (azóta lett még Sushi Go, ami egy sokkal könnyedebb játék ugyanerre a mechanizmusra, illetve a Kincsvadászt is később vettem meg, ami szintén hasonló módon építi a játékos kezét), és nagyon kedvelem ezt a mechanizmust mivel lehetőséget ad nem csak arra, hogy az ember a saját céljait tolja előre, de ad egyfajta kontrollált, rejtett konfrontációra is lehetőséget a többi játékossal, amikor kifejezetten úgy játszik valaki, hogy ne adjon tovább egy nagyon jó lapot a mellette ülőnek a kezében lévő lapok közül. 

Érdekes módon maga a card drafting a tapasztalatok alapján ebben a játékban kifejezetten nehezen tanítható meg kezdő játékosoknak - az említett két másik játékban ugyanezt sokkal könnyebben abszolválják, szóval nem érdemes olyanokkal leülni 7 csodázni, akik még nem láttak card drafting játékot. Ez valószinűleg azért van, mert sokfélék a kártyák és nehéz az elején mindent átlátni: a mechanizmust, az opciókat, a kártyaszíneket, stb.

- 7 játékossal is játszható
- akárhányan játsszuk, 30 perc alatt megvan a játék (szabálymagyarázattal 45 perc)

Játszási szám: több, mint 100 (kb. 40 élő, 60 online játék a BSW-n)

RATING: 7

-----
Update after playing final version: The multiplayer solitaire gets a little old. I'm not so keen on games where every player does their own thing. Player interaction is minimal.
------
This was one of the more popular prototypes at the Gathering. Or I guess it's more of just a preproduction copy, since I think it's basically done. This is a card game that feels kinda like a board game. With drafting. So sort of like Fairy Tale, but the cool part is how each player is directly related to what each player to their left/right is doing, but only indirectly related to the other players. All game play is in parallel, which means the game scales from 2 (or maybe 3 I don't know) to 7 players, with effectively no added time per player! That is really nice. This got pretty positive feedback from most players, as far as I could tell. I'll definitely be looking for the released version. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Over time I have developed a healthy sceptical attitude towards eveything that gets hyped in an unnatural fashion; and when 7 Wonders fell victim to this ‘disease’ I decided to let the game be until I was able to give the game a go in a quiet setting. So I didn't try at during Spiel 2010, didn't purchase it there either. Without doubt it would be a reasonably nice game, but no more than that, really.

And 7 Wonders turned out to be that, with one or two things which make it stand out from the crowd. First it is very accessible. The main mechanism of passing cards around means you cannot plan very much, and instead have to make do with scavenging and hoping for the best. Ever since Notre Dame used a similar mechanism I've been of the opinion that this [i]doesn't[/i] promote player interaction: players just react to what they're given, build whatever is best to build (which sometimes is a guess), and from time to time take a look at their opponents when there is a [i]really[/i] good card in there. Second, 7 Wonders plays very well at high player numbers, although to be honest the design cheats to accomplish this: it simply limits interaction between players to the immediate neighbours on the left and right. (In other words, there's seven overlapping 3-player games played at the same time.) Still, in clubs and the like the tendency exists to put Citadels on the table when there's 6 or 7 players and there is demand for something quick: that Citadels is not conceived for so many people is besides the issue. Fortunately, that title can now retire in style as 7 Wonders fills the gap nicely.

Those are truly assets for the niche the game fits in. What remains is a simple collect-resources-and-transform-into-VP game with, entirely expected, multiple ways to victory. The basic structure is very simple (as expected again, because of the ease with which you play as a newcomer); on the other hand, it leaves very much open the question what remains of the game when played more than a few dozen times. 7 Wonders is very tactical in nature, and the decision space limited: those are not assets for an extensive longevity. So while I can understand [i]some[/i] of the attention the game is getting, I certainly don't understand this sort of chivalric romanticism:[q="Greg Schloesser"]7 Wonders is an amazing design. There aren't many games that can pack this much tension, decisions and strategy options in a 30 - 45 minute time frame, while accommodating up to seven players. The game seems to have all the elements to give in great longevity in a hobby where most games fade to obscurity after just a few years. It also has all of the elements that should make it a front-runner to capture industry awards such as the Spiel des Jahre and International Gamers Award. Although this is a year wherein there have been numerous promising games published, 7 Wonders seems destined to rise to the top.[/q]There is, however, a genuine mystery surrounding this game: why on Earth gamers were willing to spend €40 on a box containing 7 small player boards, simple wooden discs, some simple cardboard chits, and about 4 packets' worth of playing cards. My suggestion would be to wait until the game takes on a much fairer price of approximately €25—and for that, the game's rating is lowered by 1 point.

[b]Update[/b] I don't really notice the difference when playing with 3. There is a tad more control over what gets played by whom, but not enough to up or lower the rate I've given the game. It remains friendly material, and it beats Citadels... But I won't purchase it myself.

[b]Update 2[/b] That 'owned' flag is not me. It's my partner, you understand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Gra, o której słyszał chyba każdy, kto chociaż odrobinę interesuje się grami planszowymi. Klasyk, must have każdego gracza - zresztą nie bez powodu. Mechanika draftu i oddawania kart wymaga czasem zrezygnowania z własnych korzyści, żeby popsuć plany przeciwnikom. Ogromną zaletą jest wykonywanie przez wszystkich ruchu w tym samym momencie, więc partyjka zazwyczaj jest szybka, możliwość zagrania nawet w 7 osób (z dodatkiem Miasta 8) - ogromny plus, bo chyba nie ma drugiej takiej gry, która spełnia kryteria tematyki i czasu rozgrywki, jednocześnie przy tak dużej liczbie graczy. Rozgrywka za każdym razem inna, wymagająca do samego końca. Dzięki zróżnicowanej punktacji prowadzonej dopiero na zakończenie, gra aktywnie się do końca.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good game that I'm not in love with as much as most, but with a group of 4-7 people it does well. In each of three rounds you are drafting cards from your hand. But each turn you only take one card and then pass the rest on. While some will come back to you (depending on the number of players) most will not, so you have to be judicious with what you take, or sometimes deny other players. You can score in a variety of ways, such as military, science, economy, etc. I still rate it a 7 currently, but probably only because I don't play it too often.

Plays:
2012 - 1
2013 - 4
2014 - 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This game is perfect for me because it only supports three players and I only have two friends.  If I only had one friend, I'd have to play with a "dummy" player where I'd pretend I had an extra friend at the table and that is even sadder than only having two friends.  If I somehow made a third friend with a name like, let's say, "Henrietta" who, I dunno, worked downstairs in Processing and I dunno, had a cactus on her desk that she put little hats on for different holidays, well, I'd never get to play with her since she'd be across the table from me, since if I sat next to her, it would be weird, right?  So I'd pass cards to Jeff and Jeremy, and never to her, which means I'd never get to "accidentally" slip and brush against her hands and we would never get married and have four dogs named after my favorite breakfast cereals, Chocula, Cap'n Crunch, Twix Rabbit, and Special K with Strawberries.

So it's a fun three player game, but I will never find love.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders reminds me of a fun type of poker game I played back in the 1980s called "pass the trash".  7 Wonders is simple, cute and fun to play.  I prefer this game with 4 or more players.  The expansions 7 Leaders and 7 Cities are really what made the game for me and raised it from a mediocre game to something most of my gaming friends can sink their teeth into and enjoy.  The theme of trade and conflict in the ancient world of the Mediterrainean has a nice touch to it.  The game pieces and cards are colorful and nice.  Originally, I used this game as a filler game when first purchased, but I was surprised by how much the game was nominated for play thereafter.  If you are looking for a game that plays in under an hour, I highly recommend 7 Wonders with the expansions.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A brilliant little game.  Players are faced with a myriad of choices that slowly start to disappear as each round progresses - and the decisions made early on can have major effects later in the game.

What is satisfying is that there is no one clear path to victory.  A balance of buildings might work, or perhaps a strong military, or even the right combination of scientific knowledge.  Each game is different than the last, and every player decision affects everyone else.  A delight!

The cards and boards are beautiful to look at.  If I had one complaint it would be the cheap box insert, flimsy directions and unnecessarily large box.

RATING: 7.5
Hesitant at first to pick up a drafting board/card game, still I had played Magic the Gathering in the past.  I had also drafted it quite a bit and did enjoy that particular aspect of the game.  I didn't know how it would convey into a board game design as the main feature of play involved.  Picked it up after reading and viewing some reviews, and started off a Friday Night as the main attraction.  It sure did hit the main attraction, after the first initial play with five people in total, it broke the ice with us. We talked, laid a card, talked (looking at what people had done), picked another, and so on and so forth.  

Not every game brings out so much discussion and badgering like this game does for my group.  Hearing, 'look at how much science he has,' or, 'holy ****, that is a lot of Military next to me,' it gets the blood pumping for me.  We had six plays of the game that weekend.  I suggested I sleeve the cards to everyone, and the response from everyone was the same, 'yes do that.'  With just that phrase, I can tell I'm going to get a long mileage out of this game; so I better make sure they stay nice as long as possible.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
w/ leaders
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Clever mechanism to keep playing time low with many players (all players take their turns simultaneously) - an extremely big plus in larger groups! This definitely makes 7 Wonders my most preferred strategy(ish) game for 6 or 7 players (or for 8 with [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/111661/7-wonders-cities]Cities[/url]), because many of the alternatives tend to have problems with too much downtime between turns. But I also like it a lot with fewer players, it is even good with 2.

It has a high level of luck compared to most other games I love and is probably more tactical than strategical. But there are still several ways how strategic planning can pay off and deep considerations can be made and give definite advantages.
The still rather high level of luck means the game is well suited to play with and appeal to beginners who have a chance to win even in their first game - but in contrast to many other games for which this is true, it's still also thrilling for the more experienced players, at least for me.

I hate hidden trackable information (HTI) in games (see my profile) and thus don't like the rather strong incentive for the memorization of hands in 7 Wonders - I don't want to play "[url=www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/7688/memory]Memory[/url]". But I'm willing to tolerate it in this otherwise excellent game! Besides, the bigger the group (in which 7 Wonders particularly excels compared to other games), the fewer hands will come back to you and the fewer returns you get from memorizing cards.

Another minus is that the two sides of several of the wonders could clearly and thus should have been balanced better. This is most obvious on Ephesus, where the B side is clearly and reasonably undisputably stronger than the A side. On Rhodes and Alexandria, the B side is too close to clearly dominate the A side as well in my opinion - but at least it isn't as clear as with Ephesus.
I am not quite sure how this could have happened particularly in case of Ephesus as it is really obvious if you add up - wasn't it a design goal to make the two sides of each wonder as equally strong as possible?
This is particularly annoying for me because I prefer to draw only the wonder randomly and let the players choose the side. The game would be better if it were a real choice more often.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a great light game about drafting, with civilization theme. But unlike fairy tale (which only set collection game), there's a great amount of mechanics in this game. Also, each player will have their own wonder (with different ability) making the game really flavorful. 

The game itself is very tactical, with some degree of strategy. There's no winning strategy. You must be able to look at your opponents, and draft accordingly, whether try the strategy that they're not doing, or counter draft. Also, the game is quite easy to teach (if you're experienced teacher), and lots of fun, making it great game for gateway.

RATING: 10
After few play this game seems to be very good in any number of suggested players. And there aren't many games for 7 player of such quality. And the short gameplay time is a big advantage, too.

After number of game sessions where this game has been an enormous success I must raise the rating to 10. This game is truly addictive, replayable and so much fun.

After 2 years spent with 7 Wonders I must say, that there is no other game, that hits the table that often. After so many games, there is not the "wow" factor or the feeling of freshness anymore, but still the game is very addictive even after such a long time (and the Cities expansion made a huge step forward to replayability, because it adds some variety and randomness (in the good meaning) to the base game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.9
Exceptional game. Milestone genre by itself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Components: Nice, over-sized cards, though they really start to fill up the table after a bit. Wonderful art. The iconography is clear but too small in the 'costs' corner of the cards, making it difficult to audit my neighbors as the cards are played.

Experience: I went into my first game thinking I would invest heavily in raw and manufactured goods, so that I wouldn't need to rely on commerce with my neighbors. This ended up pushing me toward a brown/gray/blue strategy, since I found myself continually strapped for cash. Other players focused more on commerce, or on science. I hammered my neighbors with military, but they were able to compensate in other ways. Very interesting.

Seems to be well balanced, and I expect that as we become more familiar with the cards, the game will become more competitive. With complete knowledge of all cards in circulation (except for the guilds in Age III), and with better knowledge of the build chains, one could employ different strategies with better clarity than I was in this first outing.

I appreciate that my neighbors can't muck with me too much (other than taking my cards, and vying for military might). Nearly every card is attractive to build. Whereas in Agricola the game mandates that I have a little of everything, this game, like Stone Age, seems to push me more toward extremes: specialize in a few different scoring methods, and let the rest fall to the side, otherwise I end up being mediocre in everything.

I'm beginning to feel like Science is too good, as more often than not the player who scores the most in science is also the winner. I also want a bit more direction in terms of final scoring (somewhat provided by the Leaders), to prevent me from just making the same choices every time.

Like in Kingsburg, there isn't much in this game to make me try new strategies; our group is in a bit of a rut with the types of cards we play.

First Played: 2011-03-30
Last Played: 2016-09-06

4 players: 8
5 players: 5
6 players: 5
7 players: 1

RATING: 9.1

RATING: 10

I prefer the game on it's own, without expansions, which is why I've never picked any of them up.

I rate this a 10 as I've never not enjoyed it, whether it's been 3, 4, 5, or 6 players. I can't see there being a time I would turn down playing this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Easy to learn, fast, and contains almost no downtime due to the simultaneous drafting mechanic. Despite its apparent simplicity, it offers a fairly fulfilling strategic experience which only gets richer with each expansion you add. There is not really much player interaction, even with the expansions included, but the drafting does allow you to hinder your opponents' progress indirectly by playing or discarding a card you think they may desire. 

One of the most impressive aspects of 7 Wonders is how well it scales. It is very fun, challenging, and engaging with 3 as well as 7 players and plays just as smoothly and quickly with any player count.

RATING: 6
With as many plays with 3+ as with only 2, I prefer it at lower counts.  At high player counts, it's light and fast, but that's about it.  There's not a lot to decide.  And then it ceases to be anything resembling fun if one of the 6 or 7 players goes overboard with AP.  If I want a serious game of 7 Wonders, I'll play it 2-player.  But I don't much do that even.

A note about my rating:  It was about 3 years between my first plays of this and acquiring it and finally playing it again.  All during that time, it sat near the top of my wishlist.  Its praises kept ringing in my ears, and my anticipation and expectations kept rising.  This worked to the detriment of my enjoyment of 7 Wonders nowadays.  I want to rate it higher, but it's not something I want to play very often.  Though I don't know that I'd turn down a game.  I think it's a solid game, but I'll usually go for other tableau builders like Uchronia or San Juan over this one.  They lack the drafting, but are more satisfying.

RATING: N/A
Played
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast playing and interesting civ-building game with the twist of using a rotating hand draft mechanism. Cards are a bit too big for what they are (same info could easily have been put on standard cards), resulting in overuse of table space and hard to sleeve. Knowing what's in each of the decks is fairly important, and I could see a six/seven player game where you get *one* draw from each "hand" as much more tactical than the three player game where you get to pick two and can hope that cards come back around to you. 

Provisional 8 for now because it's quick to set up and play. The fact that we played two games in a row was a good sign, I felt. Science cards (greens) may be too powerful unless other players prevent them from being chosen through wonders or discards, and even the second is no good against a player with a wonder that lets them take discarded cards.  Three may be the sweet spot for this particular game, but only time will tell. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Exp: Babel, Catan, Cities, Leaders

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Everything this game does it does fine. But it doesn't feel like it does anything especially well. Once you're a few turns in, the cards you choose are fairly obvious and hate-drafting is rarely worth it. There's a little engine-building but not so much that it feels really rewarding when that engine works just right. There's some set collection but I'm not convinced that set collection is capable of making any game good on its own merits. And, finally, the paths to victory are pretty heavily unbalanced and subject either to luck of the draw or how much the people playing are willing to set themselves back (usually to their peril) in order to prevent the leader from winning. I mean, I'll play it without complaint, but nothing here excites me.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders was one of the first games I played when getting into the board game scene, and it's a wonderful example of what's on offer. It's competitive without being aggressive, the mechanics are (providing you stick to A side) easy to pick up, and even a new player can overcome an experienced one with the right hand and quick thinking.

While I wouldn't say I play it regularly anymore, I rarely say no to 7 Wonders when it gets pulled out at a party.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is an enjoyable medium euro game. It is easy enough to understand and play, offers tough choices, encourages interaction and scales from three to seven players. In addition it plays simultaneously and at a fast enough pace. Regardless, 7 Wonders is not a thematically strong game and most plays of it are not very memorable. A mechanically solid, if slightly unimpressive, game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2-7 players, 30-45 minutes, light medium, card drafting/deck building

https://boardgamegeek.com/article/21720247#21720247

This is easily one of my favourite games.

I've played a dozen games with 3-7 players and it is great fun everytime and with every player count. It seems rather complex at first, but it plays rather naturally after a few rounds.

In its core this is a card drafting / tableau building  game over three phases, where you want to build up your resources at first to be able to build your own economy, military and science and if possible, you personal wonder. To do this, you choose one card to play and pass the other cards to your neighbour. When all the cards are played, then intermediate scoring takes place (on military power) and the next phase starts. After phase 3 the game ends and final scoring takes place.

There are several paths that can lead to victory, but it's usually best to focus on one or two routes. Keeping a close eye on your neighbour is very important as you can benefit from his resources, goods and -especially in the last phase- from the cards he/she has played.

All in all, I really like this game. It plays rather fast, so you can play a number of games on a single night. I rate this game 9/10 and would play this again anytime :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Found at Value Village Ballard for $2.99 along with Cities expansion

RATING: 4
2-7/4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fun game that somehow manages to capture the feel of building a civilization in a short period of time. As cards are passed you need to quickly decide how best to utilize what you have been given, even if it means abandoning your original strategy. There is a small amount of interaction, mainly in deciding whether to keep something to benefit yourself or to go with the lesser card in order to deny it to an opponent who needs it more. You also need to plan with an eye on what resources you can buy from your neighbors, and to be prepared to deal militarily with them as well. The game scales pretty well, with a different challenge depending on how many are playing. 

While the expansions add variety, the smoothness of the base game gets messed with just enough that I feel the original is the way to go. I keep the expansions to add as a change of pace.

Cards are sleeved. Base game box includes Leaders and Cities expansions, Wonders expansion and several promo cards. I also have the Broken Token insert.

RATING: 3
this one just didn't do it for me.
It felt like you had to invest more than what the game could possibly ever give back to you. If you want to play it well you might not have to MEMORISE ALL cards in the game but you should have a rough feel for what kind of options there are. In that respect it felt almost like a trading card game or LCG to me (learn all the cards and find the best combinations). 
It felt a bit pointless playing it with compeltely new players. The basic "draft" gameplay is very simple to teach, but players are then usualyl at a complete loss of what there actually supposed to do with the cards or which ones to collect. You do learn pretty quickly how some of the cards work but it didn't feel worthwhile to me... and then the game ends in a huge point salad of counting and adding up points on a little note pad....  arrghhh!!!!

While i didn't want to give it too low a rating after having only played it a couple of times i now feel that i have very little interets in revisiting it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Antoine Bauza really hit the jackpot with this "broadband" game (and the sales numbers validate this sentence)!

7 Wonders apealls equally for the family, for parties, for gamers - it's the game that offers the most quality on account of it´s versatility!
Altough fairly simple, it´s mechanic is not perceived at once by non gamers, however, by the end of the first game, they usually get it without problems.
This is the only game capable of providing a taste in creating a civilization with such an easy set of rules, based on a card drafting and a set collection, that plays itself in no more than an hour and doesn´t get any heavier or longer by having a higher number of players - this is truly remarkable and (i think) a unique feature among the world of boardgames. Very well done!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Next to Settlers of Catan, this is one of the first modern "board" game that I've played.

Great family and large group game. A classic.

Pros: Simultaneous play, low downtime. Great introduction to player interaction through simple card drafting mechanism. Civilization building theme with simple tech trees. Relatively quick gameplay and setup. Good cardboard components and art. Iconography is easy to understand at a glance. Comprehensive rulebook.

Neutral: Not infinitely replayable but there is a lot of game in the box and there are several expansions which add new cards, mechanisms, and length. Due to the different types of cards and icons in play, the first game is a throwaway learning game unless you understand card drafting and civilization building.

Cons: Weak cardstock but just playable without sleeves.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The rules are intimidating as all get-out; just start playing and work it out as you go.  By your second run-through it'll take you an hour for a game - by your third it'll be more like 45 minutes and you'll have "got it".

This is one of those games where there are half a dozen different ways to score.  Trying to pay attention to all of them will just bury you in detail; just pick one or two to concentrate on to begin with, til you get a feel for what works and what doesn't.

Very entertaining.  Watch who you sit next to!

RATING: 6.5
(Sònia)
2-7 Jugadors
Temps: força ràpid, independent del No de jugadors, doncs els torns són simultanis. Uns 30-45 min.
L'objectiu del joc és tenir més PV que els demés.
Draft + Set Collection: compres cartes que et donaran possibilitats de fer més coses als següents torns.
Pots negociar amb els veïns immediats (així com atacar-los).
Els PV s'aconsegueixen de vàries maneres:
- comprant directament PV
- fent investigació
- amb victòries militars
- i, de forma menys massiva, amb diners, i amb altres cartes.

(Experiència en 2 partides: han guanyat els que han anat a pel poder militar. Si tens moltes cartes verdes d'investigació també sumes molts punts, però el militar maxaca bastant).
----
(Experiència última partida: el de màxim poder militar ha quedat últim... perquè no l'ha tingut de bon principi suposo)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I really enjoy the surprising complexity of this fast-paced tableau-building card game.  Several times I've figured out strategies that lead to regular wins, only to have those strategies fade and fail when my opponents' adjust their own play.  Plus there's nothing else that can support seven players with such little downtime and overall game time.

Almost all of my plays are for 5-7 players, the range I prefer.  Under 5 the game changes and military becomes much more dominant, and with 8 players the randomness of cards received is too great for much any strategy at all.

RATING: 6
The civilization theme helps a lot.
This is basically a dumbed down version of Fairy Tale: draft and instantly play the card you get, instead of choosing the order in which you can play it.
To catch up with the less depth, the game get more complex, with several scoring systems.

Additionally, to have a broader success, it suffices to blow on the hype, have a big box and an insane price tag... this is what you need to reach the top 15 on BGG.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Well-designed civilization-building card game.
Nearly impossible to create a 100% balanced civilization, so there's quite an interesting strategic dynamic involved in selecting your pathway to victory: will you build up your military at the expense of science? Will you be ruler of the marketplace at the expense of your strength in battle? I definitely recommend this with 4+ players if you can, because this just adds to the depth of strategy. However, most of my games have been with just 2 players, and it still has engaging gameplay.
Certainly one of my Top 20 favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
有趣的遊戲. 運氣成份不能忽略, 新手上下家很容易成造王者.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
2-7

Voorbereiding:

Elke speler krijgt een wonderbord en 3 munten.
Verwijder uit de 3 kaartstapels de ongebruikte kaarten (afhankelijk van het aantal spelers).
Selecteer willekeurig paarse kaarten voor de tijdperk 3 stapel en schud deze door de stapel.

Speloverzicht:

Er zijn drie tijdperken: tijdperk 1, 2 en 3. Punten worden uitgereikt aan het einde van tijdperk 3. Aan het begin van elk tijdperk krijgt elke speler een hand van 7 kaarten.

1. Kies een kaart: 

Elke speler kiest en speelt een kaart gesloten, daarna draaien alle spelers simultaan de kaart open.

2. Mogelijke acties: 

a/ bouw de kaart open (je kunt hetzelfde gebouw niet twee keer bouwen)
b/ bouw de kaart gesloten als een Wonder (van links naar rechts)
c/ leg de kaart op de aflegstapel en neem 3 geld van de bank

3. De volgende hand: 

Elke speler geeft zijn handkaarten door aan de naburige speler. 

Tijdperk 1 en 3: in wijzerzin.
Tijdperk 2: tegenwijzerzin.
De laatste kaart van elk tijdperk die alle spelers overhouden, gaat naar de aflegstapel.

Gebouwen:

Geldkosten: de kosten worden aan de bank betaald. 
Gratis bouwen: het gebouw kan gratis worden gebouwd. 
Grondstofkosten: de aangegeven grondstoffen worden geproduceerd door de stad van de speler en/of gekocht volgens de handelsregels. 
Gratis bouwen (keten): Als een speler reeds een kaart met hetzelfde symbool heeft liggen, mag hij alle kaarten met dat symbool gratis bouwen.

Wonder:

Grondstofkosten: de aangegeven grondstoffen worden geproduceerd door de stad van de speler en/of gekocht volgens de handelsregels.
 
Productie:
De grondstoffen van een stad worden geproduceerd door het wonderbord, de bruine kaarten, de grijze kaarten en sommige gele kaarten. 

Om een gebouw of fase van een Wonder te bouwen zonder handel, moet de stad van de speler de grondstoffen produceren zoals aangegeven op de kaart van het gebouw of op het bord van het Wonder. 

Grondstoffen worden niet verbruikt tijdens het bouwen. Ze kunnen elke ronde tijdens het hele spel gebruikt worden. De productie van een stad kan nooit verminderen. 
Handel:

Elke speler kan alleen handelen met de twee naburige steden. 
Elke gekochte grondstof kost 2 geld, te betalen aan de eigenaar (spelers kunnen nooit weigeren om grondstoffen te verkopen). 
Een verkochte grondstof hindert de eigenaar niet om zelf deze grondstof in dezelfde ronde te gebruiken voor zijn eigen bouwen. 

Na elk tijdperk volgt er een militair conflict.
Elke speler vergelijkt het totaal aan schildsymbolen op zijn militaire gebouwen (rode kaarten) met het totaal van elk van de naburige steden:

a/ Speler heeft meer schilden dan zijn buurman: +1 fiche (in tijdperk 1), +3 fiche (in tijdperk 2) en +5 fiche (in tijdperk 3). 
b/ Speler heeft minder schilden dan zijn buurman: -1 fiche 
c/ Speler heeft evenveel schilden als zijn buurman: geen fiche.

Elke speler krijgt dus, afhankelijk van de situatie, 0, 1 of 2 fiches op zijn speelbord.

Na Tijdperk 3 tellen de spelers hun punten:
1/ punten op militaire fiches
2/ 1 punt voor elke 3 geld
3/ punten op het wonder
4/ punten op gele gebouwen
5/ punten op blauwe gebouwen
6/ punten op paarse gebouwen
7/ punten voor groene gebouwen
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the few satisfying games that can handle large numbers without taking forever to play. True, this is achieved by essentially being multiplayer solitaire with some minor interaction with your immediate neighbours. Interaction is obviously via war points, but also via denying cards to your downstream neighbour and avoiding what your upstream is collecting. The drafting mechanism is handled well and the different ways to score provide a nice illusion of strategy and control. The cash and resource management doesn't get in the way of speedy play. A good game to start a game session or to wind down after something meatier.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders is a nice game that i randomly enjoy playing although it doesn't hit the mark as I like but not love the game.
The very first few plays with new players always go with the sentence "I don't even know why i need to collect these". After few plays players start to get the logic and the game goes though very well.
The game works well almost only with people who has few plays behind their back.
A way more casual alternative, if you don't have a fix player group, would be Sushi Go.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game plays very differently with six or seven players than with three. In the former version, you pretty much do the best you can with the hand that's passed to you; you don't know which cards you'll get or when you'll get them. The three-player game, on the other hand, permits some planning, as you see each hand twice and can predict somewhat the cards that your opponents will be interested in. I enjoy both versions.
The variety of ways to score is impressive for such a quick game, although with 6 or 7 players, collecting the blue cards seems to be a tough strategy to defeat, and the science cards seem to be a losing proposition unless the other players are asleep at the switch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: great design / well balanced game / obviously well thought out / great components.

Cons: just doesn't excite me very much.  

Analysis: the initial experience of playing the game numerous times was a good one.  The game was fun enough, especially the card drafting mechanic.  But I didn't get a sense of the overall theme of "building" something.  The card names were superfluous and the powers/abilities of the cards linked with the card names didn't matter (like Dominion in that sense - like a pasted on theme).  There are multiple paths to victory (more military or more science etc.) but I never got a good feel for what might work better than others. Almost like the game is TOO well balanced in that regard.  Which makes it seem almost like it is random in terms of which path to take.  

After all of that, it was still enjoyable enough and I would probably play it if asked.  But it just fell flat despite the great production and obviously good game design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[2011-03-24 Rating: n.a. -> 6.5]

After playing 7 Wonders numerous times on Brettspielwelt and also face to face, I finally settled down to give this one a 6.5. After reading the first positive reviews, I was eager to give this one a try. The first two games went really well and I had a lot of fun. But the more I played it, the less I liked it. I mean, it's fun to build your own little civilization, but it feels more like a pastime than a game.

Because there are about a hundred ways to score points, you just have to take a route that no one else follows and hope that you'll get the cards you need or at least some cards that give you more points than your opponent. There is no real long-term strategy or hard decision making. I guess, this game is just a little too light for my taste.

RATING: N/A
May 2016, Present from Lily
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a very fun and quick game to play that scales to ANY number (well starting at 3 players).  Why does it scale up so well?  Because everyone plays their turns at the same time!

The core mechanic is a Magic: the Gathering style booster draft.  Everyone looks at a hand of cards, chooses one card, and hands the rest of the cards to the player next to them.  Once everyone has chosen a card, everyone plays that card at starts the process over by looking at the cards that were passed to them. 

Each card has a cost to play (just like in Magic) and a benefit.  The benefits of the cards follow a civilization style chart where you can get prerequisites which allow other cards to be played for free.

There are several types of cards: Resources, Marketplace, Military, Science, Civic, and 1 other (they were purple, but I can;t remember what they were called).  Resources and Marketplace enable you to play cards, and the others give you victory points.  

After 3 rounds of booster drafting (just like in Magic, where you pass left, then right, and then left again), the player with the most victory points wins.

7 Wonders plays very quickly, is not too taxing, and is very enjoyable.  My only fear is that it might not have too much replayability, so my rating will go up if I start to see that there is a lot of hidden skill.  In all, this game is highly recommended by me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 2
Is this a game or a shared experience? Where are the meaningful choices? This is an entry level game with too many rules and symbols to attract new gamers. This is a "line in the sand" game for me. If someone rates this higher than a 7, I'm playing games for much different reasons than that person. RATING: 5
Despite the fact that the "User Suggested # of Players" indicates that this is "Not Recommended" for two players, I honestly believe it's best with two. (I'd have to give the two-player version an "8".) This is due to the control you have and to the fact that every other turn you get to make decisions for two players (you and the dummy player). As soon as you add a third player, your decision-making is cut by one-third, though it's still a decent game (probably a "7"). But as you add more players, you lose more control, and I have no interest in playing this with more than three. Despite my complaints about the scaling, this is a well-crafted game with some very clever mechanisms. But if I'm going to play a multi-player filler, I'd rather play something with no set-up time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

By the end of the game, just before scoring, everybody feels confident and happy with what they have created!  That itself is the best compliment to the game! 
It s a game where there are many roads to victory! So you have to pick one, but ignore none. Otherwise you stand no chances at the final scoring. A must have!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders is about drafting.  That may sound silly, but it's important because many people come to this game looking for a different kind of strategy.  For those who enjoy drafting for its own sake, 7 Wonders delivers.  You need to be attentive to your neighbors so that you aren't fighting them the same points and dragging yourself down versus the table.

Because of this, playing with players that don't think about the drafting and doggedly pursue set collection based on whim can produce unsatisfying games.  With players that really like to draft, the game gets better and better.  Not an amazing game, but one that is very solid as a short, fun experience.

Plays well at all player counts and those who claim it's less deep with more players are simply less familiar with larger draft table dynamics.  In fact, I think three player is the least skill intensive player count.  Judicious selection of expansions can make the game even more interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Can't decide whether this is a 7 or 6.  I like the drafting element.  I like the chaotic planning this game delivers.  But how much planning is there really and how much is this just a random draft.  I can appreciate that it plays with 7, but with that many it really becomes a crapshoot because you can't plan a strategy based on what you've seen.  The cards won't make it around again.

That said, the fact it plays quick was enough for me to rate it a 7 instead of a 6.  Games with a lot of randomness need to be quick games and this does accomplish the fun in a short time.

Update: Dropping to a 6 after 3 plays.  It's just too light for my taste to rate any higher.  It's good for a sporadic play here and there.  The shine is wearing off quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Players whip through three epochs building up a card based civilization.  Uber-quick game where players choose a card and either build it for function, trash it for gold, or use it as one of the three foundations for their wonder.  Repeat 17 more times, passing your cards around the table, so they circulate.  You also have six battles with your neighbours.  Tote up points for all sorts of things 25 minutes later. Beautifully designed super-filler, gorgeous art (although the icons could be clearer), and it garnered an immediate repeat play.  Turns are blisteringly fast, in fact it feels a lot like playing Spacebeans, if that makes sense.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A favourite in my house that sadly doesn't get played nearly enough! 7 Wonders is a set collecting and card drafting game which is set in the ancient world, when great cities commanded power and architectural wonders were erected to transcend the ages. Players will each lead one of these ancient cities and through three ages of card drafting, build a civilisation, commercial success and military powerhouse to win the game. Card drafting simply put for those who don't know, is where a player has a hand of cards, keeps one, passes the hand to the next player whilst simultaneously receiving the remaining hand of the player on their other side, then puts the kept card into play in the game, paying any costs depicted on the card (in 7 Wonders at any rate, other drafting games do not always require this). In 7 Wonders this happens over three rounds (or Ages) before the game ends and points are tallied up to reveal the winner. Card types include resources which you can use to buy other cards and pay for wonders to be built, which in turn give you additional points, items or powers, military strength, which is tested at the end of each round and the people with higher strengths than their immediate neighbours receive VP whereas those with lower totals get -VP. There are also civilian card which simply give VP, science cards which must be collected into set to score, commercial cards, which give out money and points throughout the game or at the end of the game for various reasons and finally guilds which award points based on the colours of the games in each player's tableau and sometimes those of his/her neighbours. 7 Wonders is a great classic game that I never tire of playing, especially with the various expansions. It plays up to 7 people but 4 or 5 is the sweet number I think, 7 can be awkward as it is more of a team game, while 2 player is downright awful and those out there who generally only play with one other person would be better suited to 7 Wonders: Duel

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Quick to teach the rules and short playing time makes this a great gateway game, while still being interesting for experienced gamers. The different wonders are nicely balanced and provide extra replayability.

One caveat is that despite the box saying 2-7 players, it really doesn't work with 2 or 3. Essentially this is a 3-7 player game since special rules are required for 2 players, but it doesn't work well for 3 either.
