=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good game, but it falls a little short of the hype, to be honest.   Lite civ-building.   The drafting element has a cool wrinkle where you play each card before selecting another.   But, there doesn't seem to be as much "hate drafting" here as there is in Fairy Tale because that game has conditional scoring cards that really require more risk assessment.  One cool thing about this game, however, is that it really plays well with 7 people, which is a rare feat.  With multiple paths to victory, this game should see plenty of plays, but since Fairy Tale scratches the same itch (mostly) in a third of the time, 7 Wonders might not see quite as many plays in my estimation.   Setup time for 7 Wonders is a problem.  I did appreciate that each player's wonder gives different rewards.   But, really, it boils down to "pick a card & play it".  That's all there is.   Rating 7 (ha-ha).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A slight-step above a gateway game, 7 Wonders is a classic.  I first played this a long time ago in my early days of Euro-gaming with a not-so-friendly group at a meetup and no one would really explain the rules.  However, I was STILL able to get a grasp of the civilization and engine building aspect of accumulating resource cards to build more cards.  It was logical, intuitive and felt very natural.  
Instinctively thinking I should just try my best to diversify, when the scoring came at the end, I actually came somewhere in the middle range compared to the other players.  With the exception of the Science cards, the scoring is very simple and straight forward.   Often when I introduce this to new/non-gamers, they get this déjà vu feeling they’ve played this before; that’s how instinctive this game is (very much like Splendor).  

While my first experience with it was tainted by the players at that particular meetup, I’ve since played it many times at meetups (with friendlier people) and came to love it.  

The game is fast and a fun activity when you have a lot of players who don’t want to split up into two groups.  As far as strategy, well… while experience at knowing what cards will come up during each age has its advantages, it really comes down to the luck of the draw as to what cards are passed to you.  You can try to block or exploit advantages, but there is a lot of luck in the game.  I’ve seen first time players win a number of times (although they almost always had a LOT of help from their neighbours).  And the scoring at the end is a chore (best to get the computer application to do the math for you).   
The amazing artwork is some of the best I’ve ever seen in a game and gives 7 Wonders a very classy feel.  You very much feel you are building a civilization from ancient times.   

Some people may critique the game for its lack of interaction (especially against players on the opposite side of the table), but the simultaneous selection mechanism eliminates downtime and all players are considering their selections concurrently.  Thus it makes the game feel fast as everyone is constantly engaged in play.   There aren’t many games out there that can accommodate 7 players that aren’t straight-up party games.  That said, I’ve never played this game with less than six players and usually play it with the full seven.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Could be talked into as a three-player game... No way that I'll play this again with 4 or more...

RATING: 9
This is one of the most unique games in my collection and certainly one of the most strategic at such a high player count. Its gorgeous art, mixed with its quick play time and its generous player accessibility, make this an awesome game.

[b]5.8.2011 Update:[/b] Now that I own this great game and have the responsibility of teaching it, I have come to realize that it is quite the burden. It isn't on par with teaching a monster like Puerto Rico, but it definitely takes time and ruins the ability to play this quickly if there are any newcomers present. I might have to drop my rating a little.

[b]6.20.2011 Update:[/b] Finally played a 2 player game and I can report that it is fantastic. The ability to use the 'Free City' (we called it Bob) as your pawn to both help yourself and hinder your opponent is very fun. The ability for this game to scale from 2-7 players negates my above setup complaint. Rating stays.

[b]9.6.11 Update:[/b] Two things have this game firing on all cylinders lately: most of my game group finally knows it (therefore doesn't need to be taught) and the addition of Leaders! Rating goes up and added to my Top 10.

[b]8.17.12 Update:[/b] I continue to look forward to playing this game. I never turn down a chance to play it and it always impresses new players. Rating increases and it moves up to #5 in my Top 10!

[b][url=http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/68485/7-wonders_short-guide_game-summary]7 Wonders_Short Guide_Game Summary[/url][/b]

[b][url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/filepage/82122/7-wonders-2-player_short-guide_game-summary]7 Wonders 2 Player_Short Guide_Game Summary[/url][/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I liked this game from my first play, and still do after many more.  It's a wonderful (pun intended) system of interlocking card types, resources, shifting incentives based on your neighbors' actions, variable player powers, and so on.  

There are subtle, but very important, differences in the game when playing with different player counts.  This is due both to the number of shared neighbors as well as the extra cards put into the deck for the additional players.  The game does a good job of balancing these additions, but it's still a little uneven.  
Some deride it as little more than an activity, but I've seen that skillful play will carry you through most of the time.  Yes, you can get screwed by cards clumping up, or by another player who decides to snipe a bunch of things you were counting on, but it is a card game after all.  Yes, playing with the full 7 is kind of chaotic, but show me a 7p game that isn't.  (And I still feel like you have more control than it might seem, at least on local events.)

The game's got great replay value, solid expansion potential, and plays in a fairly short timeframe (though setup can be a bit of a chore).  
If I have one gripe, it's over the changes between the 1st and 2nd printings of the game.  I don't miss the wooden money from the 1st ed, but it was awfully nice to have the wonder names and power descriptions in English.  The newer printings are language-neutral, but that means new players get confused by even more symbols, and have to refer to the manual more often.  
Oh, and while most of the wonder boards are a real choice between the simpler A and more complex (yet still balanced) B side, at least one (Ephesus) is just flat-out better on the B side, and should never be played as A.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This may be my current favorite game --- looks overly complicated at first, but it's not.  My 6 year old has picked it up and can beat us if we're not paying attention!  Looking forward to getting the expansions soon.

RATING: 7
Simple, Elegant, and Strategic.  A game I can play with just about anyone and have a good time.  Very little down time between turns with the card drafting mechanic which is very nice particularly with an Analysis Paralysis player at the table.




=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's convenient that the game scales so well to player counts as high as 7, but the reason it can do it is because of a mostly solitary experience. I don't like draft-and-pass as the primary way of interacting in a game: denying one neighbor one card usually has a limited effect, a high opportunity cost, and is done in secret. Further, the learning curve is surprisingly steep. There are lots of icons for new players to learn. And to play strategically by knowing the odds of future cards coming your way, you really should know all the cards that are in all the decks at each player count. If you don't, early game choices may feel arbitrary, and late game choices may feel like straightforward selections of which cards give you the most VP in each disconnected turn. Sold my copy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Gyors játék 5 emberrel is, valszeg 7-el sem lehet lassúbb.
Amolyan Dixit a stratégia játékoknál: gyors, pörgős, ugyanakkor itt azért tervezni is kell, és előre látni. Nyilván a kártyák ismerete a játékot pozitív irányba befolyásolja, de ez együtt tanuláskor nem akkora baj. (Mármint, h tudod, h milyen kombók jöhetnek ki, mire érdemes figyelni).
Ugyanakkor az ára erős túlzás kategória, nem véletlen említettem a Dixitet: nagyjából annak ára lenne a reális érte.
Amúgy egy tökéletes játék, van egy party game érzete, pedig nem az - valszeg a sebesség miatt-, és ugyanakkor meg komoly tervezést, előre látást is igényel: mit vegyek ki ami nekem jó, de hagyjam-e bent azt, ami másnak viszont nagyon jól jön, stb.
Igazából a játék nálam 9-es lenne,(kategórián belül, abszolute nézve inkább 8) az ára vitte 8-asra.
Síelésre pl ideális lenne, ha vmi komolyabbra vágynánk, de mondjuk nem egy igaz gamers gamere.
Ugyanakkor a doboz is erős túlzásnak tűnik, kisebb is kényelmesebb lenne, de valszeg már a kiegekkel terveztek.
Amúgy kinézetre jó, minőségre jónak tűnik, és a játék izgalma is megvan, kérdés persze 30. játéknál is megvan-e ez. /Mondjuk amennyit én játszok 1 játékkal, ez nem igazán kérdés/indok/.
Update: Azért a kártyák minősége hagy kivetnivalót...A játékról: azért van benne szerencse adag rendesen, legalábbis kevésszer játszó játékosoknak biztos: jöhet rossz kártya sor folyamatosan, amivel nem tud mit kezdeni a játékos. Ami persze valószínűleg a kártyák ismeretével, és gyors terv váltással kiküszöbölhető.
Az általam eddig játszott 2010-es esseniek közül az egyik legjobb.
Az ár -hisz ez csak 1 kártya játék- ellenére megkapja a 9-est, majdnem :-)
Update x: szóval továbbra is kellemes játék, szerencse elég nagy, de gyors, és picit azért gondolkozós, és 7 fővel is max 1 óra...

The only down side I can see is that once people are very familiar with the game they may know exactly which cards to look for early on in the game giving them a clear advantage, but I don't know how much of an advantage. I'd love to see more cards but the way it plays right now is beautiful.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My number 1
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
My new nickname in my gaming circles is Zevin Wonders - short for Zevin wonders why this game was ever made.   That's not true actually, I do respect the game designers for making such a widely received 7 player game that can play in 30-45 minutes.  What just boggles my mind is why everyone likes it so much?  You have limited control over your strategies.  It's not a true drafting game in 5-7 players(which is the number of people who tend to gravitate towards this game b/c of the lack of game choices with that number) because you will never or rarely draft in anticipation of getting something back.  So there is almost always a best card to draft, little to no strategy in drafting something in one pack because you know it combos well with something in another, and in my experience, if you sit next to one or two pacifists, you have about a 99% better chance of winning the game.  Science is rarely viable except when coupled with the leaders expansion or as previously stated if you're next to some hippies that 1 age I warrior can bash into 18 points in your favor.  Some starting civs are significantly better than others.  This game basically comes down to one giant luck box.  All of which I would be totally okay with if EVERYONE didn't ALWAYS want to play this game.  There are 7 of us left at game night.  Me: "Let's play a 3 and a 4."  Others: "Well 7 Wonders plays   7." Me: "sigh..........."  If everyone else out there wasn't so damn enamored with this game I'd aptly give it a rating of a 7.  But thanks to the mindless zombie rending flesh craving this game triggers in otherwise sane individuals, I felt it my civic duty to all that is rational and just in this world to do my part to keep this game out of the top 10 BGG games.  Thus Zevin Wonders, you have a special place in my heart as the only game I've ever rated a 1!  Mazel Tov!   Addendum - I heard through the grapevine that 1 ratings may get thrown out as spam.  I cannot in good conscious let that happen, thus I shall reluctantly raise my 7 Wonders rating to a 5. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I love drafting. Drafting was my favorite way to play Magic back in the day. So that's a plus for me. After five plays I enjoy the game and I'd be happy to play it again, but I am not feeling so eager that I can't wait like I do with many games. I spent a lot of time during the games I played helping to teach others and not worrying a lot about exploring strategies for myself. The five plays I've had don't feel like enough to get a definite picture of how well I'll like the game in the long term. I am very interested in adding it to my collection because it is a good game with a short play time for 2-7 players. I believe I will enjoy it and it will be good for many of my gaming situations, but I'm not necessarily expecting it to become one of my personal all-time favorite games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Took me a long time to play this insanely popular game.  It's easy to see what makes this so appealing.  For one, it's super easy to learn but provides deep gameplay and difficult decisions.  There is just the right amount of player interaction for my tastes.  The best thing about it is that playtime isn't increased with player count so it plays 7 in the same time as 3.  Really cool and tough to pull off.  I also love that depending on which wonder you are constructing you get a unique player ability.  Really nice game all around.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
... this is such a poor game .. Solitaire, but without the fun .. NO interaction/NO tension/NO strategy--NONE -- why is it so highly rated ??? .. just because something is popular, does not mean it is good !! ... (my latest experience listed below) ... just shoot me billy ...

I was caught at TABS into a seven wonders match with seven chairs filled with seven people around a table surely seven foot square ...
... the person on my right nudged me and exclaimed .. 'HA ! my army is all powerful, and will run roughshod over you ! , here is minus one point!' ... and to the person on my left, I gently said , 'oh, I am so terribly sorry, but would you mind awfully much if I bought some wood from you please?' ...

... and the four other individuals across the vast expanse of tabletop, whom I could barely see ... where but in yonder galaxy a far far way away ... nary a shout, nary a wave, nary a nod, nary a wink .... same game . different universe .. I could but fairly be playing solo ....

... we seven, upon finishing seven wonders, embarked yet again, on another seven wonders quest -- and yet again --- galaxies apart, the four disappeared in their rocket ship spreading the word to far flung , as yet, unexplored, vast nether regions ...

... why were the gang of four present ?? why did I play seven wonders, not once, but twice, at the end of a long day in the Canadian legion with but two cups of tea and chips ??? ... upon wrapping the second seven wonders, we proceeded to stack chairs and put away tables -- it was later than late -- the four outer galaxians had returned -- we chatted aboot the moon ; the stars ; the space-ness of space -- the four ruminated upon wonders built ; armies crushed ; wood purchased ; leaders leading ; space conquered -- whilst I -- forlornly gathered my coat, my hat, my bag , and with lonely angst, retired to Bedlam .......

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
With four players game is fabulous.  With three or five players it's decent - there is a little too much to keep tabs on if you're not familiar with the cards. I found the game really horrible with 2 players (I recently played Among the Stars 2 player with a BGG user variant.  You could apply that to this game and I'd like the 2 player more) because the dummy player felt cumbersome. With 6 or 7 players, please refer to the rant below:

This is one of the most consistently silence inducing games I've ever played, except when people see that Altar card for the first time.  Other than that, gameplay usually takes on the atmosphere of a ghost town with chatter only resuming when it comes time to dole out victory points.

All the same, this game has enough sumpin' sumpin' to make me want to play it again.  It's just that every time the game ends I feel a little unsatisfied, a little bit hollow on the inside, like I just drank a zero calorie beverage that wasn't water (me being really bad at the game and not quite understanding it might be a factor here).  Seven people quietly sitting around a table looking at cards.  It's kind of like the museum of board games.  It's pretty to look at, but is it fun to play? 

This game is a wolf in sheep's clothing.  The gameplay itself is simple, but there's a lot going on with card distribution, card types, and how the cards relate to the wonders.  Or maybe it's actually a sheep in wolf's clothing.  At first glance it seems lean and fast, but when you consider how everything interlocks there's actually a ton of delicious fatty meat to chew on.  I think if I could break through the barrier this might be one of, if not my favorite game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.2

RATING: 6.5
initial rating after a few plays ... rating 6.5 - it feels like a 7.5 after initial playing, but rating goes down with successive plays.... likely will settle at a 6.

pros 

plays fast and has a feel of strategic planning
which will allow you to achieve a certain amount of success.

cons

only an illusion of control or strategy and you're play, aside from guessing what cards you will be passed to you, likely doesn't determine the outcome, especially if there is a weaker player at the table.

i'd rate this as a solid B - happy to play, but more of a fun activity then a game. will not purchase.

RATING: 8
Players draft a hand of cards and choose amongst cards for resources, set collection, trade bonuses, military focus, or cultural buildings. Three hands of cards and the game is over, making it a welcome addition to any game night. It can be difficult to explain the iconography to new players, but once it clicks, everyone seems to enjoy this. Cities and Leaders expansions add some specific strategies that players might otherwise not choose to adopt, which is welcomed. For a game that has short play time as a selling point, it always seems like I want it to last a bit longer.

30-60m, best with 3-5. 20+ plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This game fills a very unique niche: an easily explainable  card drafting game that scales beautifully from 3 - 7 players.  The game time doesn't even increase dramatically with a higher number of players due to the simultaneous nature of the game play.  Sounds great, right?  For a lot of people it is, the game is already rated 73 and it hasn't even become available for the general North American public.  For me, I just found it to be boring and too light for my tastes.  It's not even that I dislike 7 Wonders because I could easily play it if asked to by people.  I just don't consider it to be a game I want in my collection.  I wonder if it's the whole 'drafting is the game' that bothers me.  I'm not fussy on Fairy Tale or 7 Wonders but I love the optional card drafting in Gosu and Agricola.  I wish I could better articulate what aspect of the game makes me feel the way I do about the game, but I can't.  Oh well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

I can't tell if it's the most brilliant or overrated game I've played. Seems best with three or four. Any more and it's too much out of my control. One of my biggest problems with Puerto Rico is the whole kingmaker aspect of it. It's very present in this game, and probably worse, but at least it only takes 20-30 minutes.

RATING: 6
I could see my initial 9 rating dropping, but after one play, I can't stop obsessing about this game.  That hasn't happened to me in quite a few first time plays.

Yet another initially intimidating, but ultimately simple game.  Once you get through the rules, the game flows smoothly and quickly and you find yourself questoning why the rules explanation took so long in the first place.

Edit:  After several more plays, I really don't enjoy the take a card and pass style of drafting games.  It makes it near impossible to plan ahead and I want strategy, not tactics.  And given it's mostly tactical, it's not well enough balanced for that.  I'd play again at this point, but the mood will have to strike.  I can see the rating drop further.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
Engine building game with some interesting mechanics, including hand passing after every turn and multi-use cards. Suffers from weak theme integration and cumbersome two player rules. Dark, muddy art not to my taste. Tiny icons hard for 50 year old eyes, especially when they must be seen in another player's array across the table. As a two player game, rates a 5; with three, a 6.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Card drafting at its most pure. 7 Wonders does what it does well, but what it does is not particularly interesting. The interaction between neighboring civilization is great in theory, but is rarely strong enough to influence the decisions of players in a meaningful way. The game also feels abridged to a fault, preventing the game from fully embracing its epic scope. There are several different strategies to pursue, which gives the game longer legs than you might otherwise expect, and certainly lends to its popularity. Its certainly a fun game, especially at the medium player counts, but one that has been outdone over time. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game should be viewed as a filler, and with proper expectations, can be enjoyed for what it has to offer in about 30 minutes.  I love the angst produced from having multiple great cards to choose among or being forced to pass a card to your neighbor that they can greatly benefit from.  There are five ways to score significant points including military, civilian, scientific, guilds, & some of the player boards and I've seen wins with heavy specialization or diversification.  What path one chooses is strongly tactical so flexibility is a must.

RATING: 9
This is a great Multi-player game. There are enough winning conditions so that different paths can be engaged by different players in the same game. The card drafting keeps everyone on their toes, and situationally aware. If you blink, you will miss what your neighbors are doing and could lose the game. The only drawback to this game is that you need a really big table for laying out all the cards and pieces in a 4+ player game.

RATING: 8
Bonus pro
--Very easy to get to the table due to being a good support for 2-7 players to get a quick play.


Pros
--Works very well with any applicable player count
--RELATIVELY easy to explain and get an attentive group of non-gamers playing
--Always ends with the sense of accomplishment, whether or not the scoring went well

Cons
--Feels moderately random due to limited strategy options
--Can feel samey after repeated plays
--Not terribly interactive

Overall my satisfaction has waned up and down on this game, where currently it's on a high.  Not a terribly deep game, but, it's great depth for "family game night" and is a very solid filler otherwise.

RATING: 6
A solid light drafting game that will seemingly scale really well. There's probably more interaction than your standard engine building card game, and more importantly the interaction is more accessable than Glory to Rome or Race. Overall, I thought the game was pretty good, and I see this title having potiential in my group for a go to game for 5+ players. I'm looking forward to future plays. 

60 Plays in and I think I'm done with this title. It's a little too random for my tastes. The expansion definately increased my willingness to move on. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I loved the Draft-Mechanic in MtG, and I love it in 7 Wonders. Its a great little game that can be explained and played very fast. Sometimes the choice of which card to take card is obvious, but most of the time you really have a tough decision to make. Do I deny my opponent a good card? Do I need money? Do I want to advance my wonder? Do I want to specialize on a certain card type, or scatter the chances over all colors? I also like the choice between different starting-wonders and the great card artwork and the symbols that are easy to read and understand. The only minor letdown is the quality of the cards, but I double-sleeved them, so I don't really care about wear and tear.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I can see why this has been such a big hit in 2010. So-called "Civ-themed", plays fast (even with a large group) and interesting tactical decisions to make with (apparently) multiple paths of victory. What I like is that it's not a multi-player solitaire. There's ample interaction with your neighbours and not just through the card-drafting.

But hype is probably just that - hype. The Civ theme is pasted on. It's at heart a "get production then convert to VP" game using a card-drafting mechanism. Which is not to say the game is uninteresting, but the theme could have been anything. If you're looking for a deep Civ theme, this is the wrong game. 

It's also not a very strategic game. Decisions you make are largely tactical (some may say "forced"). There's a lot of "going with the flow". And I'm not sure about the multiple paths to VP thing. Seems like you must go for the green cards to have a shot of winning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This one is pretty much a classic. Many non-gamers have already played it and so it's a great transition game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Card drafting is one of my favorite mechanics and it's executed very well in this title. The hype for this game is well deserved for how well the game scales and for the multiple paths to victory. It's not a filler, but it's not a civilization builder either. The iconography presents a small learning curve for gamers, but a large learning curve for casual gamers. The end game scoring can also be cumbersome at first. It only takes two or three games to get completely over the learning curve but it's there. Your first few games will be fairly random as you're not sure which cards are the most valuable at the time.

I don't play it enough to warrant getting the expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
A very enjoyable game. All its mechanics interact nicely, there are many paths to victory (which is something rare for a game this light) and the fact that all players play at the same time reduces the downtime to a minimum, for a reasonably short game. Great for introducing people to the gaming world. I've played it dozen of times before finally getting tired of it, but I've heard that the expansion takes care of that.
Be careful though with the unwilling king-making: science victory will always win if no one tries to stop it.

RATING: 7.5

I haven't played this one for a long time and it is probably having to go over the iconography again that is the main hurdle to playing again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It’s a reasonably good game that came on strong for me but subsequently faded a good bit. The gameplay itself is good – choose one card from a hand given to you and pass the rest to the left. The choices are simple but very tough – to build infrastructure or military or science or just score points? That the game scales well up to 7 people is another plus.

But after several plays of it, the game started to feel samey and the experience stale. The game is simply not that deep after all. A lot of the time you’re guessing, not playing strategically, and the decisions get less interesting as the game goes on, not more. By the last round you’re locked into a strategy and just hoping cards that you need show up. 

It’s OK on occasion for a large group, but when I saw them starting to make expansions, I knew I was out. This is the kind of game that does get samey and does need expansions to liven it up, and I don’t think it’s worth it to chase them. Moved it on and don’t regret it.

- the agonizing decisions to make with drafting
- the two-player expert variant adding much more strategy
- being able to civ-build in half an hour

I dislike:

- that the cards are black-bordered(?!?)

Final verdict: Quick civ-builder that plays simply but deeply.

Sleeves: Arcane Tinmen
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A true classic, and one of the few games that both unexperienced and hardcore gamers can enjoy. Quick to play, but with great depth of strategy and a number of ways to victory. The expansions add replay value to a game that already has plenty. If you call yourself a gamer, you must own 7 Wonders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
7 Wonders is a very engaging game that offers many scoring paths and ways to get points.  The ability to purchase and sometimes use your neighbors resources and abilities is quite creative.  At the same time, it is not terrible confrontational: the battle system is just one of the many ways to score points, and the victims aren't crippled by losing and still can even have a chance to win.

What frustrates me is the difficulty with developing a long term strategy.  The cards come as they may, and it seems that you have to build what you can as it comes along.  Sometimes the card flow fits in with your plans, and sometimes not.

The two player "Free City" variant is interesting and almost feels like a different game, seemingly more strategic with many more opportunities to mess with you opponent when controlling the free cities.  

In the end, 7 Wonders is quite a brilliant game.  It's best attribute I think is that it plays well with any number and because of the mechanics, doesn't suffer any increase in downtime as the number of players increases.  It is also one the very few games that is playable, and plays well, with that dreaded number of 7.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
After just one game, I had to say I didn't understand what the fuzz is all about. New mechanics, though. I guess the expectations were too high. However, after a number of games, I must say it's almost the perfect family+ game. There are so many strategies to go for, and it's always hard to know which card to pick. The interaction between the players are really great, both when it comes to the military power and resources. The game scales so well. You only need to concentrate on your neighbouring players, except for with the sciences. I love the war fight in this game. The only minus point in this game is a couple of (maybe) unecessary rules when it comes to the names/titles of the cards.

This is the best gamer game you're going to find for 7 players.

RATING: 7
A really solid drafting game, 7 Wonders is reasonably fun, but kind of a bear to teach.  I have most of the expansion content for it, but frankly find myself not using it, even when we have it in play (ie Babel tiles that never get chosen).  I actually appreciate how much theme is put into subtle things - like the Great Wall of China having its name in Chinese characters, and giving you a military boost for using a lot of stone.  Still, it's not a game that I [i]love[/i], and when I'm playing at the higher player counts where 7 Wonders really made its name, I'm more likely to tend towards party games.

Like Puerto Rico, this is another game where I actually prefer the 2p variant.  The ability to "hate draft" using the dummy player adds a layer of strategy and interaction that can often be missing from the higher-player-count game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I once played this 6 games in a row, and it still didn't get old - there are always new tricks to try (and I really sohuld stop the pure science strategies)

RATING: 8
Wanted to hate this game but recently played it and it's a fine game. I'd say it's largely solitaire with minor interaction via the draft and goods commerce with your immediate neighbors. Seems like it should be a mess but it is surprisingly not. Once players are familiar with the basic game it seems like most games will be pretty close.

Since it plays so quickly you pretty much have to hope for the best in some regards because you can't always count on getting what you need. Maybe some long-range plan will work out but more likely you'll need to be flexible and make the best of what comes along. Fortunately, it seems like the game offers enough opportunities to make a decent go of any hand. And before you can curse your luck it's over.

RATING: 9.5
Unbelievably great fun and depth for the time it plays in.  Lots of replayability!

7 Wonders + Leaders + Cities + 5-7 players = Awesome!

The Leaders expansion works even better with the debt aspect of Cities which makes for a terrific experience.  Combining both expansions makes money more tight by giving players the opportunity to buy one leader card each Era.  When used in conjunction with *both* expansions, it makes the debt aspect even more powerful as it affects more players - and when it does it's quite brutal!  More players also means more opportunity for debt events and other things to mess with you.  Great stuff, and amazing the depth that can still be played in about 45-50 minutes of playtime!  Grade: A+

7 Wonders by itself (no expansions) = 9/10 (still an "A" because it plays well under 1 hr.).

RATING: 8
Similar to RFTG, with the simultaneous plays, and very similar phases and goals, but a much more approachable and new player-friendly mentality.

While the focus is still on strategy, there's less of a luck of the draw element, and more of a, gauge the other players to determine your strategy component.

First play may take a while longer than the estimated game time, but the game moves far more quickly when all players are experienced.

RATING: 8
Crafty game with a lot of moving parts. With many paths to victory, a good player must find what benefits him the most while hindering others. I love this deep and subtle aspect of the game. While experience does offer some advantage, nothing is guaranteed strategy-wise, making the game sometimes feel a little chaotic or random. 7 Wonders is easy to pick up and scales well (so far, from 2-4). 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Only played it once, 2-player. It was fast, fluid and fun. I understand why it has had so much success. I'd happily play it again, especially with more players, but my kids were too young and I didn't see ever getting my copy to the table so gave it to my brother's family.

Update: Having inherited another copy, I've played it a couple more times still as a 2-player game. I love Duel, but I still don't (yet?) see why people dislike the 2-player variant. A game of 7 Wonders can be played so quickly, with interesting and agonizing choices and a breezily fun theme, I respect this design more with every play. I can see how it might benefit from expansions after a reasonable number of plays but then – hey – expansions there are and apparently they're great! My 8-year-old has now played this and adopted it, and I can see it hitting the table relatively often. Huzzah!

RATING: 8
Fills a niche: a "dessert" intellectual game, perfect for that last half hour of a long gaming session where the players are too tired for another brain burner but also not in the mood for a pure fun filler like King of Tokyo. 7W may be the simplest game I know that offers interesting, and sometimes agonizing, choices every single turn. It supports more players than my gaming table does and the beautiful artwork does not hurt. After a dozen plays, I suspect that the dominant strategy is to spread investment on all civilization dimensions; specialization is a losing one. The Leaders expansion may mitigate that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Rating history: 9..8..9,8,9...|8

DEC/11 RATE:9 Played this with 6 people and was completely taken with it. It's not really a civ game, it's a set collecting game that uses drafting, but I like drafting games, and this is more fun for me than Fairy Tale.

DEC/12 RATE:8 Just received this is a trade and played 2 players. It didn't quite have the magic. But I was tired and cranky, so maybe that affected my enjoyment. Or maybe the 2-player game is just not as magical.

DEC/12 RATE:9 I now think the 2-players game is amazing. The additional layers of trying to withhold from your opponent and supply the "fake" players with resources you can buy inexpensive all works very well.

20 plays in: 8. Still solid, but obviously most plays are like other plays. I prefer it with Leaders expansion. (Oh, and forget everything I said about it being a good 2p game. There are so many other, better 2p games.) JUN/15.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Another interesting card game which begins a genera.  I find it interesting that you interact with people only adjacent to you, yet you are trying to get the best score of all the players.  
     None of the games have lasted over 30 minutes.  Graphics are nice and colorful.  It feels like a well thought out and tested game.
     Another game that lends itself to expansions, I am sure.
     Although I have read that some feel it has similarities to Dominion or Race for the Galaxy, I don't agree.  Yes, they are all card games, and you are building something, and the most victory pts. wins the game, but the mechanics on all 3 games are so different.  I own all 3, love all 3, and could play all 3 back to back and not feel redundant.

RATING: 8
Received as a gift in a local Secret Santa exchange. Thanks! Very cool and original, and I can see how it could be highly addictive. My wife likes it too! If only we'd discovered it before we became parents, it probably would have become our latest "go-to" game, alongside Carcassonne, Ticket To Ride, Kingsburg, etc. I've had some other successes introducing it to new players: it's incredibly easy to teach.

If you're an iPhone/iPad user, I strongly suggest the 7 Wonders Companion app: it's a lifesaver during scoring. There's an Android app too, but the iPad app is nicer and gives you another Wonder to play with.

RATING: 9.5
7 Wonders 七大奇蹟 3-7(4)
After 20 plays of 7 Wonders, with expansion Leaders and Cities, I still crave for more opportunity to play. With Leaders, it adds a nice layer of strategy to the already-thinky game. With Cities, it adds more interaction between players. I was very fond of this game right out of the bat at the first play. Though my group of friends had shut it off completely with distaste. Over the years, me and one other had persisted and insisted to play 7 Wonders despite their mockery with numerous tries, and eventually we prevailed! We have changed their perception with time and shown them how good 7 Wonders is. I appreciate the design of the game a lot; in particular it is probably the only game that can accompany large group and be finished under and hour with right dose of complexity and weight.
+Variable setup
+Great art/theme
+Card drafting extravaganza

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One of my first exposures to card drafting games

Pros
-Plays quickly (30 minutes)
-A few paths to victory
-Player interaction
-Drafting is fun
-Different civilization powers (each civilization also has an alternate set of powers) - seems to be they are all very balanced
-Game scales with number of players well (you have to add or remove specific cards)

Cons
-Player interaction only occurs with players on your left and right (an issue when there are many players)
-How well you do depends on the people to your sides
-Need to keep track of what resources people have (minor)
-Fine line on balance of power when there are few players
-Difficult to explain how to pay for building to non-gamers (resources are not income and refresh each turn instead of being consumed)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast card-development game that takes up to 7 players; the art looks amazing. The interaction could be strategic rather than tactical, but I can't say for now.

I've been suspicious of the massive hype, and "but it's fun!" responses to criticisms of shallowness and lack of replayability. I really enjoyed my first several plays of the game but have cooled somewhat.

Race for the Galaxy has far more depth in the same playtime; Dominion has more variety. 7 Wonders seems to repeat the same scoring methods each game, just with different balances.

Despite having the promo, I'm of two minds about actually getting the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Good game from time to time. Good replayability and artwork.

A lot of options and dilemma when choosing a card :
- should i open the game with that resource ?
- should i go for military to anticipate the end of the turn ?
- should i let myself collecting scientific buildings ?
- should i put in my tableau this huge 8 points civil building ?
- should i discard this card or build my wonder to prevent my neighbor to take it next turn ?

The choice must be made by paying attention to your opponents.

Still trying to find a strategy but it seems very difficult as it depends upon the number of players and indeed of your wonder.

However, I have two complaints :
1/ it isn't a civilization game as it is written almost everywhere
2/ you don't feel yourself building a wonder

EDIT : want to try 5 players configuration. Until now, for me, 4 players configuration is the best one.

EDIT : do not want to play it with more than 4 players (less control)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Un juegazo que ventilas en 30 minutos + o -, pero que en ningún momento te da la sensacion de ser un filler, sino un juego con importantes decisiones tácticas. Se puede jugar bien desde 3 a 8 jugadores (con la expansión), presentando según el número distintas sensaciones, cuantos menos más control, cuantos más el caos se hace patente.
La interaccion entre jugadores es limitada, si bien siempre puedes "perjudicar" a alguno con tus acciones, o beneficiarte de sus recursos o construcciones.
En fin, buen juego, muy adictivo y felizmente poca duración lo que te permite encadenar varias partidas pudiendo hacer un "minitorneo".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.85

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Talking about card games, I preffer, deeper games as Race for the Galaxy, for example.
In the other hand, 7W is a light, fast paced and funny game! The people that I've taught this game always say they liked it a lot.
About it's components, I'd like to mention that are very mediocre (specially talking about the quality of the cards), but despite that, I think 7W is very recommendable to play with family, non-gamer friends and for short game sessions.
Finally, I'd like to say that IMO 7W is over rated in the BGG's boardgames rank.
So... not the best, but not too bad; not too complex, but fast paced and funny... Certainly you geeks will hate or love it. No middle ground!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A civilization filler card game. Gameplay is rather simple, certainly much more so than, say, Race for the Galaxy or even Dominion. You receive 7 cards, choose one of them to play, and pass the rest on to the next player. Cards provide resources or money which allow building more advanced cards, or victory points right away.

There is a little bit of strategy in the card drafting with fewer players, but with more, it becomes entirely tactical. It's going to be interesting to see if the game can hold up with further plays. It is, however, a little too simple for its own good and doesn't offer enough diversity to be steadily engaging.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Multi-solitaire, it's not original at all and allows easily mistakes and cheatings.

RATING: 9
Very nice, easy game.
Pro: with every player-card you have to play differently (different powers), that makes it more changeable and entertaining. Nice card drafting system which allows the game to get harder as the players improve. different ways to win.
Con: you will have to play a few times to consider all factors, cards still in play and other players movements. But that is also a pro of this game.
You don't know who wins until the very end, that's something I particularly don't like at games.

RATING: 8
This is a nice mix of strategic choices and ad-hoc decisions. The different boards aren't perfectly balanced but it is good enough to enjoy the game and have a real chance of winning. You have to find a way to maximize your points but also have an eye on your neighbours. Sometimes it is more important to deny them a card than to play a certain card you want.
The game scales quite well with up to 7 players without adding much downtime. I like it a bit more with 3-4 players as you see most hands twice and can plan ahead what propably will come back to you.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good production values: cards are fine; cardboard chips, battle victory tokens and player's wonder boards are good quality.  The art is good, nothing mindblowing, but solid.
The design of the game is good and clever. It doesn't feel very thematic, because you focus more on resource management, getting victory points and hate drafting, but still, you are building a city/civilization on your board, so the mechanics match the theme just fine.
Gameplay is fast (45 min per game), with some good tactical decisions to be made, but not a lot of strategy. Knowledge of the cards and resource management is key here. It's not a gateway game, because for a non gamer there is a lot of stuff to keep track of (what resources do I have, which ones do I need, what buildings can I buy for free, how to score points, how to use science cards, how to limit the points of my neighbours, etc.), but it's not a difficult game to explain, understand or play, just really difficult to win if you don't have the experience. A new player will need some plays (from 2 to 5 probably) before he or she can roll by themselves. It's a really good second step game, with a little more depth to it, but still fairly easy.
To sum up, the game is fun, not complex, but with different options, difficult choices and good replayability because of variable powers of the wonders and number of different cards. And finally, it scales really well, up to seven players!

RATING: 8.5
Excellent jeu! Facile et stratégique! On commence avec un paquet de carte, en choisit une puis le donne au prochain joueur. + extension Leaders
Rajoute les leaders, un round de draft qui donne une direction intéressante à la partie! Rend le tout beaucoup plus intéressant. +1 Merveille

+ extension Cités
Rajoute des cartes cités noir, rendant l'argent beaucoup plus important. Permet de jouer jusqu'à 8. +2 merveilles

RATING: 9
Received two copies, one from Game Surplus and the other from CoolStuff on December 13, 2010. A third copy from Thought Hammer arrived on December 14, 2010 (which I sold to a friend).
2/16/11 - 22 plays later I rated it: 9.5 . Not quite yet ready to give it a 10 but I do think this one will ultimately be the most played game I own. Excellent filler. Best game I've found for my family. A great lunch-time game. It moves quickly, no down time, scales from 2-7, offers just enough decision-making to keep in interesting, but not so much that AP sets in. It's fun to play. If luck enters in, then it is light enough and quick enough that no one gets bent out of shape.
Why not rate it a "10." If it has staying power, and if it were a tiny bit more strategic, there would be no doubt.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a great game that works well with 4, but gets better the more players. It can be played with the family and is not too difficult to teach and learn. There is a good variety of strategies to win and the puzzle to get as many points as possible is very interesting. I do wish the game had a little bit more interaction as you are very focused on your own cards and then a little on your neighbors, but still this is a great game.

-Leaders: I like the Leaders expansion as it gives you a few more important choices to make over the course of the game.
-Cities
-Babel: Have only used the great projects yet, which was an interesting addition. Will have to play this more.

RATING: 9
7 Wonders is a real interesting card game and takes a different approach to set collection mechanics that I highly enjoy.  It is easy to understand, fast to play and it is really helped along by the almost simultaneous game play that can happen.  It readily supports between 3-7 players. The artwork is beautiful. The card drafting mechanic is solid and feels unlike other games. 7 Wonders is a statement of gaming and a prime example of how great a card game can be.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
7 wonders definitely has it's fans but I am not one.  This game is highly one dimensional, and it's one dimension is usually a small part of other games - drafting. 

Not to say you can't strip something down to it's bare essentials and have a pure and strong game, but 7 Wonders isn't that game. In fact I find the game highly suspect after a few plays.  It seems players not knowing the nuances of the game have just as much chance to win as others do.  

Recently I played a game after long hiatus, and had forgotten what most cards did.  I played against 4 other strong players (who have played this game alot) and to my amazement, after playing rather ho-humly , I won by a country mile.

Designs like this are the equivalent to chewing on a cloud.  Harmless and tasteless and not very filling.

Save the hype for a better game!

RATING: 9
I saw a meme that summed up 7 Wonders perfectly, it said:

Round 1:  What am I doing?
Round 2:  Why are we going the other direction?
Round 3:  I'm confused.
Scoring:  Oh!  I get it!  Let's play again!

This game is a good, mildly vicious, game.  It's one that is great if you have limited game time (45 minutes or less) or you just want a quick game before long games.  Simple play; pick a card to take or buy each pass through three rounds.  Complicated scoring (have someone good at math!).

Great to play when you're 7 people. Few games manage this trick. Works like a treat for 4 players and up. Simple mechanics, good variety on replay, good level of challenge and no downtime as everyone plays their turns simultaneously. Could have wished for more variety in the starting city and tracking points is near impossible until the very end. Still highly recommended!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonder is a great card-drafting game. In its favour is the number of players it supports, the accessible theme and the short play time. The downsides are the amount of table space needed which can become quite significant with a lot of players.

RATING: 3.2
Game with 7 players devolved into a collection of independent, simultaneous, local games between your neighbors.  The best player has no way to "bubble out" of such a scheme, being trapped as a local maximum.  Moreover, the gameplay itself was not immediately obvious as a first-time player, biasing greatly toward those who are more familiar with the rules.  The gameplay is alright for a large group of people, but not really that much fun (and with more people, turns into independent games as noted above).

RATING: 7.5
Not entirely sure yet. The art is beautiful, but the components are pretty poor. The price is high, considering what you get for less, also from Asmodee, in games like Claustrophobia.
The game play is definitely more interesting than Fairy Tale, but takes longer. And I have yet to see how much it boils down to solitaire, since blocking seems more difficult than Fairy Tale (where you can discard 2 of your 5 cards).
I still want to play with fewer players. I imagine there is more strategy involved when you are able to see cards passed to others again when they come around a second time.

UPDATE - I've enjoyed this much more in my recent plays. The components in the new edition are stellar (love that my card sleeves fit!), and we've been enjoying the 2-player variant quite a bit.

RATING: 10
Acquired December 2010 

October 2011 - Our family group has really enjoyed this game during the past year. It has quickly become one of my favorite games, and I expect we will play it for many years to come. The fact that it plays in a short time frame, with up to seven players, makes this ideal for us. It is an outstanding design, and must have been extensively play-tested before publication.

November 2012 -- This is still an amazing game, to me. I would enjoy playing it more often, because I tend to forget the best tactics between game times. Maybe we will get it out more this coming year.

2013-November:  I have enjoyed this game every time I've played, although I have seldom won it.  It's just a great game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A light worker placement civilization building card game - what more could you want. You have just 3 lots of 6 turns to select (draft) a card from an ever shrinking hand of cards with which to gain resources, buildings, and VPs. Each turn you select and action one card and then pass the remainding cards of that hand to the player on your left and recieve the remaining cards of another hand of cards from the player on your right - I think I'm feeling dizzy. No direct player interaction but you must be conscious of what the other players are doing in order to avoid passing on a card that could profit them to much. Scales brilliantly for up to 7 players - it is mostly multi-player solitare! Components/art are good but not outstanding.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Best feature is how well it scales for multiple players as everyone takes turns simultaneously.

Simple basic mechanic of drafting 1 card from hand...and passing on hand. Card has a primary use but also two other possible uses which increases the options and thus choices.

Helps to know something about how cards change in each age else can get somewhat stuck later...but easy to tell new players about that.  In essence the first round (age) is about building your production engine, whilst the last age is about scoring victory points - with middle round being a mix.

Nice that there are several viable strategies (i.e. different paths you can choose to get VPs), with decision of what card to draft providing the tactics.

Interaction is important, is with your neighbours and is generally indirect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not quite sure what the fuss is all about, really.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is LOADS of fun. I love the drafting mechanic. Some decisions are easy; others are excruciating. I'm not sure if the rating will come down with repeated play - I think I've only got 3 or 4 games under my belt - but until then this is a well-deserved 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

I typically loathe games where I can't do anything truly useful during my move (see Catan), but I'm still intrigued by the many paths to victory players usually have. At least this one doesn't overstay its welcome like epic games of punishment such as Eclipse.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I heard a lot of buzz about this game, and I must say I was very dissapointed. Not only was it extremely light, but it was quite boring. How is this any better than other card games out there. RftG, Innovation, Thunderstone, Dominion are all more enjoyable than this. I have become very skeptical of new card games at this point, and this is exactly why. The only innovative mechanic is passing cards to other players after a play, but it usually results in minor strategic decisions. I also very much disliked the placement of information. Cards stacking on cards makes it difficult to read what each building is, and if you splay them, each players board takes up a huge amount of area. Won't play again unless there is little to no choice and I'm bored.

RATING: 10
One of my group's favorites. Quick to play once everyone knows the iconography. Fairly easy for BG novices to learn. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The more I play the more I love it.  Fits most types of gamers.  My wife loves conflict and is more of an ameritrasg fan, where as I am more of a euro guy, and we both love it.  For the conflict players you can build a whole game plan designed to grab a variety if cards while actively selling off or building wonders with what other people are building around, while the euro gamer can at the same time play their hand without looking at anyone else, and both can be very successful.  At first glance and after the first game or do you may think the game isn't very deep, yet somehow everyone I've taught it to had told me that after a night of playing it they woke up that night thinking of strategies and ways to play out their wonders.  Great game!

RATING: 8.5
Very nice game, plays fast but still manage to offer you interesting choices. Not sure how well it plays with 2 players.

You draft cards while playing one each turn, using resources that you and your neighbours produce.

It's incredible how much the game is influenced by other players' choices: you only interact with people on your left and your right, but (without direct conflict) you have to take in account their choices.

Distrust expansions: just like many other simple and fast games, it does not need it. It has replayability enough and does not need the elongating addition of leaders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fantastic short game, I also own Mannenken Pis, Catan Island and Leaders expansions. A really nice filler and along with Carcassonne my only entry level game. In my book Seven Wonders is a tad above Carcassonne although both are just excellent little games. Only drawback is the quality of the deck, but this can be solved with special sleeves. Fast, funny, easy to grasp, and very recomendable for beginners but very funny for gamers too, an instant hit and a classic. Deserved hype, two thumbs up for this wonder of the boardgame world.

RATING: 7
My husband and I like 7 Wonders and rate it a 7, but I don't think that it will become a favorite 2-player game for us. Although the free city (dummy) mechanism works well, it slows things down because the players take turns selecting and playing a card for the free city. This means that one player's turn tends to take twice as long as the other's, and the added downtime in a game that is designed to have no downtime at all dampens the fun a bit. Still, we enjoy exploring various strategies and seeing their results, and we are glad we have this game in our collection.

RATING: 7
Great game with excellent aesthetics and theme.

Pros:
+ Impressive artwork,
+ Well made smooth mechanics,
+ Game has very short play time - half an hour or maybe less (if players know rules well),
+ The game is strategic and interactive - players are quite dependent on other players actions, however game itself has low random chance.

Cons:
- Replay value is not very high, however, if you are playing game quite rare and not many times in row, replay value is still decent and you get some new experience in game,
- Resource cards are meant to be put under Wonder's board,  but it's not very convenient to do that,
- If you want to play game many times or very often, you will probably need expansions, because it will be not enough variety and replay value with just base pack.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders may just be the most versatile game in my collection. It's easy to play, only lasts about a half an hour, and scales equally well from 2 to 7 players. That's a valuable game that slides neatly into a lot of different situations.

There just aren't many games for six or seven players that play as smoothly and effortlessly as this. It works so well because you really only need to pay attention to your immediate left and right neighbors. Because of its facility at handling a large table of players, I think a lot of gamers mostly play 7 Wonders at the upper end of its player scale. But if you've never tried it with just two or three players, you should!

At the lower player scale, there's more opportunity for planning and more ability to steal valuable cards from your opponent. Getting passed each deck multiple times definitely adds some meat to the game. The two-player version is the meatiest of all. With two, both players alternately control a neutral third player. You'll want to use the dummy player to help yourself and screw your opponent - which proves to be a lot harder than it sounds.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
7 Wonders never gets old, with or without the expansions. The drafting mechanic is absolutely great, turns are short, fast and furious. The fact that cards are revealed simultaneously significantly shortens the time it takes to play the game. This does not limit the multiple strategic options you have. I personally tend to go for a technology victory, but since my friends now this I like surprising them once in a while. While in essence you are playing cards, the beautiful board and cards make me really think that I'm building an empire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played 20 times or so. I feel like I'm against the trend here but this game feels a little too light for me. It's certainly playable and fun...I just find myself wanting more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The reviews are generally good. Card drafting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is all about "drafting." If you don't know what that is, then think of a large family gathered around the dinner table. 
Dad takes a plate of assorted meats, and picks out the particular cut he wants. He then passes the plate to mother, who does the same, but when it reaches the third or fourth family member, most of the best cuts are gone, or the specific favorite you were looking for is already sitting on brother Biff's plate. 
And Biff,that sniveling but-monkey, will use his prime cut of beef to wage bloody war against you, costing you precious victory points. Maybe you sister took all of the "science" meat that you were trying to accumulate, or you took that one slice of baloney, not because you wanted it, but because you know cousin Freddy desperately wants it, and there's no way you're going to let him have all the baloney, so he can make a sandwich later; a sandwich that lets him get another slice of baloney for free on the next turn.
That's drafting, and that's 7 wonders.
It hangs onto it's civilization building theme about as well as Dominion does - and that means, not very well. You never feel like your actually "building" something. You're just trying to get the right cards to maximize your points, and maybe denying cards to the person on your right or left, depending on which way the card draft is moving.
If you've ever played a game with drafting mechanics, it's probably due to this game, which is the best example of the mechanic, but, it's also the WORST example because it demonstrates how luck-centered drafting games are. It all depends on the draw of cards, and your luck of being on the receiving end of someone else's inattention. 
After all rounds are played, it may be difficult to tell who won, but's it's always easy to tell who LOST. Because when you lose, you usually lose big, and that would be okay if the game had some fun built into it. 
It doesn't.
And the process of determining the winner involves so many calculations and conditions. The game just ends, with a big deafening thud of Math hitting the table.
I know some people who really love this game, and have all the expansions. I get the "game" part of it, and it all functions and works very well, but it just isn't fun, at least, not for me.
It's more like an intellectual exercise pretending to be a game, that isn't very intellectually exact, due to the luck involved.
Those who are good at 7 Wonders, are very good, and they will win again and again, and want to play it again and again, while the rest of us have moved on to things like Ticket to Ride or Shadows over Camelot - games that are actually FUN.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Surprised I've played this as much as I have, considering my poor opinion of it initially. I'm a big fan of Fairy Tale, and I've often felt that this was a bloated version of that. 

However, my opinion changed as I got to play it more. There is reason for the love. Drafting is fun. Always will be. The choices here can be tough. I don't love the military "cold war". And I don't love the need to collectively stop the player going for science. But the Wonder system is wonderful. I love how building your wonder gives you meaningful ways to trash a card an opponent may want. 

I will never own a copy. Everyone else does. But I'm happy to play it from time to time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A civilization themed game where you each round pick a card depicting a building which you either build, use for money or use to build you wonder. The rest of the cards are then passed to you neighbor.

What makes this game special is that it is a game that plays up to seven players in a short amount of time and yet feels more of a game than most of the fillers. Besides that, it is a polished and slick design. I am a little addicted to the drafting where you pass the card and the balance between making a good move for yourself and passing a great card to your opponent. The game is almost purely tactical, because even though you can have a plan on what you want to do in your game oftentimes the cards that are passed on dictates how well you are going to do. What you can do is to mitigate the risks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Im my opinion - enjoyable for 1 maybe 2 times. I love every card game - but this one is boring :(

RATING: 5.2
7 Wonders always leaves me flat and I don't see how the game gets as high of a rating as it does here. No matter what strategy I pick (military, science, point cards, etc.), I never feel as if my strategy is "working". You never find out if you have won until the very end. The last time I played, the winner had 47 points while the worst player in a four player game had 40. You never feel as if you are separating yourself throughout the ages. Is that good balance? I guess, but it doesn't resonate for me. This game rarely hits the table, although it is a nice palate cleanser in between meatier gaming sessions.

RATING: 7.5
This is the first game I bought when I started to get into board games. I have about 5 or 6 plays on the game from before I knew about BGG and the play tracking so I have played a bit more than it says.

I really like this game because the drafting mechanic is one I am familiar with from MTG, and I really liked the theme because I am a big fan of games like Civilization and Rise of Nations. I like how there are a bunch of different ways that you can win the game. Another feature I liked is that you can only interact with your two neighbors, so if you are in a game with 4 or more people you aren't able to directly effect some of the players in the game.

I want to get more play with this game and I am looking at expanding it in the future after I get some more play out of the base game.

RATING: 8
I like civilisation building but don't have the time, or the geeks, to play Advanced Civilisation or 7Ages these days. 7 Wonders is nicely reductionist; some of the flavour of a good civ game (trading, developing technology, military considerations, building cities and wonders) but with 0% fat.  Negotiation, diplomacy and geo-political manoeuvring, are elements that I would not usually sacrifice, but then this is an aromatic light bite rather than a 6 hour banquet.

RATING: 10
There is a good reason this is the top ranked family game. The best aspects of this game is that it is quick to set up and can be played in 30-40 minutes.  It is easy to learn but has enough strategy to make it interesting. And anyone can win.
I think it is best with 4 or more players.  With 3 players all resources are available to all players, some at a price of course.  
When my family received Settlers of Catan, we quickly bought all of the expansions and played very often.  This has now occurred with 7 Wonders as well as we play very often.
Virtually all of my Plays shown are using both Leaders and Cities as well as the extra boards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Though it's not the most amazing board game ever, 7 Wonders does have a few very key qualities that make it great: length, depth and number of players.  2-7 people can play a comfortably complex game in less than 45 minutes with little to no downtime for everyone involved since players all act simultaneously.  The civ building theme is completely pasted on though, so it's hard to feel like you're actually building something, not just making optimal card choices for points.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's fun, but probably better with more than 3 players that I use to play it with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
good game... for about the ten first games, after that you get bored since it's mostly the same thing over and over again. Images are nice too... I wouldn't buy the game, but it wouldn't bother me to play it once or twice a year. I prefer deep replayable games like agricola, Arkham Horror, Eldritch Horror, Tales of Arabian Nights, or card games better made like Seasons, magic the gathering, Testament of Duke de Crecy, etc. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
7 Wonders is both fast and light, but is facetted enough to open many avenues to follow on the path to victory. There is not a lot of deep strategy going on, since all the decisions have to be taken on the spot, and the different paths to victory remain rather intractable right up until the end. It is a very tactical game with a big element of luck ("the unexpected") involved. This game is repeatedly being faced with sets of options to choose from and trying to figure out which one will help bring together everything in the end.

I like the way the theme is implemented both in game art and in the rules. As far as the latter is concerned, I  specifically like that there are so many different paths to obtain victory points, and that some of the choices one can make later reconnect to other choices. Certainly, there are much more invovled civilisation bulding games that are much better in the simulation aspect, but none are as fast, as rich in choices and as colourful. This game has a very particular flair, which makes it very attrctive. 

I mostly play this with two or three players, because then the game acquires an additional strategic element, which adds quite a bit of depth. The only thing that would keep me from recommending 7 Wonders unreservedly is the fact that you don't get a lot of material for your money.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The game's simplicity belies the strategies and decisions that are present.  Players must make decisions as to which cards they seek to construct, realizing that by concentrating on a few categories they will likely be forced to neglect other categories, most likely to their detriment.  Further, this decision is influenced by the strategies being pursued by one's neighbors.  It is also wise to keep an eye on what resources your neighbors are producing -- and what they are not producing -- so you can plan accordingly.  

Choosing which card to keep can be tough, as there are usually multiple cards that are beneficial and fit your strategy.  Plus, the knowledge that you will be passing a desirable card or two to your neighbor is troubling.  Sometimes a card would be so valuable to your neighbor that you opt to keep it instead of a different card that you coveted more.  While these decisions are angst-inducing, their resolution is generally quick, so the game moves along at a brisk pace.

For me, the only knock against the game is that you can only significantly influence and be influenced by the players to your immediate right and left.  You have little real influence on the remaining players and, indeed, may not even be able to see what they are collecting.  Since you are not concerned with these other players, however, it does have the benefit of keeping the game moving along as there is little need to assess their holdings.  

This drawback, however, pales in comparison to the excitement and brilliance of the game.  There is a persistent tension of trying to collect the cards you desire.  Yes, much of this is dependent upon the cards you are passed, but everyone is forced to pass along valuable cards.  So, the odds are good you will be receiving cards that are beneficial.  It is fun and challenging to construct a set of cards that enable you to construct more valuable and beneficial cards as the game progresses.  It is not exactly an "engine building" game, but it has some of the elements.  

7 Wonders is an amazing design.  There aren't many games that can pack this much tension, decisions and strategy options in a 30 - 45 minute time frame, while accommodating up to seven players.  The game seems to have all the elements to give in great longevity in a hobby where most games fade to obscurity after just a few years.  It also has all of the elements that should make it a front-runner to capture industry awards such as the Spiel des Jahre and International Gamers Award.  Although this is a year wherein there have been numerous promising games published, 7 Wonders seems destined to rise to the top.

RATING: 7
Enjoyable, relatively simple and fast game of card drafting - although not as simple and fast as "Fairy Tale", which has similar mechanics. It's very nice that it supports up to seven players without adding much playing time or chaos, since the actions are simultaneous and you only have to watch your immediate neighbors. However, it is a bit weird to have no interaction with other players beyond those two.  Also, it's extremely hard to assess how you are doing in relation to your opponents, given the convoluted scoring system. The decisions are very simple and I'm uncertain about "staying power".

RATING: 5
Joc de cartes amb mecanisme de draft, es tracta de buscar combinacions entre diferents tipus de cartes i fer el màxim de punts possibles. Incloú comerç (tot i que l'altre jugador no s'hi pot negar), interacció "militar" i asimetria entre els jugadors. Molt ràpid de jugar i escala molt bé de 3 a 7 jugadors (ja que realment només jugues amb els jugadors del teu costat).

Tot i que és un joc perfecte per iniciats, resulta complicat d'explicar. Temàtica molt enganxada.

Actualització després de més partides: tot i que el joc no funciona malamament del tot amb molts jugadors, es torna molt poc controlable, ja que de la "mà" que reps en cada torn, no te'n torna gairebé cap... El joc té sentit jugat a 3-4 jugadors.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Pretend you're some sort of despot from...a couple of thousand years ago or so and trying to pimp out your main city to show who's the prettiest.  Well, that's a crude way of describing 7 Wonders.

Not entirely unlike Civilization (video game), as the unnamed ruler of a foreign kingdom, you have a plan to elevate your city to greatness, building civic structures, boosting your military might, investing in science and commerce whilst making sure you have the resources to construct a Wonder of the World.  Thing is, you're competing against a bunch of rivals with similar ideas.

The game is played simultaneously - everyone chooses a card, acts upon it and passes the hand on to the next player which means that everyone has a fairly balance chance of getting both favourable and unfavourable hands whilst screwing over rivals and being screwed by rivals.

This goes on over three eras where the resources needed to constuct buildings increases and competition gets fiercer and fiercer.  And then the scoring at the end of the game where one's decisions will either go with or against a player.  

Great game, quick learning curve, many different strategies to try, less competition factor and more focus on your own achievements.  And be sure to download the unofficial scoring app which lets you upload your scores to BGG!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
not for me. tedious.

My favorite one is Cities which adds some variability without dictating strategy. Extra wonder boards are also nice. Leaders I dislike because it makes the game more swingy and really does not add that much. Best with 4 or 5, but still good with any number from 3-7. Takes the best part of MTG (drafting) and leaves out the boring part (playing out the games). (1.9.2017)

RATING: 10
I'm reluctant to give 10 for any game, but 7 wonders is genuinely outstanding with only a few minor flaws that only become apparent after a lot of game play.

Works well as 2-7 player game, but it's always exciting when we get 7 players because we get to use the 7 player cards.

Delightfully complicated, takes probably 3 games to understand what you're doing.  Complex enough that it keeps your interest even when you play it regularly.

Quick to play: we've done a full game in 15 mins once when all players were focused.

Card choice is always tricky: you always want several of the cards.

The real magic of 7 Wonders is that despite the complex rules, with often many players at different abilities and ages, somehow the games are almost always very close.

RATING: 8
One of the best new euros in some time.  Only complaints are odd sized cards (hard to sleeve) and don't play with any AP prone folks or you will sit around watching them look at cards.

Other than that, this is really a good one.  It plays fast, maybe half an hour, scales really well, has multiple paths to victory, and the different wonders along with card draw make every game different.  Military is balanced with science, is balanced with other strategies...  really a great euro and one of the best to come out in the last few years. 

Fun per minute and great scalability get this game to an eight.  If it was a 45 minute game that didn't scale, I'd rate a 7 or less.
