=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
While ostensibly a game of card drafting, 7 Wonders is really much more about deciding where to commit resources. Each turn, a player selects a card, passes the rest of the hand, then plays the card. The card will either generate points towards winning in some way or else enable future cards to be played. This is the crux of the decision: resources for the future or points now. Since virtually every card does one (or both) of these things, it is far less important which particular card one takes. 

The scoring is reminiscent of Knizia, with some being interactive, some cards scoring multiple ways, etc. Like other games of this ilk, the complex scoring comes at a price as the last few minutes of the game will be spent doing addition to see who won. It plays very quickly and I could see playing this multiple times in a row. One of my favorite features is the wonder boards, which provide variable player powers, and nudge (but don't force) players in a certain strategic direction. It works well with almost any number of players because you are really only concerned with the players directly to your left and to your right. That said, with more players, the tactics of trying to "wheel" a certain card will not come into play.

There are a lot of euro-style mechanics neatly packed into this short game. It does have a very meaty feel considering it is essentially filler-length. The ability to accommodate so many players is a nice bonus as well. For its niche, I don't think any game has done this better, but for something deeper (or for thrills) you will have to look elsewhere.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
ESSEN 2010

Very good - enjoy playing and would suggest it

--> even better with expensions : Leaders / Cities.

RATING: 6

RATING: 7
A relaxing game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
There are a lot of things that I like about this game.  It's easy to teach and fun for newbies, and yet it has lots of depth.  It doesn't have a turn order or "first player advantage" because all players choose an action and reveal them simultaneously.  It also can play up to 7 players with little change in playing time because you basically only interact with your immediate neighbours.

There seem to be many strategies to follow.  But it's important to realize that sets of sciences (green cards with different symbols) are worth 7 points each, so it's always good to go for breadth even if you're going for depth in a particular symbol.  Also, it's good to put up *some* sort of military card so that your neighbours don't win free points from you for free -- that is, without changing their play to prevent your military power from equalling or surpassing theirs.

Going for all blue (bonus points) isn't as good as it looks... need some diversity in green and red and even yellow to keep your options open.

Update: September 2014. 6 --> 5
This is OK but not good. For a game which could and should move at a brisk pace (since you are only making one decision per turn), there is still far too much information featured on each card for a game of this weight. Despite the game being a simultaneous action game, and also one with baked in strategies (which in turn means turns in which the 'obvious move' will appear directly after the first quick scan of the cards), the slowest player(s) set the pace. 
-----------------------------------------------------------
Update: July 2015. 5 --> 3
I can now say that I've actively avoided playing this game. There are so many other accessible card games that offer more meaningful decisions for their time frame.

RATING: 6
This got played into the ground when it first came out, but after a few years off, I once again see the appeal. Back up to a 6.

===

It's a reasonably fun card drafting game, but that dreaded "multiplayer solitaire" feel pervades. After a mere 6 plays, it's really starting to feel samey to me. A brisk tempo and short play time help a lot though, and keep it in the realm of quick opener or closer. Still, this one doesn't have the legs I'd hoped it would have, and eventually I see it settling around a 6 or even a 5. 

Note on the 2nd edition: Nooo! They took away what language was present and replaced it with incomprehensible icons! This thing already had too many icons, this just drags it down and makes it even more inaccessible. BAH!

RATING: 8.5
My family and I really enjoy this game.  Be warned, though:  it may take a few games before you can fully appreciate the strategy involved.  This was a situation where my wife and son seemed to pick up on the fun of the game after the first play, but it took me about 4 or 5 games before it started to click.  That would most likely explain why I didn’t win my first game of this until our 8th play or so.

Winner or not, I discovered how to play the game and started enjoying it more and more.  We have only played it with 3 players, so as much as we enjoy it with us 3, I can only imagine it being that much more enjoyable playing it with more (I am almost afraid to, since I think it may cause our 3 player games to go from fun to somewhat boring, if that makes sense).

The one downside is that even though it is called “7 Wonders”, it would have been nice to have a larger selection of wonders to have a little more variety.

In any case, once I figured out how to *really* play the game, this became a top-5 game for me.  Technically, I should say this became a top-5 game with the addition of the Leaders expansion.

RATING: 7
[Initial Impression: 7]

Fast-playing resource management game that has a simple primary mechanic, but also multiple routes for earning VPs. This makes it pretty intuitive and quick to explain, but also gives it a relatively deep feeling for such a quick-playing game. There is a lot to juggle and the combination of starting boards will provide a different feel, so clearly there is a lot to learn and plenty of room for strategic variance across many games. Doesn't immediately leave me feeling like I'd want to play it over and over like I do with Race for the Galaxy or Dominion, but scratches a similar itch, and reminds me a bit of Stone Age in a way. Definitely interested in trying it again.

RATING: 9
I really like this game.  It plays very well with 3-5 (all I've played so far.)

There are a few minor iconography tweaks I would make.  Specifically keeping the Coins and VP symbols in the same place for the small icons in the upper center of the Yellow Cards.

Looks like this will hit the table often as it plays quickly and has some legit decisions to be made during play.  Passing your hand of cards after each play keeps you up on what your opponents are doing as you don't want to pass them a great building they may be able to build for free.

EN: I played this game just a few times, but I can say that I am a big fan of it. In it's case the principle "more people, more fun" is working. Playing with two or three people doesn't make sense. The real game begins with four players. The game is nicely done, but without much distraction - simple cards and cardboard chips. The greatest advantage of 7 wonders is the opportunity to pursue a strategy of victory, depending on your cards, or a miracle, that you are building. To the end of the game it is hard to say who has an advantage, and who will be the winner. Highly recommended for plays with more people.

RATING: 8
A clever game that takes drafting cards to another level. Each round of the game, a draft of cards is passed around which contain improvements you can build for your civilisation - if you have the appropriate resources or can buy them from your neighbours. Each improvement scores you points, sets of developments score you points and in the end, you need ot have the most points. A fun, light game, but in the end not so wonderful that I need to own it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
An interesting twist on "Screw your neighbor" or "Pass the Trash" poker games. You have seven cards, and after choosing one to play, you must pass the rest to your neighbor to your left (or right depending on the age). The only problem is that ALL of the cards are something you want! The problem is which one will maximize your production or points, while limiting the benefit(s) to your neighbor.

The mechanism is so absurdly simple, making for an extremely light game, or so I thought. There are agonizing decisions to be made with every card. Further, the cards you set up early in Age I will affect your ability to score points in Age III; there's plenty to lament on what you should have done or not!

My only quibble at first is that this game requires some memorization of the available cards in order to do well, similar to Glory to Rome. However, the learning curve is not as severe, as there is very little to read in terms of text on each card; the symbology is straight-forward and easier than Race for the Galaxy.

The game shines in the fact that it can scale up to seven, with no appreciable or proportional increase in downtime, finishing in 30-45 minutes. Card selection and play is simultaneous, so downtime is the relatively same whether there are two or seven people playing (well, there may be more of a chance of an AP-induced straggler with larger groups). Initial rating: '8'.

Update (10/02/11) 10+ plays: This game has definitely peaked. It's still not bad as a quick filler, but people are starting to grumble about the stale nature of the game--people have figured it out. Will an expansion help? I'm beginning to not care too much to get one. Also, teaching non-gamers may be a bit too much for their first game, so this is not as good a gateway game as I thought. I'm dropping this down from an '8' to a '7'.

Update (12/15/11) 19+ plays: I introduced this to my gaming club at work at the annual Xmas party to great success--everybody loved it. A hint to teaching larger groups: teach no more than 3 newbies at first, and then have them teach the next three newbies for a 7-player game (which is what happened). The drafting mechanic and card choices will require a lot of hand-holding for the first Age; having three "veterans" (each with one game under their belt) definitely helps to guide the new-newbies. 

I've concluded that the 7-player is totally chaotic: there just seems very little one can do to "steer" their destiny. It is also somewhat dependent on the left and right player/neighbor binding. Players that are new or inexperienced may not necessarily build optimally (for them), and indirectly may affect what I can build. There seems to be a coupling of what I can build relative to what resources my neighbors are building. If they don't build up, I spend actions building up resources and forgoing juicy victory point buildings. I can't quite articulate it, but something about the player binding really bothers me. I will need to play a number of times more to figure it out.

* * *

After reading the comments of users who rated this a '4' or below, I am beginning to understand the negativity. 7-player is a total crap shoot since you will never see the cards you've passed over. It is a much harder game to grasp for newbies, since they will not know or appreciate the interactions of the cards or the combos that are available.  It probably is a better game at 4-player, since some of the cards will cycle back to you, providing some strategic options, rather than solely tactical ones. The game has a rather short half-life. Still, it was a breath of fresh air when it came out, and one has to give it kudos for the amount of excitement it generated for it's ground-breaking design; it was a candle that burned brightly and quickly at both ends, and now it's time to move on....

Update (05/27/12) 34 plays: If there are 5-7 players, I will grudgingly play, if we are still waiting for more players to arrive. The game is no more than a social vehicle. I don't care anymore if I win or lose, because of the various issues raised earlier, as it just seems pointless to try. Dropping to a '6'.

Update (01/02/2015) 41 plays: Yes, it is fun to play once in awhile and agonize about the cards you want to play. Then, the randomness and chaotic nature of the game starts to seep in, and I see it for what it is. It is a great game in terms of game design, making it a good introduction away from the lighter gateways. However, for gamers looking for meatier play, it soon becomes like a meaningless exercise in futility. It is still a "6".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Though rife with shocking nudity and Masonic devilry, the game functions well enough for what it is, a "super-filler" that hosts up to seven players in 30 minutes.  It's pretty, engaging, and the small decisions are nice.  At the end you're rewarded with an awesome/mediocre/just-plain-sad tableau that tells the story of your soaring/forgotten/broke-ass civilization.

[i]But...[/i]

The game suffers grotesquely when players don't counter-pick—the player who manages to seat themselves between two milquetoasts will win with a shockingly massive score.  We're talkin' 37-42-52-[b]87[/b]-33 shocking. 

"What the hell were you doing?!" I ask Ms. 87's neighbors.

They blink as if slapped.  "I was building my civilization," they say.

"For the love of God," I rave, "Why did you keep passing her [i]exactly what she needed?![/i]"

"Well," they mumble, "I had other things to do."

"Yes," I gurgle through clenched teeth, "Like making sure she doesn't double all our scores!"

So, yeah, this game requires mouth-pooping in order to work.  When everyone keeps a scatalogical eye on their neighbors—and even up- and downstream some—it's a nice little card drafting game that's over quickly enough that you don't notice the undigested corn.

When playing with people who refuse to poop in their neighbor's mouths, I [i]strongly suggest[/i] you sit between two of them in order to maximize your score.

[b]After 25 plays:[/b]  Much better (I'd rate it an 8) with the [gameid=92539] expansion.  Leaders allow you to focus your strategy (just a little), or at least build some synergy.  Or, with a poor selection, have hilariously random historical figures running your show.  [i]Hatshepsut in Rome?![/i]  ~LULZ

Expansions owned:

[thing=92539]Leaders[/thing]
[thing=111661]Cities[/thing]

[thing=154638]Babel[/thing]

[thing=133993]Wonder Pack[/thing]
[thing=110308]Catan[/thing]

All beautifully ensconced in a Broken Token insert!

RATING: 7
Nice drafting game.  My main complaint is that it is fairly easy to make mistakes and almost impossible to tell when your opponents have done so due to the simultaneous nature of the game.  I very often wonder how a person could have managed to buy so many expensive buildings with so few resources.  Having said that the simultaneous gameplay has allowed the very difficult feat of producing a seven player game with almost no downtime.

I got Sushi Party Go because it was similar to this (which I don't own, but have ready access to) but 7 Wonders is deeper and the added complexity adds a lot more interest for not a lot more hassle.

RATING: N/A

Coonabarabran
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I don't know why people rave about this game so much.  They created a new categorization for the Speil des Jahres and this game won but I don't know how much this is due to the new category.

The entire game is about drafting cards, there is only so much you can do in a larger game.  With players of vastly different skill levels you can find people getting advantages that you could never alter no matter how hard you try.

If played in the context of experienced gamers who have played this game at least 3 times previously, and all players are similarly astute about drafting to block or maximize advantage then I would probably rate the game higher.  But for the environment where no one game gets to be played dominantly for two months, then 7 wonders is difficult to play well but easy to play randomly.  In some cases people win and don't realize how or why.

My personal variant is that I want to outscore the people to my left and right, the absolute highest score doesn't matter to me.  I also like to look at the delta between the players to my left and right, if I beat both those players by a decent margin and they have similar scores I consider that better than a higher overall point spread over both players if those players have vastly different scores.  Something like the product of the two deltas, compared to other players product of the two deltas.

The game can be played quickly, and I suggest allowing less time for each draft as things progress - keep it moving quickly.  Some people in my group grind over what to do and have 2 or even 3 drafts backlogged waiting for them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.57
I’ve heard 7 Wonders called a good gateway game, and I really don’t think it is; but what I think it is is a good gateway engine-building game. [thing=143884]Machi Koro[/thing] is a good gateway game, but not a good engine-building game. The ‘engine’ there is another way of saying putting all your eggs in one basket, and that’s effective in Machi Koro, but it’s not engine-building.

But in 7 Wonders, you’ve got not only engine-building, but also logistics: You want to build your engine, but you’ve also got to plan ahead for your wonder; you need to build the things that will let you build your engine. Aim 7 Wonders at a group of new gamers and watch them scatter, but wait until they’ve learned [thing=13]Settlers[/thing], [thing=41090]Magnate[/thing], and [thing=25554]Notre Dame[/thing], and 7 Wonders will be the next best thing: real engine-building, a step into [thing=28143]Race for the Galaxy[/thing] and [thing=35677]Le Havre[/thing] and [thing=19857]Glory to Rome[/thing] and [thing=31260]Agricola[/thing].

The grudge I have against 7 Wonders is that I like it less than Magnate [i]and[/i] less than Le Havre. Le Havre pays off its complexity debt; Magnate has a debt more suited to its gameplay. 7 Wonders is just a little more complex than it needs to be, and it has a little bit of a Feldian feel to it: There’s a lot to keep track of, but not as much actually going on. Subsystems feel like little scoring minigames related to each other only in that when you choose to play one minigame you can’t play another.

I like 7 Wonders, and I look forward to playing it as a family, but I look forward to playing other games even more. It’s not a game to discard after we’ve moved on to better games, but it isn’t one of those better games, either.[color=#ffffff]a9Z4MnAx[/color]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Recommend Cities Expansion! Also great for 2 players!

RATING: N/A
4 Spieler
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
1.萬里長城是特殊奇蹟，建造不需要依順序，其餘奇蹟建造須由左至右，建造不分時期
2.除了咖啡色(基礎資源)與灰色(科技資源)卡片上資源可被交易，其餘不可被其他玩家購買(如板塊、黃卡等)
3.遊戲起始卡片要分人數取出(3+、4+等..)，抽排順序會變
4.科技卡片算分 同類平方  每蒐集一組+7分
5.棄牌拿取順序模索拉斯王陵墓>萬里長城>青樓公會
##########################
遊戲流程：
遊戲會進行3個時期，分別使用時期1~3的牌堆，每個玩家發7張手牌。
時期流程：
1. 選1張卡。
2. 執行動作。可執行下面3個動作其中1種。
a.蓋1個建築。
花費所需的代價。有些建築若有蓋出前置建築則可以免費蓋出。
同名稱的建築只能蓋1棟。

b.蓋1個奇觀階段。
花費所需的代價。將卡片背面向下壓在玩家所蓋的階段的下面。
建築階段需由左至右依序蓋出來。

c.把卡棄掉得到3元。

3. 將剩下的手牌傳給下一個玩家。(時期1和3往左傳，時期2往右傳)

- 每個玩家打出6張牌後，時期結束。和兩旁的玩家比較軍事力量(紅色卡片)。
- 若軍事力量比對方高，則依時期1~3可得到 +1/+3/+5分 的衝突標記。
- 若軍事力量比對方低，則得到 -1分 的衝突標記。
- 若平手則沒事發生。
- 將衝突標記放到玩家的奇觀圖版上。
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
One of my favorite games of all time. It plays every player count well(2 players is "interesting"), it's easy to teach and plays in a very short time. There is a good amount of game in the base, but I feel the expansions greatly helped in making varying strategies and increasing the game's replayability without adding too much complexity. Personally, my favorite is Leaders, since it adds the most to the game and will refresh the experience to those who may be burned out on base 7 Wonders, followed by Babel and then Cities. 

I think if no more content was made for 7 Wonders, I'd be completely happy at this point. The game has provided many hours of fun and enjoyment with many different people of experience.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A simple card drafting and 'engine' game build around some fairly bland cards. There are plenty of different directions in which to diversify, but the Science cards represent such a powerful scoring multiplier that unless several players collect them, then the lucky recipient will probably be the winner. The game really needs the players to be self-balancing here, otherwise anyone who keeps being passed those lovely green cards is a shoo-in to win. The problem with all games of this type is that no-one knows the future, so putting down any card is a gamble as to whether you'll be able to build on it further. The same charge could be levelled against Race for the Galaxy, but the formula works better there because end of game cards are in the deck from the start and so give you a clear target to aim at. This is light, unchallenging fun, but nothing to go overboard about.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7-What else!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]IF ALL THE CIVILIZATIONS DEPICTED IN THE GAME HAD BUILT THEIR EMPIRES AND LEFT THEIR MARKINGS ON THE HISTORY BOOKS THE SAME WAY THIS GAME UNFOLDS, I HARDLY BELIEVE THEY WOULD BE ONF ANY RELEVANCE TODAY[/b]

It is not usual for me to come across games I don’t like, for one reason or the other. If those games are about civilization building and historical elements, the probabilities of it not making the cut are astronomical. But then again, if it wasn’t for games like this, I wouldn’t like my historical and building games so much.

7 Wonders, despite the unjustified fuzz about it, is not a great game. In fact, I dare say it’s not even a good one at all. The whole drafting mechanics supporting it are clearly broken and tend to turn the game into an all-out mess on the table when experienced players play with beginners. But in the spirit of fairness, I must say that my experience with this may not be the best base for an objective verdict, especially because I learned to play it with another 6 guys at the table, with a friend of all of us explaining the game. From the get go, the game is clearly the most boring and chaotic experience ever when played with more than five players, maybe even more then four. However, that’s the closest I’ve been to actually playing the game, so writing about it from that perspective is the best one I have. Sadly, I don’t think I will ever play 7 Wonders again. *Sigh*

The draft mechanics are interesting and it was pretty simple for me to understand them since I am a rehabilitated Magic: The Gathering player. The only problem with this is that most of your game depends on the luck of the draw factor that comes with this type of games. If you need a certain card, there’s actually no real certainty that you’ll get it, because after drafting a card in each turn, players get to see what the others choose, so blocking choices for the other players, king-making decisions or radical changes in one’s own strategy (Which for me makes the game nothing but a “win some, lose most” ordeal) forced by not getting certain cards are way too common and frequent in a game that plays almost unnecessarily fast. There’s no actual strategy behind this game, only feeble tactics and very weak decisions.

Maybe with a lot less players, with some time to read the rules quietly and at least a few minutes to make a good, conscience decision on which card to choose and how to use it would make the game a lot more interesting and complex, but for now, I’m keeping away from that game. Too bad, especially because the arts and graphics are gorgeous and the whole them stroke my History buff nerve.

[b][i]I. Criteria[/i][/b]

Mechanics: :d10-5:
Design & Art: :d10-0:
Packing & Presentation: :d10-8:
Theme: :d10-9:
BGG Factor: :d10-8:

[b][i]II. Sliders[/i][/b]

Abstract [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Themed: A Civilization building game based on the 7 Wonders of the Ancient World is definitely my kind of game and despite the fact that the cards in the game are useful for any player and civilization, the idea of all of those cards being so simple and basic are perfect for a game where the players vie for the best Wonder for their people, especially because most civilizations started pretty much in the same way.

Simple [b]___[COLOR=#FF0000][4][/COLOR]______[/b] Complex: When playing with faster players, more experienced ones or whatever, taking your time for each decision is impossible, so you tend to look for the “best” card you have at that moment, without considering if the card itself might help you with other projects or endeavors within your own personal board.

Strategic [b]_______[COLOR=#FF0000][8][/COLOR]__[/b] Tactical: Card-drafting games this quick and unstable are almost impossible to be thought of as “strategic”, since most of the decisions you have are limited by the hands you get from the other players and the previous cards you got on your board. Certainly, some long-term building or collecting could work just fine, but those possibilities are way to constricted by the low chances of getting the exact cards you need or want.

Luck [b]_[COLOR=#FF0000][2][/COLOR]________[/b] Skill: Skill on 7 Wonders is shown not in the cards you choose every time a new set is handed out, but how well you end up using them as a whole in the end. Meanwhile, the luck of the draw factor plays the most central role in this game, with the exception of the draw consists on a set of cards of which one must be chosen, the rest possibly handed out to be permanently lost. There is only an illusion of control in this game.

Fiddly [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] Elegant: Something worth mentioning is definitively the elegance of the rulebook and the rule set. The game plays smoothly and it’s almost never a necessity to have the rulebook close by to consult on this or that special rule. The very simple mechanics are very well exploited, and the rest depends on the player’s decisions.

Indirect interaction [b]______[COLOR=#FF0000][7][/COLOR]___[/b] Direct interaction: The military cards in the game are nice and it puts into the game the aggressive competitive element needed in all true civilization building games, which is the armed power. Some cards are better, some cards are cheaper, but it’s always fun to see the reaction on the other players when armies are way too big to be stopped. However, the idea of only being able to attack the players right next to you, makes the whole army side of the game a bit lame and boring, and way too limited in certain occasions. Also, the idea of needing sometimes the resources of your neighboring players is interesting and very adequate, but it happened pretty much the same as what goes on with the army cards.

Cutthroat [b]_______[COLOR=#FF0000][8][/COLOR]__[/b] Friendly: Playing to win, to be the best builder, to be the strongest general, to block other players decisions or just to collect certain cards or colors or whatever the players want at the time is possible, and I suppose it’s fun enough. Decisions in the game are the basis for everything, so playing like a dick just to annoy other players or playing on one’s own terms is just as good.

Heavy use of language [b]________[COLOR=#FF0000][9][/COLOR]_[/b] No language needed: The game is almost in all senses text-free and as mentioned above the elegance of it makes it almost completely unnecessary to reach for the rulebook every time a doubt shows up. Symbols and combinations of symbols are easier to understand and make the game somewhat faster and lighter.

[b][i]III. Number of players recommended[/i][/b]: 4.

[b]CHEERS![/b]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
It's ok, easy to learn but I'm far from blown away by it. I don't get the hype, this is just a filler with no substance.

RATING: 8
Is a good large-group game, with multiple paths to victory. Fast paced and generally fixed duration, once people are familiar with the game play mechanic.

Can have a bit of a learning curve for first time players, as the third age cards are generally dependent on what resources / path to victory a player is taking. But, first time players can generally get decent scores muddling through.

RATING: 7
High-quality filler with some depth to it and plenty of replayability.  This is a quick card-drafting game made engaging by fear of one's neighbors, greed for the best cards, and a certain amount of calculated risk.  Somehow I ended up playing this over and over again, without ever really intending to--that's the sort of game this is. (Seventeen already? Sheesh.)

RATING: N/A
[NEW] 28 Jul 15
[STORE] jogonamesa.pt
[PRICE] 29.33€
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I get that this is broadly considered a modern masterpiece, and I can see why. Drafting is a fun mechanic. There are lots of strategic avenues in 7W that play out across rounds, so over the course of the game you can build a decent shot at victory even if your first round feels like you got stuck with stuff you didn't necessarily want. The short playtime means you can get some genuine strategic depth out of 15 or 20 minutes.

Here's the thing, though: I don't love it. I've found 7W consistently difficult to teach to new players - not because of mechanical weight or because the rules are extensive, but because the iconography and the way strategies develop over rounds is complex and intimidating. That gets better over the first few rounds, but I have tried 7W on a few different groups now, and every time it's a lead balloon. People are so confused initially that even though they're finally "getting it" by the time the first game ends, there's no desire left to try again.

[b]Sushi Go![/b], meanwhile, hits most of the same notes in a much cleaner, faster, more accessible way (and is also infinitely less irritating to score). And [b]Among the Stars[/b] gives me the mechanic, with more strategic depth but without the iconography or endgame scoring math homework, plus the added visual splash of the space stations being built and what is (to me, anyway) a more fun theme. Sorry, 7W. I guess you're just not for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Gloriously simple yet a lot of fun. Love the fact you can play with so many people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a little too complex for family gaming, and I'm not sure the complexity is actually justified for the depth of the decisions you need to make (e.g. does the tech tree really add anything to the game?).

Being able to affect only your immediate neighbour (to a first approximation) works around many problems inherent in this sort of game, but (if you'll excuse the tautology) means you have very little influence over most other players.

For a quick, light game it's OK, and going up to 7 players while remaining quick is nice.

RATING: 9
We really love this game.
The first time you play it, it seems a little bit complicated. But once you learn how to play, you get so fast at it that you wish it were a longer game. It's not something I'd recommend if you want hard core gaming, but you can set it up quick and start having fun when you don't have hours available to dedicate to a game. Most games last only about half an hour, so if your looking for a game that doesn't have a lot of down time and is quick to set up and play, I would recommend this game.

RATING: 5.5
A double-edged sword, this game is.  On the one hand, it can be hard to maintain a strategy throughout an entire game due since you are basically at the mercy of the cards.  On the other hand, there aren't many other games out there that have as many avenues to victory, can support so many players, and play as quickly as 7 Wonders.  It's easy to get burned out on this game since it's played so often (due to the aforementioned quick play time and flexible player count), but I don't think I'd ever turn down a game.  What the hell, it's only 30 minutes right?

RATING: 4
I enjoy 7 Wonders well enough to play it, but not quite enough to own it (especially seeing as everybody else in the world owns the game, it feels like). I vastly prefer it with 3 or 4 over any other number. I don't tend to like dummy players (as with the 2-player game) or not seeing much of the same "pack" ever again (as with the 5+ player game).

Sometimes I sort of wish I still had 7 Wonders, but then I get over it. Maybe if an expansion comes along that really kicks it up a notch for me, I'll rebuy it. Leaders definitely isn't it.

--Jan 22, 2013--

I occasionally play 7 Wonders. Every time I do, I like it a little less. I will now play it every few months, but never twice in a row. I do not believe any expansion will get me to rebuy 7 Wonders. Funny-- I don't usually take a game from a 9 (which I think 7 Wonders started at) down to a 4 (current rating). Ouch!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Quite fun. Hard to impose and stick to a strategy though, and who wins often feels a bit random, and at the mercy of the players directly next to them paying attention and sacrificing what they are doing to prevent it. 

Like: It's possible to win in a variety of ways. Card drafting as a mechanic is fairly interesting. 

Dislike: Every game plays out fairly similarly. Reliance on other players to pay attention beyond what they themselves are doing. Some players take way too long to make simple card selection decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
First played at Ludo-Outaouais in November 2011.  I wish we'd had time to play more than once, as we didn't realize the importance of some types of resources until the third Age.

Anyway, I like the mechanics of this game, and especially like that everyone plays simultaneously.  We played with 4, but playing with 7 wouldn't add much to the length of the game, nor would there be much downtime for players.  I think that's the best feature of this game.  Everything else (various ways to obtain victory points, theme, etc) are all a distant second.  It's an OK game... not my favourite, but it fills the need for a quick non-party game for large groups.

RATING: N/A

Those chains are hard to plan for and easy to miss, which may slow he game down. That is a bad thing for a game where the fast gameplay is a major feature.

RATING: 8
A game that takes seven players and plays in ~30 minutes?  With civ-building?  Sign me up!

One disadvantage: Relies very heavily on card-drafting.  If one or more players is weak at card-drafting, it'll unbalance the game.  You need to ensure that all players are equally matched, or keep an eye on everything that's going on at the table and kibitz a little when you see a player's tableau getting out of control.

RATING: 6
This a very beautiful game to look at.  The cards are a wonderful bit of design and the game mechanics are elegant and varied.  So, why don't I rate this higher?  I think the first 20 times I played it, I enjoyed the game.  But, after that, it starts to wear itself out.  It's a game that's very lightweight.  There are games that actually explore aspects of ancient civilizations and are a bit of a learning experience.  This game does none of that.  To some extent, it's empty calories.

RATING: 7
Very entertaining draft/deck-based game, with an interesting them, good artwork, and balanced mechanics from 3 to 7 players. The game is a bit slower at 6-7 players, and definitely works best with 4 players. The icons and symbols are a bit hard to grasp at the beginning, and there are a few rules that you will definitely overlook in the first few games, but this game is definitely more entertaining than Dominion, and more open to non-hardcore gamers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a great game!  The setup relatively quick, games take roughly 30 minutes, and a great deal happens in a short period of time.  While there are quite a few symbols for a new player to learn, 1 or 2 plays through will get you up to speed.  There are many different strategies that you can employ and the game can vary quite a bit depending on the cards you are dealt and the actions of your neighbors.  The cherry on top is that it works with 3 - 7 players and still feels balanced.  I have not tried 2 player.  After playing it more than 20 times I may not suggest it as a first pick, but I am almost never disappointed with it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Simple card-drafter that can accommodate up to 7 players. Unfortunately, players only interact with their immediate neighbours (the player to their left and right), and even those interactions are largely passive-aggressive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great looking fast game, where 3 seems the sweet spot and 2 an interesting option. Gets much better with the B side of the wonders.

After many plays I've decided to modify my initial rating. Now, I believe that the game should get 6 for 4-7 players (5 for the gameplay +1 for being something that is not a party game but can still acommodate up to 7 players), 7 for 3 players and an absolute 8 for the 2-player experience (especially with the B side). With the 2-player officila variant, the game comes through as quite deep and involved,retaining its speed and grace. I highly recommend it.

Oh, one more thing. 7 Wonders is one of the most beautiful games I have (+1 rating), being at the same time surprisingly expensive (especially when you think about the quality of cards)and put in an obviously too big box (-1 rating).

Overally: still a solid 8!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Liked this a lot.  Core mechanic is card drafting (i.e., pick a card to play from your hand, then pass the hand to the next player).

Game appeared to be immediately in the comfort zone of folks who have played card-collecting game draft event; however, it did not take long to pick up for those of us without that background.

Some similarities to Race for the Galaxy in that you are trying to build up your civilization's resources and accomplishments in a fashion such that your cards actually complement each other.

Another big plus is that the game plays quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a miraculous game in civilization. Unlike other civilization building games, 7 Wonders has simple rules. Above all, this game has considerablly shortened the playing time. Unbelievably, as a civilization game, 7 Wonders takes only less than 30 minutes. Although the  playing is short, players still can experience the original civilization building. Of course, 7 Wonders is not a classic civilization game, so that this game cannot offer the same fun with other classic civilization games. 7 Wonders shows highlighted elememts of civilization. Nevetherless, this is almost the only civilization game which allures normal users to enter real civilization world.

RATING: 10
The first "designer" board game I purchased on my own.  I had owned Catan and Carcassonne previously and 7 Wonders blew those games away.  

Fun to play, easy to teach - always a few interesting decisions every age (esp. the 3rd).  Have recorded 70 or so games with my group so far, and through it all 7 Wonders has stood as the best of the bunch.

For me, the game has little to offer anymore - I've nearly mastered the strategies.  The game is still a blast to play because the group really enjoys it and it brings us together in a resonable play time.  A classic for sure.

RATING: 10
OWNED SINCE 2011
A great game. Easy to learn BUT because of the many icons it is not easy to teach to new players. It is quick to play, so it gets played a lot at my house. My kids, ages 8 and up, understand and enjoy this game. The parents can handicap themselves (start with less coins or start the kids with extra)when playing with younger players. Although the theme has been done before, the way it is played is unique, and it fills a spot in my collection no other game does. I highly recommend it in anyone's collection. I have none of the expansions yet, but hope to get some.

RATING: 4.5
I don't grok the love that this game gets. Yeah it plays 7, but in practice it's just as if multiple 3-player games are happening at once. The icon-filled cards are quite confusing; I would never bring this out with nongamers. But what really sinks this game for me is the spreadsheet scoring at the end. For a game with supposedly no downtime, it sure feels like tedious sitting there at the end while everyone sits there calling out numbers while someone else writes them down or plugs them into an app.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Well I think I have played this game enough times to rate it now. While I applaud the concept of creating a fast paced 7-player civ game I really think the multiple paths to victory in this one are mostly just a skin to disguise points and they don't do that very well. Sure the game is enjoyable enough, but it is also kind of boring. I can only win by playing Green, and I can't be bothered playing green anymore. Victory, especially in large games, is mostly random. It does kind of depend on what your neighbours do and take, like if one of them plays no military then you need very little military to gain a lot of points. 

So yeah I think I have done my dash with this game. Rating is based on initial appeal, I've probably cooled to a 5 personally, but I think with gamers who are less into the strategy and control elements of games than I am will likely enjoy this for longer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.5
The supported player counts and the playtime, coupled with theme, are 7 Wonders' saving graces. There are a few choices early in the game that you need to be thoughtful about, but after that it feels like the game largely plays itself. Resources don't seem like enough of a constraint by halfway through the game, and there are few interesting tradeoffs to make with each hand that is passed to you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Resource and set collection game where you pass cards around the table and try to pay for the best cards to ultimately collect the most victory points. Nice looking game but I think the game may be a little over-rated because it is not a particularly unique idea or game strategy. The cool factor related to the 7 Wonders of the World and game graphics helps it score. You require a fairly balanced group of players to keep better players in check from chalking up a big advantage. Good, fun and fairly quick game for 6-7 players because of its simultaneous card play, but not the years best game IMO.

RATING: 8
It does just what it says it does, it plays 3 to 7 WELL and does it in 30 minutes flat. Its a filler with a weak theme so don't expect more, it does play well, it plays fast with no downtime and also keeps you interested. It also has that let's play one more game addictive quality.
 
I was leary about a game of just a pure draft and thats all but it works out quite good and shit it plays 7 players, how many games are decent and play 7 in half an hour?  That and it’s easy to teach mean its a great gateway game and this puts it on the wishlist for me.  

You are building up your player board by drafting cards, once you know the cards (which only takes one game really) you can do some planning on how you want to  build combos on the table (set collection). It's nice that the player boards push the envelope all a little differently too, so one board encourages to play a certain strategy and another board a slightly different one. 

The obvious comparison is to Fairy Tale but I'll do it versus Dominion. Dominion probably has a little more depth just because the cards you are drafting are face up and open to everyone where as here you know what you’ll probably get and probably need but it isn’t as certain. Once you own cards things are kind of flipped around because once built here they are on your board and stay there where as in Dominion the cards randomly come to you and you don’t know how they will combine. They are different games but fill the same niche of a good 30 minute filler, personally I give this one the edge due to scaling and no annoying shuffling, this game will likely make its way to my shelf.  

I do think replay with the current cards is limited to maybe 20 plays tops and some will be bored of the cards after 5 - 10 games. For me this isn't as big as problem since I want it for a filler only and for family outings *BUT* the BIG box and BIG price really mean they should have included a lot more cards which might stop me from buying it at the current price. Note the cards are a good thick stock but black rimmed and not that durable and this means unsightly wear on edges, and the cards are too big for regular sleeves :( 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

What a triumph!  A seven player game that plays quickly, with depth, and tough decisions.  A regular favorite with our game group.

RATING: 8.45

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
PRO:
7 Players; Simple to Teach and Play;

CON:
I feel the overall randomness of the cards you are given, and the actions of your neighbors, strongly outweighs the strategy you employ. 

I think that there is a chance that if you look at every card you can [legally] play each turn (maybe also including setting up your wonder if your have that capability as an option), assign a number to them each, and then roll to see which to do, you could still end up winning the game. The only argument with that is the preference you would show to science symbols, and possible military depending on your neighbors. 

In references to the actions of your neighbor: A neighbor that ignores military can give you an easy military victory each age, and a neighbor that doesn't purchase cards to block your sets of science symbols can let you walk away with a lot of points for the win. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Beautifully designed game that comes and goes effortlessly
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an amazingly lite game of civ.  Even my dad was able to learn it (not a gamer) and whup my butt.  You get a big hand, play a card, pass the hand to your neighbor.  To play many of the cards, you'll need prerequisites (like a mine to make a necessary resource).  You build up victory points through various types of cards.  Very quick, little forward planning, challenging to make the most of each hand, very enjoyable.  Games unfold pretty much the same way every time so replay is somewhat limited.  Good for a once per session filler, especially if you have a lot of players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I was a little cool to this after my first play.  It took until the middle of Age Two before I "got it", and even then, I had no idea what types of symbols and cards were to come in Age Three.  It's clear there's a lot of replay potential here, and it's clear that, like RftG, there's a lot of value in knowing the general composition of the decks, even if you don't have the card list memorized.  It'll take 2 or 3 more plays before I can rate this fairly.  

Update: the official two-player version of this is underrated.  There's a lot more screwage and tactical play when you a) see each hand three times a round instead of once or twice, and b) can manipulate the dummy player's board to mess with your opponent.  I think I prefer the official variant to the "just deal three hands and take turns playing for the dummy" variant.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Much the way Dominion is the standard for deckbuilding games, 7 Wonders is the standard for card drafting games.

The chances I won't keep it in my collection are pretty low, but I don't find myself wanting to teach it anymore because it's not as much fun when a new player plays irrationally (makes sitting next to one really important to have a better shot at winning). It can also take up to an hour to play with new players due to explaining symbols and clarifying rules.

It's a classic, but I really don't see it as a gateway game anymore. For players new to card drafting, I recommend Sushi Go! as a better introduction to the mechanic.

RATING: 5

I don't see this as a family game at all - and how it has reached number 1 on BGG in the family game section, I just don't know - well I do, most people have a different family to me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
2011-07-27

Initial Rating: 8.0

Thanks to all the hype out there, I was expecting an amazing game, 7 Wonders is a great game but not what I expected, I love civilization games and this one is not one of them, the theme is pasted on but I can get around that. I think it is one of the most versatile games out there, I like that it can handle 6-7 players in a short time frame, but the ideal in my opinion is 3-4 players, anything more and the players see too few cards (which greatly increases the luck factor), the game is not very deep, almost always it is more tactical than strategic as you react to the cards than you receive,  I consider it to be a "familiar" Race for the Galaxy (as both games seek synergy between cards) which by the way I prefer and recommend over 7 Wonders. On the bad side, the cards are of a very low quality, must sleeve ASAP. In conclusion I like 7 wonders, it is a very good game but I think it is over appreciated, I will buy it once the hype calms down.

2012-04-17

Also counting the points at the end is a bore.

RATING: 5
It's difficult to get inspired to make a creative comment about 7 Wonders.  It is what it is.  The drafting is interesting, and I'm sure there's a whole metagame around denying important cards to opponents while keeping a coherent strategy oneself.

In the end this isn't my type of game.  If I'm going to play a thematically challenged 30-minute card game I would rather play Dominion.  In particular I can't imagine playing 7 Wonders again without the Leaders expansion.

RATING: 6
I love the draft format.  I think I will enjoy this game more once I take the time to research and understand the upgrade paths.  As it is, I feel like I am just randomly picking cards without regard for an over-arching strategy.

I wish that there were more cards in each age.  I am used to Magic draft where there are three packs of 15 for an 8 man draft, as opposed to 7 "packs" of 7 for a 7 man draft.  There is not as much room for signaling, wheeling, and general maneuvering with so few cards.

RATING: 10
This is a perfect game. The mechanics are simple and new players learn quickly. It accomodates up to 7 (a running theme, in keeping with the title) players with no lag in play time or boring waiting periods. It can be a genuine surprise to see who has won at the end of the game -- unless you keep meticulous track of what everyone else is building, which, admittedly, some people do consider fun.

I can think of nothing bad to say about it. It's one of the first nerdy games I was introduced to and I was hooked from the start. I, in turn, make it one of the first games I introduce new gamers to. It hasn't misfired yet.

RATING: 9
7 wonders is an amazing game.  It is probably my favorite short term strategy game.  It packs tactical and strategic decisions in a 30-45 minute game.  Because everyone is acting at the same time, there is very little downtime.  There is luck in what cards you draw in what order, however, most of the time, your decisions matter.   The Cities expansion adds needed additional variety and depth.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I have played this game several times with my gaming group, but mostly with large groups. The first several times that I played it, I had thought it was awesome: So many different card types, so many different ways to score points, using resources that either you had previously built or paying for the resource(s) from one of your two neighbors. It was the first card drafting game I had ever played, and it had interesting mechanisms.
Fast forward months later, and it seems that the people at my gaming club have outgrown the game. While we would always play the game about once a week, the game just does not hit the table as much these days.
Because I was able to find it for a cheap enough price, I decided to buy the game myself (I would not have thought that I would have originally, since there are a lot of people in my gaming group who already own the game and I try to buy different games so that I can bring different games to play at the club).
I decided to teach the game to my family. We have played 3 different games so far. 2 of those games were 3 player games and 1 of them was a 5 player game. However, all 3 of those games were won by my father, using almost the exact same strategy every time. He would build a lot (but not all) resources early in the game, and then come Age III (and Age II, to start somewhat) he would gather and build most of the high scoring straight-out blue victory point cards. If you have a bunch of blue cards that you are able to build because of your variety of resources you built early on, and sprinkle in some military, and what do you know you have almost an unstoppable path to victory. I swear, there was one game in which my father gathered 30 victory points just in blue cards (8+6+6+4+3+3=30) While you can also scoring points from science cards, you need to commit and hope for specific cards, and on average / card may only net you 3.5 points/card. Whereas with blue cards, even snagging just one can give you 3 to 4 points minimum, going up from there. Also, my father was also able to execute this strategy in a 5 player game (although 2 of the players were new to the game in that particular case and were just catching on the strategy towards the end of the game), too, so although it could be that only the 3 player game is flawed.
Although I have not played any further games with my family, I believe that this game is so unbalanced, because I believe that the above basic strategy can be executed time and again and become a dominant strategy to winning this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3

RATING: 6

San Juan and Glory to Rome are superficially similar but feel a little more like I'm really doing something in front of me with other people. This feels like I'm playing cards over the internet.

You are the leader of one of the 7 great cities of the Ancient World. Gather resources, develop commercial routes, and affirm your military supremacy. Build your city and erect an architectural wonder which will transcend future times.

RATING: 6.7
Non-gamers have a very hard time with the rules of this game. For this reason, it is actually a poor choice for the main situation where people want to play it - as an opener in a mixed group of 6 or 7.

Pros: 
- Plays very fast on everyone's second game; can take under 45 minutes with 7 players.
- Nice, consistent iconography (YMMV!)

Cons: 
- Heavy rules considering the length of the game.
- *Not* a good icebreaker in mixed groups - Too complicated.

RATING: 8
I've only played this once so far, but I think I really like it. As has been mentioned elsewhere, the card drafting mechanic makes for a nice, quick game. It's the kind of game that is fun enough at first, but the strategy and game play get much deeper the more plays you have.

Update: I have played this many times since I originally rated it, and I really enjoy it. What it has that other drafting games don't is a phased approach that allows you to build on previous rounds (Ages). It's really a brilliant game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
The box says 2 players are possible... it lies.
Basically, it's card drafting with the hopes of getting the right combination so that you "build" your monument, but that's it: once the card is taken, you do nothing with it. Too many players = no chance at choosing multiple cards per round.

PLUS: easy to learn, plays quick
MINUS: boring -- doesn't encourage table talk or player interaction
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love a good drafting game and this is one such game.  If the cards had a linen finish and the boards didn't warp, I would totally buy this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The basic gist of the game is to play cards to get access to resources and money, then use resources and money to buy cards that get you points. You can buy resources from your neighbors on either side if you don't produce them yourself. Military cards create a kind of majority game with your neighbors - you get points if you have more swords than they do. Each player is also given a play mat, and each mat shows a different wonder that can be built in 2 or 3 stages. The benefits that come with each stage are unique for each wonder. The game play is simple. Everyone is dealt a hand of 8 cards. On a turn, you play a card from your hand and then pass the hand to your right or left. Play a card, pass. Play a card, pass. The last card in each hand is discarded. Do that for 3 hands (there's a different deck for each hand) and then the game ends. It probably plays in less than 30 minutes with experienced players.

I think the game's main strengths are its short play time and high possible player count. It plays up to 7! The game play is pretty strong for such a simple game, although I suspect 90% of your decisions are based on what you need more than what your neighbor needs. Of course, the box is 4 times larger than it needs to be, probably to house the massive number of expansions this game will probably inspire. This game is worth having for me simply because of the player count. If it only played 4, I might not bother trying to acquire it, but since we are trending high on the player counts these days, I think it has a place.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
v

RATING: 9

I think new players should play several games one after another to get a "feel" for the game.

RATING: 7
A solid 7 for this one, based on about a dozen plays thus far.  Not sure I like the marketing hype (reminds me of Agricola) where they didn't have sufficient English editions at the start then suckering everyone into buying one.  Anyway, hope to get my copy soon.  Game plays quickly, multiple scoring options, but the card-passing mechanic has been seen before (Fairy Tale, Notre Dame) and there's not alot that's terribly new or innovative.  Think it's going to be alot like Dominion for me, alot of play at first, then kind of a lowest common denominator game, when people can't agree on what to play.  The darling of this year's Essen crop, it's shooting up the BGG rankings as I write this -- but long, term, does it really deserve anything higher than a 7?  The ability to play with 7, however, is a big plus, however.

Sept. 2011 Update:  Still maintaining my rating of 7, and should add it's probably the one game most played over the last six months, not so much because of a desire on my part, but just that  it's become a "lowest common denominator game" that everyone is willing to play -- it's quick, if you don't do well you can blame the luck of the cards, it plays with 7, etc.  I suspect it's alot more likely that the game will get played less and less as time goes by, and the one thing I am hoping for is that someone adapts some of the more creative elements here into a meatier game -- sort of like how Martin Wallace has taken Dominion to a new level with "A Few Acres of Snow."

RATING: N/A
42.49 csi
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I went into this game biased, as I have been keenly interested in the Seven Ancient Wonders of the world for some time, have devoured books on them and even created this geeklist last year on games related to the Siege/Colossus of Rhodes (one of the Wonders). So, kind of a given that I'm all over the theme of this one. The art doesn't disappoint, absolutely beautiful and detailed, and so much better than the underwhelming Tower of Babel art (another 7 Wonders game). Some of the best art I've seen this year.

The gameplay itself is a pretty straightforward card game of building and developing, kind of a light civ game arc. What I find really cool about this one is the overlapping "trios" around the table; you're intensely involved with each of your neighbors, who are each also involved with both you their other neighbor, etc. There is also a ripple effect around the table based on cards played/drafted/passed. Very interesting dynamics and not one I've seen before. It's not as "group social" as for example a game of Bang! or Werewolf, but it's still far from solitaire.

It's a perfect game to play in those 30 minutes where you have 4-7 gamers already and are waiting for the last few to trickle in so you can split into 2 tables.  Up there among my favorite card games along with Biblios, Citadels and Verrater.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an empire building game in which players have a hand of cards from which they select a single card and then pass the remaining cards to the next player. Some cards generate resources and others require those resources but generate victory points. Some cards can give you cash and there are also cards that as you have more in a set give increasing amounts of victory points. There are also military cards and these are needed to keep up with your neighbor. It is also possible to buy resources from your neighbors. I like that the game seems fairly simple to learn, but offers various paths to victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Fast and fun, 7 Wonders lends itself to repeated plays if only to play out the "what if" scenarios. Having dominated one game with a military strategy, only to have it fail miserably the second time, I can appreciate the ability and the need to adapt your strategy based not only on the cards that are available, but also to the actions of your neighbours. To that end, the game feels more controlled with 3 players, as you can try to counteract what your competition is doing. Beyond that, and there are one or more players that you will have no influence on - a limitation that can be at times both exciting and infuriating. Ultimately (and, as always, with the right group) 7 Wonders ends up being a surprisingly fulfilling yet still wonderfully short and fast game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I've played this exclusively with 4 players in a family-type setting, but I've quite enjoyed it.  We've played a lot of Sushi Go over the years, so we're well prepared for the drafting aspect of it, and I like having something (a little) more meaty to put on top of the drafting.

My son picked up the game very quickly - as with other tableau / engine builders he doesn't really worry too much about what other people are doing, he just wants to build cool stuff.  So far, that means you can count on him rushing the Wonders or Military, but I'm sure that as we get more plays he'll change it up to focus on Science or Cash or whatever.  

This will definitely be getting more plays, and I'll have to revisit.  I'm also curious how it plays with differently sized groups.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders has grown on me more than any other 2010 release. Went up from an intial 7/10 to 9/10.
---
7 Wonders topped out all the Dominion clones as the buzz game of the Spiel 2010 in Essen. To be fair, it's not one of them. It's more a full-blown boardgame version of Fairy Tale coupled with the desire to design the ultimate 30 minute civ light game of building up your tech tree. The surprise is that it's successful at conveying that you are building a civilization in this short time! Combine this with the ability to host 7 players as well as a good accessibility for new players and you have a clear winner - even for people like me that are not to keen on engine building games where knowledge of each card is vital for good play. It's not as deep and varied as Dominion though and probably not as expandable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE - 2 Sept 16 Still love this game. Awesome. Don't like the Cities expansion much but really like the Leaders expansion. Still a 10. This game has real staying power. Now own 7 Wonders: Duel and that is equally brilliant. Great to be able to play a 2 player game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Love the tension of card drafting--perfect mix of strategic planning with just enough randomness to keep you on your toes. Scales from 3 to 7 players effortlessly; with 3 or 4 players, it's a tight, strategic battle, but as the player count rises, the game opens up and feels more random and casual (which is generally ideal for larger groups).
Definitely a gateway+ game since it takes longer to explain than the typical gateway game, and since the game builds up over 3 ages, it takes a play or two to understand how choices in the early game affect the later game. However, once new players get the hang of the iconography and flow of the game, it's easy to play (and get to the table).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Brillante!!!. No la había jugado y no veo la hora de volverlo a jugar. En compañía de mi familia.
los componetes son muy bien logrados y la ilustración muy bonita.
El desarrollo del juego es bastante ágil y la mecánica utilizada de rotación de mazos hace que la planeación a futuro sea difícil ya que en el próximo turno de ese mazo es posible que no encuentres la carta deseada. 
Quizás uno de los juegos que mejora con la inclusión de mas jugadores.
Proximo objetivo conseguir las expansiones con el objetivo de completar la serie de 7 Wonders. Pero hay que resaltar que el juego por si solo es demasiado completo y de alta rejugabilidad.
valoración inicial 10

RATING: 10

In addition to that, it's also just a fun novel citybuilder with player-interaction (competitive and not), a great theme and the feeling of actually building up a marvelous civilization. Sadly, there's not that many cards, so after a while you feel you've seen it all.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very quick game, which is easy to learn. Nevertheless, it has enough different paths to the victory. Interesting aspects are buying resources from neighbours and also the cards with rewards depending on the results of neighbours too. In other words, it is not enough to look at your own board only. It is essential to know, what your neighbours are doing, what cards do they need and what cards could be used to your advantage.

Itin greitas ir lengvai perprantamas žaidimas. Be to, turintis pakankamai nemažai skirtingų kelių į pergalę. Įdomus resursų pirkimo iš kolegų aspektas, taip pat kortelės, kurios duoda efektą priklausomai ir nuo kaimynų rezultatų. Kitaip sakant, neužtenka žiūrėti vien tik į savo lenta, reikia domėtis ir tuo, ką veikia kaimynai, kokių kortų jiems geriau būtų nesiųsti, o kokias lengvai galima panaudoti savo naudai.

2. It's simple to explain to new players.
3. There are a lot of ways to win.

RATING: 5
The resource system seems to be there to ensure errors are made, and makes it just too much for it to be a true gateway or a truly quick game. Most of the high scoring cards being based on your neighbors' cities means that what you do matters little compared to capitalizing on what they do. Military is a false interaction, where actually focusing on it is terrible strategy: if you have to invest a lot, you're losing ground compared to all non-neighboring players.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This was an initial hit with my group but we've cooled on it significantly.  The mechanic of passing hands is certainly unique and interesting.  Frankly though it feels like the same game every time I play.  Get resource cards early, try to get sets of green, maybe go for war cards depending on what your neighbors do.  Ho hum.  The leader addition adds some to the game but honestly not enough to make the game feel any different.  Honestly, and I can't explain why, many people I've played with just can't grasp the cost of cards and can't figure out how the card hierarchies work.  I find myself constantly playing rules police which greatly takes away from my enjoyment of the game and probably takes away from the enjoyment of everyone else as well.  I haven't cooled enough on it to let it go but at the same time I haven't been suggesting it for play anymore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
On the one hand, it's a very fast game. On the other hand, it's... a very fast game. You do the old resource acquisition/victory points conversion routine, and then you look up and see whether someone else got a better deal, and whether your suboptimal plays intended to curb the guy next to you were in any way worthwhile, and whether the other guy next to you similarly managed to screw himself and you. Some cards will be hideously effective in the right position (and useless to the person charged with keeping them from getting there), while others are a crapshoot. I think this might belong to a category of games that just don't interest me that much (San Juan, Saint Petersburg, Dominion), but I'd play it again to make sure. It is after all a very fast game.

First impressions confirmed: I am not good at this and I don't care to be. But it's very fast.

Later impressions: It is in fact better with few players. Adding more dilutes the draft and means you will be competing against random scores across the table you have no meaningful relation to. Can be a 6 with two or three; can be a 4 with five or more. Still very fast.

Last (?) impressions: A 7 with three, deduct one point for each player above or below.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
I find myself entirely disengaged from this game, in part because the theme seems entirely irrelevant. It feels like a messy, contrived and inefficient way of collecting cards. As a consequence I just sit and wait for my turn, with no interaction with anyone, and hope than nobody suffers from too much AP, or tries too hard to calculate what some other player has scored so far. I never care whether I win or lose or what is happening to my collection of cards. I understand that there’s some skill involved, but for me there is just too much luck and not enough strategy – the fact that I won my first game against 2 very experienced players is enough for me to never want to play again. With larger groups the luck increases and there's less and less reason to hold onto any card that doesn’t directly help you.

The best way to increase your chances of winning this game would be to have a perfect memory. Since I don’t care about it enough to try to remember the cards, the probability of me winning is a random function of the actions of the other players, coupled with my own rather haphazard decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nearly perfect.  I mean it...absolutely perfect, for what I look for/need in a game.

It handles up to 7!!!  In a quick and streamlined fashion. (Although you lose a lot of "control" over the game and its outcome...)
It offers tons of choices.
It's expandable (which I eagerly anticipate).
It's portable.
It's fast to set-up, play and re-play.

Only niggle is that :
1) it is easy to make mistakes during scoring (there's just a lot to keep track of)>  So, everyone help each other with your scores and all should be fine.  

2) it's a tad luck driven depending on seating arrangement, Wonder draw, Guild draw, etc.  But it plays so quick it doesn't truly affect the score imo.
If you have a rash of bad luck, just play again!
 :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With 6-7 players it's pretty light and easy to teach other players usually can't hurt each other too badly, which is usually a good thing with larger groups.  

With 3-4 players it's very strategic and filled with meaningful decisions, usually a good thing with smaller groups.

The art is beautiful, the game plays quickly the system is clean and easy to understand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
7 wonders is a very good game:

PROS

1. It is popular with lighter gamers even though it has a fair amount of depth to satisfy more involved gamers
2. It is efficiently paced, never drags.
3. you are allowed to be clever, and the game rewards you well for good decisions. 
4. very rare to to be done over by luck if you are a good player.

CONS

1. Easy for a player who doesn't know what he's doing to frustrate someone who does know what he's doing through unbalancing the game dynamic, so can get annoying.
2. First few plays will be a bit uninvolving because you do need to generally know the cards to get into it properly and enjoy it/work out a strategy
3. Depth goes to a point, after which there is nothing left, therefore not top 10 material. Once you hit the glass ceiling (takes a fair few games, so lots of life there) it gives you an empty feeling and becomes a game you dont mind playing and enjoy but would not really go out of your way to play particularly...

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I like 7 Wonders. I don't love it. The casual gamers I know like it far more than I do, likely because of two key virtues. One is that it's a 30-40 minute civ game, when most of them take several hours. The other is that the drafting and simultaneous selection minimizes downtime. I don't find the game sufficiently deep to hold my interest. There isn't enough opportunity to carry out strategies with a high level of confidence, or develop creative strategies based on what other players do. I rarely think "next time I'll try this approach." Games that make me think about my next play always rate higher in my books, and 7 Wonders falls short in this regard. Even so, I enjoy playing 7 Wonders because people I enjoy spending time with love playing it. That's the main reason it will remain in my collection. The expansions have added some interesting elements, but not enough to change my overall rating. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.6

RATING: 7.5
This gets a lot of play based on the short length, and scalability from 3-7 players.  You only get ~18 cards to play each game, so practically every decision point is agonizing.  It is a game of almost pure tactics, with very little long term strategy.  Also, for a game straddling the "gateway/family" line, it can be difficult to teach to newbies.  This is the reason I haven't ventured into any of the expansions, since I frequently find myself playing this with first timers.  

approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  25+

RATING: 8

Easy to get to the table for people with more than passing interest in gaming, but unsuccessful with game-resistant family members. Hasn't come to the table super recently (only because we've tended toward newer games in our collection), but likely to make its way back to the Top 5 once the new game smell wears off. The companion app is well worth the effort - scoring is by far one of the most tedious parts of the game and the app streamlines scoring and logs plays well. Haven't yet used the app-specific civ, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I'd say this game is about a 7, but easily gains an extra point for being the best filler, period.  I'd give it 8.5, even.

This game is simply a must-have.

No matter who, what, when or how, you can always get a game going.  You can play with gamers or casual players alike, or even people who have never even played games before.  You can play with 2 to 7 players and you can explain the rules in about 5 o 10 minutes.  It plays under an hour, no matter the number of players.  Again, it is simply the perfect filler.

But let's be honest, gamers will not enjoy this one as much.  A lot of luck is involved in the draft (especially in the 3rd phase), the quality of your neighbors, and the purple cards.  It can be a bit frustrating for the hardcore gamer who feels played a good game, but loses nonetheless.  But generally not enough to refuse to play.  However, it makes the experience for the casual gamer extremely pleasant.

We pretty much always end our boardgame nights with a game or two of Seven Wonders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The genius of this game doesn't become apparent until you've played a few games. Now that we've all mastered the mechanics it has become the favourite game in our house (2 adults, 2 children of game playing age).

RATING: 5
Not seeing the wonder here.  As far as family games go, this is not one I would spring on non-gaming family or friends.  It plays quickly because of simultaneous action resolution, i.e. the drafting mechanic, but with no sense of joy and no feeling of connection to the other players that you typically get from playing the best "gateway" board games with non-gamers or lighter-style gamers.  
I've had far more fun and more social experiences playing Settlers (if they think fondly of Monopoly), Ticket to Ride (if they like traditional card games) or Bohananza (if they like games at all and humorous haggling, basically).

RATING: 9
What can be said about 7 Wonders that hasn't already been said? It's a wonderful (dohoho) drafting game that focuses on equal parts points engine and opponent screwing. 7 Wonders plays fast and offers plenty of options to attain victory, but does focus heavily on iconography which may be a bit challenging to new players. However, it's intuitive enough that most players will want to play time and time again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The real deal when it comes to "civ-lite" - almost to the point of being super-lite given the short playing time. But in spite of how quick the game is to play, there's a good deal of strategy and tactics packed in, and you really do have some sense of building up an ancient city over hundreds of years of history. Once you're set up you can easily play several hands in a matter of a couple hours, and while the cards are generally the same your hand from turn to turn will always be different, giving you different difficult choices every game. A solidly designed game, and I only wish the cards were stronger so they didn't need sleeving.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
