:star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star::star: (50 plays October 2015)
This is the game goes well with any level of board gamers. The beginners can learn how to play the game after one play through and then they will continue to learn the real fun part of this game play after play from that point on.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Includes the Expansions:
7 Wonders: Catan (English/German first edition)
7 Wonders: Cities (English first edition) (2012)
7 Wonders: Leaders (Repos Production English First Edition)
7 Wonders: Wonder Pack (Multilingual first edition) (2013)

The tower part of the Babel expansion quickly got old. In a game where you only play 18 cards, having something that can change the rules to the extent that you are stopped dead in your tracks is too much grief to bear. I had to ditch that expansion.

7 Wonders is a good light card drafting game with a ton of expansions. The problem is, people suggest it whenever we have six or seven players, and that is the worst version of the game. By far, the base game is best with three players, since you will actually get to see the cards you pass to other players come back to you twice. Also, warfare plays a more significant role when you border the only other players.

I have also been having a lot of fun with the Cities expansion, and I definitely prefer that version of the game. Diplomacy further marginalizes warfare, but that's OK, as it gives you cards you can easily use to build stages of your wonder. I'm not sure the three player game works with Diplomacy, simply because it can completely destroy a military player's engine. But then again, with Cities you get to play another card, so four players becomes a great option for 7 Wonders + Cities.

Another bonus to 7 Wonders is the fact that it works beautifully as a family game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Great game

RATING: 8.5
[b]Purchase/Selling History: [/b]
Bought with Brynn at Millenium I think? '13?
Sold to Millenium 1/2018 for 7 Wonders Duel, Pantheon exp. and Mystic Vale: Mana Storm

[b]Rating: 8.5[/b]
[i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4[/b]
[i]Component rating[/i]: [b]1[/b]
[i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]
[i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b] (+.5)

[b]Player considerations:[/b]
Have played with 2-5 I think and with all games like this I love more players, especially since military is more spread out then. Don’t like as much with 2 players.

[b]My thoughts:[/b]
Somewhat simple/repetitive, but I love the addition of leaders to the game to create a more unified strategy. Also science seems like the way to go if you want to win more often than not and with leaders it can become way powerful. Great replayability despite how little variation there is with the cards-thanks to the drafting and wonder board element.

RATING: 6
Love drafting mechanics. Great replayability with the multiple different boards and 2 sides for each. Game is extremely better the more people you have. The game is just heavy enough that it feels like a full game, but can easily be played in just under 30 minutes with experienced players. Easy to learn, set-up, and can play multiple times in one night. Game has gone down over the past two years. Not interested in playing without expansions.

RATING: 8

I tend to favor the straightforward accumulation of buildings that provide VP (blue) and completing my wonder.  But I've played the game enough to be able to branch out into tech (green), military (red) and/or other mechanisms depending on what everyone else in the game is trying to do.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Solid fast civ game that plays up to 7 players and you will want to play again immediately afterwards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Slightly more than a “gateway,” this popular drafting game has a lot to like. Plays up to 7 players (although I like it with 3-4 much better), plays in about 30 minutes with experienced players and appears to involve meaningful decisions all result in a good all-purpose game for most collections. Despite this, I consider it well within the “filler” category and do not take more seriously than it deserves. As with many card games, your choices may be obvious depending on what cards you get. Also, your neighbor’s actions can influence your outcome as much as your own. With random Guild distribution, the luck of the draw can determine if your path will be a successful one or not. Also, some wonders appear to be better than others under certain situations. Nevertheless, I find it a fun game to play. I am often more interested in trying a certain strategy or achieving a certain score and less concerned if I end up winning or losing.

Отличная драфт-игра для больших (до 7-и игроков) и малых компаний. Простые правила, минимальная продолжительность игры (30-60 минут, которые практически не зависят от кол-ва игроков), чувство удовлетворения от сотворения чего-то своего - всё тут есть.

Дополнения немного меняют игру, но в целом делают её ещё лучше и насыщенней. Повысил рейтинг до 9/10.

RATING: 8
Great card drafting game. A bit dry with 3 players, and a bit too luck-driven with 7, but great with other numbers. I prefer 5, but both 4 and 6 work well. Interaction is indirect, but constant: you have to continuously keep in mind what your neighbours are doing, as you are affected and can affect them in multiple ways.

RATING: 8
Very creative and inventive. Taking the drafting mechanic created by CCGs like Magic The Gathering, and making a game around it. The only thing that I suggest about this game is do not judge it based on one play. The first time you play it you are more or less playing to learn how cards work, and what you need to focus on. After that first play the game becomes much easier, and you really start to feel like you know what you want to do with the game. The only true gripe I have is not with the game itself, but with the rules. The rule book is kind of dry  and a little bit confusing. To be honest I learned to play this by watching a how to play video. Other then that though wonderful game and truely a modern day gem.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Everyone I talked to at BGG.CON really liked this.  I briefly saw people playing it and wasn't that excited, but then talking to arkibet at the airport afterward convinced me to take another look.

[b]Update:[/b] bought this as a birthday present for myself.  8 games so far, 3-6 players, I haven't won once.  I've been beaten by 8-year-olds, first-time players, and people who don't even [i]like[/i] games.  THIS GAME IS BROKEN

[b]Update after 45 plays:[/b] everyone in my family will play this (including my wife, who generally hates games), so that's good... [i]but,[/i] this game is "just OK" to me.  (The Leaders expansion improves it significantly, as it gives you more long-range goals than "well, I'm Babylon, so I guess I'm going science.")  Normally you get to make 18 decisions per game, and as the player count goes up, you have less information on which to base those decisions, so gameplay is mostly seeing whether the cards go your way.

(Several times now we've had games where someone's gotten hosed--being unable to finish, or even [i]start,[/i] their wonder because other players are burying the cards they need, or because they just got unlucky--and this can make the game not-so-fun for that person, because there's nothing they could have done to prevent it.  At least the game is short...)

So, I like that it's simple and approachable and scales to many players (and I think it's fine 2-player with the "free city" rules included in the game), [i]but[/i] it's so light that it's basically filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

This happened at Christmas where I taught 4 others how to play before Tea when we had one game, they then wanted to play a second time after tea. This is actually a rare occurence with most games (immediate replay request) and says something about its initial appeal. Don't know if it will stay the distance - I will probably get browned off with it after the 4th expansion set......

RATING: 7
Good game. 7 Wonders is a quite abstract (theme is just pasted up), but it doesn't mean the game is bad. It actually offers lot to do and no downtime WHICH mixed with the short playing time MEANS that the game works. There are some issues too: very small icons (and unnecessary big pictures) in cards which makes it a bit too hard to really get the overall situation clear. Another minus is, that every game feels a bit same than previous ones, because you play every game with the same cards (and use almost all of them). But still... yes, 7 Wonders is one of the best games released 2010 although it's far from GREAT. Vut sometimes all you need is a game, which you are play again and again... and I'm happy to play this game every now and then! ;)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In essence, 7 Wonders is a card development game. Some cards have immediate effects, while others provide bonuses or upgrades later in the game. Some cards provide discounts on future purchases. Some provide military strength to overpower your neighbors and others give nothing but victory points. Each card is played immediately after being drafted, so you'll know which cards your neighbor is receiving and how his choices might affect what you've already built up. Cards are passed left-right-left over the three ages, so you need to keep an eye on the neighbors in both directions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Impressive card drafting game that weirdly feels like a cross between Fairy Tales (drafting, scoring) & Catan (resources).  Also somewhat reminiscent of Glory to Rome with cleaner & faster play.  Very fast with impressive depth & strategy given the short length.  Scales ridiculously well, supporting up to 7 players with gameplay that remains consistently interactive for all (since all play simultaneously).  A must have.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The concept is interesting, it is one of the few card drafting games that I enjoyed to play. One of the reason why is because the memory aspect is not very important. You don't need to remember what are the cards in circulation like in fairy tales.

The problems in this game is that as the game progress it gets much slower and annoying. At the beginning of the game, you follow you instincts and what you need. But as you progress through the game, all cards have resources requirements, which requires more calculation. 

And then at the 3rd age, everything gives points. So you are always trying to calculate the Victory point generated by every card in your hand to know what is the most valuable card. So it now becomes just long, annoying and not fun to calculate.

Else, I would say the the game play is pretty simple and ingenious, and I quite like the fact that you can use adjacent player's resources by paying them.

In general, It's a relatively good game. I would not mind playing it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
FTL Secret Santa 2010.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
LIKES:

* Plays 3-7 equally well but with a bit of a different flavor.  However, I find I prefer 3-4 player counts to allow for some potential planning ahead knowing you'll get some cards back from your starting hand.
* Each monument has different special abilities which bring some LIMITED extra replayability.
* Several viable different ways exist to score and win.
* I enjoy the card drafting element that is central to the game.
* Makes an excellent filler that plays in 20-30 minutes and is easily and quickly taught.

DISLIKES:

* Each person's display takes up a lot of table space.
* Lacks many interesting decisions.  
* I do have some concern about replayability as the game may feel samey after a while.  However, there are allegedly expansions coming out which may help provide difference in play.  This is not a deep game by any stretch.  After 8 plays, I am feeling a good bit more "meh" about this game.  I expect to keep it around since it is easy to teach and understand for people and plays 7, but this isn't one I expect to be clamoring to play very often.

RATING MOVEMENT:  9 -> 8 -> 6
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My family really enjoys this game.  The turns in this game are the best I have seen  as everyone's turn happens at the same time.  This really reduces any downtime and makes this game fun and quick to play.  There are also many ways to win, so it is a blast to try new strategies.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Heten játszottuk, ebből egyvalaki ismerte csak előzetesen a játékot. A szabályokat az első játék alatt teljesen sikerült megérteni, szóval könnyen tanulható. Ha a tanulást leszámítjuk, elég pörgős, gyors játék, szerintem nem nagyon lehet 3/4 óránál tovább elhúzni. Minden cselekedet párhuzamosan történik, emiatt egyáltalán nincs benne holtidő, amikor várni kellene a többi játékosra.

A játék alatt mindenki építgeti a saját csodáját, és ha nem lenne elég nyersanyag hozzá, a két szomszédos játékossal lehet kereskedni (ez a kereskedés nem igényel interakciót: egyszerűen odaadod neki a cucc árát, és ennyi (a nyersanyagok nem materializálódott formában léteznek), azaz ha valaki kereskedik veled, akkor ezt abból veszed észre, hogy odarak eléd néhány pénzérmét).
A többi játékossal való kapcsolat kimerül tehát a kereskedésben és abban, hogy próbálsz a lehetséges lapok közül olyat beépíteni a csodádba, amire vagy neked van nagy szükséged, vagy amire a melletted ülő játékosnak lenne, ám te éppen ezért elhasználod előle. A nem közvetlenül melletted ülőkre csak még közvetettebb módon lehet hatni: felhasználni olyan lapot, ami majd két vagy több kör múlva neki nagyon jól jönne... De ezzel nem nagyon foglalkozik szerintem senki, csak a közvetlen szomszédaival és önmagával.

Interaktív elem a játékban tehát alig akad, de mégis sokat kell figyelni a közvetlen szomszédok lépéseit, nem lehet csak magunkra figyelve játszani (vagyis lehet, de tuti nem fogunk nyerni).

Mikre kell figyelni?
1. A saját haderőmre a szomszédaiméhoz viszonyítva (ha erősebb vagyok, plusz pontot kapok, ha gyengébb, mínuszat).
2. A nyersanyagforrásaimra: szinte biztos, hogy legalább egyvalami hiányozni fog, amit a szomszédjaimtól kell majd beszereznem kereskedéssel. Érdemes tehát olyan nyersanyagforrásokat beépíteni a csodánkba, hogy a szomszédjainkéval együtt teljes legyen a paletta.
3. Figyelni kell a technikai mérföldkövekre: saját részre ugyanabból a típusból minél többet összegyűjteni, de a szomszédjaimnak minél kevesebb összegyűjtésére módot adni. Ennél a pontnál érdemes az összes játékos csodáját figyelemmel kísérni, hiszen láthatjuk, hogy az egyes technikai vívmánytípusokat hányan gyűjtik - ha sokan, inkább másik gyűjtésébe érdemes belekezdeni.
4. Sok speciális kártya is van, amik szintén a szomszédjaim lerakott lapjaitól függően juttatnak engem különböző előnyökhöz.

A játék nagyon sokrétű, ez a pontozásnál jól látszik. Mindenkit 6-7 szempont alapján pontozni kell, és e részpontok összege lesz az adott játékos végső pontszáma. Sok pontot lehet szerezni a technikai vívmányok összegyűjtéséből. Sokat ha a seregem nagyobb a szomszédaiménál. Sok összegyűlhet, ha közvetlenül győzelmi pontokat építek a csodámba. Ha a játék végén marad pénzem, az is pontot ér. A sok speciális lap is pontokat ér, a legkülönbözőbb dolgokért lehet velük pontokat szerezni. És akkor egy csomó minden van még, ami most épp nem jut eszembe...

Szóval gyakorlatilag bármit csinálok, pontokat fogok kapni érte. Ha sikerül jobb kombinációkat összehozni, az sok pontot ér.

A játékban a fő döntési helyzet az, hogy az adott körben a legfeljebb 7 lehetőség közül melyiket válasszam beépíteni a csodámba. Ez gyakran nagy dilemmát okoz. Egy kevésbé fontos másodlagos döntési helyzet pedig az, hogy ha mindkét szomszédommal tudok kereskedni, akkor melyiküket válasszam, azaz melyiküket erősítsem a pénzemmel. Egyéb döntési helyzet nincs, de az elsőként leírt tényleg súlyos döntés, hiszen azzal határozom meg, hogy mit csinálok az adott körben - el lehet rajta gondolkozni rendesen, és tipikus, hogy háromszor is meggondolja magát mindenki, miközben kiválasztja a lapot magának.

A játék szinte teljesen nyelvfüggetlen. Néhány csodához tartozik egy egymondatos speciális képesség, ami szövegesen van megfogalmazva, de ez egyáltalán nem okoz nehézséget. Minden mást szimbólumok jelölnek, amik kifejezetten könnyen megjegyezhetőek, egyszerűek. tehát egyedül a szabálykönyv elolvasása igényel nyelvtudást, a játékelemekre lehet mondani, hogy nem.

A játékélmény: pozitív. A főbb tapasztalataim: könnyen tanulható, gyors, folyamatos és valódi döntéseket igénylő játék (azaz nem csak báb a játékos, akinek mindig pontosan tudható, hogy mi az optimális lépése, hanem ténylegesen az ő kezében a döntés a jövőjéről). Tetszik, és akarok vele máskor is játszani! Úgy érzem a további játékok vele növelni fogják a rá adott pontszámomat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[u]Comments:[/u]
I don't know why I waited so long to try 7 Wonders, and its not that actively avoiding trying it, but when I finally did get to play i thoroughly enjoyed every second of it. This game fits right in my wheel house for what I enjoy and look for in a game. Multiple strategic paths to choose from, quick playtime, ease of understanding for new players, and difficult choices all mark this as something that I need to have in my collection. I played my first game with both the Cities and Leaders expansions and that may have been a little bit too much for first time players in terms of iconography in the game, but with quick summaries on the rulebooks even those were not a problem most of the game. This game is simply a fun, and I can't wait until I can play it again.

RATING: 8.1
Love this game, have played it with many different people and it's always a winner!

RATING: 8.5
4-7p

2p variant:

8p variants:

1/  With 7 Wonders base set and Leaders exp. (Catan Island promo board)
Note: Due to limited numbers of cards, Catan Island B cannot be played at the same time as Hanging Gardens B.

SETUP:
1. Remove the blue Pawnshop (7+) card from Age I. Use all of the other cards.
2. Remove the yellow Bazar (7+) card from Age II. Use all of the other cards.
3. Choose 8 guild cards and shuffle them into Age III. Set the other guild cards aside. We will use them later.
4. Use every leader card. Semiramis is required. If you do not have a rule set aside for her, I would recommend: "Cost: 3 Coins. Power: Semiramis can learn from her defeats. Every negative military token acquired counts as one war power for the upcoming ages."

GAMEPLAY
1. During Age 0 (choosing leaders), deal 4 cards to every player, and build your Leader deck as normal (take one, pass to your right). This should use 32/36 cards.
2. In each Age, deal 6 cards to each player. Instead of the normal rule, where you choose between 2 cards on your last turn and discard the unused card, you will only have one card to play.
3. Play as normal, following the rules for the Leader expansion.

CHANGES TO WONDER/CARD ABILITIES
1. Colosseum B, 1st Stage - Draw 3 Leader Cards instead of 4
2. Hanging Garden B, 2nd Stage - Draw one more Leader. You may immediately play an extra Leader Card from your hand by paying the usual cost. (This is the same ability as Catan Island B, Stage 1)
3. Mausoleum A, 2nd Stage; Mausoleum B, all 3 Stages; Solomon Leader Card - Choose one other player, and look at the cards they used for their Wonder stages. Choose one of the cards and immediately play it for free. Replace that card with one of the unused cards (pawnshop, bazar, or the 2 extra guilds).

---------------------------------------------------------

2/  With 7 Wonders base set and Catan Island promo board.

SETUP:
1. Remove the blue Pawnshop (7+) card from Age I. Use all of the other cards.
2. Remove the yellow Bazar (7+) card from Age II. Use all of the other cards.
3. Choose 8 guild cards and shuffle them into Age III. Set the other guild cards aside. We will use them later.

GAMEPLAY
1. In each Age, deal 6 cards to each player. Instead of the normal rule, where you choose between 2 cards on your last turn and discard the unused card, you will only have one card to play.

CHANGES TO WONDER/CARD ABILITIES
1. Hanging Garden B - Not playable.
2. Catan Island B - Not playable.
3. Mausoleum A, 2nd Stage; Mausoleum B, all 3 Stages - Choose one other player, and look at the cards they used for their Wonder stages. Choose one of the cards and immediately play it for free. Replace that card with one of the unused cards (pawnshop, bazar, or the 2 extra guilds).

---------------------------------------------------------

Variante pour Leaders:

Draft L02

Chaque joueur reçoit 5 cartes Leaders, en défausse 1 (face cachée) avant de passer les 4 cartes restantes à son voisin de droite. Le draft se poursuit alors comme L01 et chaque joueur se retrouve donc avec 4 cartes Leaders pour débuter la partie.

Draft L03

Chaque joueur reçoit 5 cartes Leaders. Le draft se déroule comme L01 mais quand les joueurs reçoivent 2 cartes de leur voisin, il en choisissent une et la deuxième est défaussée (face cachée). Chaque joueur se retrouve donc avec 4 cartes Leaders pour débuter la partie.

Précision pour L02 et L03 : si vous jouez à 7 joueurs, vous avez besoin de 7 x 5 = 35 Leaders à distribuer sans compter les Leaders supplémentaires que nécessitent le plateau « Rome » et éventuellement le plateau « Bruxelles » (A) s’il est placé à côté de « Rome ». Pour éviter la pénurie, les Leaders défaussés lors du draft (L02 et L03) réintègrent la pioche et peuvent être réutilisés par « Rome » et « Bruxelles » durant la partie.

---------------------------------------------------------

RATING: 8
Really great game, and the best in its category. There's a reason every drafting and set collecting game is inevitably compared to 7 Wonders, and it's not just because it was one of the first designer games to be successful with the mechanics, but because it's still the best at employing those mechanics. The expansions make this game even better, with more replayability and even tougher decision making.

RATING: 7
This game will be a fantastic experience for a group of gamers who know it well and are competitive when playing. The general game play mechanic is sound and the paths to victory are balanced. Problems lie in the flooding of iconography for new players, who never seem to really know what's going on until near the end of the first game. If they are willing to play another then all is well but most that I have played with were not interested enough for a repeat play. There seems to be some issues with components quality too, with the insert inside the (stupidly oversized) box useless and the cards wearing very quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A Race for the Galaxy light, that can be relatively easily played with new players.  A little faster than Race, a little less downtime (the choices and combinations are more obvious).  A hit with the family (one of the few times were J or E asked for another game).  Since I love Race, but E does not like it so much, 7 Wonders is a keeper, that fills the role of a challenging-enough fast game (30+ minutes).

I do not find the interaction much more interesting than in Race.  In particular, the social interaction is not much more present.  In both games, I spend about as much time thinking about what my opponent are doing than in Race.

Rules: I forgot quite a few rules, up to my 3rd play (at least).  I don't remember having so many problems with Race, whose rules are maybe a little more streamlined and natural.  Rules I missed up to my 3rd play:
1) I forgot the change in the rotation direction between Ages.
2) I missed the rules that resources can only be bought from wonders+brown+grey cards (not from the yellow, commercial cards, which represent interior markets).
3) I missed the rule that earned coins cannot be used immediately. For instance, they should be put *between* players and collected along with the cards passed along (or by themselves, for coins passed in the reverse direction). 
4) I missed the rules that cards must be played face down before any action is started.

RATING: 8
[b]Wonderfully scalable card drafting game that plays super fast for a large group.[/b]
r{[i]7 Wonders is a good, quick microcosm of a civ game.[/i]}r

SYNOPSIS
Players start with unique resources and goals for building the wonder on their player boards. Then the card drafting begins. Each opportunity to pick a card provides good decision points throughout the game such as when to gather resources or build out with the resources currently available, when to choose a favorable card for oneself or remove from your opponent's reach a powerful card for them, when to build up military or science knowing that it will affect how those around you draft their cards thereafter. Finances are a concern to manage well all throughout. Each age ends with a concise battle for which one can prepare by building up defenses or attacks. There are different routes to victory including through use of military, science and culture cards.

COMMENTS
Often this game's ability to scale extremely well from 2-7 (8 with Cities expansion) without adding much to play time is given as one of its positives, but I'll also add the game play itself is noteworthy. It does an admirable job of mimicking civ building by way of card drafting. Plus it does so elegantly and quickly.

PROS+, CONS- & NOTES*
+ Tons of variety and replayability with this one.
- Focused reliance on immediate neighbors during game play results in lack of interaction or concern for other opponents.
* I recommend checking the math of neighboring opponents for accountability. Honest mistakes can happen if left unchecked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Mechanics of simultaneous game play works well for keeping kids involved, as compared to turn based strategy games.
The many different game elements and complex scoring model makes optimal strategic play too cumbersome for the fast action the format creates socially.  So best for groups to play more socially than competitively.  In other words, make a reasonable choice quickly instead of looking for optimal choice and everyone will have more fun.

RATING: 8
This was my [url=http://www.daveexmachina.com/wordpress/?p=4805]Game of the Year[/url] for 2010. It looks like a chaotic mess, but it’s super easy to teach and pick up, and it plays lightning fast. Out of the box there are lots of different ways to approach it and mix things up a bit, and it can be easily expanded. It scales easily from three to seven players, and since the action is more or less simultaneous, adding more players doesn’t increase downtime. Everyone I’ve played it with has enjoyed it and been up for another game of it immediately afterwards.

RATING: 5
I'm not sure how to rate 7 Wonders. It's so much fun to play, and yet at the same time it's just not all that much depth to it. 

And yet, I'm hard pressed to name any game that plays up to seven people in about half an hour that's actually interesting. I guess time is really the key point here; no matter how badly you might be doing, it'll be over soon. And you can just play again. 

Or to paraphrase a friend of mine:
I don't feel bad about losing; I can't imagine feeling good about winning; I make some decisions, am informed of a result, and go about my day.

RATING: 9



=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
We had been curious about [thing=68448][/thing], especially after all of the attention that it had garnered when it was released.  It sounded almost like a holy grail---this was a game with good decisions and great artwork that scaled from 2-7 players.  How could you not have it in your collection?  So when we found it for a good price, we ended up getting a copy (as well as a copy for my sister).

When my sister visited over the holiday break, we took the three player game for a spin.  I think part of the hype of [thing=68448][/thing] is justified.  It's a very attractive game with great artwork.  My wife and I always enjoy these types of tableau-building games, so we felt more or less at home already.  However, it's still fairly easy to pick up and almost ventures into gateway game territory---my sister is not a hardcore gamer, but she was able to enjoy the game pretty quickly.  At least in the three player game, there's some nice interaction with the card drafting and you have to pay attention to everyone's tableau.  I wasn't a big fan of the iconography (some of them still remain a little confusing to me), but it was still an enjoyable game.  I can see how it would work with more as well.

However, after my sister left, my wife and I broke this out for just the two of us.  Generally, we don't mind dummy players too much---we enjoy [thing=6249][/thing] and [thing=66188][/thing], but the dummy player in both of those games is relatively easy to use.  In [thing=68448][/thing], the dummy player mechanic felt needlessly complicated.  Instead of just looking at your own tableau, you now had to look at the dummy player, so it felt like you were playing two boards.  Instead of just dumping cards, you had to consider all of the options that the dummy player could actually build, which actually took us a little bit of time to calculate all of the available resources, which card would benefit us more than our opponent, etc.  All of this was on top of the same type pf calculations you had to do for your own tableau.  Perhaps it will get better over time, but it felt like too much effort.  

If it was just the two of us, we would probably pass on [thing=68448][/thing], but it's a good game to keep in the collection when more people are over.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Strategy vs luck: I think there's a good balance here.  There's definitely a lot of strategy, and the strategy involves what the people next to you are doing a lot, and what the general populous is doing as well (if everyone is going for green cards, then you should definitely not do that strategy, for instance).  But there's also quite a bit of luck, to the point that you can't be guaranteed that the best player always wins.  So I wish the strategy-to-luck ratio were a little bit higher...but hey, this is a gateway game to eurogames, so I don't really consider that a serious problem.  Just a quibble.

And then there's the best part of the game: the drafting mechanic.  It makes the game even more interactive because you're thinking about what you're going to give your opponents.  This might be the best game with the drafting mechanic although it's not the first.

There are multiple paths to victory, but I've noticed that a lot of the time, the person who won had to get VPs from almost every category to do so.  Not all the time though; I just witnessed a winner do it from basically only 3 categories.  So again, that's a quibble.

Replayability: good.  Even without the expansions I've played this many times and not had issue.  I can always go for different hybrid strategies and there are not only 7 wonders, but two sides to each wonder, which each play differently.  Combine that with the fact that I'm dealt different cards each round so no hand will ever be the same, and you have pretty high replayability.  There's also slightly different compositions of cards for different numbers of players.  

Now I will say, replayability isn't perfect because after all, you're pretty much always just building cards.  But that's where the expansions come in; I just played Babel and it's great.  It adds extra options for each turn and gives me a chance to add even more strategy to the mix.  

Are all the paths to victory balanced?  Well, sort of.  But again, it really matters on what people around you are doing.  You could waste a lot of turns on a war with your neighbor to have more red cards.  Or you could waste time doing green cards when other people are also doing them and decreasing what's available for you to score big.  So, while a couple of types of cards are oftentimes stronger, it's very situational, and I like that.  It basically means that this game doesn't have to worry about being extremely well-balanced.  (And from the best I can tell, they are fairly balanced btw.  Maybe reds are a little less than others.)

Theme: I feel the theme pretty strongly, mostly because of the art.  Every card has good art on it and your boards are really nice panoramas.  Now I will say, do all the mechanics necessarily fit thematically?  Such as the drafting mechanic?  No, not perfectly.  But the drafting mechanic is what makes this game great and I'm not sorry for it.  And then there's several other things that contribute to the theme, such as warring and trading with your neighbors, and each country/wonder being a little differentiated, and the global supply.  So I have no complaints on the theme.

Component quality: great.  The only thing that could be better is metal coins; but pretty much no games have those, and hey at least these look like coins even though they're cardboard.  The art is really beautiful too; one of the top 3 games I've ever seen in terms of art.  Overall, they paid attention to detail with these components and nothing seems crappy.

Length is great.  We oftentimes play in only an hour.  It's really impressive to pack an awesome euro-gateway-game in only an hour.  The game basically doesn't get any longer for having more players (unless multiple of them are newbies and you keep having to help them individually).  But even with noobs, it doesn't take more than about an hour.  This is amazing.

It does feel samey after a while without expansions, and the expansions haven't clicked for me yet.

Because this game is so well-rounded, and it is outstanding in the length category (can't think of any game with a lower length-to-strategy ratio), and because I only have 3 minor quibbles with the game, I rate this highly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.8

To add to that 7 Wonders is convoluted beyond belief, many tout it as a 'simple' gateway game, I disagree with that notion as it takes many, many playthroughs until you can develop any kind of strategy. Seasoned players that know the cards and combos have a huge advantage over those that don't.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
Players: 2–7 
Best: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I enjoyed 7 Wonders, and if you are a fan of the new wave of euro engine card games (Race for the Galaxy, Dominion and it’s imitators) I would strongly recommend that you try it out. While direct comparisons to those other games are superficial, there’s no denying that it’s becoming a genre.

The main draw is the drafting mechanic. While it’s as old as Magic: the Gathering booster drafts (about 15 years), it hasn’t been heavily explored yet–Fairy Tale is about the only other major game to try it out. It has the virtue of keeping the game moving at a decent pace (everything in 7 Wonders is keyed off what card you draft, including a couple of “pass” actions which require discarding a card). While things can seize up with players who are unfamiliar with the cards (my game was one veteran and five newbies), and experienced group should finish a game in 20-25 minutes, probably faster with a smaller group.

As much as I enjoy 7 Wonders (and I do – I will happily play it again soon), it’s a little hard as a fan of rich, meaty euros not to notice a couple of places where 7 Wonders could have been more interesting. The resource mechanism is a bit dull – it promotes some player interaction and keeps the rules density low, but the decisions are rarely tense. Either your neighbour has what you need or she doesn’t. Frankly, this is a problem with most post-Caylus cube-pushers (7W doesn’t use cubes, but the feel is similar), so it’s hardly fair to single out 7 Wonders, but a problem is a problem.

Also, the elements – military, economic, science, monuments/structures – are distinct silos. With one notable exception, there are no instances where building up your science helps your military or improving your economic power (beyond basic resource production) makes scientific progress more efficient. In some cases, playing a card will let you play a card from another silo for free later, which is a nice touch, but it only comes up if you see the relevant card and if playing it will help you out more than the other cards you have to choose from at the time.

Finally, it’s weird that the purple guild cards – analogous to 10-cost buildings in Puerto Rico or 6-cost developments in Race for the Galaxy – score points based on your neighbours’ position. It creates an incentive for your right-hand neighbour to take a different path than your left-hand neighbour, but the main effect is to give you much less control over which guilds are useful to you. It’s bizarre that the capstones of your game have nothing to do with what you’ve played up until now.

Nevertheless, these are quibbles. The card drafting is fun, that game’s arc is a little forced, but reasonable for a short card game and once you know the cards better, the game will go quickly. Like the start worlds in Race for the Galaxy, the different powers of the different wonders will help to keep the game from feeling *too* much alike from play to play. Unless you are completely europhobic, it’s certainly worth trying out. It may not be every gamer’s cup of tea, but the overhead for trying it out is low.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
mamy Izy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
While there is no direct interaction in this game, there is plenty of indirect interaction in buying "resources" from your neighbors, though I dislike that besides hate drafting key cards there's not much you can do to players not adjacent to you. There are a lot of icons but they are pretty intuitive.

I understand why there are only enough cards as enough for the starting hands for balance issues, but I wish there was more variety of which cards came up. I feel like this game will get quite a bit more stale in the future unless you constantly play with different player counts. The different starting wonders do add some variety but I don't think necessarily changes up your play style by a huge amount.

Despite these flaws this game seems to have good strategic depth especially for such a short game (I am only at the level where I am only concerned about what I can do to boost my own points, whereas a better player could figure out how the cards drafted would help their neighbors, and an even better player could extrapolate further), plays a wide range of players at least somewhat well, and has great artwork.

RATING: 7
4 plays with 5, 6, 7.

I have to start off by saying that I don't think that I care for this game with 6 or 7 at all. It simply takes most players too long to make their decisions for a game this light. 

I've said it before and I'll say it again; this is an upgraded Fairy Tale and that's a high compliment in my world.

A game like this should be played fast and dirty. You can always play again or even several times in a row.

Update:

More plays and I'm still interested in exploring the game space more. There certainly are strategies at hand here. We always make sure that the purple/bonus cards that are being used are fully revealed and explained to allow for some long term strategy and planning.

My only real frustration is that often you lose by mere points through no fault of your own. It's still short, fast, and interesting. Certainly a fine replacement for Fairy Tale of which we have played far too much.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Teaching this is a pain, what with all the icons and the various scoring systems.

As far as play goes, it's a tactical drafting game. Take one card from a set -- either the one that's best for you (usually) or the one that the guy next to you really needs (occasionally), then give the rest of the cards to that guy. Rinse and repeat.

Some sort of strategic plan tends to emerge about halfway through the game, but the eventual winner seems to owe a lot to how useful his neighbor's tableaus end up being. The Leaders expansion helps set up a strategy sooner, but I'm not sure how much it mitigates the luck-of-the-neighbor effect.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Sir Christopher Hatton (in black case)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Average game. Moving up with more plays. This game started as a 5 and is now up to an 8 !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The most versatile and most-played game in my collection next to Splendor, it sits in kind of a board gaming holy grail. Has a place in every game night from 3 to 7 players, with any number of new and experienced gamers. It is the only satisfying medium weight game that can play 7 and has interesting decisions without dragging all night, but also really lights up at low player counts where you see the same hand more than once and really try and work out what your friends are going for.

Simultaneous turns keep everyone happy, and the wonder building is easy to understand. The more I play it, the better it gets, but I do need an expansion or two to be really excited about a game of it now.

It is obviously not perfect; the eventual payoff of any decision becomes more random the more players you add, and Halikarnassos is awful unless players are discarding cards you need (which would be terrible; better to take them yourself or build your wonder than waste a turn).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Very good card-drafting game with an awesome theme. 

It can be overwhelming to learn at first (it's very difficult to predict what will be effective in the later rounds when you haven't played much before) and there are tons of choices to make, but it feels very fun and rewarding to watch your strategy unfold successfully once you've gotten the hang of the game. 

I'll say that Sushi Go is a better card-drafting game for newer players, as the mechanics are very similar but the design is much more approachable.

RATING: 9
Pros: 
* Plays up to 7 with no downtime. That's quite remarkable!
* Easy to teach and play
* Takes under 30 mins
* Lots of replayability

Cons:
* For an empire builder, it certainly lacks that epic feeling of achieving something extraordinary
* None to very little interaction with players not seated directly beside you.

All things said, this is an amazing game, and it can be played with anybody

RATING: 8
A medium-weight civilization card game.  Experienced players can have a lot of fun with this and play it quickly.  One down side is the game takes about as long to teach as it does to play.  But the complexity is not so bad.  Like most card games you will enjoy it more as you learn the cards and combinations.  Excellent artwork.

I would not view this as a perfect gateway game though as I have played with non-gamers and groups have struggled with this.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Card game con meccanica draft.
Ad ogni turno si sceglie una carta dalla mano e si passano le restanti al giocatore successivo.
Con le carte è possibile produrre risorse con le quali costruire edifici, meraviglie, tecnologie ed opere di guerra.
La cosa positiva è il poter adottare la strategia che si ritiene migliore per poter fare più punti possibili, variandola durante il gioco in base alle carte che capitano in mano.
Rigiocabilità praticamente infinita.
Molto consigliato per i neofiti

RATING: 6
A light, gateway game that is fun if you don't take it too seriously.  Civ building by selecting a card from a hand, and then passing the hand along. 

A good game for a larger number of players.

There is enough here to keep a board gamer interested, but not so much that a casual player would be overwhelmed.  You can learn this as you play.

The only part of the game that could be confusing to someone new is the scoring (you score on several different categories).  That and you cannot really keep track of or impact players that are not next to you.

While entertaining, you will not really feel like you have built a civ or a story....Zzzzzz....  see TtA for that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
It's good, but perhaps over-hyped. It's entertaining enough while you're playing, and quick enough to give sufficient reward for your time, but I suspect it is quite possible to play 'optimally' from your available choices and lose by a reasonable margin due to the vaguaries of your positioning re neighbours and their choices, hand order etc - frustrating if you're the competitive sort, but acceptable in such a quick game. I do think there are better choices out there in this category though, perhaps Augustus, for example.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a gorgeous looking game; the cards are probably bigger than they need to be for functionality, but the great artwork justifies this.

I like that this game plays well with the full range of players, and this is all thanks to simultaneous play, and the fact that only your immediate neighbours impact your game directly. 

Depending on how the cards fall, at times there's not a lot of interesting decision making involved; it's hard to form a strategy in the early game, because you have no idea what guilds will come out in the final age, and in the final age, it's often just a matter of choosing from among the cards you can play which one will score the most points. This is therefore definitely a lighter game, however it is not a luck-fest; the game rewards careful play, and in our group there are one or two who regularly do better than others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5

I have now played it multiple times (more than the ones reported on BGG) with the Wonder Pack expansion, and decided that I do not wish to play it again unless to please others and be in good company.

RATING: 8
Crear una  civilización con recursos proporcionados por las cartas que se sacan al azar es el objetivo de este juego. Se requiere de algo de  estrategia y suerte con las manos que le tocan en cada ronda. Es fácil jugarlo con solo dos personas..El diseño es bueno, pero la calidad de las cartas deja mucho que desear. El juego se basa en pasar cartas todo el tiempo lo que garantiza un desgaste acelerado. Por esta razón a mi copia le conseguí forros de plástico. Algunos puede pensar que es difícil a la hora de mezclar las cartas...Pero no lo es ..y si  aseguro juego para largo.

RATING: 5
7 Wonders is wonderful for handling 7 players so well.  However, I've taught many people this game and it consistently fails to have impact.  I'll explain the rules, Play a game and no one wants to play again.  Mechanically it's very interesting, but it just fails to connect so often.  Eventually I found that Between Two Cities is a better game for high player counts, it's less complicated to explain and has more interaction between the players.

每個人可以進行的策略相當多樣，每次遊玩都可以有不一樣的體驗

但還是一個值得推薦的遊戲

RATING: 7
7 Wonders is a great game, particularly as a gateway. It is a drafting game with simultaneous card play so that games are quick no matter the number of players. Because of this and its low complexity, this is a good game to start or end sessions with. It's good for building up one's playing area, while still interacting with one's neighbors, either through trading, military, and guilds. It offers multiple routes to gain victory points so as to not become too stale. 

Though a good game, I am burnt out from playing it so much. I haven't tried any expansions, but maybe they could breathe life back into it for me.

RATING: 3
Dieses Spiel verkörpert für mich in Idealform den derzeitigen Trend im Eurosektor. Mehr und mehr Aufwand hinsichtlich Regeln und Material bei bescheidener Spieltiefe. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is the game you would get if you mixed Citadels with Glory to Rome. It seems to scale quite well -- we've played with every number of players allowed. It is relatively quick to learn, everyone had a good handle on it after one play. (There are a lot of symbols, but they are easy and relatively intuitive.) It plays quickly too. The cards are thin and seem they would damage easily -- you need sleeves if the game will see the table regularly. There are supposed to be 7 expansions eventually, but I think that would definitely ruin the game. (We found the expansion symbols are not as intuitive as with the base game.) We have all of the expansions for it so far, but only Cities gets used much. (We don't tend to like expansions that change the flow of a game.) All in all, I'd recommend this game as a "must" for any collection, but expansions aren't necessary to enjoy the game. Nothing else plays quite like it and the high player count (that actually WORKS) makes it even more unique.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Probably better described as a heavier Fairy Tale than a lighter Civilization, 7 Wonders sports a lot of smart decisions – a hassle-free resource and trading system, limiting interactions to your direct neighbours, borrowing the no-money-down building chains from Attika and, finally, putting the whole thing through three well-differentiated stages.

The 30 min playing time causes a strong urge to have another go directly, and the only niggling doubt I currently have is whether the strictly limited pool of playing cards (with only the guilds as a dynamic element) might impact the urge to have another go in a couple of months. On the other hand, we’ve only touched on the potential depth that could come from trying to throw a wrench into your opponent’s plans as much as developing your own, and with increased interaction like that, the replayability would increase strongly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
***UPDATE*** 11-2-11 - Played it two player and enjoyed it very much. Thanks Donovan.


[b]First impression of the game?[/b]
Feels like Dominion or Race for the Galaxy. I'm glad I got to try it. After a first play, I'm not eager to run out and buy it.

[b]What are the highlights?[/b]
I like the interactivity between neighboring players. The card passing mechanic is cool but the change in direction seems arbitrary. The graphic design of the cards is beautiful and well thought out.

[b]What are the drawbacks?[/b]
There is a lot of iconography that I'm sure once you've played it enough, you would get the hang of. The game play seems a bit simplistic and flat.

[b]Who would enjoy this game?[/b]
Gamers who enjoy Dominion will dig this. I just don't see it having the expandability of a game like Dominion.

[b]Who would [i]not[/i] enjoy this game?[/b]
I think this game is pretty hyped right now. Hardcore gamers, if smitten at all, will lose interest quickly.

[b]Would you play this game again?[/b]
I would give it another go...the group I played with seemed underwhelmed and confused by some of the mechanics, so I don't feel I got an accurate feel for the gameplay. As these types of games go, I would rather play Race for the Galaxy, San Juan or Dominion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
7 Wonders was the third official entry and was purchased after the wife and I played it at one of those infamous game nights where the Uber-Nerds showed up with their duffel bags of board games.

This is a fantastic game and will always be one of my favorites - there's plenty of strategy, but the gameplay is fast-paced.  The theme is really engaging and the components really reflect that with gorgeous in game art.  It's also really accessible to new players - although they likely won't truly get until after they've played a couple of hands, but no matter since 7 Wonders is short enough that you can play multiple games quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This is my favorite card drafting game that features wonders of the world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Extremely well crafted game mechanic that fuses both luck and strategy into it. Each turn, players not only have to decide which area to develop, they also have to observe neighboring players to see if they could benefit from them or hinder their progress. Whether the players invest in the present or the future depends on the opportunities presented to them on that particular turn. This makes the game fun and exciting every turn. And the game plays fast (about 30 - 40 minutes) even when there are 7 players. Highly recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This plays so fast regardless of how many people are playing. That's so rare. My husband liked this enough that, after we played it with friends, we had to get our own copy.

We happen to like the two-player variant. It adds an additional layer of strategy as you have to take turns controlling the third city.

(Also own 7 Wonders: Babel, 7 Wonders: Cities, 7 Wonders: Leaders, and 7 Wonders: Wonder Pack.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
On one playthrough, this was a 7; after a second, it's an 8. This is a really good game, worthy of its hype.

The drafting mechanic is fantastic, the cards are gorgeous, and the play time is so brief that it has a Dominion-like "Let's play again!" factor to it. The fact that it scales smoothly up to seven is pretty amazing.

The symbols on the cards, as well as the big flowchart in the rulebook, make this look much more intimidating than it is. I won my first game -- a serious rarity! -- against two players who'd played before, which tells me that it's easy to pick up and would probably be a nice gateway for non-gamers.

Between the guilds and the drafting, I can see plenty of replayability in 7 Wonders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Rating based on 5/6 players.

Not a bad game by any stretch, but in larger groups you cannot interact with people not next to you (which also gives people a big advantage depending on who they're seated next to), and as the hands are stretched among more people you cannot make educated guess as to what cards will be available when the hand returns to you. Both of these factors make it really hard to do any sort of planning, and I felt like I was just guessing what to do the whole time (and I still managed to come in a strong 2nd both times). I can imagine myself liking this game a lot more with 4 or fewer players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I like the theme and card-drafting idea, but not my style of game for a couple reasons:
1) The game play results in very little social interaction (e.g. people consider their deck in parallel, looking at the resources of their neighbors, making a choice, passing their deck over, and waiting until everyone's done... then repeat).
2) For large numbers of players (6-7), you have essentially no ability to impact the farthest players. Also, for large numbers of players picking a lesser card to spoil a neighbors strategy is not a winning strategy, since you lose ground to many more players in the meantime (sort of a tragedy of the commons), thus large-player games devolve into multi-player solitaire.
3) The scoring is somewhat convoluted; it is difficult to accurately compute your neighbors' scores (e.g. if you want to determine who you should pay for a resource), which means either operating partly in the dark or else dragging out your turn/increasing dead time for other players.
4) I feel like the key way to become better at this game (after playing 5x, winning 1x, and twice being within 2 points of winner) would be to memorize the distribution of cards so I know exactly what's coming, probability of future free-buildings paying off, etc. That doesn't feel like fun to me.
5) Later on in the game, your path feels mostly-chosen. For instance, if you've been investing in science, you must continue. If you haven't, then you can't switch. So the choices become less and less interesting over time.

Perhaps I had high expectations simply because of its awards and ratings, but I was expecting better. Definitely worth a few plays, but I don't think it was worth owning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
First I have to say, that the game is actually quite good in some ways. Its quick, quite easy to understand, you can even develop some strategy to build your way to victory and if you're good with planning in minutes, with a little bit luck, you'll get what you planned. So why so low rating? Yeah, I have to admit that this game is not for me, basically because its gathering quite lot of things, which I usually don't like on games. First of all it lacks any atmosphere, for me its just counting and counting...as an typical euro game, but in euro game, the counting can get you to victory, because euro usually don't count with luck. So guess what... in 7 wonders, there is a lot of luck. There is possibility that you will or not, get the card you want. You have to always count with choices of people, sitting next to you from both sides. Based on what they already have, how much money they have and so on. And that's the only interaction, you have during the game. Yeah, watching the table of your neighbor. Maybe some trading. That's not good enough for better rate, sorry. I have to admit that it was innovative with pick and pass mechanic.

RATING: 7
An easy enough game, though some concepts you may have to be careful with when talking to new players (the fact that you don't use up resources seems to confuse quite a few people).
Light, usually quick if you don't have a player who is particularly prone to paralysis analysis, this is the perfect fit for people new to the hobby and who aren't comfortable with the level of competition common to more advanced games.

RATING: 6.29
We played this at BGG con with a new group. Neither Erin nor I had played before. I didn't really "get" the game going in, but by the end of our first play, I feel that I understand it that much better. Part of my difficulty understanding the game was due to the explanation I received. Sometimes it's hard to learn a new game at a convention, however simple the game may be, and this was no exception. It's interesting how all you do is draft. I like the variety of options, and feel it plays well with 6-7. I'm glad I own it, but I'm not sure how often it will get played.

RATING: 5
3 / 5 - Good

Alarm bells have to start ringing when I can walk up to a table with 4 experienced players, learn the game, and beat them on my first play. But it's engaging enough and the card-drafting mechanic is addictive and under-utilised generally. It gives one a deliciously warm glow inside to remove a card from the deck that you know the player next in line wants desperately before passing on the deck :)

RATING: 7.58
Rating:

Game quality: It's better than Settlers of Catan due to the lack of randomness, and that's about it. Just a number of things going on for a decently done mechanically nice horse and pony show, but it never felt engaging or dynamic on the level you would think one of the big named games would be. No clue how I feel about card drafting. It kind of felt awkward but more plays are needed.

It's a lot to take in for a new player. I'm still not sure how important certain aspects were. It was a quick run through of the rules and we went. 7.

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: No game gets the "Should I buy this or not" treatment more than this game and thus it is a perfect candidate for a 5. 5.

Do I want to play this if asked: Maybe not long term but certainly at least one more play. A game I judged early and now looking back I think I would view it as being higher, but I don't know until further plays cement it either way. 8.

Overall: 7.58.

Rating Potential: I don't see it going down unless I decide it isn't worth the purchase. Gut feeling tells me it might be worth it. I have a feeling this goes higher and becomes one of the few games that went up over time in part because I changed as a gamer.

Keeping the rating for now after a second play. My issue so far is that I have been taught it via a Con so in the spirit of time saving, rules have been missed. Add in playing it two years apart and  I can never get a real good grip on the game. Still a five for the willing to buy it if I was starting over, but I'm leaning on this being a no. My guess is Lewis and Clark officially kills this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Ordered Nov 8th 2010
Received Dec 8th 2010

I really can't say enough good things about this game.  It plays in about the same amount of time with 7 as it does with 3. With a couple of new players in the mix you'll play about an hour and with seasoned players, about 30-45 minutes. 

7 Wonders is definitely a "gateway" game. It's light, that is, not overly thinky; chess it is not! However, there are plenty of agonizing decisions to make and plenty of ways to screw up your own plans as well as those plans of the people playing to your left and your right.

New players may need some help on their first game; there are a lot of details to go through but after one game, I've yet to see even non-gamers not "get it".  It might feel a bit overwhelming the first time but the second and third time, you'll get it. Kids seem to like it too (great family game) with younger ones teaming up with an adult to make those fun decisions to deny dad those cards he really needs! :-)

RATING: 5
A really mediocre game. In my PERSONAL OPINION (don't start PM'ing me saying that it's just my opinion, because it is), this game is really overrated - all you do is collect cards in turns, almost no interaction between players, just people sitting together doing whatever each wants to do. If you want to play a civilization control game, try Through The Ages: A New Story of Civilization. Yes, this game is shorter and easier but again, there are other way more fun medium-duration games than this (for example Citadels would be a comparable game to this one and way more enjoyable, forcing intrigues, bluffing, teamwork)

RATING: 8
Simultaneous drafting makes this game great choice for even 5+ players unlike most games. Good with less than that too of course. The artwork is pretty good too. Replayability is pretty good, especially with Leaders expansion. It's a surprisingly dry game for a Bauza game once you've grown familiar with it, but even then it's pretty quick and never boring.

2-Player Comment:
*7 Wonders has built-in variant, which is pretty intrusive neutral player. It's bit dull to manage it every second turn. I disagree with BGG "Not recommended" though, 7 Wonders is decent game for two, but it shines with 3+.

Expansions:
+7 Wonders: Leaders
+7 Wonders: Wil Wheaton, Esteban, Stevie & Louie leader promos
+7 Wonders: Catan Island promo

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Civilisation building by way of card drafting from communal hands of cards, and ancient wonder construction.

When I initially played this game I was new to the hobby and wasn't so sure about it.  There is some initial iconography to get used to, and some scoring quirks to understand.

Further plays and experience in the hobby really changed my mind.  This game scales incredibly well, plays quickly, and has a range of different strategies available.  Once learned, the rules are pretty straightforward and I would see this as suitable for family play.

There is interaction with one's neighbours via military (rather than declaring an attack, this is automatically resolved at the end of each era based on relative military strength) and all others by what cards you leave in each hand as it makes its way around the table. 

Great looking artwork, although the cards aren't particularly sturdy so I recommend sleeving them.

One's ability to win at this game will really depend on how alert one's opponents are and who they are paying attention to. 

Can be a bit chaotic with more than 4 players, particularly if someone gets out of order with the simultaneous action cycle.  There is an official 2 player variant which comes with the game (even though it is listed as being for 3-7 players).

Not the deepest game going around, but it doesn't try to be.  What it does in the time it takes, it does really well - a really great game.  After many plays, I am still keen to keep playing, although after a dozen plays I was keen to start adding expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders is an evergreen game. It will always sell a ton of copies per year and that's because of it's accessibility. Drafting is one of the simplest mechanics to explain/teach in modern board gaming. Take a card, pass to the left, take a card, pass to the left. That's where this game falls short for me. It does nothing unique or special. Even the theme is rather weak. Theme is not integrated into the mechanics at all, and for that very reason, any theme could be pasted over the mechanics and it would be like nothing changed. Wanna use resources to build parts of a space station? How about layers of a cake? It all works the same, so theme is kind of nonexistent. I never felt like I was building my wonder. Hell, half the time I forget what wonder I'm even playing.

It's not a bad game. It sells well because it is a solid drafting game that is so accessible. The light weight of the game makes it simple for new players to grasp onto, but the decisions that you make aren't exactly deep and complex. Just take a card. Nothing that you take is bad for you. I'm rating it a 7 because I'll play it, but my heavier-gaming preferences yearns for something with a little more depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Everybody agreed that this is nothing special after playing it once. Autistic gameplay, one builds up a set of cards while only interacting with the left and right neighbour. And it depends strongly on luck. But after some months it turned out that it is the game we played most often. Because it is accessible, flexible with a player number from 3 to 7, and it does not take very long to finish. And it is good fun. So I have to give it a better rating than I originally thought I would.

RATING: 8
I've only played this a few times as 2 player game with my wife, but each time was enjoyable. This game is beautiful, with great components, great replayability due to the unique wonders and cards, and short (so you can play several games in a row, or several other games in an evening), and scales well for 2 - 7 players. I actually wish the game lasted a bit longer so players can set up more of the really sweet card combinations, but like RftG, part of the experience is time pressure. So far, an excellent game.

*update* played several 3 and 4 player games and enjoyed each game. Not much difference between 2-4 player games. fun, quick, and light.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Interesting Drafting Game (you have a hand of cards, equal to the number of players, and you take a card and pass the rest on)

Each card you draft will be played on the turn you draft it, and can give you bonuses, and more ways to buy upgrades.  It's important to maintain balance, but also to specialize a little.  Your neighbors will effect you the most directly, and at the end of each round of drafting, there will be the opportunity for some bonus points.  

I really enjoy this game.  It's fairly simple, and not particularly hard to learn.  Each "Wonder" has a different play style and strategy.  I strongly encourage playing this multiple times, and with 7 players!

RATING: 10
Excellent game. Played 2 times the 2 player variant, 1 time with 4 players. I loved all plays even if I had to explain everything. Beautiful art and nice theme and above all (I play games most with 'non-gamers') short gameplay. Some even want to play again and again (as I do). Multiple ways to score points and multiple opportunities to change tactics. Even if you lose there is a sense of winning because you have built your own goals/city/wonder!

I also managed to "sell" this game to friends and family: it's really accessible (just after the 'symbol-hurdle') and it plays with 2-7 players.

I have the game for quite a while now and still play it with everybody and with the Cities expansion it's highly replayable.

RATING: 5

This game boils down to sitting at the table, and watching someone run away and win. Sometimes its you, sometimes its not. Not too much you can do about it really.

Not my type of game.

RATING: 6
I don't usually like deck building games, but this isn't too torturous. I think the feel of building up your city really improves what would otherwise be just a "get good cards and hope they all work together" game. Once everyone is familiar with the game, it becomes more like a multi-player solitaire. Strategy is pretty limited and so far, those with the most blue cards wins. However, it plays quickly and is easy to learn. If this was a meatier game (it's a filler) I'd probably rate it a 6. But it plays fast and is worth the time investment. Edit: Just downgraded to a 6. Played Olympos tonight and it is a much more successful "civ" game than 7 wonders in the same amount of time. I can see 7 Wonders appeal, just for some reason, I'm not a huge fan (I think I just do not like drafting/deck building card games). However, still worth a look!

RATING: N/A
*
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
7 Wonders is a fantastic empire building game in which players attempt to build resource-generating assets and use those assets to purchase various improvements to their empires.  Some assets focus on scientific progress, military might, economic gains, or just straight victory points.  Players can also construct various stages of their chosen wonder (e.g. great pyramids, hanging gardens, etc) that provide them with various bonuses.

The game uses a nifty hand rotation mechanism in which players switch hands in a clockwise or counterclockwise manner each turn.  As such, players must balance choosing the best card for themselves each round with preventing their neighbors from accessing beneficial cards from a given hand.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played A LOT--easily two dozen times or more--before we started tracking our plays in 2017. This was our most exciting introduction to modern Euro board games. A family favorite.

RATING: 10
(+4 extra)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I have now played this game 5 times and 4 times within the last 2 months.  I don't necessarily see the balance in this game or why it's rated so highly.  The player interaction is extremely low and you have very little if any effect on players who aren't your neighbors unless you play what is called a "screw you" card.  At that point all you can do is take it.  The most interaction I have had with other players in the game is when someone asks, "Is everyone ready to play your card?"  If you're into card games like Magic & Pokémon, I can see why you might like it.  However, this game is not for me.

After being forced to play this awful game again, I have lowered my rating from a 4 to a 3.  (5/10/2017)

After being forced and berated during another play of this, it's now down to a 2.  (11/8/2017)  After this last play, I did some research on this game and found out that the base game is ok.  It's the Cities expansion that kills this game for me.  Since then I've informed my gaming group I'll play 7 Wonders, but without the Cities expansion.  We haven't played it since because they don't want to remove the expansion out of the game.

After two more plays of just the base game, I like this much better without the expansion.  However, it still suffers from not being able to get cards you're after.  I understand this is probably one of those games where you have to play what's given to you, but you cannot determine that until probably halfway through the game.  I have raised my rating to a 5, but it'll probably stay here and not raise any higher.

RATING: 7.4
I think 7 Wonders is a bit overrated or maybe it got hyped too much, I don't know.
Don't get me wrong, the game is not that bad. But it is, for what it is, too simple. The draft mechanism is (almost) the hole game. The decisions are not that game changing. There are multiple ways to score points and if you did not get the cards you wanted you try to collect other types of cards. In this regard 7 Wonders lacks on depth. Therefore I like the Leaders expanion, which gives the player more direction from the very begining. So it gets more focused on an entire strategy.
Maybe I should also take a look into the Cities expansion.

Anyway I would rather play a fast game of Sushi Go with a similar game experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played this game with 2,3,4,5,6 and 7 players.  Enjoyed this the most with at least 4 players.  Hardly any time commitment per game once you're used to the different icons.  We sometimes sit down for a quick game then find ourselves playing it 8-10 times.  It's addictive because you find yourself thinking that you'll do better next time.

As you get familiarized with the different cards, you may find yourself flying too quickly during the draft.  You definitely have to take time after each selection to see what ALL your opponents are doing... not just your neighbors.  Counter-drafting is a key aspect of the game that can lead to resource denial and other strategies.

Although easy to learn, having experienced players playing is when this game will shine.  We've found that beginners tend to skew the game in favor of their immediate neighbors.  Multiple beginners lead to solitaire-type play where they just concentrate on whatever is in front of them.  This can sometimes lead to runaway victories.  The best way we've mitigated this is by teaching beginners basic drafting strategies while we teach them the game itself.  It's easier to do this during a sample game that goes through at least Age II. And remind them that there are no resource cards in Age III.

That being said, once all players are well versed with the cards and the different basic strategies, then the games become much more competitive and balanced.  We've had margins of victory as little as 1 or 2 multiple times.

This is a terrific game with tons of replay value.  Sleeves are a must.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game. Easy to learn, easy to teach yet engaging enough to be enjoyed by myself
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Great, great game.  It was a pleasure to discover and so fast you want to play another one right after.  It's a keeper and a game everyone should play at least once.

A huge bonus is that it plays as well with 7 players compare to when you play it with 3 players.

Thumbs UP!

RATING: 8.5

I also like the aspect of just being able to buy from your immediate neighbors, which makes the available resources very different for each player in a larger group.  Along with the fairly quick play time, multiple available point strategies, and scalability up to 7 players, this has become a great choice for lunch games at work.  Totaling points at the end becomes a bit cumbersome, but not enough to hurt the game overall (and would probably be easier if we actually used the included pads).

RATING: 4
Perfectly harmless. Mild amusement can be found in this, and if played rapidly it's a fine pastime. That said, unless I'm having 6 or 7 players who are low on time or low on interest in longer games or more "party" style games I don't see myself choosing this. Not hard to learn, symbols are simple with a few exceptions that need to be handled on a case by case basis, you feel you have some agency (though I doubt the extent of it at least for higher counts), you make something then you score it and ta-da. I can see the popularity in the same way I see it for Ticket to Ride. Not quite my preference.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Game in a Nutshell: Draft cards that build up your civilization. Some cards give you available resources while other need resources to build.

Played as: 2,4,5,7 player

Played with: Vanilla (2,4,5,7); Leaders exp. (5 player)

Pros: Nice, quick, medium-light game that does a good job of giving you a sense you're building something. Simultaneous drafting frees the game up to potentially move as fast with 3 people as with 7. That also means there's minimal downtime. Has a natural flow to it. Nice big cards with colorful artwork. A nice change of pace from some other games built on an overused mechanic.

Cons: A lot of iconography that isn't very explanatory on it's own. A little explanation text on the cards couldn't have hurt. Kind of a messy game when things start getting stacked up. Because of that, it has a learning curve to it that's slightly beyond the weight of the game. 

Other: I think this game has a place in just about every collection for it's unique way of allowing up to 7 people to be making meaningful decisions without interruption through the course of an entire game. I still can't think of another that does this on an individual level.

Best Use: A "heavy" filler.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I unboxed this and overall the components are nice. I love the larger sized cards. My only beef so far is the quality of the cards themselves. Just looking through them and I saw the edges fraying. The stock is decent, but the edges will show wear in one game. The printing quality is not up to par for me. In a card-based game, the cards should be higher quality. The rulebook is clear, although it has a few mistakes (nothing impacting game play). The game plays quick and is full of decisions (more so than you would expect, given the basic mechanics). It is easy to get several games in with 4-5 people in about an hour.

RATING: 4
"Ok- here's how we play.  You get seven cards, and you are going to draft one card each round and pass the deck on."
"Then what?"
"You score."
"Check.  Then?"
"We enter the second age.  You draft some cards."
"And then score?"
"Yep."
"Then?"
"We draft some more cards."
"And score?"
"And score."
"Then the game gets started?"
"Nope, son, that's the whole thing."

Passable lunchtime entertainment.  Like the variable boards.  But how anyone would want to play this 50 times and call it an 'instant classic' is beyond me.  Almost totally solitaire.

RATING: 10
This is a great game at any player count. Say what you will about the two player variant, but I think it offers tactics not available in a regular game. The gameplay is always quick and offers quite a few paths to victory. There is a good amount of hate drafting which I think goes unnoticed in some drafting games. This, however, does make it frustrating when playing with new people. You do need to pay attention. As far as "solitaire" games go, there's more player interaction than you would initially think. My all-time favorite game and with plenty of expansions, it never gets dull.
