=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
7 wonders is a fast played game. The amount of players doesn't prolong the time it takes to play because everyone does their thing at the same time.

Beginners do several mistakes because they don't understand the rules or don't remember them. There aren't many rules though.. After the first game every player understands the basics of this game but sometimes beginners keep on collecting same named cards which is against the rules.

Wonders are not equal so it makes games very different every time. It's a bother because your wonder makes you inclined to collect certain way those points. Then someone nabs your card right before your turn. I think ruining the game of others is easier than succeeding yourself.

This game is fast, idea is average and it is visually good but doesn't give us the feeling of "awesome!!"... I usually get exited about new game but this doesn't spark us that often. When we take this game out we usually play it a couple of times before forgetting it for a while.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Drew
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[u]04-Jan-2013[/u]:  This was the first big "hit" for my family after I got into this hobby, and it's still one of Mrs. Mo's favorites.  After the initial learning curve of figuring out all of the different cards and which ones can combo together, this game has been a [i]wonder[/i](Ha!)ful addition to our family game time.  Games are almost always close.  There are several strategies available to gain VP.  The art is great - except for two semi-risque cards that don't seem necessary (Baths and Altar).  And this is just a fun game.

The card drafting mechanism is not unique to the game world, but it is so in my collection.  It's such a tough decision in the early part of each round of which cards to play.  The choices are plentiful.  The resource management is a game in and of itself.  Do I build a bunch of resources and just go for big VP later on or stay minimal with the resources and build cards early that will allow future free buildings (if they come your way).

Lots of good stuff in this game.  Easily one of my favorites for it's variety of scoring, artwork, play length, and scalability.

[u]24-Jan-2014[/u]: Still high on my fave list after all this time.  Plays fast.  Always a close game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
This is a great Euro drafting game that has a legitimate amount of depth, especially with expansions. The game is over far too quickly though, which can be good or bad, but you can always play again. Very good for 3 or more players and scales relatively well, although as with many Euro games the other opponents on the table not immediately beside you barely affect you at all other than maybe screwing your draft, so while you can play with 7, there isn't really much incentive to do so.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A mini civ builder where each player starts with a civilization containing certain powers when they begin building it's wonders.  Players get a hand of 7 cards, play one, pay any building costs and then hand the next 6 cards to the left.  You can interact with the players on the left and right of you by purchasing their resources and in a round by round cold war where the player with the largest army gets points and the player with the lowest loses points.  You continue drafting and passing in this style until there is only one card left which is discarded.

The game is played in three rounds and there are a number of combos, mainly in reduced building costs (build for free if you have this other card, etc.).  For a thirty minute game that plays up to 7 players it's quite effective.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
not for me. good idea but poor material.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
*Aug 2013*After 3 plays, game gets a 9. I'm curious to see how long the *ahem* wonder lasts, but right now I'm seeing quite a bit of longevity and fun!

If my fondness for this game fades, I'll look into Cities expansion

*Dec 2013* After 24 plays, plus 6 with the Cities expansion, this game is no longer one I am dying to play any longer. 

If setup was simpler, I'd probably break it out more. With 4+ players, game is hands down improved by Cities but with 3p, the base game is perfect and fun as is, even for veterans. 

The game's one con is that it's too complex for what it is to introduce to newbs. The game doesn't present its options well enough to newbs, even with a good rules explanation. So it sits in that weird position where it's a great filler to play with a lot of people.... only setup (especially with Cities) is kinda fiddly (helps if others assist) and everyone needs to have played at least once or twice prior. 

Still, it took quite a few plays for my love affair to fade....... At a low estimate of each game taking 30 minutes (some took longer, such as when intro-ing to newbs), I've gotten 15 hours of play out of it. At least 12 of those were filled with the excitement of loving the heck outta this game. Definitely a worthy buy for most gamers, even if not a permanent keeper.

RATING: 7
Lightish card draft-style game that gives a nice, slight Civ flavor.  Grab a card, pass hand to the left, grab another card, pass that hand to the left, etc.  Really fun implementation of some M:tG draft-style stuff (remembering card layouts, aggressive drafting, estimating likelihood of getting what you want, etc).  There's the significant advantage to players who've played before, though.  Advanced play becomes highly specialized down certain paths.

RATING: 7
This is a fun drafting game that plays well at all player counts (well, maybe not at 2 players, but now we have 7 Wonders: Duel). The fact that a 3 player game takes just about as long as a 7 player game is probably my favorite thing about the game as I can play it with larger groups, but this can also be seen as its primary problem. Effectively, you are only worried about playing the person to your right and your left while everyone else in the group will not effect you. Also, the symbology can intimidate new players who will the prefer something a little quicker and lighter such as Sushi Go! 

Overall, once you understand the card play, the game is pretty quick and can be fun, but I find there isn't much long term planning when playing at the higher player counts. Also, I prefer heavier games that utilize drafting (like Blood Rage), but I'll keep this game on hand to play with friends who don't like to play the longer, meatier games in my collection, but still want something gamier than a quick filler.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders is my go-to game for 5-8 people either with more casual gamers or as an evening starter. Even poor or inattentive players can have a good time without feeling disengaged. Downtime is minimal, you can complete the first game quickly, and shuffle up for another try (the "real" game for the new players). Players can force a different strategy every game or follow the signals of their neighbors. Few games bridge the skill divide so successfully without resorting to heaps of randomness. The expansions add nice variety.

RATING: 9
The box, cards, contents, manual and quick reference are all great. The base game is a lot of fun to play. You are constantly passing cards and taking cards. The way the ages are split into three is a great concept, and you'll find yourself flying through the first age and slowing down in the next to the more familiarized you get.

The only trouble we had in the beginning was actually learning how to play the game (I wish it took you through a few turns as a player). I'm new to board gaming, so maybe this was just just myself being unfamiliarized with this type of game.

I also find the military strategy a bit lacking compared to straight-lining to science or buildings. 

I can say that the Leaders expansion sort of fixes this issue giving some more military strategies as well as a more clear goal as you play the game.

Overall, a great game to play! I recommend 3 or more players.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played once with four players and once with seven.

A short card-based game where players build up a city, getting points for various things that have been built.  Players must choose between building resources, building military power (there's no direct conflict between players, though), building science (to collect victory points), and abilities that get points or money from what your neighbors are doing.  

Players are dealt a hand of 7 cards, they choose 1 to play, and then pass the rest to their neighbor.  This repeats until the cards are exhausted, at which point a brief scoring occurs and it all happens 2 more times.  

The game allows players to interact with their two neighbors, but nobody else.  This is both good (it prevents you from having to look across the table lots), but also bad (as your score, and your abilities, depend greatly on what the two folks next to you are doing).

I'm mixed on this; it's a heavily random game (I couldn't build any advanced resource supply cards for most of the game, as I never saw them), but it's short enough that that's not a huge problem.

Update: After playing it with seven, I've realized that the game changes dramatically with the number of players.  When we played with four players, each person knew that they'd see at least a few cards from their original hand again; with seven, you never see those cards again.  So, the game turns into more of a card-counting game, where you go "Okay, if I've got this card there, and it's only one of two in the deck, then I'll likely never see it again".  The game is also hugely dependent on your neighbors, which can be a good or bad thing ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Alright game, but at 7p it's just not interesting. I like to see the cards that are being passed on multplie times. 4p would be my limit.

2017
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Draft and play cards to improve your civilization for most points.

Plays: A dozen?
Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently.
Complexity: Light.
# of players: See BGG.
Playing time: 30 mins.
Player interaction: Opportunity prevention.
Randomness: Medium - initial 7-card hand.

Replayability: Medium, this probably has some depth to explore.
Fun: Not so much, I find the experience dry.
Memorability: Not really, VP engines don’t create stories.

Thematic integration: Strained.
Components: Good. I find any game that requires pen-and-paper scoring fiddly though.

Who will like this: Strategy gamers that want lighter fare before or after the main course. Family gamers that want to move into strategy games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
People say that this is a good gateway game, but I would disagree. In order to have any idea what to do, you need to have a good grasp of the cards that are due to come out later and what resources are required to build them. Without that knowledge, there is no agency so you are just playing randomly. From my experience, this has put off new gamers while not having enough depth to keep more experienced players interested.

RATING: 6
Really great that it plays lots of players so easily and still scratches that strategy game itch.  Lots of agonizing decisions, but there's my one major fault with the game (and it's a personal preference, not necessarily a flaw): you're constantly deciding between doing something that advances your civilization and purposefully picking something else so that your neighbor can't get it.  I don't like having to play defense the entire game.  And yes, I realize that's what the game is all about, and that's how drafting works, so like I said, it's just not my style.

Az mondjuk kifejezetten zavar benne, hogy játék közben kevésbé látni, hogy ki hol áll pontok terén, a végén elég sokszor van meglepetés. Bár mások szerint meg pont ettől izgalmas.

Nagyon jó tabló építő játék egyébként, ami néhány év alatt megkerülhetetlen klasszikussá vált. Kiegészítőkkel még tovább lehet bonyolítani, bár néha már-már a játszhatóság határai súrolja az analízis-paralízis benne, ha telepakoljuk a kiegészítőkkel is.

RATING: 6
Kind of like Fairy Tale, but more elegant and easier to approach. Better with fewer players, three or four is good. I like the game, but end up playing couple of games and feeling bored - the card pool is so shallow it gets a bit repetitive soon.

So it's fine, good if you need something fairly light that works well with a wide range of players, but for heavy rotation, I prefer Dominion's near-endless variety. Then again, I'm definitely a variety kind of gamer (nah, that's just my excuse to own 30+ Age of Steam maps).

My initial rating was 8, but 7 is more honest (and more appropriate), as I'm not that likely to suggest 7 Wonders. My mom loves the game, and I think I'll probably get enough 7 Wonders whenever I'm visiting her. (Dropped to 6 later.)

Indifferent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Xmas 2010
Ok, there is a lot wrong with this game - fiddly setup, reliance on iconography instead of clear, explanatory text, almost zero player interaction.

And yet, its assets far outweigh its liabilities: not including setup, it seriously is done in like 20 minutes with a group of four, and really no more than 40 with seven. And it plays seven in that amount of time! Seven players!!! Furthermore, the rules are incredibly easy to learn, and the only real struggle is figuring out what some of the cards do. At the end of it all, and in spite of its lack of interaction, it's somehow actually enjoyable - NOT the enjoyment of crushing one's enemies and seeing the lamentation of their women but the simple enjoyment of building a sand castle.

----------------------------------------------

Rating downgrade. After many, many plays of this, I am starting to see that beyond the gimmick of drafting, there's just nothing under the hood here...

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
As predicted, this game got old fast with lots of players. Playing with 6 or 7 is just not that interesting to me. It doesn't feel interactive, and you never see the cards in your hand(s) again. It might be okay as a quick filler, but games are never that quick, so I'm always left wondering why I didn't just wait to play something else.

At the lower end of the player count, this does become a somewhat interesting game, and I must say I am impressed with the 2-player variant. It's nothing special--I'd consider it a "change of pace" from Dominion--but worthy nonetheless.

Given the prevalence of this game in every gaming circle through which I circulate, I no longer see any reason to own this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Likely the best drafting game out there.  I love card drafting in general coming from MtG, and this game delivers.  

There is a lot more depth of strategy than meets the eye.  Knowing the age 3 building costs and guilds and knowing what to prioritize early goes a long way in winning the game.  The strategy also changes significantly based on number of players (ex. military is much more powerful with fewer players).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Honestly, I really enjoyed this game at first, but I think it's a bit overrated now.  It's chief benefit is the short playing time and range of players.  The artwork is nice, and it's a pretty good little game, but it's not that deep and I'm a little burnt out on it, so I traded mine.  I may pick it up again, if they add some expansions.  It needs some variety.

Did receive again in a trade.  Not my fave but good for non-gamers, so I may pick up a couple of the new expansions.

RATING: 8
This one is getting a lot of favourable attention lately and with good reason. It plays well and has a lot going for it. One of the more enjoyable card drafting games I have played.

I like the components and the theme and the ability to play on the "B side" of the wonders really adds even more to it.

Another great option is that it plays seven people so it's possible to enjoy a group game with a bit more depth than Incan Gold or Saboteur.

Well worth playing if you get a chance.

RATING: 10

RATING: 7
Végre kipróbálhattam, 7-en játszottuk, köztük 4 új (velem együtt), 3 tapasztalt, ilyen sorrendben ('csoportokban') ülve. Miután elmondták a szabályokat megmondtam a végeredményt, és nem tévedtem: az első az a tapasztalt játékos lett, aki az I. és III. kort tekintve a kezdők után következett (a többiek sorban a dobogón), az utolsó pedig az a kezdő, aki a 3 tapasztalt után jött elsőként..

Negatívum tehát, hogy igencsak számít az ülésrend. Csalódás volt számomra még a játékosok közötti interakció hiánya, mert bár figyelni kell a másikat, és hatással vagyunk egymásra (ez tetszik is), ez igaziból csak pontokban mutatkozik meg, játékban, akciókban igazából nem (még a vásárlásnál sincs semmi, csak megveszem a nyersanyagot a szomszédtól és kész). Ez szerintem nem is igazán interakció, csak csinálgatja mindenki a saját dolgát. Ez kifejezetten nem tetszett.

De! A pozitívumok: pont az előbbiből adódóan (mindenki csinálja a dolgát egyszerre) gyorsan lepereg, az említett 7 fős játék is 1 óra volt magyarázattal együtt. Előnnyel indul, aki ismeri a játékot, ez mutatja, hogy van benne stratégiai mélység, amit ki kell ismerni, hogy jól játsszuk. Van is kedvem játszani még vele, hiszen tényleg jó játék, de a Dicsőség Rómának! ezerszer jobb!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
En casa

RATING: 9.35

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
7 Wonders ist ein schnelles Spiel, in dem Karten reihum gedraftet werden. Die Karten stellen unterschiedliche, antike Gebäude dar. Dreh- und Angelpunkt sind die namensgebenden 7 Weltwunder. Zu Beginn sucht sich jeder Spieler eines dieser Bauwerke aus und versucht es im laufenden Spiel fertig zu stellen. Für den Sieg ist dies kein Muss, jedoch bringen die Weltwunder zusätzliche Siegpunkte. 7 Wonders ist für mich jetzt schon ein Klasiker, der wahrscheinlich auch in 10 Jahren noch auf den Tisch kommt. Die Regeln sind relativ einfach, die Möglichkeiten komplex und vielfältig. Der Rundenablauf ist flott, Downtime gibt es quasi nicht. Mit den zusätzlichen Erweiterungen (Cities und Leaders), spielt sich 7 Wonders immer wieder anders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

In my top 10. fast game with many decisions in each card choice.
Whenever I teach someone to play wants to play again. With the expansions becomes more strategic giving a little more intensity to the game.

RATING: 6
Reviewed
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I LOVE simultaneous play. I have an attention span on the shorter side for games, so this beauty is perfect for me. So great for large groups as well. Don't, however, try and teach a large group of first timers. Best to learn in small groups then combine forces at a later date. I made that mistake initially and it was total chaos that really turned me off to the game for a bit. Now it's one of our groups favorites, played at almost every session. It's really fun when you get to the point where you know the game well enough to incorporate hand management into your play and can manipulate the cards that are available to the other players.

RATING: 8
Wasn't greatly impressed with this on my first play, mainly due to the chaos of joining an 8 player version with lots of newbies and a very rough game rule explanation. After a few plays its starting to grow on me and I can see its appeal as a quick, reasonably involved filler for a large group. Once players are familiar with the rules, which are short but not entirely intuitive and the symbols are sometimes too abstract (not unlike Race for the Galaxy), 7 Wonders moves along at a quick and satisfying pace. Am keen to play a few more basic games before introducing the expansions, which I believe only improve the base game.

>>I think 7 Wonders is still a good game but the base game appears to lose its appeal from being repetitive, and even experienced players still struggle to re member what the various icons mean. The Cities expansion adds some variety, but again with more cryptic icons!

>>>God I'm crap at winning this game but it is good fun, and really shines as a fast game for large groups. Works well during lunchtime at my workplace with any sized group. Yes, it's a game of drafting with neighbours but it's also interesting to see how the larger game is progressing. My only niggle is the constant reminding people how the rules work and what the icons mean.

RATING: 9
Once you have learned the symbology (which is more intuitive than that of Race for the Galaxy), this becomes a really fast filler game that scales unto 7 players without slowing the game down.
There are plenty of different strategies you can adopt and with 14 possible starting card options the game has true re-playability.
It is rare to find a game that lives unto it's hype!
RECOMMENDED.

RATING: 9
I always enjoy this one...even after almost 30 plays. The decisions feel interesting, the play is wonderfully fast and doesn't slow down with the addition of extra players much at all.

It offers a nice mix of resource generation and ways to use those resources. I like the drafting mechanic but admit that it can limit the game to the experience of the other players - in other words it is possible to have other people's decisions limit what you can ultimately achieve.

I suspect that it could lose its charm if you were playing 5+ games a week but then again at the time frame it probably won't.

Tends to always throw up close finishes too - usually a sign of good balance.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
One play impression: I can see why 7 Wonders rates so high with others.  It's a fast playing drafting game, it feels like you are civ building, it has lots of strategies that you can pursue, and its easy to learn but harder to master.  The artwork is great and relly helps pull you into the theme.  I learned that your choice of cards in the first round is really important because the two rounds after that has cards that can be only be played as long as you have the prerequisites in place.  I went heavy on military cards when it seems that the green (science?) cards are the way to go to ensure victory.  I'll definitely read the rules before my next game to ensure I have a better understanding...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is, in my eyes, a perfect game design. It looks beautiful, the mechanics are good, the downtime is minimal and it scales well from 3 players and upwards. You can also choose your level of complexity; it is as fun to play "casually" as it is if you really pay attention to what others are getting, what cards to pass on or not, etc. 7 Wonders is just always fun to play, even if you don't win!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Short playtime is the best part of the game. The base game itself is perfect. With expansions? Even better. But try to avoid Babel.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Elegant mechanisms where simultaneous turns mimimize the downtime. However, without knowing the many different cards it is difficult to set up a strategy and if you sit between two aggressive players, you suffer double since you both get attacked and lack trading partners. Still, this is probably the best of the many card drafting games out there.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.4
主題:1
藉由古文明的奇蹟來套入不同國家版圖的經營玩法 很有世紀帝國的味道，每個文明的打法特性都不同，算是有很鮮明的主題，玩起來又可以認識歷史，一舉兩得。

美術:1
不光只是圖片漂亮!各種族文明的圖板也是很贊!尤其是領袖擴充的畫風，真是精美的沒話說!

規則:0.9
看起來很複雜，都只要玩一遍很快就可以上手，只是初學者需要了解各文明的特點、能力會比較困擾!

設置:0.9
算是策略經營類中遊戲 最好設置的一款遊戲 配件不多 馬上就能開來玩，比較麻煩的一點就是要依照人數抽出不同的卡牌!(很像很多吃卡牌的遊戲都有這種現象)

路線:0.8
得分路線多元，玩法多樣!可以配合不同文明有不同打法!不過有時看抽牌運氣及上下家的文明是否有剋到你，運氣不佳真的只能陪打!

互動:1 
只能跟隔壁兩家互動 看起來很少!但玩家互動還需要透過一整輪的抽牌，基本上就能跟所有玩家發生互卡手牌的互動，最棒的是，那一款策略遊戲可以讓七個人願意坐下來玩呢?(策略遊戲的天敵 玩家人數越多時間拖越長)而七大奇蹟卻是七人玩的時間還是一樣短!這就是一個很好的玩家互動!在這一點上給與人數互動上大大加分。

個人:1   
個人強烈喜愛!

朋友:0.8 
玩咖中還是有人始終搞不懂遊戲玩法 而不喜歡! 

想玩:1 兩人也可以打!

收藏:1 這樣棒的遊戲還不收?!

總分:9.4
講評:
很棒的遊戲!路線多元!人數有極大彈性!遊戲時間短!可以連殺好幾盤遊戲!美術很漂亮!運氣跟策略並行的好桌遊!

Superb game. 
Still have not come up with a good strategy for playing this game - I feel like I'm making it up on the fly every time. But the art is great, the notion that everyone is playing simultaneously is very good, and it is a lot of fun.

Problem: This is another game where analysis paralysis could set in and slow everything to a crawl. Don't be that guy.

RATING: 10
Fun: 5/5
Just a very enjoyable gaming experience. The indirect nature of the interaction ensures no one feels picked-on.

Challenge: 5/5
Plenty of tough decisions, that just keep on coming. Lots to analyse but with so many unknowns, your intuition is often the best bet.

Theme: 3/5
You get to enjoy building up a city from humble beginnings. Trade and conflict with your neighbours adds to the theme. The fantastic artwork also contributes.

Overall: 5/5
One of my favourite games and can be enjoyed by gamers and non-gamers alike.

[thread=1513710]My full review of 7 Wonders[/thread]

RATING: 3
I didn't get it. The game-play was the same as Sushi-Go, but there was all this extra stuff. Even after 3 games I had no idea what I was doing, and ended up losing because I was just taking random cards from the ones handed to me. None of the strategies I employed seemed to work, and I just got frustrated. I would give it another shot given the chance, but they'd have to really work to get me to enjoy this game. There are too many better games out there that I'd rather play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2 Players:

Enjoyable and multi-layered game, a light version of Civilisation with enough routes to ensure that tactics can change on the fly.  I enjoy the way the game opens up through the three ages, also the challenge of playing with different player boards and taking turns to activate the Free City.  This game is likely to have a secure place in the collection for a long time to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I fear Antoine Bauza will be confined in my mind to the realm of games the idea of which markets fantastically while the reality ends up underwhelming after a play or two. Here are the numerous issues with 7 Wonders:

- For the amount of interesting decisions you get, the game is really hard to teach.
- There are 7 ways to score victory points at the end of the game. Some of them imply several mathematical operations. Because of that, determining the leading player or the viability of your current plan is a chore.
- You barely interact with your neighbours and the potential drafting shenanigans are totally incidental. You can't even refuse a trade.
- The tech tree is stupidly hard to learn by heart, there is only one player aid for the whole table and, to make it worse, the ratio of cards of each type is dependent on the number of players.
- You can't count on a given guild card fitting your plan to be present in a given game (let alone then tabling to you); thus the whole guild card type is about randomly giving a swingy amount of endgame points.
- Counterpicks are not a thing because they penalise you alongside the bashed player while helping everybody else.
- Amongst all the choices you have, you're lucky to ever get more than two that are contenders for "best move this turn". The game is quite autopiloty, especially in later parts.
- Being able to care about what other players do would require a turn order rather than simultaneous play, which would unfortunately triple the play time.

As a result, nobody at my table is laughing or smiling or talking, aside from the occasional forced trade. It's pretty much a solitaire experience - and not even a good one.

RATING: 6
This game is virtually impossible to settle on a consistent winning strategy since there are so many variables including number of players, personality of players, random playing boards, and randomness of card drafting. I enjoyed it more when card selection was done in turns instead of simultaneously, the latter ended up feeling like I was playing a very hectic solitaire where I had no idea how I was doing until the final scores were tallied.

In fact the design is so streamlined I don't think I want to buy any expansions for this. I'm worried that it will dilute the experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.75
- Aucune interaction avec les joueurs à l'autre bout de la table;

- En ne pouvant recevoir deux fois le même paquet de cartes à 6 ou 7 joueurs, il est impossible de choisir deux cartes dans le même paquet. Contrairement à d'autres jeux de "draft" (Citadels, Fairy Tales, Magic), il n'est pas possible de constater, au cours du draft, quelles cartes ont déjà été sélectionnées et quelles ne l'ont pas encore été. De plus, l'ambiance est bien souvent celle-ci: On attend que le dernier joueur ait sélectionné sa carte (petits temps morts), puis, lorsque c'est fait, on regarde notre propre zone de la table, sans trop s'attarder aux autres joueurs.

- Il est impossible d'acquérir des cartes de ressources à l'Âge 3. Cela implique donc de devoir sélectionner à l'Âge 1 les cartes ressources lorsque cela est possible, à moins que nos voisins immédiats fassent le travail pour nous et que des cartes style "Comptoir" nous soient disponibles. Bref, la rejouabilité est peut-être un peu altérée par ce détail, car la première phase du jeu semble être assez "scriptée".

- Des joueurs expérimentés semblent être avantagés, pouvant tirer profit de mauvaises décisions de leurs voisins moins aguerris tout en étant relativement peu vulnérables face à ces derniers.

- Jeu un peu trop court pour autant de matériel utilisé.

"[COLOR=#003300]You have limited control over your strategies. It's not a true drafting game in 5-7 players [...] because you will never or rarely draft in anticipation of getting something back.[/color]" [dzevin]

RATING: 9.9
Elegant, almost perfectly balanced mechanics. The best thing about this game is that there is no universal strategy, you need to be flexible and react to what's going on. Slightly random.

After 6 games, updated from 8 to 9.

After ~30 games, updated from 9 to 9.9. Only minor (even unnoticable for most people!) issues with balance prevent me from giving 7 Wonders the maximum rating.
The ramdomness I mentioned before is actually not important, as it's counterbalanced by the drafting mechanism.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Quite a fun little game that packs a whole lot into relatively quick gameplay. I found the idea of trading and warring with only the two closest players to be refreshing. I'm sure I've got a lot to learn regarding finite strategy with this game, but I do feel there are some balance issues between some wonders. Clearly Halicarnassus has the best ability in the game and I've found that whoever has it tends to win. The drafting mechanic is relatively simple and resource costs make sense to me, but for some reason it's been hard for newer players to connect with. That being said I don't feel like this is a great game for entry level board gamers. It's been easier for me to teach some heavier Euro-games than this, which doesn't make a whole lot of sense. Can't fault it too much as it's a blast with people who get the hang of it.

RATING: 8.5
This is what good game design is all about. Easy to learn, difficult to master. Offers something for both casuals and gamers alike. Skill in 7 Wonders comes from observing your opponents and trying to foil their schemes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In this card game, each player starts as a Wonder (with different abilities). Game plays in 3 ages. Each age you select from 1 of 7 cards, pass them on,  play the card, select from 6 and so on, until you have played 6 cards per age. The cards have various casting costs, or provide resources. The interaction is being able to purchase goods from your left and right hand neighbor, while you also earn/lose points through military with your neighbors. The cards played provide points, and you can also construct stages of wonders on your board for points. 

This is a really good game, and makes you want to come back for more. There is a ton of variety, and different apporaches to take. As well, this game fits in 7 people! Rating likely to rise with more plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Very clever game. Quick and yet deep. Only played the 2p variant thus far but even that is rated an 8. Would like to try with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is great for filling that niche of a nice fairly quick, fairly light game that is scalable to a big tableful of people.

You can go through the game happily enough without stressing too much, just watching your little civilization grow, or you can engage your brain with tracking your opponents developments and trying to optimize everything. This game works well in a good variety of situations, with different numbers of players of different tastes, ability levels and ages. I've never had a bad game of 7 Wonders. That's why it's always available to play when we have people round for games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5.8
I hear great things about it and like the short time it takes. It looks like it really does better with 3+ so that makes it mostly out for us because I can only rely on 2 and I'm not crazy excited for it. However, I definitely want to play to try it out.
UPDATE:
I had a chance to play it and I like it so far. I don't think I've had enough experience to determine how I feel completely yet. I definitely enjoyed the play through but didn't gain a strong enough understanding yet to judge. However, I like the components a great deal and the card drafting and passing mechanic seems slick and original. It seems that there's less punishment for having a poor hand in this way because of the passing/drafting and how this can be utilized strategically. Its a set collection and economic game that's very euro and I didn't mind it at all. I look forward to trying it more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The rules are simple enough to teach to practically anyone, but there are certain rules that some people find difficult to understand (some don't get the resource production, some the buying, and so on), but after vigorious exampling anyone should be up to speed.

RATING: 9.5
My wife and I love to play this game, it is one of our favorites. I think the brilliance of this game is how quick it plays with 2 players and it plays in the same time with 7 players.

There doesn't seem to be very many good strategy games that a large group can play in under an hour, including set-up and take-down time, but 7 Wonders is one of them.

The other thing I love about this game is how balanced it is. There are so many ways to win. The problem is, each game, I see multiple paths I could take and it is hard to discern what the best path is because I want to take them all!

RATING: 8
Great gateway-plus game. It's a little complicated to explain initially if you're not familiar with the card-drafting mechanic, and there are a lot of little icons and things to figure out, but once we played through a couple of rounds it was straightforward, and it plays quickly since everyone decides which card to play simultaneously. There are lots of really interesting choices to make (balanced between building yourself up and messing up other people) without feeling overwhelming. It's also one of the few non-party games that plays reasonably fast with lots of people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
An elegant card drafting game that accommodates up to seven people with ease and still within 40 minutes. Games always vary, based upon guild cards, starting player wonder mat and the randomness of the cards. This creates a lot of replay value, which is guaranteed for this game. Game is quite balanced, resources can be purchased from your neighbours for flexibility and there is many paths to victory.  Overall a very fun game that can be played over a hundred times. 

Cons:
-Little interaction with all players, confined to immediate neighbours.
-Choices can be obvious for skilled players, creating an ‘autopilot’ gameplay.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
Juego de cartas basado en el mismo principio de la variante Draft de Magic The Gathering: consiste de tres rondas en las que cada jugador recibe una mano inicial de 7 cartas, debe mantener una y pasar el resto a la persona que tenga al lado.
La diferencia con el Draft está en que las cartas que uno roba debe jugarlas inmediatamente en vez de mantenerlas para armar una baraja.
Las cartas representan recursos (con los cuales se paga el costo de usar otras cartas), poder militar, tesoros, avances tecnológicos, edificaciones, etc. y combinándolas de distintas maneras (y en ocasiones teniendo en cuenta las cartas que hayan usado los jugadores sentados a la derecha e izquierda) permiten obtener puntos.
Es super sencillo de aprender y además es muy ágil, una partida dura menos de media hora.
Es un juego excelente, de mis favoritos actuales aunque aun no lo he jugado tanto como quisiera.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
7 Wonders was one of the first board games of the new generation that impressed me. Nice and quite simple mechanics, very good iconography, this game is a lot of fun. A few things bother me, though. First, contrary to most people, I don't think it scales that well. With up to five players, you can still compete with a fair setup, since everybody shares at least one neighbour. With more than that, though, you can sometimes fall between people with a very different level and have a very unbalanced experience. In any case, it's a fun game anyway, just not a very fair one.

Second, although the rules are quite simple and the iconography well made, this game is still a pain to teach. Too many icons and very creative rules makes it very hard for a newbie to grok. Sometimes, even intermediate gamers may suffer a bit.

Third, it goes for too long. For a simple game, 7 Wonders, for me, overstays its welcome a bit much. There are deeper games out there, with more things to do, and sometimes simpler to teach, that take around the same time.

Finally, the final scoring is a chore. This is actually also part of the problem I have when teaching it. Every time I must teach someone about the technology scoring it's a nightmare. Sure, they understand the math, but they seem not to understand why such an annoying system was chosen for this game. Neither do I.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So after seven plays of 7 Wonders I think it's time to rate it as a solid 7...

...anyway, the idea of drafting cards by passing small decks from player to player is certainly not new, but basing an entire game around it is definetivly special.

A game of 7 Wonders is divided into three ages. In each age, players gets seven cards each, picks one of these to play and then passes the remaining cards to the next player. This is repeated until all cards have been played.
Cards fill different funtions. For instance, brown and grey cards are production that is needed to play cards of differend colour. Other cards represent military, economy, technology, monuments and so on.
Also, cards become progressively better in each age, but you need cards from precious ages to play the later ones.

Just about everything you do in 7 Wonders will score points, but figuring out how to score a lot while at the same time keeping the other players down is certainly not easy. I like how cards scores differently. Blue, green and red cards all score points, but in varying ways. For instance, green is set collecting, while red is a race against your neighbours.

You can also use the cards to build on your unique Wonder, or simply discard them for money.
Finally, you are allowed to use the production of neighbouring players if you pay them.

It's easy to think of this as solitaire, but you need to keep an eye on the other players. Perhaps you don't want to go for green cards if to many other players are doing so, but you might need to do so if only one player is going green...

While there are lot's of different options with the different kind of cards, the best option seems to be to do a little bit of everything. This makes the game a bit too unfocused for me some times.
More importantly, this lack of variation makes the above mentioned solid 7 a lot less solid. It might even border on a 6...

If you add the Leaders expansion you add a bit of focus, making the game jump from 7 to an 8, perhaps even a 9!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite game of all time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2.5
Have played about a dozen times and taught to several groups.
Although I don't mind teaching, would actively avoid playing again.

Why don't I like 7 Wonders? It's priced like a premium board game and comes in a large box, but is essentially just a large deck of cards and some chips. Iconography and scoring are too convoluted to make it easy to introduce to non-gamers, but the game depth is very limited (especially with larger groups) making it a poor choice for gamers. Player boards are very poorly balanced. Player interaction outside of the standard card draft is very limited and mostly incidental. Theme is just a justification for the artwork instead of having any value in the game.

What does it do well? Scale to different player counts - there aren't many games that work with 7 or with 2 players. You lose strategic depth that way, but the game works well enough and (outside of lengthy scoring at the end of game) the time-to-play doesn't change significantly. The art is very nice.

There are better drafting games. There are better filler games. There are better party games. There are better games with large groups. There are better games with small groups. There are better gamers to bring out with non-gamers. So what niche is 7 Wonders supposed to fill?

Many people love 7 Wonders... I'm squarely not in that category.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
One of must play games.

I'm quite impressed that our 6 and 8 year old kids have picked up the game and feel confident playing.

RATING: 6
7 Wonders is a fun, fast-paced card drafting, light civilization building game... until the endgame scoring. Everything grinds to a halt as one person tallies everyone's scores before announcing a victory. "And the winner is... Math!" A great game hampered slightly by a boring endgame.

On the bright side, if you are recording your gameplays on BGG, this is the easiest game to input as 7 Wonders forces you to write the details of each game out to find out who wins.

Another complaint is the main game component, the cards, are not very durable and will quickly show wear. Also, although advertised as a 2-7 player game, the 2-player version is a variant that requires a Dummy 3rd player which isn't ever a good implementation.

The only real gameplay difficulty is teaching new players to be aware of cards with prerequisites. The progression icons are tiny and easily overlooked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Theres alot of fun to be had with this game, a fairly light drafting game that develops more depth the more plays you have
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fast fun light engine (civ) builder.  Even with large group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very fun card-drafting game where you start with seven cards, pick one to play on your wonder, than pass the 6 left over to your neighbor.  You than look at the 6 cards handed to you from your opposite neighbor, pick one to play, than pass the rest to your neighbor.  Do this until one card is left, throw it away, than move on to the next 'age', three ages in a game.

Fun game that plays up to 7 easily without really adding much time from 4 players to 7.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Countless games played, I never seem to get enough of 7 wonders. A must have for any board game collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Masterpiece! One of my favourite games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Tras jugarlo he entendido rápidamente por qué gusta tanto. Es sencillo, emocionante y dinámico, con resultados a veces sorprendentes, con tantas variaciones, que después de una partida va otra.

El juego es, desde luego, una maravilla. Lo que no me parece tan maravilloso es que más que un juego de tablero es de cartas y viene en una caja desproporcionada donde sobra demasiado espacio. Me imagino que en ella cabrán las expansiones, pero prefiero una caja más pequeña y no llevarnos a engaño. Bastante me ocupan los juegos en casa, cada vez que uno viene con un 50% de aire pongo los ojos en blanco. Tal vez ayude a justificar el precio, que si bien me parece un pelín caro para la cantidad de material que hay, para mí está correcto sólo por el diseño del juego (su mecánica y que lo veo bien hecho) y las siempre increíbles ilustraciones de Miguel Coimbra (en tono más realista que Small World por ejemplo). Seguramente el mismo juego en un formato de cartas más estandar con unos ajustes en las fichas de Maravilla podía caber en una caja tamaño Bang!

Y es que ese es otro punto del juego: el tamaño de las cartas. Recomiendo comprar las fundas especiales (que no se encuentran actualmente en las tiendas, sólo online, y que desgraciadamente vienen en packs de 100 así que hay que gastarse más o menos 5€ para que te sobren 50). Un gasto extra, pero es que las cartas van a tener mucho trote...

El juego depende mucho de la suerte, tal vez demasiado, por lo que idear estrategias puede resultar muy frustrante. Así que a mi parecer es un juego de no comerte mucho la cabeza e ir haciendo lo que parezca más ventajoso (que ahí radica la parte estratégica, hacer las mejores elecciones es lo difícil) y no mirar demasiado hacia adelante o confiar en la suerte. 

Desarrolla tu civilización y elige entre la guerra, la ciencia, el comercio, la cultura o tener la mejor maravilla del mundo!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The game has falls in the "middle category" - I have not had much success using this as a gateway game for new players (as opposed to something like Stone Age), and it does not have the "meaty" decisions required for a group of serious gamers.

It's saving grace is that game time is short - however, I'd rather play Glory to Rome in the same time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This is a nifty game! Scales up so effortlessly and has many meaningful choices packed into a short ~30 minute game. First, a couple negatives:

One slow player can make this game drag! If you play with someone who is prone to AP or just scatterbrained, hands of cards will start to pile up next to them and then the happiness of simultaneous turns will vanish. Not a huge problem, but I like this game as a fast game. Not a slow one.

I don't really get it. Yes, that's not the game's fault, but I really struggle with the strategy I believe. I do reasonably well with the people I play with, but I can't tell when I play a game well, or not. Part of this is a testament to 7 wonders. There are a few different paths to victory, and that makes the choices in the game not always obvious.

On the positive side:

I love the artwork! Cards are fun to look at and they make it easier to imagine your civilization grow. It's a pretty quick game, so you can play a few games even on a tight schedule. Mechanics are nice and sensible, and there is more than enough strategy to chew on.

So, I probably haven't given this game the proper plays it deserves. As of now, it's not a favorite of mine, but it's on the next tier of games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
BGG hype-train of 2010, played in the first weekend of 2011.  Result?  OK, broken clock -- you win this time.

It's a clever little drafting game that forces a number of difficult decisions in a short amount of time.  It seats anywhere from 3-7 seamlessly.  And again, it's over almost before it starts.  There's a couple of clearly over-developed paths to victory, which is its only real downside.  You're going green or blue/red, or you're going home.  And by the time Act II shows up, your choices are already made for you.

The other downside is a product of its own making; there's no way this game could live up to its hype.  30-min civ game?  No.  It's a slightly more complex Fairy Tale with a new theme, and it costs 3x as much.

2017 UPDATE: Not much has changed.  I'll play this game whenever you put it in front of me, especially if you're new to gaming.  But it's not my go-to game and it never will be.

RATING: 7.5
Fast drafting game that supports many, plays quickly and is easy to teach. It tends to feel a bit samey sometimes, and the drafting aspect doesn't compare to Magic: the Gathering. Nevertheless, it is good fun and a good contender in the filler-length bracket.

I have found that going for all of one thing rarely works out well (although when it does it can be ridiculous, particularly science); going for a bit of everything consistently places well (hence the samey feeling).


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
For starters, you get a hand of seven cards and can play one. Without knowing what you're going to see down the line, it's pretty hard to determine what the best cards to pick will be. You have little idea of what resources you're going to want, and you may simply never see certain cards if others get them before you. It seems like this is almost completely the luck of the draw.

I've not played this with three players yet, but I think that might have a bit more strategy to it. A six player game is almost complete randomness. Not terrible, but not that exciting.

After playing this with two, I think this is the best way to play. This actually brought my rating up. You see more cards and with the added strategy of deciding what to do with the NPC, there is far more strategy here than with more players.

After four plays with three, I think this works well with three. You can more easily keep track of what other players are doing, so you can have a better idea of what to pass/keep/bury. I think I'd prefer this as a three player, playing a few games in a session.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fast card drafting game not very deep, but with a nice number of decisions.

I don't agree with the people that say there's no interaction. You have to see what people are building to maximize your strategy and even if you can only interact directly with the 2 neighbours, more interaction would lead to gang-banging againt the leader.

I think it plays out best with 4 players (6-7 is way too much, you never see again the cards your pass).

RATING: 8.5
Simple in it's complexity.  Complex in it's simplicity.  This is destined to be a gaming group fave.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very fast "civ game" built around drafting. Mechanically very solid and fast to play. Drafting part is best with 3 or 4 players as then you get same hands back a couple of times and can actually do a bit more than just react to cards you have. Every player start with different wonder that can in 3-4 stages giving different bonuses and gives your start resource engine. There are some tougher decisions to be made during game but it is still pretty simple game. Biggest thing is the fact it works rather well up to 7 players and is easily playable under 60 minutes even then.

Cards are of course a size that doesn't fit nicely in any card protector available (yet). This can be a problem as you use a different subset of cards depending a number of players and cards are easily-markable-black-bordered, of course.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 wonders is strong, fast, and smart.  The end.

Anyone can play this game [the 2 player variant proves it!] and it really feels like you're generating a civilization.  Is it the end all be all civilization game?  No, god no.  This is a civ-light game and you're really just playing different 'types' of cards that affect a different aspect of point calculation.

But it still feels cool and like you're developing a civilization!

Now.  If you're the type that just see's the score system and will take 10x longer than everyone else per turn to optimize everything, then go stay with your heavier games.

This game is light!  But it's a fun light game.  I can play heavier games and enjoy this one for what it is.  The art work is fun and the mechanics blend in with the theme and after a game or two the games are pretty fast!

Negative reviews usually attack this game because it's 'simple'.  It is.  This game won a ton of rewards probably because it appeals to such a broad scope of people.  And for me, a person who hosts games for not just a set group of people, but literally people I just met and who usually play video games, this is great!

If you have a set group of hardcore gamers who only play TI3 or Dune, then this game probably isn't for you.  But respect the game, it's good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm sure that I will eventually start to get tired of this game, but at the moment, I will play it whenever offered.  It's as close to a "10" as I would get right now.  It really scratches the drafting itch that I have from being a long-time CCG player.  Amused by the notion that this could be considered "multiplayer solitaire" seeing as how you know the options being passed to you, and from you, to other players, which affects your strategy.  My only major problem with the game is that you really only focus on the players to your immediate left and right.  It's frustrating in a large game when someone across the table wins -- it's not like you could do much about that.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Gioco semplice, veloce e capace di unire in un tavolo fino a 7 giocatori! Questo è il segreto di 7 Wonders, gioco che per linearità può ricordare Dominion, ovvero un card game travestito da board game. Non stiamo parlando di un capolavoro di strategia e meccanica tipo Puerto Rico o Caylus, ma di un fillerone, un tappabuchi dalla durata contenuta (specie dopo le prime partite di rodagio). Tra gli aspetti negativi c'è sicuramente la poca interazione (diciamo pure assente) con chi non è seduto vicino, ma che rispecchia la poca influenza che civiltà lontane possono avere tra loro. Il prezzo è abbastanza alto in rapportato ai materiali. A mio avviso è un titolo un po' sopravvalutato.

With the expansions (especially Babel for more players) which bring up the variety, it's a solid 8 now.

Easy and fast to play, and it can be played over and over without being the same again as it's numerous cards and boards gives you a huge amount of possible combinations to avoid repetitions. The only downside for me is that it takes way to long to be explained (even though the dynamic of it is quite simple) as you have many possible ways to score making the explanation fase long and tedious.
Once you've played it a couple of times it becomes a fab game.

RATING: 6
Very good civ light, however missing a little bit direct interaction for my taste (and a board). The artwork is really beautiful. Apart from the theme, it's very much an "okay game above the average". One great strength it has is that it scales very well. Also, it's easy to learn and forgiving. And with 1 hour play time or less it is short, yet still provides a good experience. 
However, I will always prefer a full civ game if the time frame allows it. 7 Wonders is just too light for me - not to say I have mastered it, but building a civilization has to feel EPIC in order to really impress me as a theme.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[b]7 Wonders[/b] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (10):[/COLOR]

[i]- Beautiful artwork on the cards which helps the theme come through.
- Plays well with 3+ players.
- Quick playtime (under 45 minutes) even once you add more players.
- Card drafting made extremely accessible, this is an easy game to teach.
- I enjoy building a tableau of cards that builds on itself and allows you to obtain better cards.
- There are enough different ways to win which helping to give this game good replay value.
- Great game to begin/end a game night.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8.5):[/COLOR]

[i]I will start by saying that I had been looking at this game every time I am looking for a new family game to play with both of my older kids and my wife. Well I don't know if it is the #1 family game but it is a really great family game. There are two things that really make this game shine for my family.

First is the simultaneous card drafting, there is absolutely no down time in this game. As much as we love playing games like Kingsburg or Stone Age there can be extended periods of downtime while someone is trying to figure out their optimal move. In 7 Wonders everyone is making that choice at the same time and as the amount of cards you have to pick from dwindles the pace of the game picks up. 

This leads into the second highlight of this game: 1/2 hour game length with 3+ players. My two older kids are 11 and 8 and we love to play games and we now have a great game that we can play in about a 1/2 hour. This makes it a great game to pull out on weeknights when we don't have time to play a longer game. We have some great 2 player games that play in a similar time frame (Agricola All Creatures, Morels and Jaipur) but up till now no really good 3+ player games that fit into that time span. 

Overall I couldn't be happier with this purchase, my wife and kids love the game, we can play in a 1/2 hour, there is very little downtime and there is a good amount of strategy to be found in this game.[/i]

30 plays -> base game 
2 plays -> Babel
4 plays -> Cities
5 plays -> Leaders 
11 plays -> Cities + Leaders
1 play -> Babel and Leaders
1 play -> Babel, Cities and Leaders

RATING: 10
The components of this game are of truly superior quality.  The artwork is beautiful, and the boards, cards, coins and tokens are very sturdy.  There are similarities in terms of play with Dominion, but 7 Wonders plays faster and is more interactive.  Because of the way the hands are passed continuously around from player to player, the decision as to which card to play on any given turn can be deliciously painful.  There are many different paths to success, which keeps the game exciting and suspenseful, as I find it hard to tell who's winning.  (5+5)

RATING: 7
Interesting game - this is one that *really* plays differently depending on who is at the table /and/ where they sit.

Has an interesting choice mechanic where you hand off cards to your neighbours. Can lead to analysis paralysis among some players.  Otherwise turns are quick.

Scoring can be a bit of a chore, especially with the science group.  Also I'm sure those with a good memory for the cards would have an advantage after a time.

I've tried this with a few different groups, getting middling success with a couple of them but one group REALLY liked it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Certainly a hot game in my groups - through the sheer depth-for-playtime. A lot fitted into a small, quick package. It is wearing a little thin for me, and the games are starting to feel 'samey'. I guess this is a natural function of the fact that you can fit so many games in on a night. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I find there are too many options possible for victory. You can score with whatever you want, so it is almost like playing in the dark with not too much strategy. There are options to block and sets to make. Positive is the quick playtime and nice card mechanism.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A really nice ramped up version of Fairy Tale, where hands of cards get passed around, you pick one and play it to your tableau, then pass the rest on. You play out three rounds / decks / hands, with each deck have increasingly better cards. Cards come in a lot more flavours than FT which increases the number of strategies you can try. You tend to play resource cards early as these give you the pre-requisites for building the later bigger scoring cards, which could be straight VPs, sets worth VPs, VPs for specific collections, etc. If you're intent on the win, it has the same "gamble and hope" strategy requirement as FT, eyeing off what the people around you are collecting, going for something else, and then hoping the cards you want come to you drip fed one at a time and not all bunched in one hand, and that other players won't also start collecting them before you. At 30 or 40 minutes I don't mind the lottery feel though, and I've enjoyed each playing. I know it's not going to be dripping with depth, but it's one of those games I'll enjoy whenever pulled out, which may be frequently given it caters beautifully for up to 7 players without downtime. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
Hard to know where to put this game.  The rules are very easy for people who play this hobby, it scales well to 7 players and it should play in 30 to 40 mins.

On the other side, players who are not into this hobby will take a bit to 'get it' and I have some concern if the game will get old after a large number of plays.

This is a very solid game and worth getting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Friend owned
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Awesome light-weight Eurogame.

I always play with cities and leaders.  i like it 3 and 5 players.  some say 2-players is broken.  my wife and i play it 2-players all the time and love it - although we did make a minor adjustment to how we pass the cards in the 2-player version, and it plays better.  we pass the free player's whole hand around the circle, just as we would in a regular 3-player game, then take turns playing 1 card from his new hand each turn.  a simple change makes a huge difference. but i know some people are purists and consider rule tweak to be a board gaming sin.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I could play this all day. Modern Classic. Delightful med-light Civ-building card drafting game in less than 60 minutes for 2 to 7 players. Though it is very intensive in the usage of icons, the game is very intuitive when learning how to play; things click after 1 game. Careful management of everything that comes your way, while watching your 2 "neighbors". Different types of gamers seem to enjoy this.

Artwork is good. Design is good. Need a large table space. Need patience to teach this.

2 Player variant is another great Wonder, in my unpopular opinion. I loved it 2 player but my (gamer) wife did not. However, now 7 Wonders Duel fulfills that need for us both.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love it love it love it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Well done!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
"Fantastic game for 6-7 since the simultaneous play makes it quick. It's too complex for non-gamers, and has more randomness than I enjoy. I also don't like the hate-drafting. I won't play with 2p, and with 3-5p I'll suggest something else."

What I like:
- Simultaneous play, so quick if people know the game
- No direct attacks
- Resources and "tech trees" are clever
- Civ theme is nice
- Multiple paths to victory

What I don't like:
- Fiddly setup, with cards in or out by player count
- Hard to explain to non-gamers or casual gamers
- Yellow iconology, especially, is tricky
- 2p neutral player sounds horrible
- Almost being forced to hate-draft is annoying
- Randomness can kill you (or hand you the game)

This game shines with 6-7, providing a reasonably meaty experience with quick play time. Unless there are first-timers, in which case it can bog down (90 minutes). Even at 6 I would prefer Peloponnes as a reasonbly-quick; almost-medium civ-themed game.

I have played mostly without Leaders, and twice with. I don't think it adds enough to be worth the little extra time and little extra complexity, but it's ok.

Mechanically I would put the weight at 2.5, while from a depth standpoint maybe 2.2, so the BGG-voted 2.3 is reasonable.

As a Magic player drafting was also a big thing for me. That moment before you get to see your cards is just exciting. 7 Wonders connects that feeling with a beautiful game, which knows how to use cards and boards to build something wonderful.

Thumbs up: Draft, the monumental art, no downtime at all
Thumbs down: 2 player variant is not very good, excessive use of symbols, specially for the extension

RATING: 5
This game was mainly created, I suspect, to frustrate people due to its seemingly random nature that can be controlled but ultimately lurks beyond your reach. Much of the time, I'd rather roll some dice and put on a movie than play this game. With the expansions included, it's even more of a blah fest as you wonder whether other people will simply undo you or the cards themselves will simply get shuffled in a way that happens to undo your strategy without providing you a viable way to reform your tableau in a game-winning way.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is great. Fast paced, with almost all decisions interesting, and multiple feasible options. The simultaneous play works amazingly well - you don't have to wait for your opponents, because you're playing at the same time they are!

The short length of the game and the scaling from 3 to 7 players are both very rare features of a game this good. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game will always have a place in my collection, simply because of how well it scales to the number of players. Plus, I really enjoy the card drafting mechanism and the interesting decisions it forces you to make. Excellent game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent drafting game that scaled well across different numbers of players.  The mechanics make your neighbors at the table critical to your success, but also competition you need to be at least a bit wary of.  You've many ways to score (and score well), but you need to keep in mind what the neighbor you'll be passing cards to is doing and whether what you pass them will help them too much.

Beautiful production quality paired with quick play and many options.  Easy to get in a game in an hour, simple to teach, and lots of variety from game to game.

RATING: 10
Fast paced and hugely rewarding game, in which the game develops extremely quickly. If you aren't watching your near neighbours closely and other opponents at all then the game can evolve without enough time to combat others, or remove critical choices from them. The choices are endless and there are many paths to collect points to win the game. I love card games and this one is really engaging, the cards are so well put together with all the reference required in symbols.
Can't wait for expansions and for this title to true rank along and fully compete with Dominion as my favourite game that I own.

RATING: 9
One of the best card/boardgames i've played! 

The draft mechanic is fun and very well implemented, there's almost no waiting/downtime since the actions are all taken at the same time, and choosing what card to take is very fun as you have to adapt to what other people are playing/taking.

Another nice thing to say is that the game really changes based on the number of people playing, so there's some replayability to be found there.

Highly Recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Yes it plays from 3-7 and yes it can be taught and played in about 30 minutes by almost anyone, but I still do not get all the hype and neither did the other people I played with. It is a light draft style game. You get a hand of seven, chose a card, everyone plays simultaneously and then you pass the cards to a neighbor and repeat. You need to gather resources, build an army, construct your wonder and various other tasks in order to get points. It falls along the lines of Roll Through the Ages, so if you enjoy that game, you will likely enjoy this one. I found it to be a fairly good filler, but not something I would generally play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5

RATING: 7
The first few times I played this I enjoyed it a lot, but since then I've found the games I have played less and less interesting. This might be the fact that I have started to play many more complex games, but I don't feel like I'm building a civilisation when I play and sometimes I feel like I don't fully understand the consequences of the cards I am taking (this comes from not playing it regularly).Although it plays up to seven, I've found games with more than 4 people a little less interesting as you can only interact with the two people either side of you and you don't get to see the same sets of cards multiple times, which takes away from the strategy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gioco letteralmente snobbato allo Spiel 2010, a causa del girone infernale attorno allo stand della Repos e anche per la mia bassa soglia di sopportazione nei confronti dei giochi da carte.

Giocato a Play 2011, l'ho comprato subito. Che cantonata che ho preso a Essen! Dove lo ritrovi un gioco, che non sia un party game, che mette a sedere sette persone, facile da spiegare, che dura poco e che scala da dio?

Regole semplicissime ma azzeccate, meccaniche dei commerci e delle guerre ben calate nell'ambientazione (praticamente giochi contro le tue due civiltà confinanti), possibilità di fare combo interessanti e di vincere con le strategie più disparate... cosa vuoi di più da un gioco la cui spiegazione delle regole dura quanto la prima partita?

Dopo qualche partita è un po' ripetitivo, certo, ma comunque un successo strameritato. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Great with 4-7 players and plays in about 30 minutes.  One of my favorite tier 2 games for people new to the hobby.  Some people complain about the minimal interaction, but I like the level. A bit difficult to teach to non-gamers as there is a bunch of symbology and the point-salad nature can make it a bit confusing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
As a filler-type card game with a little depth, 7 Wonders is a far better choice than Dominion for me.  I appreciate more good games with the Fairy Tale-style drafting mechanic, and I really appreciate being able to play with 7 people without increased downtime or chaos.  That said, it's still a filler-type card game, so it's still pretty random and will not satisfy the desire to play even a medium-weight Euro.  Basically, I wish it had more depth and less randomness, but as a filler that can accommodate a lot of people, this is a winner.

(5+ plays)

RATING: 6
Kind of glad I didn't buy this so far, but with repeated plays, it might change a bit. Really, this feels exactly like fairy tale just with prettier pictures.

Edit: After quite a few plays, this game settles on a 6 rating. The biggest appeal of the game is 7 players in under 45 minutes and that really just doesn't do it for me. It's a solid game but not really a whole lot of substance. I'd willing to play it each time it comes out, but I'm not actively seeking it.

Edit2: After playing it again after a long while, I still enjoy the game. I'm not actively seeking to buy it or play it, but I'd definitely play it if asked. A nice filler that can be played relatively quickly if everyone is on their game.

RATING: 10
One of my all time favorite board games. Simple gameplay, as you just draft and play 18 cards, but not simplistic, as it can go as deep as you want to, in terms of tactics. I can play it either as a filler or as the main game of the night and I'm always willing to hop in, so a perfect 10 from me.

RATING: 9
Excellent card-drafting games (one of the best). After the first play(s) it feels very intuitive, not too much cards to remember what can be in play. Nice progression through the rounds. Interesting neighbour mechanic (you trade and fight only with the players next to you), which creates sort of zones around the table. And maybe most important, different possibilities to win, different strategies to choose from. Best with 5-7 players.

RATING: 8.7
I love card drafting games and this is a very fun, not too long card drafting game that is fairly easy to teach and play, even with new players. It's easy to play this game 2-3 times during a game night even if you're playing multiple games thanks to the quick play time. I also love being able to buy things from your neighbors where you actually pay them to use some of their resources, this is fun and addictive. I strongly recommend picking up the Leaders expansion with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I enjoy playing 7 Wonders with people who have played it before, but people who claim that this is a great gateway game and one that is easy to teach are full of it.

The card-drafting, dozens of icons, spending resources that you retain permanently, and using the cards in myriad Chudyk-like ways make for a very steep learning curve for a lot of players new to the hobby. Although it's simple for gamers to play and not incredibly deep, this does not make it a good game to teach to your in-laws over a holiday weekend.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This feels like a re-implementation of Knizia's Ra, but I prefer Ra.

The artwork in 7 Wonders is amazing and there is enough historical flavor to inspire learning about the leaders - so that is a plus. The game plays quickly which is also a plus. Passing the hand of cards around the table is an interesting mechanic.

On the negative side, scoring at the endgame is clunky. Player interaction could be better. I can buy a resource, get points off of your tableau, make you pay a debt, get or lose points militarily or try to deny you cards going around the table that you might need. That seems like a lot of stuff to do to the players on your right and left, except it didn't feel like I was seriously planning in that manner, but rather just playing the best card in my hand.

My main complaint is that there are too many symbols in 7 Wonders needlessly complicating the learning curve.

I prefer the uncertainty of when the resources will be available and when the Epochs will end in Ra.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

It was nice to try this but I wouldn't play this on a professional level. Not that I would any other game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Fun Factor: 7
Components: 7 (Decent but not overwhelming)
Theme: 8 (The civ theme here works!)
Mechanics: 9 (Nice card drafting mechanic, this is a good game if you LOVE card drafting!)
Theme + Mechanics: 9
Replay Value: 9 (After several plays it becomes a bit flatter in terms of excitement factor)
Scaling/Players: 9 (This game scales very well but I would not recommend with lower numbers of players as much.)

Subjective: -0.5 Now this is just my opinion, but the game is a bit too fluffy and light after repeated plays.  It just doesn't quite have the meat I need to make it hit the table with my gamer buddies again and again, but with children and non-gamers it fires on all cylinders.

This game is the best game I purchased this year in 2011, and it was an impulse buy.  Bottom line, it is worth purchasing, whatever your game group and/or style of play.  It's just that good.

1/12/12 - It's been a while since I've played it but it's still my wife's favorite game. Once you get over the many (but easy to understand) symbols then this game becomes second nature and flows really well. It plays 7 players and games are really quick. Awesome game. I'm going to have to play it again soon.

7/15/12 - The family has grown to like this game and it's something we can all play quickly. Unfortunately they forget a lot of the rules and the iconography can get a little intimidating for someone who doesn't play often. I purchased the Leaders expansion but have yet to play it with them. The simultaneous turn and the city building are my favorite parts of the game.

RATING: 8
$0 - birthday gift 2013

Goal Met :star::star::star::star::star: $1 or less per play

Great family game for my 4p game group! My brother keeps on wanting another match even though it was almost midnight! A good balanced game with no clear runaway leader problem. The perfect mix of strategy/depth and randomness gets a thumb up from me.

---- Update ----
My sister-in-law prefers this game over Dominion because she feels less "screwed" by my brother simply because the card drafting mechanic makes it less obvious in the sense that someone works against you. In Dominion, attack cards are more direct and personal.
