RATING: 8
A useful game in a game collection because it copes with a wide range of player numbers (2-7, 2-8 with cities) and doesn't get much longer as you add players because of the simultaneous decision making and play.
The depth is ok for the game length (45-60 mins) but the game is long for a filler and short for the main game of an evening however it provides me with an alternative to playing Dominion in this slot.
An alternative would be Nefarious but this has better acceptability with the people that I game with.
I consider one of the expansions essential, not because of the extended game time, extra complexity or the 8th player but because even without using the expansion cards, you can fit the entire game into the expansion box and make it much more portable.
For this reason, buying both expansions is probably a mistake.
Update: after 50 plays to run time is down to 30 minutes including setup and tear down and this has enough depth to be the default end of evening filler. We almost never play with any expansions, except the extra Wonders.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders has got a bit of an initial rules-explanation investment, and the cards get more complicated (resulting in more questions, not fewer, as the game goes on), but ultimately it's a fairly light game.  Yet for all that I enjoyed it a lot, as there are a lot of different directions to go, and there seems to be enough variation to make it interesting for at least the first several plays.  Beyond that I refuse to make a prediction.

I always enjoy playing it, and yet it's so different and kind of tricky to teach (and, by extension, to remember all the various little facets) that I can't see suggesting it, though I'd gladly play it if someone else were willing to take the initial heat for teaching newbies' first plays.

I want to give it a shout out because it actually works with 6 or (mirabile dictu!) 7, without a substantial addition of downtime or waiting to resolve your own turn.  Most tactical games of this sort can play 6 or 7 only by adding time, but 7 Wonders, by limiting concerns to one's neighbors, pulls it off.  Of course, this limits one's impact on the rest of the players, changing the game a bit, but that's a trade I'll gladly make.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great game! The drafting mechanic on every turn means that there is no down time at all, no matter how many players there are. It is also interactive as what you play/your score depends on the cards played by the people on either side of you. This is a great game for a large group of people. The 2-player version, however, was much less enjoyable. We both had to build two wonders (two wonders for each of us and two dummy wonders) and it became quite confusing. We spent almost as much time deciding what to play for the dummy hand as we did our own. So - great game overall but not for two players.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Seven Wonders has been on the market for about a year now. It arrived with much fanfare and lived up to the hype by receiving numerous "Game of the Year" awards. What makes Seven Wonders so appealing is that it does everything well and some things very well. For starters, it fittingly accommodates up to seven players, and games only take 30 to 45 minutes. This combination is unheard of outside of the party games genre. On top of that, it has solid game mechanics, excellent artwork and a great theme.

Each player is the ruler of a civilization and must not only build one of the seven wonders of the ancient world, but also develop their city and protect its borders. The many necessities of a civilized society place great demands on your limited resources. Economy, education, culture, government, technology, military, and of course the completion of that magnificent wonder all need to be addressed. It sounds like an awful lot to accomplish in a 30 to 45 minute card game, but it works quite well.

The game mechanics are what makes Seven Wonders such a unique game. It doesn't really introduce anything groundbreaking, but instead combines familiar mechanics in a way that makes the game quite versatile. Everyone takes their turns at the same time by playing cards from a hand that changes each turn. Each card represents a building that provides benefits such as natural resources, manufactured goods, money, military strength, and points. What you choose to build depends on what you can afford and what fits into your strategy. There are several paths to victory - will you invest heavily in science, build a robust economy, or crush your opponents with your army? (Mind you, no actual battles take place, and like practically every European game, no one is ever eliminated.).  With that being said this is a very good game that I would recommend to anyone.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Bom e rápido. Sempre rola repeteco.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is essentially a drafting game. What you pick changes what is available to others and what they pick changes what is available to you. If you like the process of draft for Magic: the Gathering you will like this game.

The game comes with a two player variant but it really isn't worth playing. You will need at least three people for this game. Because everyone takes turns at the same time, there is little down time. This game really shines with lots of players. I recommend playing this game with 7 people if possible.

Also to understand how this game works you should do a practice run. Meaning the first time you play you won't have any clue what is going on, but the second time everything will make perfect since (or at least that has been my experience when I learned and when I teach others).

All in all a solid game with lots of replay ability especially if you have a large and varied play group.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Drafting game that plays up to 7 players by adding more cards at higher player counts. Since all players only interacts with their immediate neighbors to the left and right, the game does not vary significantly in length regardless of player count. The drawback is that the more players there are, the greater the risk of getting duplicate cards which can't be drafted to play, since you can't have two cards with the same name in your tableau. Although they can be exchanged for money, I like this at the lower player counts.

The two player game is solid but uses a dummy player that the players alternate drafting cards for. For me it works just fine, but many seem to prefer 7 Wonders Duel for two player games.

After trying higher player counts, my preference would probably be in the lower range of players, 2-4. The reasons are that at the higher player counts, there are multiple copies of the same card. Since you can only ever have one card with the same name, the second card would be useless unless you can squirrel it away in your wonder. At lower player counts you will also have the chance to see the same hand more than one time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really enjoy this game. If you like card drafting types of games this is an excellent game. Similar to sushi go, with more strategy and complexity. Every game is different.

RATING: 7
The value to 7 Wonders is in its short game time, depth without too much complexity, and ability to handle a good number of players without significant down time. If the game took any more time to play than it does or was any more complex I probably wouldn't like it; fortunately, it hits the sweet spot.
Its ease of entry, taking only a little more instruction than a casual game and can be taught to non-gamers fairly easily, makes this a nice game to break out in a non-hardcore gaming group or inbetween games. There is strategy to your choices so gamers who prefer heavier games can still enjoy it. Since you don't invest a lot of time into it you don't feel like you need much more.

RATING: 6
Update: Not a game that interests me anymore as just too busy graphically with the optimal 4 players.

First play with 3 was interesting as I noticed that as you see your diminishing hand of cards 3 times and both your opponents twice, if you could/care to memorise the contents of each hand you could set yourself for efficient card play (unless your passing neighbour denies you that desired card). So with more players means the loss of this aspect (which triggers the mastery instinct that drives the need for a repeat play). 

Yet the fact that upto 7 players can be 'interested' simultaneously is one reason for 7 Wonders inclusion in many game collections.But the more I play it with 3 or 4 the less convinced I need to go on the ride with more players and not using all the cards seems a waste.

RATING: 7

Update: I think I much prefer this game at lower player counts. The more there are, the more random and chaotic it feels. You can make all the good choices you can, but still be screwed by the distribution of cards and the unpredictability of your neighbors.

RATING: 3
Really? This is the game that has garnered (undeservedly, in my opinion) so much hype. It qualifies as the ultimate BGG 6 rating: "some fun" and "may play sporadically" mostly because it moves (and is over) quickly. Too much iconography for casual gamers; not enough strategy for gamers. Will play as a filler while waiting for others to finish their longer game. Not interested in buying. 

Still baffled by its meteoric rise in the rankings here. Is it because of a shift in the core demographics of the BGG user? Not that that is a bad thing... I mean if this can sell over 10,000 copies maybe I can make some money on my new game, "Fart in a Box"

Lowered my rating to 3.0 after 8 months. Still have not played it again. Every time I see it being pulled out I make some excuse to make a quick exit. I think my last one was that I had to have razor blades inserted into my pancreas.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
To a certain extent I'm just tired of this game, after 18 plays. I like the simple drafting mechanism, but this game's icons are really hard to understand, which undercuts the enjoyable simplicity. Especially when the leader's expansion is included. The game also gets less interactive the more players you involve, but with fewer players the cards get less interesting. The method of scoring the green science cards feels needlessly complicated in comparison to the rest of the game. I sold this game and it's expansions when I came to realize that I got the same positive feelings from playing a quick round of Sushi Go, as I did from a lengthy play of this game, but it didn't come with all the stuff I didn't like.

:nostar: Art and components
:nostar: Innovative mechanics
:star: Handles 5 or more players
:nostar: Good with min or max players
:star: Low time between turns
:star: Comfortable complexity
:star: Re-playability
:star::nostar::nostar: Enjoyment

RATING: 6
:thumbsup: Hard-pressed to think of things I like about this game. I keep it because I can see getting some value out of it once my sons are old enough to learn it, years from now. 

:thumbsdown: To begin with, I find the 2-player variant very awkward. It's only worth bringing out with 3 or more players. I find the player interaction lacking and the decisions flat. However, for such a one-dimensional game, it fails as a gateway for having so many icons and categories of cards to explain. It's a pain to teach, or maybe I just find it to be a pain because I don't care for the game. This could definitely be a case of perhaps finding more to the game after repeated play but I never hit upon anything intriguing enough to motivate me. Unlike other games, I don't get a feel that I am building anything in particular as much as simply maximizing points.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The first thing to say about 7 Wonders is that it is really just Fairy Tale with more appealing artwork and some additional wrinkles. That's not a problem as Fairy Tale is a great filler and the wrinkles are improvements. But don't come here expecting a meaty card game of the like of Race for the Galaxy or Glory to Rome. Where this game really excels is allowing seven players to play something with a little more substance than 6 Nimmt in 20-30 minutes. That's achieved by the clever breaking down of the game into subgames between you and your two neighbours. There's really no need to look across the table as you'll only be buying resources from and scoring points based on the players to either side of you. The speed is achieved by having nearly everything happen simultaneously; I was amazed by the lack of downtime. But I probably won't be buying this. There are going to be copies everywhere anyway, and I suspect replayability will be limited until the inevitable Dominion-style expansions start appearing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It's a pain to teach new players because of all the card symbols, but I love it. It's great how it doesn't really take any longer with 7 players than it does with 3.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
This game is a tableau-builder which uses an innovative draft and pass mechanism that keeps all players engaged at all times. And that is the only positive. It should honestly get a 2 or 3 rating, but due to sponsor deals, it's at least a thousand places ahead of where it belongs on the hit parade here, so I downvote as hard as I possibly can.

Before you start, setup is a nightmare, requiring specific cards to be stripped or added from each of three age-specific decks depending on the number of players. Heaven forfend somebody wants to back out or join in while you "haven't started yet"  

Once you start, you will have no idea what you are doing, and the age-specific nature of cards means that there is no making up for missed opportunities later.

As something like a parody of a Eurogame, strategy is in fact impossible, since you cannot know your own nor anybody else's score during play, so you have no clue who you should be cooperating with and who you should be working against and are playing this as a solo optimization problem.

When you get to the end, you will have people pull out their mobile devices to run the scoring algorithm. Call me old fashioned, but a game that requires a spreadsheet to score should not be a non-digital game. Scoring literally involves 7 different types of set collection counting, some of which are additive, some of which are subtractive and some of which involve square roots. I'd dismiss it as "point salad", but that's sorry cliche and most people can make salads quicker than they can tabulate their score in this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Love this game. Love the interaction, balance, and dynamics. Still haven't played all of the expansions but am really looking forward to it!

RATING: 7.3

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
No rating yet because I've only played with 3 players. I really like a lot of the design decisions they made Rewarding players for defensively drafting three cards through the course of the game is a great way to make meddling with your opponents' plans a viable strategy, they somehow manage to make drafting a red-colored card feel like an act of war, and the mandatory trading of resources makes drafting resource cards a really interesting decision. Some say that the green cards ruin the game, but my gut tells me they need to find a better green strategy. I'd like to try this with more players to get the full experience of the game.

Edit: Tried with 5 and then with 7, and it was very cool! This really needs more players to work, but when it does, it's exactly what you want to bring to the table when you need something quick for 4-7 midrange-skill gamers.

Edit: I just played a session with half-new players, half-veterans, and that dynamic caused some weird things to happen. I understand this is a problem in most games, but it's even worse here, because veterans can't even help new players or give them advice without looking at packs they're not supposed to look at. We finished, and the game was alright, but this one really loses a lot when players of different experience levels play. Use with caution.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is one of the best new games I have played in a long time.  It plays quickly, there is no dead time, there are a ton of decisions, and multiple ways to play and win.  I do not think that you can play one strategy every time and be successful.  You have to watch what the players on your left and right are doing and adapt accordingly.  You also have to work with the cards that come to you.  It is a very enjoyable game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My biggest beef with this game is that there's no solid way to interact at all with something somebody across the table is doing in a 5+ player game. I can't affect them via military, can't trade resources, etc. Obviously hate-drafting things is a pseudo-interaction, but it rarely makes that big of a difference, especially since most of the pack will be gone by the time it gets to them anyway. Most of the time I feel like I'm playing a game with the people on my left and right, and there's a nebulous "other player(s)" that I have to make sure I beat in points as well.

That said, the game itself is solid on mechanics. I do enjoy playing, and (especially with people who know what they're doing) playtime is quick.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
A nice variant of efficiency engine games with a bit more possible interaction due to trading, military and victory points based on opponents' buildings. I especially like the mechanic of choosing one card from your hand and passing on the remaining cards. It plays very quick and I the only thing that is left for me to find out is whether it plays well with 2 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
WOW!!!!! This game is Definitly deserving of its rank on Boardgame geek!!! This is the type of game that allows a player to use lesser strategy tactics on other players, resource managment, and a huge alternating gameplay with different wonders that force a player to think in a differnt way. I enjoyed being forced to think in different ways based on the wonder I had. I first started with the Statues of Zues on Olympus and that went rather well (I came in 2nd out of 4, by 1 point)(it is an easy card to build and doesn't mess with the build up and conquer theory most Warcraft III & Command and Conquer players are used to. THen I got the Rhodes (colosseus) and got my ass handed to me since I was a build up the forces and send the horde type of player and now i was to focus more on resouces than fighting and got waxed by everyone. I then played Babylon and won that game by 1 point out of the 4 and was interested in the Guilds and building structures not so much in armies or money. That was a cool game for sure.

I would STRONGLY recommend this game to anyone who likes a light game with a mild strategy mixed in. It is well deserving of its high marks and love it gets. True quality and Fantastic Artwork makes this game a must have for everyone.

RATING: 7.5
To be completely fair to this game, I would have initially ranked it a 9.  In fact, I think I did.  Out of the gate, this game is a blast.  What did this game in for me was, essentially, figuring it out.  We played this game over and over when I first got it, and the gameplay eventually became rote.  The expansions do a nice job of adding new wrinkles and replayability, but only for so long.  I still enjoy playing this game when a larger group (6 or 7) gets together.  Especially if it includes people who aren't super-into board games, but I won't reach for this game if I'm the one picking.  I'd rather play Time's Up if it's a casual group, or Among the Stars if it's a more gamer-y group.

RATING: 8
Game is really smooth and fast. Offers multiple paths to victory but avoids a lot of the AP that similar strategy games encounter due to the card drafting mechanic. I've seen people win using all the different methods which is what you want to see.

There is definitely a little bit of a learning curve for new players but once you get the basics it is straightforward. Card Icons are very easy to understand and provide the necessary info.

Great replay value due to the random starting player boards and selection of available cards. Plays well with almost all player counts and I enjoy the 2-player variant just as much as the other player counts.

RATING: 5
A fine gateway game for introducing your non-gaming friends to medium-light strategic thinking.  
7 Wonders doesn't overstay it's welcome, but still gives the feeling of having achieved something when played well.

However, clunky endgame book keeping and a general lack of depth or player interaction prevent this from being much more than an introduction to drafting, and a gateway the board-gaming world.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Splendido gioco, veloce, capace di unire in un tavolo fino a sette giocatori e alla portata di tutti. Questo è il segreto di 7 Wonders! A spiegarlo sembra complesso ma la naturalezza con cui lo si gioca mostra quanto sia in realtà intuitivo. Scalabilità altissima e durata sempre contenuta grazie alle giocate in contemporanea. Un "cardgame" travestito da "boardgame". Bellissima la dinamica di passaggio carte, bellissime le plance e le carte da gioco. Poco meno di un "giocone" di alta strategia molto più di un "filler". Tra gli aspetti negativi, se proprio vogliamo trovarli, c'è sicuramente la poca interazione con chi non è seduto vicino, ma che rispecchia effettivamente la poca influenza che civiltà lontane possono avere tra loro. Uno dei giochi più belli mai provati. Belle anche le sue espansioni Cities (principalmente aggiunge le carte nere), Pack (quattro nuove plance) e quelle scaricabili da internet (soprattutto le plance) fatte dagli appassionati di questo gioco. Uno dei giochi che non deve assolutamente mancare nella Ludoteca Ideale!!! International Gamers Award... 2011.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So, uhm, Never play this game.  No, Not even then. Card drafting and Resource management is not the end of the world, but when the people to your right and left can limit what you can do with their choices as well, Then you have a player sitting there doing nothing worth doing.  Don't design a game that encourages me to not bother playing since I'll never get a effective choice.    I get that I have to chose to adopt a couple of strategies to focus on rather than trying to branch out, But when my opponent can clearly see what the goals of my society are before I even play, that gives them too much power to stop those goals from ever happening, even if they have different goals than mine for their society. I suppose I could choose goals my society wouldn't normally have, and screw theirs over, but I couldn't seem to effectively withhold enough cards from them in the drafting.  It's just an hour plus of "hey,you get to eat Crap."  Sucks. I have two words for this game: P and U.

RATING: 9
One of my favourites at the moment. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
So much to like about this game.
- It can handle up to 7 players.
- It's a fairly fast game, once everyone knows how to play.  I have personally completed several games in less than 20 minutes, when playing with experienced players.  Plus the game time doesn't increase significantly by adding more players.
- The game is really easy to explain.  I usually just explain the simplest rules in a couple minutes, and then have new players ask questions in the middle of a game.  Additionally, my 7 year old son has played this game, and has almost defeated me several times already.
- I love the fact that the game has almost no downtime, because of the simultaneous card drafting mechanic.  I'm surprised more games haven't taken advantage of this mechanic.
- It has a decent amount of strategy, although your strategy is typically locked down into a certain track by Age III.
- Replayability is huge.  You can always try different civilizations and different card drafting strategies, depending on what your first couple hands show.
- There are expansions to add to game variety.

That's a lot to say, but I really love this game.  One of my favorites, for sure.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
School game.

A lot of fun to play and deceptively simple - I was initially put off by all the iconography, but needn't have been. The game gives a really good sense of development and it satisfies the civ-building itch that I want to scratch more frequently than most. On the downside, I feel that the game plays itself to a large extent. 90% of the decisions are no-brainers and those that aren't don't feel critical or agonising. Despite this negative, I will still welcome the opportunity to play. It is slick and fast and the theme appeals.

RATING: 7
[b]RO[/b]: [i]07/05/2015[/i]

Unlike most games 7 Wonders scales exceptionally well with any player count (up to seven, of course); because of this it is a game I often break out with a large group.

7 Wonders is a light card drafting game at it's core. Thought and strategy are required for an edge in game play, but the overall nuts and bolts of the game are exceptionally easy to grasp. Recommended for new/casual gamers. That said, there is enough meat here to keep a serious player satisfied.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Extremely interesting drafting game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Just a flat out great game.  It's tons of fun to play and with little or no language on the cards it's very easy to bring to a multi-lingual crowd.  The mechanics are fun, the set up is random which helps prevent meta-strategy, but also keeps consistent.  There are several paths to victory and the layout allows you to block others' paths on the way to yours.  Interaction is minimal but your choices affect everyone in the game.  This adds a lot of tension without the game being a friend-ender.  

The only downside is that this game is a bit of a table hog.  For anything larger than a 3 payer game get a larger table or play on the floor.  

Also don't bother with the 2 player variant.  Buy Duels if you want to do two players.  This game wasn't designed for 2 players so the 2 player rules are just kind of silly.  

Other than those things there nothing negative I can say.  It's beautifully drawn, and obvious that the designers put a lot work and effort into every detail of the game.  Great work Mr. Bauza and crew!

RATING: 9.73

The multi-player game is also fantastic and is both easy and fun to play.  Really good for 3 players - which plays really tight, but scales well to greater numbers too.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a game that I enjoy more the more I play it. The mechanics are simple but offer a lot of choices. Knowing when to pay someone for their resources or tossing a card for money or build your wonder may seem fairly insignificant, but these little actions add up fast.

Perhaps the game's greatest strength is how fast it plays and how more players (up to 7 or more!) barely increases the playing time. In fact, it's so fast you barely have enough time to stop and look at the beautiful artwork.

I started off not liking 7 Wonders very much, but it has quickly become one of our favorite short games. I highly recommend grabbing an expansion or a couple promos too.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A good short filler for up to seven people. Colorful and nicely made. Took me a few plays to start to see the interest, and I'm still not sure that it should be ranked as highly as it is; but it's a good, solid game. The two-player variant is surprisingly intricate and almost vicious.

RATING: 10
Pros:
- quick playing time allows me to get in games easily.
- cards are nice and colorful.  It looks pretty on the table and gets the attention of folks passing by.
- I enjoy the draft-and-pass mechanic to construct your play field. 
- scales well for almost any number of players.

Cons:
- the cards are a little flimsy and wear.  Can be eliminated by sleeving - but I hate sleeving :)
- some of the backs of the cards (age 3) are slightly a different color than others.  Doesn't bother me much, and again can be eliminated by sleeving, but does bother some.

 7/20/13 updating to a ten.  This is a great game my whole family enjoys.  We recently added the cities expansion which helped round out things nicely.  Also constructed the fan expansion lost wonders, which is fantastic.

Es de Ricardo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Dan has this.
Description: Ancient civilization city building, card drafting, set collection game with simultaneous action selection and variable player (Wonder) powers.
Weight: Light.
Number of players: 2 to 7. Good with all counts from 3 to 7.
Designer: Antoine Bauza.
Publisher: Repos Production.

Impression: First it was awesome, than it started to be repetitive, and finally I started to enjoy pretty much every time we play. And no matter how many players there is, it flows like a charm, due to simultaneous action selection. Drafting is something that takes the most time because there is a lot of decision making. Will you go for blues, or greens, or more resources, or maybe military, maybe you need money, or perhaps a stage of your Wonder or you just simply want to block your neighbor from getting a certain card. Haven't yet tried all the expansions.

Likes: Drafting. Simultaneous card play. Many different double sided wonders (more than 7 with expansions) with unique powers on each side. Using resources from your neighbors for a fee. Multiple viable strategies.

Dislikes: It might become stale after you try all the strategies. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very good (and fast) strategy game !
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
We played this with a friend and really enjoyed it.  The decisions/interaction with other players makes this game very expandable.

The simultaneous player turns makes this game move quickly too.  Occasionally you'll end up waiting for that one player with analysis paralysis, but it's not bad.

Really a solid game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I bought 7 Wonders to introduce to my gaming group (my partner, my mother and her partner, as well as a gamer friend with whom I sporadically play a board-game once in a blue moon) after TTR and Catan.

7 Wonders is a essentially a card game that utilises a drafting mechanic that allows players to select cards that will allow them to develop their civilisation and build their Wonders. There are a number of different paths to victory available, and using the cards to build a tableau representing the development of your civilisation, and the various development 'engines' (paths) is visually pleasing. 

7 Wonders didn't feel as satisfying as I hoped after all of the positive reviews. The reason for the extra .5 score is because the game scales incredibly well - playable from 2-7. I played with 3 players because my friend and my partner were both late drop-outs (former had to head home for dinner and got waylaid by TV, and the latter feel asleep on the sofa.

Re-rated: 1 point increase after playing with the full compliment (7) of players at a London on Board meet. I foresee more play an an increased rating w/ full player compliment and possible expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good, quick and light game. Play with the family at holiday gatherings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
Players: 2-7
Time: 30-45 min.

Each player controls an ancient civilization and plans a path to victory by attempting to score points in science, military, commerce, civilian structures, guilds and by building their Wonder. Players take turns simultaneously via a unique card-drafting mechanic: you choose a card from a hand, then pass that hand to your neighbor. The rules are simple and there are multiple paths to victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Have played this probably ~20 times with 2 & 3 players.  Good game with interesting choices, but not very...exciting, which is fine.  It moves along quickly until the last round when we start into the purple cards and calculating what will maximize our points and minimize everyone else's.

A very good, solid, entertaining game that doesn't take too long to play (less than an hour, perhaps as quick as half-an-hour).

RATING: 9.8
This is an incredible civ type game that plays quick and easy but has so much variety.   Multiple ways to win and is everything I would ever want in a quick civ game.  It's thematic, makes sense and really nice to look at.   after two more plays this game has displayed multiply ways to victory.  Unfortunately not my victory but I love it game.  I did earn a beer for losing with the expansion rules though. edit :notched my first win-the aspects of this game just get better and better.  It's quick like Dominion but deep as I need a civ game to  be and despite the majority of card being identical, the game plays different each time.  I guess the only thing I can say bad about the game is that the hands can be random an sometimes so you get a hand of garbage and other times you get everything you would possibly want. I have to raise the rating of this because i can't see a time I wouldn't want to play.

RATING: 10
Card Drafting, Set collection.

I love, love, love this game.  

I never get tired of it and as you can see I have almost everything you can get for this game.  It's excellent.

The play in this game, to me, is very fast and engaging, you have some player interaction.  Most of that is concern for what your neighbors are doing but that is something.

Recommend the insert if you want to get the expansions, makes life way easier.

Owned Expansions:

RATING: 8
[b]5 plays in:[/b]

Both my wife and I really enjoy this game so far. My parents, however, found it to be much too complex. This surprised me, but I think it is at least partially because the information and icons on the cards are pretty small and my dad's eyes are not good enough to easily read the relevant information. 

I love the simultaneous action mechanic in the game and other game design decisions designed to keep things streamlined and moving. (For example, military resolving against only your two neighbors.) Would love to play this more with several player counts.

Anyway, I'm hoping to find some players as this game is going to get stale using 2 player variants.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've played this around 5 times, with between 4 and 7 players. I just don't get the appeal. It isn't really a drafting game - you can't leave cards in the pack and hope they come back to you, even in small player games - you take the card that's best for you most of the time, or if building your wonder you take the card that's worst for your opponents. It isn't really a civ-building game... you don't really build an engine and play with it, because it's too short, and the engine is too simple. And the military feels like prisoner's dilemma. If it's goal was to make a game that scales up to 7 players without increasing much in time, it did a pretty good job... the only argument is in how much "game" was actually built.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.2
This is very poor game. Yes, it is clearly inspired by the booster draft format of Magic (one of the least entertaining and most expensive ways to play that game) but it has none of the cleverness of that.
The game tries to play very, very quickly, but it is far too complex for that level of play (a currency, 7 different resource types, 5 different victory point schemes). The core idea, of drawing a card and passing on the hand while other players do the same is sound, but if it was intended to play fast for large numbers of players (and it clearly was) it needed a much simpler set of cards, which would have enhanced, rather than diminishing the decision making process.
One for a designer to try once and go 'ooh, I know how that could be made to work' but not one to be played or bought, though it seems to have fared well in the Essen '10 hype.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A civilisation card building game spanning 3 ages. Each game lasting around 30 minutes, regardless of the number of players (3-7) which is a big plus.  It's  fairly easy to learn/teach with most people taking just one game to fully appreciate the mechanics.

Direct game play interaction is limited to the players either side of you.  The card drafting mechanic whereby cards are passed in one direction until all but one are allotted, provides some potential to limit options to other players.  The mechanic can also be seen in Among The Stars. 

There are various expansions available, none of which are essential to get a feel for the game.

:star::star::star::star::nostar: Easy to learn
:star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: Fun factor
:star::star::star::star::nostar:   Replay-ability

:star::star::star::nostar::nostar:     Overall

Why the game stays in my collection? The take one card and pass the rest to the player next to you mechanic creates situations where you are torn between picking the best card for yourself or the one that lets other players score the least. The multiple scoring paths and light feel of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Great game in which after well over 100 games (mostly online) I'm still learning. Watching what you're opponents are doing, anticipating what your neighbours (especially the one to your right) is doing (most importantly, the military cards).
I now consistently score above 50 points, but still often get beat badly. Game play is very quick, with new players max. 1 hour and with experienced players this go down to under 30 minutes, while still having plenty of strategy.

Awesome game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's remarkable just how good this game manages to be, given that the mechanics are little more than just straight card-drafting. But it manages to be near infinitely replayable because of all the different wonders you can play and how they interact with those of the other players - and, of course, how the cards get dealt. And I know of no other game that can produce such a satisfying experience with player counts from 3 to 7 in just 20 minutes or so. (I'm not a fan of the official 2-player variant, even though I think it's much better with 3 or 4 than with higher numbers - but I'm still happy to play a 7-player game). It becomes a more fulfilling game with expansions, but even just base 7 wonders, without being a particularly deep game, is really too satisfying an experience to be called a mere filler, despite its short play-time and simple mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
"Pass the trash" style card drafting game. High player count, theme, and quick play are the upsides. Downsides are symbology and the amount of table space it takes up. Although not fair to compare, 7 Wonders Duel scratches the drafting itch more for me than this does now.

RATING: 9.9

As one commenter says, this is not going to do it for those who can't find a game challenging enough unless it takes more than 2 hours to play. But for people like me, this game offers the best "bang" in terms of challenge/interesting play per "time," less than an hour to play. 

Many people consider Dominion the best "bang" for "time" out there. 

This game far surpasses Dominion to me and gets my highest rating. The only reason it does not get a 10 is that I generally believe that there is always improvement.

If someone can improve upon this while keeping under an hour in time, it would be gaming heaven.

RATING: 8
Fantastic game that's quite flexible. Really hits the sweet spot between simple/fast and complex/engaging: there are very few people that would be too intimidated to play if you're a solid instructor. That said, it can be a bit challenging to explain to someone that doesn't game often. Also works well as a two-player game, using the dummy third as a shield/bludgeon/bank. Only other minor gripe would be duration - can stretch well beyond 30-45 minutes for first-timers or those predisposed to AP. Highly recommend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Admittedly, I am not a huge fan of card-drafting games. I do not much like having my strategy be beholden to the whims of others, rather than just straight luck of the draw. The gameplay also tends to become stale after a few rounds, and I felt that 7 Wonders was no exception. The card iconography was annoyingly incoherent, and I do not think this problem would have been as significant had there not been such a sheer amount of icons to follow. I would imagine participating in multiple plays will alleviate this issue.

We played with six players, and this may have hurt the pace and interaction to a degree. I could see the interaction becoming more pronounced at three players, but the game dragged on to become so rote that I have no desire to explore it further. In fact, the myriad of expansions to the base game suggests quantity reigns over quality in this much-heralded title.

(+) Gameplay flows smoothly.
(+) Theme is recognizable and has arguably wide appeal.
(+) Variable nations and expansions provide some replayability (not necessarily much more depth).

(-) Iconography is in abundance and not always intuitive.
(-) Gameplay starts to feel repetitive and drags at higher player counts.
(-) Minimal amount of player interaction leads to a dull metagame that does not incentivize further plays. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.3
Fluid, quick, fun, light game. 

This game is tactical while hanging a strategy carrot for you to try to follow. While the game seems to be encouraging you to have a strategic plan, that plan can and probably will change as the game goes along. You just do the best you can with the cards that are handed to you and hope future hands will work with what you are trying to do.

The different paths to victory seem pretty balanced, but it is tough to win with a heavy military focus unless another scoring method is explored as well. I've won by going nearly completely commercial, civilian and scientific. Going completely military is the only path which has a hard cap of points you can earn - only 18 points total (and only if you win every single battle all game- which is far from guaranteed. 18 points is pretty small compared to scoring 58 by going straight scientific for instance).

This game scores bonus points from me for not playing any slower with 7 than it does with 3. The 2 player game even works pretty well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Roy's game (Tristen & Joe now own too)

In 2011 this game got the most play at our house. We often have a house full of people wanting to play. This game can play 7 and since folks play simultaneously, once everyone understands the game it plays fast. Great game.

http://www.asaboardgamer.com/review/7-wonders-qr/
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.755
It's surprising that a game with such simple rules can be so entertaining! Once you select an ancient city, all you do is pick a card and pass the rest to your neighbor. But should you prepare for war? Pursue advancement in science? Add to your marketplace with resources for sale? Perhaps you should just build a statue. With each player needing to build one of the seven wonders of the ancient world, should you commit resources to the great pyramid now or later? The decision making process is what makes this game so fun. We take 30-45 minutes for a 4-player game. Try it and you will be hooked.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4.5
Mechanically this game is fine, but there's so much going on it's really tough to keep track of everything all at once. Not that too many elements are necessarily a bad thing, but unless you're really policing everyone I've found it's easy to accidentally cheat by forgetting minor rule caveats and unbalancing the game.

Overall I like the game, but it's not fun enough to get it on the table.

RATING: 7
This is just a classic and packs a lot of fun in a short timeframe. This game is a great game design. It is amazing that the game can be played in 30 minutes even with the full seven player. I can't bring myself to play with anything less than 4 players but it is the easiest game to hit the table, not in terms of set up, but in terms of game play.  The rules are easy to pick up but the game is still is strategic.  

Pros: Player interaction, Quick Game, Easily teachable, Creative Mechanics

Cons: Setup time to separate cards for number of players, Not as enjoyable for small numbers
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
So far after about 5 plays this is really good. Have tried it with 4 and 5. Super fast, fun. 

Update: After more plays and more thinking about this. I think the game is perfect for what it is attempting to be. A medium weight game that gets deeper with more plays. It can accomidate up to 7 players with no down time. The game plays amazingly fast, and is a lot of fun. The production value is very high, the art is good, and the setup is really quite fast considering it is variable to the number of players.

RATING: 10

People used to playing board games will pick up on it quickly.  Usually I creme them the first game we play, but then they always beat me the next game.  I must not be very good...  I even got my family to play this a couple of times, although it was harder for some of them to follow the rules of what cards you can and can not play.  Recommended mostly for board game fans.

RATING: 6
--Dec2010-- Delightfully themed drafting game.  After only 1 play with 3, I'm not at all competent to judge its merits.  But I rather enjoyed the first outing:  it seemed rather similar in feel to _Fairy Tale_.
--Aug2011-- Yet after a few games, it seems to be a species of blind bidding.  One wins if the set of synergies one chooses aren't the current fashion amongst one's opponents.  And loses if one subscribes to the current groupthink.  It's very pretty, but it doesn't look like there's much substance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game fills a nice spot in my collection in that it is not a party game and can still play up to 7 players in under an hour. For that alone, I give it high marks. Not too complicated either, so a good one to pull out with many people, though I think the rules are a touch too complex to work with everyone.

The game itself actually provides some excruciating choices, though there's a few automatic ones too. Player interaction is higher than I expected too since many of those choices come from taking what you want or preventing your neighbor from getting that one card that will give them a lot of points. Randomness is a little higher than I care for though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Alapvetően túlhype-olt játéknak gondolom...

Van számos előnye: 2-től 7 főig játszható másik játékot nem nagyon tudok, amelyik ennyire kiegyensúlyozott a játékosszámtól függetlenül. Ráadásul ugyanakkor meglehetősen rapid is (max. 30 perc körül lehet). A jó játékok védjegyeivel bír: ezer út vezet a győzelemhez, maga a játék szép, az ikonok rengeteget segítenek stb.  (Bár, az igazság az, hogy a kártyák rajzai semmit nem tesznek hozzá a történethez, az ember szinte csak az ikonokra fókuszál). A táblákon levő csoda megjelenítések is igazán remekek.

Ugyanakkor, amik nem tetszettek benne: kvázi passziánsz jellegű (oké, hogy a szomszédokra folyamatosan kell figyelni, de 3+ fő esetén a többiekre vajmi kevés a befolyás). Mivel mindenki maga építgeti a paklijait, viszonylag kevés az interakció (a kereskedelem ellenére is). Nyugodtan lehetne konfrontatívabb is. Fentiek okán talán ezért a legjobb 3 fővel, mert mindenki függ mindenkitől.
5-7 játékos esetén eléggé "kaotikus", ahogy mindenki egyszerre építgeti a le a lapjait (persze pont emiatt a parallel helyzet miatt gyors...)
Valamint a kártyák minősége eléggé lehangoló, főleg annak függvényében, hogy egy 10eFt körüli (kvázi kártya)játékról beszélünk.

Mindent egybevetve szerethető, de nekem valami még hiányzik belőle (ezt majd talán a kiegészítők valamelyike pótolja?).

RATING: 8.5
In just three months, 7 Wonders has become the No. 1 Family Game in the World! It has all the features of being a top family game: zero text reading, quickplay, supporting up to 7 players, bright colours. You use your cards to build your own Wonders and other structures. However I don't think 7 Wonders is newbie-friendly: you got to explain to new players about the meaning of the card symbols, and they usually are not sure about which card to play/pass, which almost guarantee a loss in their debut and a win by his/her neighbor, making new players repulsive for a second session. Ah, the Card Drafting, the weakest player decides the winner.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

For me, the game is at its best with more than 5, because that's when you get the most tension out of it. I realized some time ago that what's kept this game interesting for me is the tension in choosing the best card out of every hand when it passes you by and then seeing how thing turn out. Ultimately though, interaction in this game is observational, not direct or even indirect. Trades can never be denied and the fighting is way abstracted and not very profitable. Interaction here means that you should keep an out for what others are doing, though it never seems to pay off to build something someone else would've wanted if you have the option of building something even remotely good for you.

Sold on account of hollow core and because almost everyone has it should I ever want to play.

I won't turn down a game, but it wouldn't be my first suggestion either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Quite a few reviews compare this game with Dominion and Race for the Galaxy, but, as a regular player of both, 7 Wonders doesn't play at all like the two. I suppose that, since 7 Wonders has cards which you pick, that makes 7 Wonders similar to both Race and Dominion. Which, in my opinion, it does not. Eurogamers should like 7 Wonders, but, as an erstwhile non-drafting CCG player, I found this game as generic as any other Eurogame (cards and boards have good art, though). The drafting pretty much tweaks the usual tired "multiple paths to victory" Eurogame mechanic. Drafting *does* require you deny cards the player you will pass card on to, but I'm pretty "meh" on this mechanic. As with other "multiple paths to victory" Eurogames, you'll need to "become familiar with" (aka. memorize) the cards -- not to mention scoring system -- a Eurogame tendency which pretty much negates the selling point of the simplicity of the game mechanics. If you're looking for a Eurogame with another novel mechanic (by Eurostandards, at least), I guess this is it. But if 7 Wonders is comparable to Dominion, both are just like Risk.

****

Beats me.

See, I just played it yesterday. And I hated it. The draft mechanic doesn't make the tired old "multiple paths to victory" Euromechanic any better. As for "filler", the game just took too d*mn long for what you did: pick a card and pass the rest along. 

I don't think the game's overrated at all. I *know* many BGG'ers love the "multiple paths" mechanic. I find it all too much to memorize, since you have to [-]memorize[/-] be familiar with the scoring system *and* the card distribution in the deck *and* the cards themselves. Which I find to be a PITA. Drafting, meanwhile, is a new mechanic to the Eurocrowd. Fairy Tales does it, but FT didn't add the "multiple paths" mechanic. 

Eurogamers *should* try this game. I'm not a Eurogamer, so don't have any interest in playing this again.

***

Didn't like 7 Wonders at all:
* Scales terribly with 7 players. You get a new hand of cards each turn, so it's like trying to put a strategy onto a pile of random cards.
* Turns are fast only if you know what you're doing, which means you must know the cards in the deck (assuming you want to win).
* With 7 players, you're mostly denying the next player an optimal move. Passive aggression at its finest.
* Player socialization is limited to looking over your neighbor's shoulder to look at his cards, or passing him a better hand if he or she is you non-gaming spouse.
* Yet another arbitrary "multiple paths to victory" scoring system.

We played a game of seven players, two with some experience. I think I came in second or third, with the winning player and myself saying we wouldn't play the game again.

Citadels: Deduction and outguessing. With bursts of smack talk.
7 Wonders: Deny your opponent an optimal card. Repeat until done.

I probably *would* play 7 Wonders two-player. In two-player, you will receive back the hand you passed to your opponent, so you can do some planning. Also, my two-player CCG opponent would give me the time to AP out a turn.

****

Main problems about the game for the non-gamers:

* Hidden information. *Some* non-gamers don't like the "emotional" conflict of revealing information to a more experienced player (ie. you) while not understanding the cards.

* Icons. Icons are essentially a different language. Yes, I'd like to play my games in Swahili.

That's obviously why Race for the Galaxy isn't a gateway game, while the "other" role selection game, Puerto Rico (sometimes) is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The base mechanic of this game is very simple: pick a card to play, pass the rest of the cards to your neighbour (left or right, depending on the "Age" you're playing in). But there's some clever decision making connected to this simple mechanic: what kind(s) of card(s) will you focus on for endgame scoring, which cards can you build cheapest, which cards do you definitely want to keep out of your neighbour's hands,...?

All players pick, then play, their cards simultaneously. This makes the game flow very smoothly, especially if you're playing with people who are familiar with the rules. Things don't get boring, as you're always trying out new ways of scoring that fit well with the Wonder you've been dealt.

Lastly, the components are great, as is to be expected from a [company=4384][/company]-game. Sturdy cardboard for the Wonder boards and tokens (coins, victory and defeat tokens). Beautiful artwork. And great graphic design on the cards, with clear icons for resources and special effects. The design also keeps table clutter to a minimum, as it helps you put your cards down in an organized manner - although some players still manage to make a mess of things...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A solid game for a number of reasons. Visually appealing, well-presented, and with nice tokens and boards, the game manages to be interesting without relying on wacky mechanics or themes.

One of the great things about 7 Wonders is that a game nearly always takes roughly the same time - players take 18 turns across 3 ages. Since direct interaction (apart from which cards get passed on) is confined to direct neighbours, the game remains simple with any number of players. Combined, this makes a game that can take 3-7 players with very little change in set up, and no increase in play time (except for comparing scores at the end!).

Nicely balanced around its drafting mechanic, every turn sees you building up your collection of structures. Resources being permanent is another addition that prevents gameplay becoming an accounting exercise.

7 Wonders has a rare quality - it's simple, quick and attractive enough to interest casual (or non) gamers (a single guided game is a good way to teach someone), and tactical enough for more serious players. In the two weeks since I have bought this game it has been the favourite for lunchtime games with colleagues, and often comes out at home before or after another longer game.

While it's not impossible to overplay this game, it will probably never be something you'll object to playing, and is a good way to spend some time, and introduce other people to the wonders of quality board gaming. At a low-medium price range, this game is definitely worth the cost.

Though at present (having played the game many, many times in the last two weeks) my personal enjoyment of the game would leave it rated at 9, when I consider all of the ways this game is well-made, and the impact it has had on my friends and coworkers (direct fun, and getting them interested in board gaming), it deserves the full rating of 10.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Bill
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I like the hand-swapping/draft mechanism - it eliminates a lot of potential for AP without completely removing opportunities for strategy, and allows neighbors to subtly mess with one another. The many different wonders can help establish a route to take and allow for some good replayability. I also enjoy the shifting narrative of the phases - you initially need to establish means to build things and start thinking about which route you will take. Later, you use your resources to most efficiently pursue the route/s you've chosen.
This occasionally feels a bit rote - there are resources you simply must pursue, though the game punishes you very little if you don't get them, as you can most likely buy them from your neighbors, and you can build a surprising number of buildings for free given the proper prerequisites.
What's more, it can be hard to really lock down an overall strategy for this game, in part because the paths to victory are so disconnected, numerous, and ultimately similar. Final scoring feels a little bland and overly-convoluted, and is enough of a barrier to teaching this to new players (particularly non-gamers) that I don't tend to reach for this one as much as I used to.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Visual Appeal: (4)
Art on the components is beautiful and immersive, even if the theme is fairly shallow. 21 awards displayed on the outside of the box seems a little boastful...

Components: (3)
Average quality cards. I could sleeve them I guess, but I'd expect them to deteriorate anyhow when handled heavily in so many 5-7p games over its lifetime. Wonder boards feel nice and sturdy. No warping here so far.

Theme: (2)
Take a card, pass the rest. Make a set, collect more symbols, repeat. The building of wonders while sacrificing a card fits nicely, and I like the idea of buying resources from your neighbors. The game sacrifices theme for simplicity. I used to draft MtG, and the drafting had more weight to it because your creation had to survive an onslaught from other players. In this game you create a spread of cards for points which just feels flat in comparison.

Learning: (4)
A simple game which is simply taught. One thing that the rule book might have done is provide more suggestions for new gamers who might freeze up when faced with a scoring system as layered as this one. There are 7 sources of points, and this can be intimidating. After a 7 player game with 5 newbies lasted over 90 minutes, I changed my teaching tactics to include some guidance on choosing a card. One might also consider adding a 60 second timer.

Gameplay: (2) Lackluster. Occasionally heated drafting against my neighbors, but when someone 3 seats away from me is running away with the game I can do very little about it. The game feels more controllable with 3-4 players, but if it advertises up to 7 it should play well with 7. I am disappointed that I end up reaching over this game for Resistance or Saboteur at 7 players. The disappointment is soon forgotten though, because they are just more fun than 7 Wonders would have been anyway.

Overall Fun: (2) 
I have some friends who enjoy this game quite a bit, so it comes out every now and again, just not with more than 4 players. Nothing to do while Sammy Slow-picker to your right takes his turn. The inability to actively affect the game state at large player counts. I rarely end the game feeling like I am satisfied, or that I made any difficult choices.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Enjoyment seems inversely proportional to number of times played

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A wonderful game that I always enjoy playing. The base game works very well for a family game, as the mechanics are very easy to teach and learn. While the base game can often feel like each player is playing their own game of solitaire, the expansions add elements that make the game a lot more interactive. 7 Wonders is a game that works well in most settings, regardless of the experience of the players involved.

While new players may slow down the game a little, after only a few plays the game will flow fluently enough for a full game to last less than an hour. The game also scales really well from 3 to 7 players without causing any downtime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I respect 7 Wonders as a clever idea more than I enjoy it as a game. What is clever is that traditional euro-style resource management and set collection are wrapped into a purely simultaneous design. (By this I mean that all decisions are simultaneous.) It's not hard to see how this would result in a game that can support many players without significant play time or down time bloat. That's the essence of most clever ideas - being the first to do something simple. As a game, it's just not my kind of fun. Too chaotic and short. Also, I find it annoying that nearly all of the skill of the game comes from knowledge of the decks. I feel like each player would benefit by having a massive chart showing all the cards, all their prerequisites, and what they do. Card counting also looms heavily as players begin to make more advanced decisions. While playing 7 Wonders, I can't help but feel that I'm making a decision based on some complex chart that I'm trying to picture (and remember) in my mind. That's simply not the kind of gaming challenge I seek.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Alap

RATING: 5

However, it's definitely possible to win on your first try and I did without all too much strategy involved. It's not a game that rocks my socks off but the mechanics are sound and it is well thought out.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Clearly the attraction here for me is a decent game that plays up to seven players in 30 minutes. If 7 Wonders didn't lure me and present me with this gimmick though I would be inclined to dwell on its faults: It's abstract civilization building with a drafting mechanic and the luck of being handed cards you need (or not).

7 Wonders is an overpriced game with a good trick - fast playing time with seven players in a simple to learn package. Indeed you'll be looking to reserve this for occasions when you have more than five players just so you'll be using most of the cards from the box. With three players the 63 cards used certainly gives the impression you've been delivered a little card game in an ocean sized shipping container.

Of the two card games with similar themes from 2010 I'd hand Innovation the clear prize over this for entertainment value and depth. That said, how can you not appreciate an engaging game that plays smoothly and quickly up to seven players? It's a keeper.

RATING: 6
A fun drafting/set-collection game.  Great for scaling 3-7, and drafting has the added benefit of minimal downtime, but I feel there's little you can do in this game.  Maybe I generally play with too many people but it's nearly impossible to interact with a player not to your immediate left or right, and because of this someone 2 or 3 seats downstream might just crush you because they're sitting next to the new player.  Still a good short game though.

Because of the above problem, I feel this game is probably best (tightest) with three or four players, but this game's reputation of supporting up to seven means it gets brought out most commonly when there are six or seven players.  Getting in some games with three or four might cause me to raise my rating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a great card drafting game. There is a good amount of strategy, although this goes down with increased player count. 7 Wonders plays best with 3, and it gets worse with additional players. It is still better than most games with more players, but it is not a tight game like it is with 3. The game works decently with 2, but not as well as with 3. The simultaneous action selection means that adding players doesn't significantly slow the game, so in that sense, it scales perfectly.

I like the interaction with neighbors, I like the drafting, and I like the different ways to get points. There is way more subtlety to the game than many give it credit for. While people complain about the lack of interaction, I think there is just the right amount. It's streamlined enough that it doesn't slow play, but present enough to matter significantly to the flow of the game, and in determining the winner.

Comparisons with Fairy Tale are common, but I vastly prefer 7 Wonders. The game is much tighter, especially with 3, as the randomness is confined to the distribution between the hands, rather than which cards are in the game. Fairy Tale is simpler, but it doesn't have the full range of strategic considerations that 7 Wonders enjoys. Fairy Tale feels like 10% of the game that 7 Wonders is.

7 Wonders has been somewhat supplanted by 7 Wonders: Duel for me, which combines many of the same ideas with more tension.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I am very impressed with the pacing, balance, and artwork of this game. I wish there was interaction with other players around the table besides just the two next to you though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
My biggest concern* only reared it's head on a couple of turns, but for the most part felt absent. With 7 people I felt the game seemed very solitairy... the guy who won was 3 seats to my right, and I'm not sure I could have been keeping track of his board even if I wanted to, let alone affect it.

Played a 2nd time with 4 players, and that seemed better. Makes sense, with 4 you can affect all of the players more directly, and you get to see some of the packs twice - which I think is a big part of the drafting mechanism. I suspect 3 player would be best for this game. 

* My biggest concern going into 7 Wonders was this:

Have you ever done a Magic: the Gathering booster draft? I have, lots of them. In an MtG booster draft, if you had to decide with each draft whether the card will be in your Deck, Sideboard, or out of the game... then the draft would suck. That's how 7 Wonders works though, with each draft you must decide - before seeing other cards drafted - whether to play a card, use it in your wonder, or discard it for $3. In the end it wasn't as bad as all that in 7 Wonders, but I did curse that a couple of times during each of my 2 games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Board Games Box 1 (Green writing)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This is a fantastic tableau civilization game with a simple simultaneous card drafting mechanic.  The game's theme is reinforced by the spectacular art of scenes from ancient near eastern and early western empires. I like how each player gets a different wonder with its own distinctive resource production and special wonder-building objectives. Far from a multi-player solitaire, I like that 7 Wonders keeps you on your toes by watching your neighbors tableau on the table closely from which you can purchase resources that you do not own as well as spy on their military strength compared with your own.  My wife and I also appreciate the advanced 2 player variant included in the base game which plays with a 3 player game but with a ghost player.  Best of all, this game plays in 30-45 minutes after the first couple plays and has helpful reference sheets to mitigate the various symbols on each card.  I hope to play the subsequent expansions in the near future. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Draft game, nice but I feel it needs something more
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very fun, fast-playing card management game that is a little like multiplayer solitaire.  I love how you can buy resources from your neighbors and there are lots of cards that allow you to get points based on what your neighbors are doing.  The only drawback for me is in games with more than 3 players you can do everything right and still lose if your non-neighbors get better cards, have someone feeding them the cards they need, etc.  That makes this game an 8, but with 3 players, I think its great and could go up to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

RATING: 7

Still very enjoyable, regardless. You definitely have to think about the players around you while you make decisions in this game if you want to win.

RATING: 8
gespielt
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
So this is the current darling of the Eurogame circuit.  I don't buy that it is a civilization game even though it has that theme.  It is actually fairly abstract.  Still, all of the mechanisms seem to fit together within the context of that theme, which is a nice bonus. 

In the grand scheme of things, I'm not sure of the ultimate amount of replayability.  However, with 7 (now 8 and likely more) civs each with two sides that each plays differently, there is a lot of room for just basic exploration.  In that sense, I think it will take a fair number of plays just to exhaust basic exploration of the game.  That is not a bad thing.  I'll have to see how it goes after that, but that point, I think, is still several years away.

I should go without mention that it fills a nice spot of being a quick game that plays up to seven (now eight) fairly well.  [03/13/2011]

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The card game is so different than what I'm used to. There is a little bit of a work placement feel to the game, which I love.  The game play is played over 3 rounds and your trying to build your wonder, have the biggest army or have the most cultural spots. Either way you go about it the most VP wins.  Everyone has their own strategy for winning. The ability to use your neighbors resources to build on your own city allows for so many different opportunities but it comes at a cost. The game play is pretty fast and allows for some opportunity to mess with your opposing cities.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
A game I used to play in an eurogame club to avoid playing workerplacements. Ha! I actually figured this out after I stopped playing there and feel no need to ever play 7W again. 

Turns out the difference between workerplacement and drafting isn't so huge, as far as I can tell. Action selection in this or that drag. Probably I do prefer drafting as there's less of a sticking to plan and min-maxing (less does not mean there's not still a lot of it) and you can put nice pictures on the cards. 

So 7 Wonders - it's basically a gamified [thing=12][/thing]. You have your good ol' victory point spread sheet {a1+a2+a3+n1+n2+n3+.....+r^2+q^2+r^2}, you have 3 eras, you have your building your antiquity civilisation/city/monument/whatever, only instead of pushing your luck, now your set collection comes with bolts and whistles and optimising and whohoo! Some synergy between the cards is there, but not like RFTG where card do things. This is just set collecting with some engine building. Oh and comes with baked in multiple paths to victory, now colour coded for your convenience. 

But it's no family game. Firstly there's iconitis, which gets worse with Leaders expansion (that I otherwise like) - every leader card has its own icon it seems. Secondly you have no idea what you're doing till you're done - you'll figure out how things go together in your 2nd or 3rd play. Beware, do not push this at nongamers as I've seen them drown, staring at icons in bewilderment, looking at their measly tableau, having no clue how the engine works, and the cards! the cards just keep coming in! Aaaaa! 

Cute, fluffy and harmless. 
And only Bauza's game without Japan themes - because of publisher it seems (early prototype pictures have some Japanese scenery thingies).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very poor card quality.  Too much setup time required (sorting cards in/out) and time needed to count points for such a short game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
7 Wonders has eveything a standard issue Euro has, only condensed into a card-drafting format. It has multiple ways to gain VP, the need to specialise in a particular scoring method, a little player interaction in the form of military bonuses... you get the point.

While it's rare that there's a decent game which supports up to 7 people and plays in a short amount of time, being able to only affect the players next to you can be frustrating. It becomes more interactive and less random when played with fewer players. A slightly-above-average game that I would be content playing every now and then.

RATING: 10
#4 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2017)

This game has so many things I love. Drafting! Simultaneous action! Variable player powers! Multiple paths to victory! It's fast. It's fun. This game is supposed to be released as an app soon(?!?!), and I cannot wait. I LOVE IT!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I bought my wife this board game for Christmas last year. Prior to this game, we'd only ever played Monopoly, Apples to Apples, and Bananagrams together. We opened the box and I couldn't believe how many rules there were! This game opened our eyes to the hobby. Since getting 7 Wonders last November (because we're adults and that means we can exchange early), I have played upwards for 60-70 different board games. Although I have slacked in my logging of plays, I downloaded the companion app for this game and have logged over 30 plays of this game (most with all expansions) and currently have an 81% win streak! Love this game and think everyone should add it to their collection!

P.S. If you play games primarily with 2 players and are on the fence about this because it says it only plays 3-7 players, dont worry! Despite what many people say, I actually LOVE the game's 2 player variant with what's called a "free city". This acts as a 3rd player for which each player takes turns drafting an extra card from a 3rd player deck. This adds a ton of new strategy because you can build cards that require the free city to pay you for resources, you can build cards or the free city's wonder stages with cards you don't want the other player to have, etc. Check it out!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really satisfying flow. Love the cooperative/comparative interaction with neighboring players. Especially enjoy with leaders since they give you direction even more than your monument.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Overpriced: paying for 150+ cards and lots of air in a box. Can easily be compacted down to a mid-sized box at half the cost.

Gameplay is simple: players draft a card from a hand of seven and pass the rest along. Each card has effects. The idea is to build up your 'civ' by using resources to build other cards. There's science, trading, military, etc and the game goes through three sets of 7 cards.

VPs are scored for card effects, military might, money etc. It's more an card-engine building game than a true 'civ' game though.

The game clips along at a good pace owing to its set rounds of drafting. Slightly more chaos with card with more players. Neat little filler with good graphics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Update: forgot to update this after I actually got to play it a few times. I like it quite a bit. It's not a deep Euro by any means, but for the length, weight and scalability, it scores highly with me. I'm a sucker for drafting, anyway, and it's mixed nicely here with "building" a resource foundation and scoring VP.

RATING: 8
Great card drafting game. I really like that it handles 7 players and can finish in about 30 minutes. That is a really great attribute. This game is quickly becoming my favorite card game. I enjoy that I can play with 7 players, but I don't have to pay a lot of attention to what they are doing. It makes this game less of a headache to teach new players. Not to mention there are few games that handle this number of players well. This game seems to do it all.

RATING: 6
- The game is too complicated for non- or casual gamers, as it requires card deck knowledge to play well
- The game is not meaty enough for gamers, because beyond scoring and drafting there is very little game here
- At higher player counts, you can do very little to nothing to influence the players sitting far away from you
- Denying (the) subsequent player(s) cards he/she/they need(s) feels much more important than your own needs
- If you sit in passing order behind a player who knows what he/she is doing: good luck getting a decent score
- This does not feel like a civilization building game, the theme is pasted-on (the blue cards are especially creative ...)

RATING: 7.5
At this point I'd say an 8.   Played a few times.  Most seem to get it easily and has fun and it plays well with large groups.  I know we will be playing a lot of this and using it as an intro game.

[b]Update:[/b]  Moving to 7.5 for now.  Has not always worked as an intro game.  I think not having a board and lots of options in the sense of end game made a few have problems.  They just had no clue what to do strategy wise for end game and it just wasn't fun to learn for them.  Don't quite have the desire to play this one as much as others, but still enjoy it a bit personally.

[b]Update: 12-22-2012 [/b] Leaving as is for now, but really questioning the replay value.  Last play it just seemed to be over really fast and both the wife and I just were not feeling engaged in the stategies especially with how quick it ended.  It had been a while though so won't change for now.  Maybe it has been a fluke.  

Still pretty decent and great to have since it fits a very specific niche being short, no down time and fitting 7 players.
