RATING: 8
When it comes to drafting games 7 Wonders is often the go to recommendation I hear. While it's not my favorite drafting game it certainly is a good one. Most of the rules are pretty simple, the components are nice and the the game doesn't take too long. Despite all the I still have some gripes. I feel like the trading cards can be a little complex for newer players and that after playing the game a handful of times it loses quite a bit of its replay value just because it can be a little boring. Other than that though it's always a fun game to break out once in a while.

RATING: N/A
A really enjoyable game that so far I have enjoyed replaying as much as possible.  Very nice for the number of players that can play.  It is tactical to a degree, but more than anything it is about being adaptive.

My only issue with the game would be with the Guild cards.  Since which ones you see are random each game, you can't exactly plan for them and are just hoping you draw ones that can work for you.  You don't need them to win, but they can help you out a great deal.

Also, playing with a mix of experienced and inexperienced players is almost a nightmare since you can give away huge advantages to your neighbors.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders has a feature that I think defines what I tend to like in games, what I'm going to call simple depth (simple-depth?). Games with this quality do not have simple and easy to teach, many games with this quality fail that test. These are games that have mechanics and depth, but not so much that they can not be contained within one's head.

7 Wonders I think displays this in the way players must evaluate which cards to draft and which to pass. With just a glance, it is possible to tell what my left hand and right hand opponents are likely to give me or what I take for myself and pass to them. Call it a Glance test. I love games that let me do that kind of thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

RATING: 8
[2010-11-27]
Viszonylag könnyű szabályok, gyors játékmenet, akár heten is játszható. Ez már három olyan tulajdonság, ami mindenképp jó egy játéknál, emellett pedig teljesen rendben van a játék. Izgalmasabb, jobb, mint a Dominion, kevesebb mélység van ugyan benne, mint az RFTG-ben, de a témája és könnyebbsége miatt jobban eladható a kevésbé gémereknek. Kellemes, jó kártyás játék magas újrajátszhatósági faktorral. A szerencse szerepe ugyan nagynak tűnik az egyes csodák talán nem teljesen egyező tulajdonságai miatt, illetve a kártyák miatt. Mégis úgy érzem, a jobb játékos általában ki tudja küszöbölni ezeket. Gyanús, hogy akár 9-es is lehet belőle.

[2011-07-29]
20 játék után is kiemelkedő játéknak tartom. Üresjárat nem nagyon van, hisz egyszerre cselekszik minden játékos, a játékidő tényleg 30 perc, így több parti is követheti egymást. Kiegészítő nélkül is nagyon magasnak érzem az újrajátszhatósági faktorát, minden játék más. Azért nem emelem a pontját 9-esre, mert jelentősége van annak, hogy milyen két játékos ül melletted.

RATING: 10
I was introduced to this wonderful game in a 4v4 tournament  of it arranged in my university's boardgame club and fell in love with it in first sight. The graphics, the comparatively quick gameplay, 3-7 players setup, strategy, luck... With one last place, one second place and 3 first place games, I won the tournament and thus won a copy for myself. It feels like such a great game. A great introduction to more strategic games yet can easily be picked up. I think I'll truly emjoy playing it at all times with all different strategies involving it.

RATING: 7
[i]Nice and Satisfying Quick Game with 3 Players... Gets Worse with More![/i]

Will only play with 3-4 players.

"7" is my rating as a 3-4 player game, base game only. Any different configuration I like much less, because the gameplay and strategy becomes pure optimization and luck when you cannot reliably predict or counter-draft your opponents

On the other hand, 3 player may be a little overly-analytical, but that's a euro for you.

Base Game: (4 Design + 3 Enjoyment)
With Expansion(s): (3 Design + 2 Enjoyment)

RATING: 8
Design is super-sharp, the thematic use of sevens is brilliant and awesome, and the artwork is absolutely beautiful.  The main problem is that weaker players tend to affect the game too much; a stronger player can be gifted too many points by players who fail to deny him important cards.  The drafting mechanic is clever, but also allows for some notable luck impact.  There is a lot more meat to the game than I first anticipated; navigating the resource game and that interaction with your neighbors makes for a surprising amount of depth.  I'm always up for playing this one, and it's grown on me substantially since the first play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Update 2016: After playing this a little more at a variety of player counts, I place this firmly in "Meh" terrain. I don't think I would ever suggest playing it, but I would oblige someone if that was group consensus. I would, however, actively avoid this game if there were 6 or 7 participants looking for a game. 

There are certain games, where I just can't get myself to care about the choices being made. I can't pinpoint why quite yet, but this game is among their ranks along with Kingsburg and a few others. I know there are strategic decisions to be made, however, I can't get myself to become engaged or excited by them.

7/12/12: I had a bad first experience with this game. I didn't like it at all. After playing it a few times, I'm warming up to it. I think it'd be best with 4-5 players. Possibly 3, but I haven't tried that.

RATING: 8.5

A quick, terrific, inventive game that everyone likes, for up to seven players?  7 Wonders should be on everybody's game shelf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
7 Wonders is a surprisingly rich card drafting game. You play three hands of seven cards and each turn you pick a card from your hand and pass on the rest. The turn structure really is that simple. This way you try to build your own civilization and score the most victory points in various ways. A big part of the game is to set up a resource engine that will last your game plan through all three hands, or ages. The Wonders that give this game its name provide players with special abilities which really affect your play. 
Within the game you only interact with your direct neighbors. Mainly, the player interaction is limited to  passing cards, buying resources and comparing military strenght after each age.
7 Wonders is a highly replayable game that needs a few plays to really grow on you. The virtual resource mechanic needs some time to settle in and specific card knowledge helps a great deal to do well. I first rated it a six, but over time I kept adjusting its rating: now, it's one of my few 10 rated games. Games are quick, varied and really a lot of fun. The more I play, the more I want to play and that is probably it's best quality.

The Leaders expansion adds a great deal of strategy while not adding a lot to the complexity. It adds a smaller fourth hand, which you draft at the beginning of the game and which you keep for the entire game. At the start of each age you get to play one of these leader cards. Basically you plot out your strategy at the beginning of the game based on the leaders you're dealt and draft. Hate drafting now happens less often, but is more meaningful. Also, money becomes more important since leaders have to be paid with money. This is a great improvement from the base game, where money was only used for buying resources.

I'd say the Leaders expansion is a must have expansion, whereas the Cities expansion is a very good expansion, but not a mst-have per se. Instead of three hands of seven cards, you now play three hands of eight. The extra cards are a new type of cards which add some more direct player interaction. The new cards shake up your decision tree quite nicely.

The Wonder Pack is another must have expansion, as you can never have enough wonders for extra replayability. Also, these new wonders are awesome and some of the most fun ones to play with.

Owned expansions: Leaders, Cities, Wonder Pack, Catan promo, Esteban promo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

It's a civ-themed card drafting game. Players each choose a civ, each with a different power. There are 3 decks, one per era. The cards are in various types -- resources, VP cards, etc. Deal out 7 cards per player, then draft -- clockwise, then counter, then clockwise again -- playing one card at a time. Resources allow you to build the other cards; if you don't have a resource, you can buy it from left- or right-hand neighbor. In the end, you get VP based on your cards built, your civ bonuses, and military. The military is a bit tricky to figure out, since you score relative to your neighbors' strengths. 

I quite enjoyed my first game (3er), but the 5er wasn't as good: the military is not nearly as interesting, and there is absolutely no interaction with anyone but your neighbors. In both games, the end-game VP calculation was also a bit cumbersome, although worth the effort.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Excellent drafting game that's fairly easy to teach and understand from a rules perspective. Repeated plays are in order if you want to maximize the fun of the draft and bump up the level of competitiveness.

There's virtually no downtime -- you're either drafting cards or playing cards simultaneously and resolving their effects. It also plays up to 7 players & due to the simultaneous play each player doesn't add that much time to the overall game.

[i]** Update Nov 2017[/i]
Now that I own the digital app & have played a ton of games against the AI (they only take ~5 minutes to play), I'm dropping my rating for the base game.  I didn't realize how simplistic the game really is. I still enjoy drafting and it plays quick, but I'm no longer clamouring to play. Blood Rage is now my #1 go-to drafting/area control game!

RATING: 7.7

My kinda game
Shelved
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have 7 things to say about 7 wonders
1. Its quick, real quick...dominion style quick. I'd say about 12.5 minutes per player, that means you could play it 7 times in a row if you wanted to
2. Its good looking, real good looking. The individual wonder cards are nothing short of magnificent! Almost as impressive as the wonders they represent, and the other cards are damn sexy as well. But, unlike most sexy things...
3. Its clever, real clever. I love the card drafting aspect as well as the fact that you have to purchase resources from your enemies (just like in real life)and everything about the gameplay is smooth and slick
4. Its has multiple ways to win, I love multiple ways to win!
5. Its quick to teach, like most quick games are i suppose. There are a lot of things going on, but its still surprisingly easy to teach, which is a plus
6. It has a high replayability factor. The fact that there are 7 wonders that each have two sides to play keeps it fresh for awhile, and with multiple paths to victory and a short playing time its bound to hit the table frequently
7.it has lots of cool expansions! Check em out, because like I said, they're cool.
8. I said I had seven things to say about 7 wonders, not eight, so back off.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I really enjoy playing this game.  It is a light game that is an excellent filler or can be played back to back for a longer gaming experience.  It has practically no downtime, great looking artwork, multiple paths to victory and accommodates up to 7 players.  Apart from the oversized box with terrible inserts this is a great production.  [b]I'll play this anytime.[/b]

RATING: 8
Replay value is lacking with this game.  I like the deck drafting mechanic and the game itself is beautiful but after a few plays it can get a little stale.  It's still a good, well-designed, and fun game that I enjoy playing though, especially after it's been out of the rotation a few weeks.

I do like how it is one of the few games that scales really well to different numbers of players from 3-7.  Too many games just accommodate different numbers of players but always work best with a set number.  This game plays just as well with any number from 3-7 in my opinion and 7 is a lot of people to accommodate for one game which is another bonus for large groups that want to play together.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Everyone enjoyed their first play of this.  Part way through my youngest said "this is fun!".  Rules were a little tough to get through but they weren't bad.  The scoring was tough to explain though.  Get through the first game and everything will click.  Not really that complicated.  The game play brought up a lot of table talk, "argh, I can't decide which card is better" or "you passed me this trash".  Everyone enjoyed it.

Introduced some non-gamers to this.  They were lost and confused but didn't give up on it.  One got it part way through.  I don't think they found it objectionable but they likely won't request it again.  This is not a good gateway game.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A sort of collecting card game with some really great mechanics. I like the drafting mechanism a lot, good balance of luck and strategy there. Another plus is the simultaneous game play, strategy games often come with down time when waiting for your turn and are therefor often not really suitable for bigger groups, this one works perfectly for even 7 players (which we played with) for that exact reason.
Resource management with buying goods from only your direct neighbors, a bit of military and cultural efforts to tend after; I really liked my first try at "7 Wonders" even though it took me a moment to get into it (as with some strategy games, the rules seem a bit overwhelming at first but with a few rounds played things fall into place). I assume better knowledge of the possible cards will help the strategy but we had very even victory points results in a mixed group of newbies and experts; I like it when games welcome new players and challenge people who know it at the same time.
Some complains on BGG are towards the low player interaction, whereas that is true I don't think every game needs that and I am not sure why that is minus, I like both type of games, the more solitary and the highly interactive ones.

RATING: 8
This has worked well with 2 and 4, and I'd def. like to get it to the table with more. I really enjoy the quick gameplay of this, and it's smooth and intuitive as well.

The wonders are different enough, and the B sides particularly give you a nudge into a certain direction (though sometimes the cards you need for that just don't come up in the draft...). It's also great how you need to keep an eye on your neighbours - but only your neighbours - for how to get ahead; in one game Carla and I got the same points for military when I had 5 mili cards and about 10pts, and she only had 1, with exactly 1 point! - I lost the attrition battle to John, unfortunately :( - but it's great that that can happen and that there are so many ways to win - and that you can have a say in whether your neighbours get what they need too!

Lovely synergy of form and function, and you know how I love one of those!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
My favorite board game so far. Works equally well from 3 to 7 players (a BIG plus for my large but varying gaming group). Easy to pick up even for casual players, quick to play (one game lasts about 30 minutes), and in spite of all this it still allows for multiple (and well balanced) paths to victory, giving good variety/replay value. Correct planning and decision making is always rewarded, with good old luck being there just to mix up things a bit. All in all, a very FUN game, who can appeal to all audiences (from family/casuals to dedicated players) without pretending to be the best game ever made.

RATING: 9


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders is fun and deserved of the hype for the most part.  It is an easy to teach and learn game that can accommodate up to seven players and it does this with little down time.  I rate it a 7 because of these things.  It is only a 7 however because of a few issues I have.   (My 2 plays were both 7 player games)  The card drafting mechanic was intriguing at first, and offers a meager attempt at player interaction, but it only exacerbates the inherent randomness of the game and it reduces the strategy to almost nil by only allowing short tern tactical planning.  

In the two games I played, during the third age every player immediately played the guild card if they were dealt one.  They are inevitably worth a decent amount of VP's and which one(s) you get to play is totally random.  There is no strategy in "play the purple card if you get one".   The green science cards are like a siren's song; the set collection seems like a good idea, but the payout is not enough.  It is easy to block by your opponents and you need too many cards to score enough to be worth more than the blue VP cards.  For example, in one game I collected a set of four of one type squared, that's 16 points, and then one of each of the 3, for 7 points.   So I invested 6 cards for a total of 23 VP's (not a good ratio in this game) and it would have been easy for my opponent to have buried the last card of the set, if he would have done that, I would have scored only 16 points for 5 cards.  Military is simply unbalancing in a 7 player game.  In both games I played, the winner had a mere one or two military cards played, but gained a significant amount of points because the person to the right or left chose not to play military; while the players on the other side of the table each escalated their military, causing a lot of investment with little or no payout. You see, it is almost a given that one player grabs a significant lead in military.  Let us say the player to his left decides, I can't compete with that, I will let him win military and I will concentrate my plays on VP's hopefully out gaining him in that manner.  But this allows the sneaky player to his left to play one military and gain the military points.   So it is the player two chairs away (or across the table) that gains the benefit of someone that invest heavily in Military.  

Most of my faults above would seem to lessen in a game with less players; you would be able to have more choice on Guild cards, you would be closer to the other players for military, you would see science cards more than once and it would be harder for them all to be buried.  So my score of a "7" is only for the 7 player game, I am interested to see if I am right and it is better with fewer players.  All in all it is a 7 as a 7 player game for me.  With its flaws it is deserved due to the easy of play the low downtime and the ability to engage 7 people at one time.  

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
2,3-7
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a fairly quick-playing game with low interaction.  It scales well; the experience does not change much from 3-7 players.  The main difference is that in a 3-player game, when you pass your first hand, you expect to see most of the cards again.  With 7 players, you won't.

In my experience, most non-gamers find it fairly accessible, getting the hang of it halfway through the first play.  I like how you don't have to explain the guilds until the third age.

Of course, it's got a fair bit of chaos in it; it's certainly not a hardcore contest of skill like some heavy Euros.  The best player will not win every time.  That's fine by me; I like the way it feels.  A play of 7 Wonders leaves me feeling good, win or lose.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5

I find the expansions reduce the enjoyment, but once a person owns one it always gets included.  Edit: On second thought, it is NOT more fun than it sounds.  It's actually quite dull on repeated play.

RATING: 6
Update: 11/2016: This has been completely replaced for me by Treasure Hunters.

Simple drafting game that works well from 3 to 7 players without ever being too long. It is best with 3 as every player has a direct affect on the other players and doesn't use the fake player of the 2 player.

The drafting in rounds with scoring at the end and during turns allows you to try and build up a strategy so it isn't just turn optimization. The random bonus points at the end may not work out for you though. The wonders give you a direction to go.

Little to no downtime. Some player interaction but is still a set collection game so it can appeal to many types of people.

RATING: N/A
X
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Initial rating after four plays is that this is a good game and unique enough to garner a lasting place in our collection.  Is it worthy of the gushing praise, no, probably not, but it is good fun.  One of the main problems with it is something touted as a great thing--it is a civ-building style game which plays in under an hour.  However this, rather than good, is a distracting problem to me since the game loses the grand sweep of developing a civilization engine because it all happens so fast.  I think 3 hours is probably the sweet spot for our group for this kind of game, and if we had the opportunity more often, even longer civ games would be just fine with us.

So what you end up with is sort of a cliff-notes version of civ building game play.  But if you back up a bit from the theme and view it as just a game engine, it is quite a good game with interesting special powers and benefits to following any particular development tracks.  It's just that once you've got everything humming along in a fairly tight manner, boom the game is over.

I think perhaps the guild cards should be shown to everyone before being shuffled in, to allow players to attempt to capitalize on the ones included in any particular game...otherwise blind luck in developing along a certain path can yield a tremendous amount of points in the final turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Light civilization-themed card game that's most notable for its very fast play and large player count. Depth decreases in inverse proportion to the number of players, but there's no downtime so it scales surprisingly well.

I soured on it after the novelty wore off. The main problem is that it usually gets suggested because there are six or seven players free; since it's at its worst with that many, I'd rather split into two groups... and with three or four or five players there are many other choices. Luck of the draw plays a very large role, increasing with the number of players, and the much-vaunted lack of downtime is harder to find with a full complement because there's always [i]someone[/i] slowing things down. 

Ratings history: 7 -> 7.5 -> 6.5/5 with 3-5/6-7 players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fast paced game with a great card drafting mechanic and a civilization theme which in my opinion it's sweet spot is with 3 players.

RATING: 6
A little more interactivity than games like Dominion, but several problems with this game that seems to get played so often just because of the graphics and the short play:

The ability to buy resources from your neighbors without their consent or without effect on your own use of the same resources is a bit unrealistic and random, especially when playing more than 4 players, and important resources can be permanently out of your reach, and the game is too short to be able to modify one's strategy when resources are unavailable.  Also with more than 4, it is extremely difficult to watch what everyone is doing, and respond knowledgeably.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
great game, bad quality

a fast and fun card drafting based civilization building game. great theme and beautiful art (same artist as Cyclades). easy to teach, plays fast even with a lot of players as there is almost no downtime. this all makes it fun and suitable for casual gamers but it's deep enough to be interesting for serious gamers as well.

one of the best games this year (next to Isla Dorada)

unfortunatly I cannot give it as many points as it would deserve because of the lack of quality. the card quality is really bad, as is the insert. the box is way oversized. it was a really bad decision to put a casual game in a non-portable box. also for this size they could have at least made an insert to separate the cards according to age and player number. what a shame...

Edit: 2011.09.: As much as I liked the game it got dull for me fast. It's still a great game for non-gamers to get into board-gaming but for me it's not that fun anymore.

RATING: 7.5
Elegant design... but it is lacking something. It has many advantages: It can accommodate up to 7 players, rules are quite short and easy to understood, and graphic execution is very good, if not excellent. It has some shortcomings, through: 2-player play looks like bit complicated (haven't tried yet), choices are simple (good for game time, but bad if you like to think deeper) and basically we play against two players only with almost no interaction. Good choice for large families (so I appreciate that someone published it!), quite nice filler for gaming meetings, but not a first-grade choice for me.

Edit: I've played it some more with my wife and good gaming pals and I think it started to click for me. If other players play it in more organized, focused way you also can gain more. Thus, rating raised.

RATING: 7
[Asmodée 2010 edition] {Civilization; card-passing, drafting, resources management; optimal 3-4p} 7 Wonders is a fast-paced card games with civilization theme.  The theme is not as strong as I expected, yet ok.  Player interaction is good, esp. for 3-4p.  Age I is too important for a player to formula their game strategy.  Scoring calculation is a little clumsy, it would be better if a scoring track is provided, rather than a pack of papers.

The quality of components is good but the illustration is pedestrian. The conflict tokens and card illustration can be prettier.  The use of icon is good - players can understand the usage of each card easily without many references to the rules.  The coins are disaster. I expect nicer coins for a game with such an expensive price.

In 7 Wonders guiderete una delle 7 grandi città dell'antico mondo.
Dovrete lasciare un segno nella storia della civilizzazione costruendo una meraviglia architettonica che perdurerà nei secoli, sviluppare relazioni commerciali ed imporre il vostro assetto militare.

Contiene:
7 plance di gioco Meraviglia
7 carte Meraviglia
49 carte Era I + 49 carte Era II + 50 carte Era III
2 carte speciali per 2 giocatori
42 segnalini Conflitto
20 monete di valore 3 + 30 monete di valore 1
1 registro dei punteggi
1 libretto delle regole

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
As a rule, I don't rate games I don't own, but after five plays, on the BGG rating, I'd give this a 3. It is a really poor game, and is too much of a memory game for me to get any enjoyment from it. I find it too taxing for what it is, and unrewarding in its execution. It is a copy and re-write of Fairy Tales with all of the good bits taken out, and lots of unecessary additions.

To the day I die, I won't understand the scoring method, and I've worked in accounts for over 20 years.

I find the game dull, repetitive, frustrating and irritating. I really struggle to understand why it is so popular - the only way of improving in this game is by memorising the cards, and there was nothing in game 5 I didn't see in game 1. For a supposedly 'light' game it could at least should be fun, but it is trying to be a grown up game in a child's package. I was looking forward to my first game of this, but couldn't have been more disappointed.

Look, if you like it fine, and maybe if I'd spent my cash on it, I'd be trying a lot harder to like it, but try Fairy Tale, or play Ascension or Dominion for some card based quick fun. In all the groups I'm involved in I saw this come and go pretty quickly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Purchased 3rd Edition brand new (shrink) - 1 card (Age I, Lumber Yard 3+) missing (took 2 weeks to replace).

Being a wargamer, I like the historical theme, variety of Civ boards, and the Military Phase. The artwork is excellent (especially the Civ boards).

Very light (almost a party game), it doesn't hit the table that often as it has fallen out of favor. Glad that I didn't pick-up the expansions.

RATING: 9
Can't believe how fast and varied this game is. Over a dozen plays in and I just want to play more and more. It hardly ever seems like you are screwed by the cards. Very rarely do you get handed a pack with nothing to take. I like this best with less players though. With 5 or more it just seems too wild. The chances of getting a card to "table" back to you from your starting pack is too low for me. More players also tends to let people specialize a bit too much. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I initially rated this 8.5, and it's dropped every time I get a few plays in. I hope that downward trend stops before it reaches the point of total antipathy. 

Yes, it's appealing to have a game that has so little downtime, but ultimately 7 Wonders is a very misanthropic affair. It's idal for people to whom the idea of competing with other people is appealing, but conversing with them and looking them in the face is not. This is apparently a great many people. Its most ardent fans play it with the same no-chit-chat mindset of hard-drinking poker players solemnly mulling over their hands in a smoke-filled casino backfroom.

30 mins.  Ages 10+ (could start at 8+)

Most famous and award winning Card drafting game by Antoine Bauza.  Civ building card game.  2 player variant is okay, but better game is 7 Wonders Duel.  Play in 3 ages, building off previous ages, play against your two civ neighbors.  Many ways to score points.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders is a great game in so many ways, and I think it is one of the few games that gives you the feeling of building an advanced civilization in under 45 minutes.

Point scoring is weird, though, and most of the time it is impossible to tell who is really winning until the points are scored at the end of the game.

Overall, a great game, with several minor flaws.

Also, there's really no need to buy the expansions. You're looking at a complete game here.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My wife and I love to play this game, it is one of our favorites. I think the brilliance of this game is how quick it plays with 2 players and it plays in the same time with 7 players.

There doesn't seem to be very many good strategy games that a large group can play in under an hour, including set-up and take-down time, but 7 Wonders is one of them.

The other thing I love about this game is how balanced it is. There are so many ways to win. The problem is, each game, I see multiple paths I could take and it is hard to discern what the best path is because I want to take them all!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Unique Well, as far as I know, game play. 
You never know how weak you are so the game keeps your interest till the end.
Quick game with continuous play for each player so it does not feel like a short game.
Great graphics.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The quintessential card drafting game. War is quite underpowered. Recommended for anyone just getting into board gaming. It's also a Euro that plays up to seven!!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Civilization themed card game with numerous paths to victory. Players are given an ancient wonder that they have to construct and cards that feature different resources and powers. Once a card is selected it can contribute in several different ways such as providing materials to help construct the building of the player's wonder, adding military strength, immediately awarding victory points etc. Players can also purchase resources from their neighbour on each side of them, thereby interacting with the cards that they have played. '7 Wonders' is a satisfyingly strategic game and there is a lot of player interaction, although that is performed primarily with your neighbouring opponents and therefore games within the game emerge if there are enough players. I do however feel that 'Glory to Rome' is a more accomplished game in this style despite not receiving the same amount of plaudits.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Really like this drafting game. It's basically drafting. All the time. No problem with that here.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Laura's Rank (3/15) – 3.5 out of 5. Pros: I like the artwork. It's very different in the card drafting and the player interaction in other people seeing the cards being passed around. You are always pretty close and never can tell who is going to come out on top. Good length. Cons: My only con, and it is a big one, is that it is not that good of a two player variant.

Ryan's Rank (3/15) – 4 out of 5. I really like the mechanics. I really like the feeling of civilization building. The indirect player interaction was fun. Great artwork. Good amount of strategy. My con, like Laura, was the two-player variant. It works, but I don't like playing the free city. I think this would be a great game with more people, but with 2, it's good to very good.

Overall Rank (3/15) – 7.5 out of 5

RATING: 8
Great first impressions but not a keeper.  
I should point out though that I no longer care for 7W itself. It's just not a very good game with 6 or 7 players and with less there's other games I'd rather play. It has that player order problem where if a player isn't actively disrupting their neighbors then those players have a significant advantage. Add to that the random card distribution and a good/bad shuffle can make/destroy your game and playing conservatively never works.

The more I play this with 6/7 players the less I like it and that's its whole raison d'être imo.

8>7>6

RATING: 7
The thing I like about this game is that it's easy enough to teach and it plays really relatively quickly so it's easy to bring to the table. However, I also don't like that it plays so quickly because the game doesn't allow players to really develop a long term strategy. Great for casual play, but not deep enough for those looking for a really strategic game.

Overall, it's a good game for casual play but not something I would actively seek out if I'm having a gaming night with avid gamers.

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a card drafting game.  Each player plays one of the Seven Wonders of the World.  Each wonder has a different special ability.  Players simultaneously draft a card from their hand and pass the remaining card to the next player.  Cards drafted give players resources used to draft other cards or give players victory points.  The player with the most victory points win.

This game plays very quickly even with many players.  It supports up to 7 players and one of the expansions add an 8th player.  A game will take a little more than an hour to play even with many players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Owned by Al

RATING: 9
Really fun card game. Love the artwork. Love the theme. Kinda wonky with two players, but still good. Better with three or more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is pretty good, but it can often feel too much like multi-player solitaire.  The drafting aspect is nice, but it also kills long-term strategy.  It's definitely much more tactical than strategic.

With 4-5 players, this game is great.  The more I play it, the more I like it (it's moved from a 7 to an 8 for me).  Too many players makes drafting just a 1-time thing, but with 3-5, you will see more cards come back your way.  That gives it a more long-term strategy feel, and each player tends to distinguish him/herself.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good intro to card drafting games, not too difficult to learn, but the reference sheet is handy for discerning what certain cards mean in terms of VPs. I enjoy the mix of solo drafting + being aware of what your neighbors are putting down as well since they have an effect on you at the end of each round. Each player/civilization board has an A side, for beginners or playing with the same build-your-wonder conditions, and a B side, for more specialized wonder-building conditions + rewards. Personally I find some of the civ-specific rewards a bit lackluster at times.

RATING: 5
Certainly not bad and I'll play it again but probably not thrilled about it. It has an almost perfect time frame somewhere about half hour or less. It acommodates quite a few players and is quite sociable. However, there's not much to do other than draft a card and hand off the pile to the next person. Players next to you will have an effect on you, but stuff going on the other side of the table is pretty much out of your control. Worse yet, its difficult to look over there and see what other people are doing. I hate that, when the info is publicly out there but it's too hard to really figure it out. That part is annoying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Quick card drafting game. I was very impressed with my first plays.

I think this could be a good crossover game, simple enough to bring in new gamers, deep enough to keep regular gamers entertained.

---

Plays differently with different numbers. 5+ is satisfying because your building. But you don't have as much control over the cards. 3 and 4 are the sweet spot for this game. There is more tension and thought over what cards to pass. With 3 players I've passed cards I wanted to build but figured I had a good chance of getting them back since I was in the best possition to build them cheaply or for free. Plus I think with fewer players the military is more of a threat; with more players it's more possible to build military late and take some easy points.

---

15th new to me game of 2011 (January)

RATING: 7
Quite a good game; the staple drafting game that everyone seems to know.  Great for introductory/gateway drafting.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
You are the leader of one of the great cities of the past. Each city has different special abilities which influence your strategy. You can try going for a science victory or hoard up all resources and force your neighbors to trade with you. Good amount of player interaction, easy-ish to learn and high replayability. I like the expansions as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Civilization and Empire building in a card building game.  30 -45 minutes per game makes this a great just one more round.  The game scales excellently from 3-7 players before adding any expansion.  You balance trade, government, science, and military to become the most renowned city.  I would highly recommend this game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
tl;dr: still a joy to play

This game was an instant hit when it came out. And it has since grown into a bit of an evergreen. The expansions have injected new life into the game every now and then but while I enjoy them, none of them have wowed me. But the base game still stands out as a great design. It plays fast, has quite easy rules but offers surprising depth strategy wise. Overall I still enjoy this game an awful lot. Maybe because I never played it to death.

Rating: 8/10
BGG scale: 8/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
7 Wonders was an impulse buy and a game I originally knew nothing about. I was just trying to fill up my gaming shelves, and it was suggested at some point by a friend.

A few weeks went by, and eventually, I broke it off my shelf, gather a couple of friends and got to playing. 

It's a simple, but deep draft game, with multiple levels of strategy/counterplay and options to choose. Score-counting at the end it annoying, but otherwise, the only downfall of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Interesting little game, with a couple issues.  It took awhile to understand the tech trees of which blue cards go into which next age ages.  Same with green science cards.  Purple guild cards being unknown until age 3 also makes things tricky as these cards add a ton at the end and will decide games, but you won't know which ones will be there to work toward.  Not really sure on balance between wonders.  Also, resources are not equally valued, stone is awesome, the loom is awesome, whereas other resources are less so.  But you won't know this unless you read up on the game a lot, or through a lot of trial and error understand the build paths.  Nonetheless, a fun game.

RATING: 6
"Filler" came to my mind as well when I first played it. I can see that it can get deeper with 3-4. It's like RftG - first few games I played, I hardly every paid attention to what everyone else was doing. After i got used to the symbols and figured out what were the unique worlds and 6-devs, it became a lot more interesting to watch what everyone else is doing. 

I feel that once we are more familar with the types of Guilds (6-devs), and unique cards are out there, it'll be more interesting to play, and if played with 3-4, it'll give you a lot more incentive to see what everyone else is doing.

You have limited drafting opportunities with 6p which is how I've been playing this. But even with all that, it's still a filler game.

RATING: 7
I know, 7 wonders a 7?  Did I do that on purpose?  Well, not really.  I like 7 wonders a lot, the idea of playing simultaneously and theme works out great.  My biggest complaint is there is a lot to keep track of for a shorter game which is particularly annoying because of the pacing given that cards are played at the same time.  The game also has a snowball feeling where things can get completely out of control and out of your hands.  I have never come out of this game absolutely wowed, but it is solid and decently fun.  Worth a shot if you are looking for a nice medium length family game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A solid drafting and tableau building game. My favorite mechanic in the game is how certain cards from a previous age will allow you to build a card in the current age without needing to meet the relevant resource requirements. This makes the drafting much more interesting (and makes the hate drafting that much more important).

Many people cite this as an excellent gateway game, but I disagree. The drafting mechanic is quite easy for non-gamers to pick up. However, the symbols (especially) and scoring can be quite obscure for non-gamers. Sushi Go or Sushi Go Party provide a much more accessible drafting experience for introducing people to the hobby.

While I still enjoy this game, it has fallen in my rankings because it starts to feel somewhat monotonous after a while--of course, there are many expansions that likely help bring back that freshness and diversity in the gameplay. Moreover, there are other tableau building and drafting games that I have started to enjoy more. 

Nonetheless, this game will stay in my collection for the foreseeable future since it is one of very few games that have a decent amount of strategy and can be played in a relatively short time even with a high player count. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Chapters/Indigo

RATING: 7
This is a good drafting and card combination game that handles up to seven players without getting longer.  The action is simultaneous, and only your immediate neighbors can really influence you, so even with seven players, only three really matter.  As with most drafting, you have to keep an eye upstream to make sure the cards you want won't be cut off, and to compare military strength with your neighbors as well.

The base game is probably still best.

RATING: 8.1
Only played this once so far, but I've a feeling it's going to get a lot more plays in the coming weeks. Rarely has a game appealed to everyone in our group equally; it seems that everyone loved it, and I'm in agreement. For such a quick game there seems to be a lot of strategy involved (though I do wonder if the strategies might become a little shallow after a fair number of plays).

Edit: Played a fair few games of this now, and still really enjoying it, although the strategies seem less deep than when I first played.

Edit: Played loads of games of this now, and the Leaders expansion too. I see no signs of getting bored of it yet. It just has an amazing amount of depth for such a quick game.

RATING: 9.5
This has been my first real introduction into strategy gaming.  I bought it to possibly use in class and then when I enjoyed it I got a second one and we actually play it as a reward at the end of a culture project on the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World in a class that I teach.  The students really enjoyed it also.  I tried explaining it to some thirtysomething friends and it was an hour and a half disaster that only got through the second age.  Then I explained it to 13 year olds who immediately picked up on most elements of the game and played through a full game in 25 minutes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A wonderful game.  It's really changed how I look at every other board game.  Simultaneous turns give short play times, and you're happy about every decision you make, even when you lose.  It's really hard to want to play a 2 hour game - even a good one - when I can have just as much fun - and sometimes more - in 30 minutes.

RATING: 9
An "ancient" card game that looks challenging, but is actually very quickly learned and holds the excitement until the end. Reminds me of Race for the Galaxy (symbol language), Peloponnes (theme, resources & some building rules) and Notre Dame or Citadels (draw 1 card and pass on the deck). Great both as a filler and a main attraction with several games in a row - easily accomplished as it's slightly addictive too!

RATING: N/A
Michael
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is my top choice game when playing with a bigger party (6 or 7 players). 

The game has simple enough rules to grasp them in the first round of play after a short explanation. It plays fast and easily, even with 7 players: as everyone take their turn together, there is almost no down time. The game lets you make meaningful decisions every turn, based on the cards you have in hand, your "strategy" and the situation of your neighbors. It stays tense until the end of the game, even if it can be clear earlier who is taking a lead and will certainly win the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Addictive game with some initially fiddly set up (removing cards from each deck dependent on the number of players). Very well designed, easy to pick up and play. This is going to be huge. The only problem we found was the rule preventing a player from building the same structure twice as it was easy for players just to focus on the powers and resources needed. In each of the 3 4-player games, we had at least one person build the same structure twice, which skews the outcome. Great game nonetheless.

RATING: 8
This is one of those rare games that plays equally great with 4 or 7 players AND doesn't take any longer with 7 than with 4. One nice thing in a 3 to 4-player game is that you get to see some of the cards twice, which lends a little more strategy. Every board is different, every game is different!

:star: Artwork and components
:star: Innovative mechanics
:star: Feels unique
:star: Low downtime between turns
:star: Quick and easy to teach/learn
:star: Multiple paths to victory
:star: Re-playability
:star::star::star::star::halfstar:Enjoyment

Best to teach this in stages. Only go over the types of cards encountered in the 1st Age before Age I. Then just before dealing cards for Age II, explain the pre-req aspect and the new cards. Before Afe III explain Guild cards and other new types of cards. Helps prevent information overload in new players.

RATING: 7.5
[u]Drafting City Builder[/u]

● [b]pros[/b] [i]scales well, simultaneous action selection, interesting decisions, synergistic combos/cards, quick play-time, good replayability, great expansions, unique mechanics and gameplay, easy to learn, great gateway[/i]
● [b]cons[/b] [i]luck element, seating plays a big role, minimal player interaction, lacks confrontation[/i]

This game is a keeper. It gets to the table regularly and is a perfect Gateway-Game with short playtime and high replayability. Especially the expansion "7 Wonders: Leaders" adds to it.

Great variant: Goal is to get the least, not the most victory points.

Also owned:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Terrific! because it is stunningly beautiful and easy to learn + fast to play. But I have one issue with it and only time will tell if I'm right about this. I dislike the pyramids of Gizeh or better said: their special power when building your wonder. The victory points are nice, but it's extra-expensive to build the monument and there's nothing that helps you build your engine. Everyone else has a "power" that enables them to purchase buildings, culture, trades, guilds, war machines and science more easily (all worth - well, most of them - victory points on their own). Now if you would need less resources to build your monument or if the last step of the monument was worth more than anyone else's last step (i.e. 10 victory points) then this might work. For now I consider the Egypt player's "power" a disadvantage.  

Oh, and one more thing. Quite a few times, I saw people mention this is a Civ-building game. I fail to see that. For me there's no feeling that I actually build up a civilization. Most of the times I was thinking in terms of: "Ok, I have four brown cards, opponent X has 2 and Opponent Y has 3 - how many green cards or blue cards do they have in play? I wasn't thinking "who runs the senate/ where is the school/whose realm is defended by the wall?" It's a great game with great illustrations, but rather set-collection in perfection. Probably this will displace Ticket to ride as a gateway game. It is shorter and stil much more rewarding.

RATING: 3
Ancient civilization-building card game based around a card-drafting mechanic. Sort of like Fairy Tale with scoring that makes more intuitive sense and cards with a stronger theme. Each of the different kinds of cards make sense and give you lots of paths to victory... plus, 3 to 7 players all go at the same speed.

The variety of cards and complexity of things like science scoring really hurt this game's score. It's just not the intro game it needs to be.

RATING: 9
Super interesting and fun game that also plays well at pretty much any player count (3+) and is also easy to pick up but hard to master? Yes please. Might be the most well rounded game ever. My only complaints are 1. "upgrade" abilities of cards are needlessly difficult to track and poorly placed on the card. (7 Wonders Duel fixed this by using symbols which is a big improvement) and 2. The "can't play two copies of the same card" rule is annoying (it only comes into play at higher player counts (6-7) and is only necessary because otherwise Science would be OP) but I suppose that's the risk you run with Blue/Green cards. I understand why the rule is there and why the duplicates are there but its a small smudge on the game for me.

Still a really, really good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I feel that this game has cemented its place as a blend of introduction game vs strategic game. Explaining a game to a new person takes time and there always seems to be a rule broken or two (Cards with the same name built, confusion on resource production, how to build a wonder). However they still seem to enjoy the game a ton.

I like watching other plays on their turns and seeing what they do, but too often everyone just lays down their cards and the game continues without discussion. Even with the interaction with adjacent players, it feels like something is missing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a spectacular game. It feels like Dominion, but it isn't. It's a Civ game, but it's not. It's complex, but easy to grasp. There are several paths to victory, but it plays quickly. Go get this game.

UPDATE: The more I play it, the more I realize that there's still a lot of luck-of-the-draw in this game. It's hard for anybody to really get "good" at 7 Wonders. It's become one of my favorite games to convert non-gamers to the hobby. But it's definitely becoming lighter and less satisfying with time. I'm bumping my rating down from 8.5 to a flat 8.

UPDATE: I'm bumping it yet again; down to a 7.5. It's definitely not standing the test of time for me. I still consider it a good converter game, though. So I'll probably keep a copy for that aspect alone--I spend a lot of my time introducing non-gamers to good games.
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: Euro, 7 players, civilization, civ, civ-building, simultaneous-action selection, card game, individual player boards, square box[/COLOR]

This is wonderful for how short it is. I like the civ building feel and it doesn't take 3 hours like other civ games.

RATING: N/A
This game is much better the second or third time around with the same group. Some people don't like the fuzzy victory conditions, but I like the fact that this allows you to change on the fly if you have to, or block an opponent scoring big without completely running yourself amok.

RATING: 7
Fun game for gamers and non-gamers that scales well from 3-7 and plays in 30-45 minutes.  It even travels well! This versatility is a dream for someone that plays games with a lot of diverse crowds in a lot of diverse locations. 

Update: The rules explanation makes this sooo hard to get to the table with new players.




Suitability for Travel:

I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:

Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 2
Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 2
Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 5
Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 2

Overall - 2.5
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 6.5
Light civilisation game with card drafting, 18 actions in the game, and interaction only with your immediate neighbours

It's very light and tactical, not wholly offensive, but once you get past explaining the symbols (particularly for scoring) and trading, it's a game you can play with 6 or 7 people in a reasonable time. It's also fun with 3 or 4 (and a bit more thinky)

This has been popular with casual game players who are willing to put up with a bit of rules explanation. I think they enjoy the feeling of development through the game, as your earlier choices impact what you do later.

RATING: 9

-This game is just great for what it is: Light, fun card drafting with quite a bit of random elements so everyone can win. It's not the most strategic game but that just means that everyone can play and have a chance. Nice theme, looks good, quick and fun. 


What I dislike:

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love drafting Magic: the Gathering, and I've enjoyed drafting in the board game Notre Dame, but 7 Wonders taught me that I do have a limit when it comes to drafting games. It's simply too dry. There's too short of a connection between your choices and the final victory point total. Blue and purple cards are worth points directly. Green cards are worth points according to a sliding scale formula. Red cards are worth points based on a prisoner's dilemma with your neighbors. Brown, grey, and yellow cards are worth points in as much as they allow you to build the other cards. And that's it. That's the whole game.

It's nice that it's a fixed-length game that can support up to 7 players, but that comes at too great a cost.

To have any amount of depth, 7 Wonders needs its expansions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best fast-playing strategy game I have ever played.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An interesting card drafting game that in no way what so ever should be compared to Dominion. Not so sure why it's getting that at all as the play style have no resemblance to Dominion at all. Definitely a solid game by it's own right however and fun to play. I would like to try this with a larger group as I think it would interesting to see what come around to you as opposed to trying to pass a card and see if it makes it back to you. 

UPDATE: After playing this a few more times I'm less into it. I don't like the lack of interaction between players on the other side of the table. Perhaps expansions will fix this with "Far Reaching Markets" or something. Too often you can get screwed on resources you need. 

UPDATE: I finally got to play this 3 players and I think the game really shines right here. Yes it can hold 7 but doesn't have to. At 3 players it's super fast and you have to pay attention to your neighbors even more closely as the cards you see you will be seeing twice. Also pay attention to what they developing and you can try to make your civ unique scoring points that they are leaving behind.

RATING: 8
A great game for introducing non-gamers to the next level of strategy gaming. I consider it a step-up from Settlers/TTR/Dominion/etc. The game is just solid. It uses the neat mechanism of card drafting, which forces you to make tricky decisions. This game is very much a "point salad" game. So many different sources for VPs. The nice thing is, each strategy appears to be valid. I have seen winning civilizations with all kinds of different tableaus. It is well balanced, and easy to pick up. Good game.

RATING: 8
Using the innovative card drafting mechanic, which allows simultaneous play, fast play time, limited but present player conflict/interaction, and great scaling from 3-7 players. As predicted, this was the big hit at the 2010 Essen game fair. Being a card game, the cards will largely determine who the winner will be amongst evenly matched players, but the process of evaluating and selecting the best card each turn is quite fun.

Really fun game which features multiple paths to victory.  Simple mechanics once you figure out the icons, etc.  The artwork and theme are top notch.

EDIT - 1/29/2013 - The "new car smell" is off this game for me.  Yes, I enjoy Seven Wonders and will play if it is on the table, but overall it isn't really grabbing me.

The game seems very insular to me.  Yes, you can absolutely see what people are doing around the table and act accordingly, but unless you are really into set-taking games it just isn't a lot of action.

Not a bad game, just not one of my favorites either.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Got this to add another highly ranked (yet fairly light) game to my collection and also because I'm looking into civilization-themed games.

The game is pretty slick and easy to play, but as a civ game I'd like a bit more connection to the theme. Most of what you do, in terms of thinking, is deciding which card to draft on a given turn, and there's really no thematic justification for the drafting mechanism. The most thematic thing is the arms race with your immediate neighbors. Most cards you play reduce costs of a later card or have some synergy with what you've already played (built). Science is reduced to a set collection game, which is pretty abstract.

The player interaction seemed just OK to me, coming not just from the arms race but also because you can try to draft cards you think someone else will want, blocking them.

I thought it was odd how the third (of three) eras has no new ways to get resources. You can't stockpile resources (except money), so if you don't produce enough of something, and your neighbors don't produce enough for you to buy and make up the shortfall, you can be quite sure, 2/3rds through the game, that you'll never be able to build certain things, such as stages of your Wonder!

I was disappointed by the lack of differentiation among player positions. I think games will start to seem samey pretty quickly. Over the course of the game you'll play approximately 6x3=18 cards. There are only about five general types of cards. This leaves room for (probably) a few broad strategies, but you're never going to find yourself in a particularly strange or surprising position.

...Upping .5 point to 7.5 after playing a thrown-together variant where I just mixed all the eras and then only played 4 cards per era instead of 6. It definitely wrecks some of the balance, but it was exciting and felt much less scripted.

...Tried playing where instead of drafting normally, there's a market and you put chips on the cards you want to skip over as in If Wishes Were Fishes. Adds some fiddliness but probably also some strategy.

...What I like most is the economy (deciding which resources to have for yourself and which to pay other players for) and after that, the majority game of military. I wish science and VP buildings had interconnections with something else in the engine.

RATING: 9
A great game that plays up to 7 players, with no detriment at all to the game, since you all play at once.

I would say this is only an 8 because you are dependent on the cards you have available to you to draft.  You may get someone purposefully (which is part of the game) preventing you getting other cards, but you may have others who are not stopping anyone getting any cards...so you get it from both angles.

With the Leaders expansion though it's a 10, as you have a bit more focus and there's a bit more to the game that gives you just that little bit more control.

A favourite!

RATING: 10
Everything I could want in a game. 

+ Very little downtime with players taking their turns at the same time
+ Lots of variability with each of the seven wonders having two sides
+ Scales amazingly well with more players; especially interesting is how interaction changes as the amount of players increasing
+ Interesting dependency mechanism that allow you to build cards that follow on from previous cards without having to use resources
+ Very good quality components and fantastic artwork
+ Easy to follow rules
+ Excellent strategy play with many ways to win; although balance seems to be the key
+ Keep you on your toes as you have to watch what other people are building and what resources they may need
+ Brilliant replay value

Certainly our favourite game in our collection.

RATING: 8
Wow! I really like this game. For all its complexity it is singularly easy to teach and play, and is loaded with all kinds of decisions that can easily be made in a split-second.  Many different strategies to choose from, a lot of interaction with your adjacent players. Not much you can do to affect players on the other side of the board except wasting cards they want in your Wonder. I really like the passing of cards around the board. One of the most important criterion I use to rate a game is the amount of fun I have playing it, and 7 Wonders is simply a lot of FUN!!

I uploaded a huge scan of the scoresheet for full page printing to be laminated for a reusable score sheet.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
7 Wonders is a modern classic. Antoine Bauza has designed a game with Card Drafting in such a wonderful way. In the beginning of the game, the battle is for resources. After, players keep fighting for points.
The scientific tree is my favorite way to develop my civilization, but the people who plays with me already know my preferences and keep blocking me, forcing to try new strategies.
Another way to get lots of points is the blue cards. In stage I, they get few points, but in stage III, you can get such as 8 point with a card.
The theme of developing a city with a wonder is well designed. You can get cards to develop your city, your wonder or just to get money.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
7 Wonders lasts three ages. In each age, players receive seven cards from a particular deck, choose one of those cards, then pass the remainder to an adjacent player, as in Fairy Tale or a Magic: the Gathering booster draft. Players reveal their cards simultaneously, paying resources if needed or collecting resources or interacting with other players in various ways. (Players have individual boards with special powers on which to organize their cards, and the boards are double-sided as in Bauza's Ghost Stories.) Each player then chooses another card from the deck they were passed, and the process repeats until players have six cards in play from that age. After three ages, the game ends.

In essence 7 Wonders is a card development game along the lines of Race for the Galaxy or Dominion. Some cards have immediate effects, while others provide bonuses or upgrades later in the game. Some cards provide discounts on future purchases. Some provide military strength to overpower your neighbors and others give nothing but victory points. Unlike Magic or Fairy Tale, however, each card is played immediately after being drafted, so you'll know which cards your neighbor is receiving and how his choices might affect what you've already built up. Cards are passed left-right-left over the three ages, so you need to keep an eye on the neighbors in both directions.

Though the box is listed as being for 3-7 players, there is an official 2-player variant included in the instructions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
7 Wonders lasts three ages. In each age, players receive seven cards from a particular deck, choose one of those cards, then pass the remainder to an adjacent player, as in Fairy Tale or a Magic: the Gathering booster draft. Players reveal their cards simultaneously, paying resources if needed or collecting resources or interacting with other players in various ways. (Players have individual boards with special powers on which to organize their cards, and the boards are double-sided as in Bauza's Ghost Stories.) Each player then chooses another card from the deck they were passed, and the process repeats until players have six cards in play from that age. After three ages, the game ends.

In essence 7 Wonders is a card development game along the lines of Race for the Galaxy or Dominion. Some cards have immediate effects, while others provide bonuses or upgrades later in the game. Some cards provide discounts on future purchases. Some provide military strength to overpower your neighbors and others give nothing but victory points. Unlike Magic or Fairy Tale, however, each card is played immediately after being drafted, so you'll know which cards your neighbor is receiving and how his choices might affect what you've already built up. Cards are passed left-right-left over the three ages, so you need to keep an eye on the neighbors in both directions.

RATING: 6
It's an interesting design, but I don't like it nearly as much as most people seem to. With more than four players it's far too easy to get screwed based on the decisions of your immediate neighbors, who are not affecting other players to the same extent (or at all, with more than five). The decision space is also not as large as it might appear at first, which is not surprising given how few decisions you can actually make in the game.

My 6 rating is a compromise: as a 3-4 player game I might rate it as high as 7, but with 6-7 players I'd rate it no higher than 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good:
-Perfect for people looking to become hobbyist
-Simultaneous turns
-Truly supports up to 7 people
-Scales amazing (just not with two)
-Components and Art are fantastic
-One page reference guide sums up iconology very well
-Multiple paths to victory
-Will seem familiar to Magic: The Gathering drafters

The Bad:
-Iconology will overwhelm at first
-Confusing rulebook
-Too many small decision for non-gamers
-Scoring is awkward and long
-Purple cards throw off balance

?-Make sure to enforce the no duplicate cards rule.  Ignoring it will make science strategies too strong.   

Overall:
A board game collection should be like a Swiss Army knife.  It should have a game for every situation.  7 Wonders is the perfect game for when you want to play a strategy game with 5+ people and finish in under an hour (trust me, you will be in this situation a lot).  The simultaneous turns nearly eliminated downtime and keep players engaged at all times.  The multiple paths to victory help keep the game fresh and give players direction.

I keep coming back to this game - a great "filler", but can enjoy playing it several times in a row.

RATING: 8
7 Wonders really plays like Fairy Tale combined with Race For The Galaxy like scoring and tech trees. Luck and gambling/guessing play quite a big role in the game, but considering its short playing time and almost non-existent downtime that might well be part of its charm. The game scales incredibly well from 3 to 7(!) players. The explanation of the end of game scoring and card icons is a little daunting, but everything falls into place quickly once you start playing.
UPDATE: Always like to play, even though the game has lost a little of its initial appeal. One of the best 6+ player games in existence.

RATING: 7
05/2011: 7.5
Two plays thus far, one with three, the other with four. It is basically a card-driven engine/production building game that is not terribly innovative, but has TWO major pros. 1) Short playing time. 2) 7 players. These two factors only bumped this game up by at least 1.5 on my ratings. The simultaneous action selection mechanism will always have its detractors, but I do think that it fits perfectly well with this game. The only folks you need to watch out for are your neighbors to your immediate left and right. There is plenty more interaction than I expected even though the interaction is somewhat benign and predictable.Good game, but not great.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 1
7 Wonders is a draft game, and one I would tell people to avoid at all costs. 

The theme is pasted on, there is no grand civilization feel to the game. The only interaction is with the people sitting next to you and it's minimal at that.

If you're unlucky enough to be sitting downstream to a person who knows what they're doing then you're going to be in for a rough time. You'll lament your position while you watch other people on the opposite side of the table scoring tons of points because they're positioned between people who are less experienced.

Do not believe any argument about having influence on people more than 2 spaces away from you, it's simply not true. You can table talk all you want, but at the end of the day, everyone is at the mercy of the people who are passing to them.

If you're looking for a game that lets you play 7 players, then I'd suggest Resistance. If you're after a draft game, then just play Magic the Gathering. Build a cube (which is just an assortment of cards) and draft that with some friends. 7 Wonders isn't worth your time.

I've been told that this is best with 3, but it's highly unlikely that I'll ever revisit this. It's also important to note that my disdain with this game comes from the group I was playing it with. On my right, I had my mate who's a drafting shark, and on my left, a beginner who couldn't stop complaining as I was drafting "too fast". I thought fast play was a good thing, apparently not according to some people. All the while, people sitting at the opposite side of the table were just handing the win to someone else.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great game.  The draft mechanic gets really fun upwards of 4 players and at 7 can be so painful it's brilliant. 

A simple, single "win" scenario (VPs), can be achieved in many ways - and ideally a combination.  After many plays I still don't feel the need to purchase the expansion.

RATING: 9.4
Com uma mecânica bem interessante, divertida e desafiadora, além de uma temática linda, inteligente e muito bem sacada, esse jogo te pega logo de cara. Na 1a. ou 2o. jogadas você pode não saber muito o que fazer e se perder um pouco pela quantidade de símbolos diferentes, mas logo se torna intuitivo (outro mérito para a arte).
O mais fantástico é perceber como se pode fazer um jogo completo baseado em uma única ação: escolher cartas!
Pode-se até dizer: oras, mas todo jogo de cartas (principalmente deck buildings) são assim.
Metade do tempo... A segunda grande características dos cards games é tomar ações baseadas nessas cartas escolhidas, aqui não... Basicamente basta escolhê-las na ordem/ momento certo... E isso que o torna fascinante.
Peca um pouco pelos set-up e contagem final de pontos levemente demorados, mas nada que desabone esse family game leve e divertido.

RATING: 4

7 Wonders is light strategy, NOT family.  Period.  And if I want to play light strategy I'd have hundreds of other games to choose from.  Why this game gets all the attention is absurd.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
When I first played 7 Wonders, I was extremely impressed. It seemed to pack a large amount of game into a 30 minute time frame, while allowing for up to 7 players. However, almost two years later, I have learned many more games, which has led me to discover that 7 Wonders isn't nearly as impressive as I thought. 

One aspect of 7 Wonders that I find to be extremely frustrating is the aspect of interacting only with your neighbors. It is very frustrating when your neighbors have lots of military power, so you have to have 7 swords to avoid losing a VP, while the player across the table can win every battle by only playing 2 swords. The resources are also frustrating, since if one player plays a ton of resource cards, his neighbors can leech off them, but the other players can't. I have seen games where brick cards, for example, never made it over to my side of the table, so I was without brick for the entire game. I also can't stand the guild cards that score VPs for cards played by their neighbors. So I spent half the game playing blue cards, and you can just play a card that gives you 8 VPs from MY cards? Having said all that, if the players play quickly enough, and if the game is played with 3-4 players, I find it to be rather enjoyable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Just played again last night and moved my rating up a bit. I rarely play anything but the two-player variant, and I didn't realize how much you can exploit the dummy city before. 

It's an interesting solution. 

This was one if the first games we bought, and we played it so much that as we began acquiring more games, this didn't make it to the table as much.

I have lots of games to compare it with now, and it still feels innovative. Love all the paths to victory and the subtleties I keep finding.

RATING: 9
The best game I played at GenCon 2010, and from the hype and the description, I was actually expecting to be lukewarm at best about it.  Very solid drafting mechanics, very quick play, accommodates a larger than average number of players, and asymmetrical starting boards.

---

A rule of thumb as you look down the list of comments: in virtually every comment that says it is "random" "chaotic" "luck driven" or "low interaction", you should replace those statements with "this person doesn't know how to draft".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A game about drafting, picking a route, and hoping for the best. A lot of nice quirks to the game. Combat element allows aggressive players to attack, but doesn't make passive players feel bad because outside of minus a point, you don't lose anything. A truckload of Icons, which makes up the game, so teaching can be a bit rough at first, also with a few small rules that are easy to forget. I find it a solid quick game for gamers, but actually not very suitable for non-gamers.

RATING: 7

A very clever game that I'd recommend if you happen to also find it on clearance for $10.

RATING: 7.5
Still working out the strategies....so far Ephesus has won both games with Technology providing them a healthy amount of points.  This games a lot of fun.  Relatively simple once you make it through the first game.  Knowing what cards are available down the road would probably really help you plan your economy....but this is fun game even as I wander around semi-blind.  

There really is a sense of building an empire as you go along.  Great game!

RATING: 6
Pros: one of the few strategy games that can accomodate 6+ players, card drafting integrated into set building, variable strategies, quick playtime with little downtime

Cons: no direct player interaction, limited replayability without the expansions

A decent game, especially good when you have a large group that all want to play a strategy game together. However, too little depth of strategy and player interaction for me.

RATING: 4
"Choose one card and pass the rest on" sounds way easy enough to teach even non-gamers, but there is a whole bundle of vocabulary you have to absorb about how the cards interact before you know [b]why[/b] to select anything. I'm not willing to invest the time, not really the decision process I seek for my entertainment.

Overall it just plain strikes me as attractive for middle-school age players.  

I put down a 4 rating but my thoughts truly are better matched by the wording that goes with a 3.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I played this every week when it came out, but the setup time, as well as the time it takes to teach new players the game, with a lot of variables to learn, in conjunction with the game being mostly luck in spite of so many decisions that seem important and meaningful being made, led me to tire of it fast. But I still like it and want to play it every few months or so. I'd recommend many other games instead of it that I'd get first, such as Sushi Go!, which is a fast, simple game with almost the same mechanics. But if you do get this game, you want to get the first two expansions and the extra city boards as well. The latest expansion, Babel, I haven't tried yet, but it's very expensive, and it changes the rules and makes things more confusing, so I don't think I'm going to get it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is a pretty revolutionary game, at least for me. The game definitely takes way longer to explain for the first time then it takes to play. It's a draft game where you take a card from a hand and then pass the rest of the hand to the next person. You try to build up your civilization through different means (trade, military, technology, etc) and the game is over after three rounds of this. There isn't any talking in the game at all which is definitely a strike against it in my eyes, but there is player interaction through drafting and it plays very very quickly. I might be terrible at 7 Wonders, but I'll play it any time it gets taken out. Definitely a must have for most board game collections.
