RATING: 8
The game is good, not comparable to 2 hour "deep" games but still a lot of meaningful choices in 20-30 minutes. However, I think this game is best with 3 players, maybe even 4. The more players, the more it's about randomness rather than good choices that would benefit you and interfere with your neighbours. So despite being playable with 7 players I would be hesitant to play with more than 4.

RATING: 5

EDIT: On subsequent plays the game shows that it lacks some replayability, but is great for the first dozen games and still good, but not great thereafter.

RATING: 7
spilled beer on cards... cleaned off, but probably not something to ever trade.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I was very skeptical about this game after hearing about it.  There were plenty of red flags, like a too-short playtime, and a dry-sounding production mechanic.  But actually playing it has left me pleased.  Art and art design are gorgeous.  The drafting is very simple, but there's lots of layers of stuff to consider, like what you want, as well as what you can't afford to give to your neighbor, all while retaining a really fast playtime.  This is a really tight design, plays up to seven without significant additional playtime, and has a good amount of strategy to it.  Great choice to start building a game collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This may be my favorite game that can be played in 30 minutes.  Great decisions throughout, plus there is really no downtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Some moments very common from citadels // also cards from AGE III make everything in the end of the game.

Вообще впечатление двоякое, вроде и неплохой арт, быстрые партии, но все же много схожестей с предшественниками, города - ресурсы / ресурсы-города.
Так же много действия одновременно, не всегда можно уследить за другими, все ли всем хватает, все ли честно все делают. Тем не менее игра неплохая.

RATING: 8
Great game for 2-4 players, maybe even with 5. The game with 6 or 7 players is really different, and more or less skill-low (probably even skill-less). Still THE current filler for gamers to play with non-gamers.

Still need more plays to understand how much depth the game has with 3-4 players (2p is a different beast). My guess is that it has quite a bit of depth (less than RFTG, of course, but more than Dominion, base game, would be my current opinion).

EDIT: not sure about depth (leaders solves some of it). Still a very nice game, with a lot of appeal.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Bland bland bland. I'm basically done with this after 7 plays spread over 6 months. Those 7 plays are virtually indistinguishable from each other, nothing memorable in a single one of them. Choose a card, put it on the table 18 times, add up the scores. Ooh, 42 this time, instead of 48. Wow.

edit: Ended up purchasing this, mostly just to get some use out of the promos I keep ending up with. :) The comment above sounds harsher than it is, the game is ok, it's just not "all that", and shouldn't be anywhere near the top 10 on BGG. Fun to pull out for a large group for a quick filler every few months, I have no idea why folks are playing this dozens and dozens of times in a week, or making it the focal point of a game night by playing it repeatedly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I am fascinated by the fact that up to 7 can play this in the same amount of time.  There are many paths to victory, and it is hard to know which one is best.  It depends a lot on what your neighbors are doing.  Fortunately, it is short enough that you can always play again.  I enjoy the drafting, even though its a challenge to let go of the other cards I want.  It is a drag not to be able to interact with any of the players other than the two right next to me, though.

RATING: 7
Great game to play especially with five players. The cards are extremely poor quality and this point is driven home by how much the game cost. I was really bummed that the 2nd Edition replaced the wood money with cardboard. The purple shading quality on the Phase III cards was also a big concern. All in all a great game to play but the 2nd Edition is a FAIL in my opinion. I will wait for a third edition and if they come down on price I will probably re-purchase it and donate my current copy.

RATING: 7
Rated after two three player games. The game feels interesting, but I have no idea how much there is really depth in this game. I need to play more to find out and this feels like a game I like to play more.

Rated after five three player games. The game feels good once you (and others) know the rules and mechanics. Needs to be tested with more players. Updated after two 6 player games with couple of newbies. Game was naturally slower and did not felt so tight, but in the end the games were quite even.

Game is incredibly fast once you have played it couple of times. The mechanics are good and the theme is nicely fitted into the game. The latest game was a seven player game were all of the others were practically newbies. The game was fast and most of them liked it. With large amount of players, it is quite difficult to track what others are doing.

RATING: 10
This is our favourite strategic family game. Its best feature is simultaneous play: everybody is making decisions at the same time. Because of this feature, it is possible to finish a game in 30 minutes with as many as 7 players while still making meaningful decisions. We play this one very frequently.

RATING: 5.5
Juego para mi excesivamente light y azaroso. Se hace muy corto y tiene un final que no me gusta nada, ya que el que gana la partida nunca sabe bien porque lo ha hecho :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Game plays quite fast. Once you know the rules and mechanism it may take around 25 min. for a game to be played. The game urges you to make difficult choices as you have limited amount of turns. Teaching the game (even to people for whom this might be their first ever board game) takes around 15 - 20 minutes. 

This one strikes the excellent balance between simplicity, diversity and tactical thinking. You have to plan out your moves from the very beginning to win in the very end.

Love it and I would truly suggest this as one of the first games to play with family and friends. Plays really fun with more than 4 people althouhg 3 player game has its knack :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Me, my partner and family all love this game - specially my sons. The expansions really add to the experience. By far my favourite family game in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Like many former Magic players, I love drafting, and unlike some, I still feel like this is a complete game. There is a "1st age doesn't matter" feel but I'm hoping expansions will fix this.

RATING: 9
the theme is very good, the word 7 wonders is general but always interesting. the goal to create the most influencing wonder is good, and so is the variable power among each wonder. the number 7 is really applied to this game, and it suits the theme very well

the gameplay is actually simple, it's a deck building game variant through card drafting mechanic. the transformation of each age is also cool, the rising strength of card is really good. the fact there's several aspect in the game is good because it makes the game balanced, and the fact that you cant excel in everything offers so many strategy. player interaction is good, countermeasure to opponent's strategy is ok, you need to counter people's strategy, but not too much that you should lose focus of yourself

the components are good. card design is good, artwork is really nice, the tokens are nice. the card size is a bit too big though, it makes the table feels cramped sometimes

overall, this game is very good. this game has a very nice concept translated into a nice gameplay, but really, 7 variables are somewhat too many. it's not really suitable for casual gamer, the mechanics are a bit complex. the card drafting mechanic suits this game well, and i'm always a fan of card drafting. i rate it 9/10

RATING: 6
------------------------------
NOTICE : Due to my poor spoken & written English, the rest of my comments will be written in French only but you can read my profile for more informations about the kind of games I prefer and how I rated them.
------------------------------

►ÉDITION : Repos production, français, 2011.
Éditeur, nb joueurs : 2 à 7 joueurs.
Éditeur, durée : 0h30/partie.
Éditeur, âge : 10 ans et plus.

►PUBLIC(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
☺ Jeu de stratégie mixte (quelques éléments aléatoires et/ou de hasard raisonné).
☻ Personnellement, j'hésite à le considérer comme un gateway-game, à cause de sa multitude d'icônes qui peuvent rebuter les nouveaux joueurs.

►JOUEURS, NOMBRE(S) QUE JE RECOMMANDE:
# Meilleur :
# Recommandé : 3, 4, 5
# Non-recommandé : 
# Non-essayé : 2, 6, 7
2 joueurs : je n’ai pas d’intérêt pour les configurations requérant un joueur virtuel.

►COMMENTAIRE(S) ABRÉGÉ(S):
± THÈME : plutôt plaqué; mais agrémente le jeu.
+ Aide de jeu : 1 inclus mais j’aurais aimé qu’il y en ait 1 par joueur (photocopies?). Bien détaillé.
+ Configurations équilibrées selon le nombre de joueurs.
+ Configurations multiples : plateaux individuels personnalisés.
- Déroulement répétitif : peut donner l’impression que toutes les parties se ressemblent.
- Icônes : requièrent un effort d’apprentissage et de mémorisation.

►REMARQUE(S) PERSONNELLE(S):
Jeu qui a l’avantage de demeurer fluide, quel que soit son nombre de joueurs, grâce à sa mécanique de draft où les tours de jeu s'effectuent en simultané. De plus, il présente d'autres mécaniques intéressantes tel que : le principe de "chaînage" permettant de construire un bâtiment gratuitement (si on a construit précédemment un bâtiment inférieur lié), les ressources perpétuelles (qui se renouvellent au début de chaque tour) et la guerre (symbolisée par le pouvoir de dissuasion des puissances militaires en présence).

En ce qui concerne la configuration selon le nombre de joueurs, il faut retirer des cartes spécifiques, en les cherchant une à une, dans les 3 paquets (âge 1-2-3) et donc, pour chaque configuration de joueurs, la constitution des paquets est quasiment toujours la même sauf pour quelques cartes « Guilde » qui elles doivent être ajoutées aléatoirement au paquet 3e âge. À noter que c’est l’un des aspects que j’apprécie des extensions Leaders et Cities, soit l’apport de cartes aléatoires qui atténuent le côté "figé" des paquets 1 et 2 du jeu de base).

Personnellement, c’est un jeu que j’hésite parfois à sortir lorsque je me sens trop sans-coeur pour :
1e- effectuer les manipulations préparatoires.
2e- expliquer la multitude d’icônes (ce qui fait que j’ai de plus en plus tendance à y jouer seulement lorsque tous les joueurs connaissent le jeu).

►EXTENSION(S) ESSAYÉE(S):
& « Leaders » : Oui.
& « Cities » : Oui.
& « Wonderpack » : À essayer.
& Je n'ai jamais essayé l'(les) autre(s) extension(s) parce qu’elle(s) n’a(ont) pas assez soulevé mon intérêt pour me convaincre de le faire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I don't see the appeal... but I've only played it once and had no idea what was going on. I need to give it another shot or two.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So, the buzz is telling you that this is an approachable, straightforward game with a variety of strategies, all of which appear to be fairly balanced, and which plays in about 30-45 minutes, regardless of the number of players in the game.  And ... well, it's true.  I mean, I can come in here and talk about all of these things again, but why bother?  If you haven't bought into the buzz by now, not much that I can tell you is going to make a difference.

It's also true that this game won't be everyone's cup of tea.  It's entirely possible to wind up with a totally crap hand, where your best option is to discard a card for 3 coins/1 point, and it hardly seems efficient to play that sort of game.  It also seems to be highly dependent on the luck of the draw, but playing with fewer players might help alleviate some of that, since you can manage the hands a bit more carefully.  It's also true that you have to lock in to a particular strategy early in the game, but the varieties of strategies you can try, and the ways that the game can be different every time you play it, adds a lot to the appeal.  Someone once wrote of Fluch der Mumie, "If this sounds like the thing you might like, then you will," and I can say the same about 7 Wonders.  I can say with certainty that I'm glad I own it, and I expect to play it many more times.

I'm starting to like this game more with fewer player numbers, since it means you have some sense of planning with the cards, since you'll see more cards from your hands going around the table.  With more players, you're strictly at the mercy of what's passed to you, and it turns the game into a tactical one.  With fewer players, the game takes on a bit more of a strategic edge.

3 plays: 3 players
1 play: 4 players
6 plays: 5 players
13 plays: 6 players

-----

Base game
Catan Island
Cities
Leaders
Manneken Pis
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The words 7 Wonders is really applied to the theme. Its a game about develop a civilization of one nation through variable power among each wonder. The goal is to make most victory points (VP) either via science, civilian, military, or economic way.

The gameplay is simple, it's a set collection game variant through card drafting mechanic that last in 3 Ages. I rate it 9...

Including :
- [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/92539/7-wonders-leaders]7 Wonders: Leaders[/url]
- [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/111661/7-wonders-cities]7 Wonders: Cities[/url]
- [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/boardgameexpansion/133993/7-wonders-wonder-pack]7 Wonders: Wonder Pack[/url]

RATING: 8
Maybe 8 is not enough for this game. Excellent card game, with a lot of opportunities for your strategy planning but little interaction between the players (at least not visible). The fact that until the last round you suspect but you don't know who the winner will be, makes you sit on the edge of your sit and enjoy the game until the last minute. For me, it is a disadvantage that the play lasts for so little time (less than 30' for experienced players) but maybe that is one of the magic elements of the game. Rather expensive for what it contains, but which game with so many awards is cheap? A must-try game!

RATING: 7
A solid classic. Half an hour to play, so new players can fit enough games into an evening to learn and improve significantly.

Each turn players choose and play a card from the hand in front of them, then pass the remaining cards along for the next person. There is no hidden information beyond what cards are in the hands which have not come past you yet.

There are multiple paths to victory, appropriately through 7 sources of victory points. It's not a sandbox though- there isn't the dizzying choice of strategy of other games. It's a medium-weight game.

Up to 7 players, but that's a bit much really- 3-5 is better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
7 Wonders lasts three ages. In each age, players receive seven cards from a particular deck, choose one of those cards, then pass the remainder to an adjacent player, as in Fairy Tale or a Magic: the Gathering booster draft. Players reveal their cards simultaneously, paying resources if needed or collecting resources or interacting with other players in various ways. (Players have individual boards with special powers on which to organize their cards, and the boards are double-sided as in Bauza's Ghost Stories.) Each player then chooses another card from the deck they were passed, and the process repeats until players have six cards in play from that age. After three ages, the game ends.
\13\\13\
In essence 7 Wonders is a card development game along the lines of Race for the Galaxy or Dominion. Some cards have immediate effects, while others provide bonuses or upgrades later in the game. Some cards provide discounts on future purchases. Some provide military strength to overpower your neighbors and others give nothing but victory points. Unlike Magic or Fairy Tale, however, each card is played immediately after being drafted, so you'll know which cards your neighbor is receiving and how his choices might affect what you've already built up. Cards are passed left-right-left over the three ages, so you need to keep an eye on the neighbors in both directions.
\13\\13\
Though the box is listed as being for 3-7 players, there is an official 2-player variant included in the instructions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
7 Wonders is certainly a well-designed game, but I think it's a tad overrated. I'm not sure if that feeling is just a let down from exposure to the hype machine that trumpeted its release or if it's simply because I have played (and enjoyed) Fairy Tale so much. While the details of play are certainly different between the two games, both still boil down to drafting cards and then playing them in front of you in an effort to collect point scoring sets. Fairy Tale has much better interaction however, with cards that can nullify or alter cards in the opponent’s tableau. 

It might be that 7 Wonders has such an engaging theme that many players don’t take notice of its simplicity. That's not necessarily a knock against it; indeed I think it's the one aspect that is perfectly executed. Since this game is designed to seat seven players, that simplicity is more or less a requirement. It’s not too often that a party game can pull off something this ambitious, so I suppose it does deserve some merit for doing that so successfully.

To reiterate, 7 Wonders is a very good design...I just want something a little more meaty in my civilization games, which is why I think in some ways it misses the mark for me. I do like it. I just don't think it's anywhere near as good as other card games in the top 100 like Race for the Galaxy, Innovation or Dominion. I suppose I expected more out of it, because I simply don’t think there is enough meat to the game to justify a top 20 BGG ranking.

RATING: 7
My favorite way to play Magic was booster drafts, and this didn't disappoint...much. The drafting part was great fun, there's enough interaction to keep you on your toes, and I like that the ways to score points are so diverse. However, I didn't like how difficult it was to keep track of the other side of the table, and I'm not certain that there's enough there to prevent the strategy from cracking after enough plays (or if the metagame would prevent any one path from becoming too apparent). I should note for the record that, as of this writing, I've played three 6-player games using 3 different strategies 
(military/wonder board, blue cards, and science) and I came in a close second all 3 times, so this isn't just whining about "X is totally overpowered"; it just seems like the type of game that runs the risk of getting stale for me, like Thurn and Taxis did. Then again, some of it may just be that I let the hype get me overexcited, because it is a very good game.

Update: leaving the earlier comment to note progression, but I enjoy this game a little bit less every time I play it. I dumped my copy but some friends still have it. The big issue is that I don't think it actually works that well with more than 4 players, and there are so many better games with 4 that it doesn't seem worth playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Revisiting this has me upping the rating. Just so much in so little time, a fun theme, and with one or more expansions, sufficiently variable.

Expansion remarks
-----------------
Leaders: creates more asymmetry, mixes up game state, allows some forward planning, but has too many icons to remember.

Cities: adds card variability, limited nastiness, but some fuss in setup/takedown.

Babel: changes basic evaluations, increases interaction/dependencies, can increase nastiness, but again adds icon-lookups before play.

All are expensive relative to content. Babel or Cities adds the most for the least rule intrusions if variability is desired. Leaders is more strategic (an odd choice for the first expansion).

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really great card drafting game, focused on set collection, trading off short and long-term benefits, and guessing what your neighbors will do. Hits a complexity sweet spot for me--there's enough going on that it's interesting over many plays, but easy enough to play with mixed groups of experienced and newer gamers. Scales excellently from 3-7 players with minimal increase in playing time.

One thing to note is that you only directly interact with your immediate neighbors. This keeps things the complexity very manageable (good) but also means you can essentially ignore what everyone else at the table is doing (bad). It also means that who you sit next to will be very significant! Two military-minded folks sitting next to each other will waste a lot of resources for less gain than if they sit on opposite sides of the table. This definitely leads to some metagaming, which may or may not be your thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Bought it primarily for the art and the theme, I really wanted to like it. The more I play it the less I like it.
I have played it at least 10 times that weren't recorded.

What I Like-
Plays quick at all numbers. Actually plays longer with 2 players due to dummy player management. I like the civ idea. I like the art. I like the trade with your neighbors only aspect. 

What I Dislike-
It's just 'pick a card' and pay for it. Very samey feel each and every turn. Strategy limited to denying neighbors a card they want vs scoring points yourself. Would like to try it with all cards laid out and have players able to compete somehow to get the card they want. No crescendo or build up. Flat.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
7 Wonders hits just the right length and depth for me as a "civ-builder". There are enough choices to make for some challenging decisions and yet the game manages to stay supremely simple and quick-to-play thanks to simultaneous player turns.

The "take one, pass it on" hand-management mechanic is interesting, forcing you not only to think for yourself but also about what you might be passing on to your opponents.

The game seems to scale well for all group sizes and I was even pleasantly surprised by the 2-player variant. My wife (a non-gamer) has requested 2-player games of 7 Wonders because she found it such fun. I only wish the game featured slightly more direct player-interaction but that is only a personal preference and I understand the "Cities" expansion does this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I have played this a tremendous amount of times and (while it is just now starting to get old) I can see the universal appeal of it.

Drafting games are among my favorites and this packs the feel of a Civ-lite into the game as well. There is some light player interaction, it scales beautifully and with experienced players it lasts around 30 minutes no matter the number of players.

Replay value is the only issue I see with 7 Wonders, however, it still stays fresh for more than enough plays to warrant picking this one up.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Light and fast card game, which feels somewhat pleasant - despite being very poorly designed. I found a comment made by "newuser" which sums up very well the issues with game:

Fallacies about 7 Wonders:
(1) "The game scales well." It does scale well from 3 to 4 players. Anything more and players see too few cards, don't get the chance to pick more than a single card from most hands, and don't have any meaningful way to affect non-neighbors.
(2) "Easy to learn. Good gateway game." Beyond the many symbols and icons, players must understand and be familiar with the cards in each deck before being able to reasonably judge value of cards. This requires players to sit down and study the deck or play dozens of games with blind trial-and-error. Too complex for non-gamers, not enough meat for serious gamers.
(3) "Deep strategy. Many meaningful decisions." Even under the best case assumption of 4 or fewer players, tactics are more important than true strategy. Most decisions are reactionary, based on relative point values of each card. With more than 4 players, strategy is right out the window.
(4) "Player interaction." Nearly multi-player solitaire. You aren't able to draft cards without playing them yourself, so card denial is very limtied. Can't affect cards once played. Only interaction is through passing coins to neighbors.
(5) "Well balanced." Except the player boards aren't well balanced, with some providing easier paths to victory than others.
(6) -- this one statement was about theme but I don't agree that theme is bad. pictures look pretty well and follow the meaning of cards. scoring system is acceptable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Almost always gets 2-3 more plays then we plan for when we bring it out.

RATING: 7
I enjoy the civ building and drafting aspects quite a lot. The ways to get VPs are unique enough, but they aren't sufficiently well balanced and often one's score depends too much on the cards they get late in the final round which are hard to anticipate or influence with previous decisions. Too many cards are just worth a certain amount of VP without any interesting interaction with the rest of the tableau. This makes the game simple and quick (which is a feature, not a bug), but sets a pretty low ceiling for strategy.

Eh, it becomes repetitive after awhile.  I find this is sort of the anti-gateway game.  It seems like it should be a great game to introduce to new gamers, but then their eyes glaze over at the different symbols, different types of cards, different uses for each card.

For experienced players, it's fun for about 10 or so plays, but then becomes samey as the luster wears off.

It's a good game, but not great.

*Update 11/11/12* Down to 5.5.  It's to the point where I would probably turn down a game of 7W more readily than be up for one.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my favorite board game.  Period. It perfectly combines the 4 things I look for in a game. 1: There are multiple ways to score points.  You won't win this game the way you won the last game.  And you may find yourself switching strategies 2/3 of the way through the game.  2: There are lots of ways to mess with your opponents.  Often, the choice of what move to make is whether to do something that helps you or do something that hurts your competition.  3: It's not over until it's over.  You never feel the last-place blues.  The person who swears they're losing can turn out to have won when all the points are counted.  The on-a-roll player can wind up in 3rd or 4th.  Everyone has fun the whole game.  4: There's relatively little luck.  Too much luck can actually hurt you in this game (play it and you'll see what I mean).

And while many of the other favorite games also have these 4 aspects, 7 Wonders ties up my 10/10 vote for two reasons.  First, games are short.  You can finish a game in 30-40 minutes and you are left wanting to play again right after.  Second, every player takes their turn at the same time.  There's no waiting for everyone to go before it's your turn again.  It moves fast, everyone plays all the time, and and just awesome.  Get this game.  Do it.  Right now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Top of the pile.  Play with the expansions. Balanced.

RATING: 8.7
Works: (1.4) this is definitely a two because of all the accolades.  The .4 is because of the two player game part.  The wife and I will play 7 wonders only if other people want to play it but we do not play it by ourselves anymore.
 
Inquiry: (1.4) there a multiple paths to victory with different affects in the game.  You can get combinations of cards to multiple victory points or take victory points away with a card or two.  Or you can get a combination of cards to earn victory points or other cards with victory points on them.  The .4 is because there is a path to win that is strong and can dominate if other players are not aware.

Collaboration: (1.5) there is some interactions with people because of how you trade cards in your hand.  What I mean is every one has the opportunity to see what other player have in their hands. The .5 is because there are moments in the game where I feel I am playing against no one and trying to problem solve my best move.

Organized: (2.0) the space in the box is well organized and can sort all of the different cards.  Also there is room for grubber apple sauce plastic containers to fit inside to hold all of the other small cardboard components.
 
Reading: (2.0) The rules are well laid out with lots of pictures of the cards and components.

RATING: 8.38
Card-drafting game in which you attempt to build up infrastructure and economy to build your wonder and score points.   The gameplay is fairly simple to explain although it does rely heavily on symbols to represent what each card does, which is usually intuitive but there are a few that require the use of a reference sheet.   It takes a lot of players without slowing down because turns are simultaneous.  However, your main player interactions (trade and war) are only with the people sat to your right and left, which may make you feel like you’re not in the same game as the other players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A grail of sorts: many designers have tried “civ lite” -- i.e. captures the feel of Civilization/4X games but takes significantly less time to play -- to varied success, and this is the best I’ve played.  It’s truly a compact and easy-to-learn design. There are divergent paths to victory, lots of resource management, some player interaction, and enough ancient world theme to hold it together.  That said, this game boils down to set collection.  It’s generally better to take a large number of one card type than a variety.  It’s very possible to have seven players end the game with fairly similar tableaus separated only by color of card.  Many decisions that feel extremely significant only vary by one point.  In the third Age, it’s very possible to have two or three plays per “pack” which are worth the same value.  I like the “counter-draft” aspect of the game, but I think it’s not as important as it seems at first.        
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

It doesnt play very well with two, it gets a bit confusing during the third age. Unfortunately I havent tried it yet with more players, and even though I see its potential, its theme is not accessible to casual players. I really want to give it one more try though!

RATING: 9.05
The concept of having a 7 player game take maybe barely longer than a lesser player game is fantastic.  The card drafting mechanism of everyone taking a card and passing the rest to the left and right is brilliant.  More games should use that concept.  You don't have to wait for every individual person to make a move, and you effect the people to your left and right a lot throughout the relatively short but strategically packed game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Took awhile for me to get this to the table, but it became an instant hit.  Very open-ended gameplay which makes it easy to change both your strategy and tactics.  

Love that you not only have to concentrate on the civilization that you're building, but it is an absolute necessity to watch the opponents to your left and right.  If you don't, you are playing blind.  

Easy to get into, even if you or others are new to the game.  After a few turns, game-flow becomes intuitive.  The one element of gameplay that isn't immediately intuitive is the scoring mechanism.

This is mitigated by a large, colorful summary sheet.  It shows the scoring mechanisms as well as each card that triggers scoring.  Easy to follow.  This same scoring summary is also printed in full color on the back of the game instructions.

Great gateway game.  Fun and fast card game.  If you are someone who enjoys civilization building games, definitely scratches that itch.  Replay value is high, especially now that there is an expansion (sold separately) to add to the variety and strategies employed in the base game.

Good times are waiting for any one who decides to play 7 Wonders.  :)     
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great Gateway game, good replay value, still fun

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Note: rating is for base game only.

I think this is a good game, but not really a great game. It's possible I might change my rating if I end up playing it more than 20 times. 

I believe a lot of the acclaim for this game has to do with it being playable by large groups without tons of setup, and without a huge time investment, while still having some considerable depth. I respect that as a major design achievement. But I think in the future it will be completely outdone, many times over (I hope). I just don't find anything particularly exciting or elegant here - it's a pretty good drafting game (but only a drafting game).   

It's also noteworthy that I think it's not as good with 6-7 people as others mention. Even with a really good group, a 6-7 player game can be a lot slower, and it's really difficult to keep track of the entire game state. That said, I think it's underrated as a 3-player game as well. 

The area where I find the game to ultimately be limited is in the amount of information you can glean by looking at cards. Some cards have VPs listed on them. Most don't. Why not? The military and science cards totally have space for text, but new players have to constantly be reminded of what things are worth what VPs. That's just a minor example, but I think that the rules could generally be integrated into game play a bit better. Sure, maybe after 10-15 plays I'd remember every card, etc., but it just could be smoother. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Overrated? Possibly.
Will I continue to play? Yes.
This is just a great game!

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An amazing game.  It's a filler game as far as play time (30 mins), but the numerous scoring methods provide multiple strategies, and this game will probably always be played several times in succession, so it ends up being much more than a filler.  There is no downtime, no matter how many players, and it is super-versatile, playing just as good with 7 as it does with 4 players.  There is interaction, but it's mainly limited to your immediate neighbors, so you don't have to strain looking across the table, and you can easily keep an eye on either side of you to block what you think they need.  It's a fun game to play because there's a fair amount of strategy without becoming work, and there's no boring downtime waiting for others to take their turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
To its credit, 7 Wonders is an extremely light Eurogame that plays in one hour or less, regardless of the number of players.  That's impressive.

But each player's ultimate success is fairly random, since both wealth and victory points are dependent chaotically on what your immediate neighbors choose to do.  As proof, I crushed everyone on my first play of the game (7-players), and that's simply unacceptable given that I had no idea what I was doing.

So yes, new players can do well.  But when newcomers can do [i]that[/i] well, there's something not quite right.

RATING: 9.5
Excellent, fairly light, and very smooth-playing game built around card drafting.  Since everyone is drawing and playing cards simultaneously there is virtually zero downtime, and the whole game goes very quickly [i](30-40 minutes at most; less once everyone knows what they're doing)[/i].  It supports up to 7 players, but is a rarity in that adding players does not add to the time requirement.

[-]I'm giving it a solid 8.5 as a rating right now, but with the strong potential to go up to a 9 once I've played it a bit more.[/-]  I've played this enough now to make it a [-]9[/-] 9.5.



[color=green]Thanks Dan![/color]

RATING: 8
The best thing about 7 wonders is that it plays up to 7 players.  I can't think of another game that is as engaging, as quick, and as fun as 7 wonders for that many people.  Also, 7 wonders is great because there are no real turns, so there's no downtime during the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A good game that's fun and more-ish with plenty of decisions to be made in its half an hour playing time. However, you can reach saturation point with it where each game begins to feel samey. 

It's similar to a Magic: the Gathering draft only without having to play the game afterwards. This is clever because the best bit about Limited Magic was card drafting and deck building. What made those drafts great was pack evaluation, signalling possibilities, great variability and the thrill of opening packs. How does 7 Wonders compare on these points?

Pack evaluation: Working out which is the best card in the hand you've been passed, given what you've drafted already and what is likely to come your way. Sometimes what would be the best card in a vacuum is not the best choice given your previous picks. I'm glad this is still present in 7 Wonders, although there aren't so many things to factor in compared to Magic. This is likely to become more important as players get increasingly familiar with the game. The first few games will involve some relatively uninformed picks, but I can see a learning curve here to work through.

Signalling: Much more obvious in 7 Wonders, as players can see what you've picked after every pick. 'Hate drafting' is possible by spending cards your opponents want to build your wonder or to turn into coins.

Variability: Except for the purple scoring cards, the same cards are used in each game, so there's never going to be a game where one particular colour is present in greater numbers than another, or one resource is rarer. Expansions may change this. Without them, some variability comes from the different wonders each player can play and the interactions with different neighbouring wonders. There aren't as many different cards as I'd expected.

Thrill of opening packs: With every pack you open in Magic, there's always the hope that you'll get a ridiculously powerful card (usually rare) that fits right in with the rest of your deck. This is a complete lottery, but it's still exciting. In 7 Wonders, the only thing that matches this is hoping your 3rd Age hand contains a purple card which scores for cards you've already played. Not quite as thrilling, but also less swingy, so probably fairer all round.

It's easy to pick up with a depth that belies its simplicity and has the advantage of accommodating up to 7 people with little increase in time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Probably my wife's favorite game. We own the Cities and Leaders expansions and additional Wonder Boards as well.

Plays well with 3-4, or 5-7. A fantastic game.

RATING: 8
Juego de civilizaciones en el que se usa el sistema de "draft". Este sistema consiste en que todos los jugadores ven una serie de cartas, escogen una y pasan el resto al jugador de su lado y así sucesivamente. Nuestra civilización se va desarrollando mediante cartas en los aspectos militar, económico, científico, cultural, etc. Para ser un juego de civilizaciones es bastante sencillo de jugar, lo cual no suele ser habitual para este tipo de juegos.

RATING: 8
Game is somewhat easy to teach (1 playthough oftens seems enough for people to get the game), although how technology is scored takes a game or two for new people to get used to (especially the impact of gathering technology). Plays quickly, keeps everyone involved almost constantly and can introduce non-gamers to what else is out there in the boardgaming world.

I like the theme as I'm attracted to this historical era, so that's a small plus for me as well. I like how they used bigger-than-usual cards, but that makes it harder to find sleeves for the cards if that is you thing.
The box insert is pretty and usefull, but the actual space you would need to store this game can be drastically reduced by not keeping it in it's original box.

RATING: 7
The shear amount of options of cards/abilities/strategies of this game can be confusing to new players, but those who have played it, have really enjoyed it. The fact that it plays up to 7 without a substantial increase in time is also great.

While there is quite a bit of variability in the based game as player count, wonder, cards available to draft, all change from game to game, I can see how it could feel "samey" over time. Luckily there are many expansions available should I ever get to that point.

As it currently stands, it's a fast, fun game to play.

RATING: 10
A true classic of our time.

A benchmark in accessibility, speed, replay, and passion to replay. And not shabby in the curve for tactics and light strategy, neither. Allowing a fastplay game to develop into years of entertaining experimentation.

Advice to anyone with a "Game Designer" badge that rates 7 Wonders below a 5: In poker we call that a "tell".

RATING: 9
Put playing this game off for a while for some reason.  No idea why.  It is such a great game that is very easy to learn and plays nice and quickly.  Love how the game works perfectly with either 3 or 7 players.  Lots of strategy and thought needs to be put into what method you are going to use to win the game.  Try to get a few rounds of this in every few weeks in my gaming groups

RATING: 8
card drafting game with enough variety that it is decent.  it plays quite a few people, so that is nice.  the theme is good, and there's a certain amount of tactical variation.  a good short card game.  the art and feel of the cards and boards are wonderful, and the idea of battling your left and right neighbors is good.  You really have to think some before passing that handful of great cards on.

RATING: 9
7 Wonders' main strength is its innovative game mechanic, whereby all players consider their options at the same time. That shortens game time significantly. The fabulous artwork adds to the feel of the game. Best part is its two-player variant, which does not feel flat and overly random but instead provides much intrigue.

Recommended for gamers who are looking for shorter game time board games to act as fillers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The Amazing artwork hooked me in before the hype really got going... and some nice reviews from geeks I trust dragged me the rest of the way... and I'm glad they did :D  This heavy filler has just enough decision points and angst over what cards to play and pass to keep it interesting.  While it doesn't feel much like civ building... it does feel like building something (or failing to do so in a bad game...) This will be a great game to wind up or wind down game nights for a long time to come.

Also, the 2 player variant is just great.  It adds a few more decisions to be made and more opportunities to deny your opponent cards.  It is a bit slower to play with 2... but if you want a bit more in the game its the best way to play!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For maybe two years I tried to play, but my desire didn't materialize. Finally, I bought it because It was cheap and I moved to another country leaving many games at home. So I had to start a new gaming group, and I took the chance to buy the game. 
We played 4 and all first-timers; me, the only gamer, explained the rules. Some people got them very easy others didn't. So this was a - point, but I didn't expend more than 15 minutes doing it (+ point). The most difficult part to grasp for them was building the wonders' levels. 
We played the first age one by one, and it helped to clarify the rules, and soon after it was smooth. Everybody was engaged, looking at each other's tableau and think thoroughly. It took a while to finish, but it didn't feel like that. 
I don't like brainy games although I love board games because the tension they give and the difficult trade-offs. 7wonders gave me this, and I could play it with non-gamers, and it seems everybody enjoys it and it doesn't feel overwhelming.  What I miss were the laughs, the table talk and jokes, I guess is a matter of the group.​
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
Amped up Fairy Tale.  Some cards are worth points, others give you resources so you can draft and play better cards later in the game.  Each player gets a different Wonder, with its own abilities and point systems.

Light and quick but definitely deep enough to be satisfying.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
It's good! Enjoyable, interesting, has just enough interaction but can be quite solitaire if desired, which is a nice break from my usual sorts of games. Plus it plays almost any player count. It's not got endless levels of dynamic card play and strategy, the game is quite simple but there are multiple paths to victory, intriguing decisions to make where the optimal move is not always obvious and you can mess with other players a bit without being too cruel. I like it a lot.

RATING: 7
Nice drafting game with next-door-neighbor interaction to make it quite playable with 7 players.  Impressively, the 2-player drafting works really well, too, due to the clever mechanisms provided to create a schizophrenic third player (played alternately by each player... from the real player's slightly-enhanced hand!).

As I play this more, I think my rating my be at risk of rising from [b][bgcolor=#99ffff] 7 [/bgcolor][/b] to [b][bgcolor=#66ff99] 8 [/bgcolor][/b]....

RATING: N/A
Despite being called a gateway game, the rules for 7 Wonders can be a lot for new players, particularly the different ways each kind of card scores. However, the many ways to score offer a lot of variety even with just the base game. This is a keeper and will probably be counted as a classic given a few more years.

RATING: 6
You can play this with 2-7 players and get a gaming fix. Nothing really draws me to playing it apart from that it's convenient in terms of time and players it can accomadate (ie 'What shall we play, there's X of us?', 'I know...'). It's a bit like pulling the lever on a one-armed bandit - its over pretty quick and I'm eargerly anticipating the scoring. It fits the bill and you get those gaming decisions you crave but I can't give this game a better rating.

Can't mention this and RftG in the same breath. RftG has incomparable art and is much more cerebral. Different games entirely.

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
I can still play this game for two reasons: it's fast and pretty. As a game though I find it uninspiring. The length and the mechanic do not allow much room for changing/adapting strategy during the game, so you're basically taking chances as you can't forsee when and if you're going to see certain cards.
Also there is really not much in the way of interacting/interfering with other people, and to me the game totally lacks tension.

Update: with more plays and the Cities expansion I'm starting to like this game more. Still not my favorite nor the example of excellence most are claiming, but a nice and pleasant game to have handy for many occasions (and the short playing time helps).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
After 10+ Plays: I wasn't too impressed after my first play of this, but I kept getting pulled into it because it is so popular with my group, and now I like it even less.  The drafting only provides the illusion of different strategies, when in reality you do the same thing every game.  If I'm collecting green cards in one game, how is that functionally any different than collecting blue cards or red cards, which give points but in a slightly different way?  Add to this tedium the fact that among competent players, the outcome is nearly all luck.  Whoever draws or gets passed a few fortuitous cards in the last round will dominate.  

In large part this game has the same fatal flaw as Fairy Tale--drafting is not a game by itself.  There needs to be something that the draft is leading to, which creates actual interesting decisions during the draft.  Otherwise, you're just left picking the highest point cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I Liked this game but tired of it and traded it away.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Hmm . . . I'm still unsure of what I think of 7 Wonders. On one hand, the drafting mechanic certainly is intriguing, and I am impressed by the balance between the different scoring strategies. On the other hand, I am not convinced that it would not get old after the cards are more recognizable. Even in my second play I was less enamored than I was originally.

I believe my opinions are affected by playing it with fewer players (4 and 3). One or two games of 5+ players should provide a more complete picture. I do find myself wanting to play again, even if only to clarify my opinion of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Typical Euro. Good mechanics and no theme whatsoever. There is absolutely no flavour of antiquity except for the words on the cards. The strategic choices are really confusing and it will probably take some time to get the proper strategies. Personally I felt this was a complete waste of time to play, though I accept that other gamers may admire the mechanics.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Medium weight, pretty simple to teach. Fun with pretty good replay value since the different wonders and different drafting affects what strategy you'll use. Far more tactical than strategic, since the cards you draft and what your opponents choose can prevent you from planning what you want to do in advance. I really like that the simultaneous action selection prevents the game from slowing down with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Tried to use it as a gateway game. Ended up being too complicated because of all the different card types. Also the other players expected something more interesting to happen after the drafting than just calculating final score.

Still seems like an interesting game to me. Only I don't like the card designs because the cost indicators are unnecessarily small and the iconography is not always very clear so using text in addition wouldn't hurt.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.25
Plays quick, is relatively easy to explain, the girlfriend loves it and you can play with 7 in 30 minutes. The game certainly is great for casual play, as filler or as warmup. New players need one or two games to fully grasp it's concepts (how draft works, how to find a balance of resources, how to chain your buildings). Experienced players can enjoy the layers of strategy that reveal themselves after several plays, while there is still the chance that a casual player can compete for the win. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Really good game. Some say this game is overrated but I couldn't disagree more. The beauty of this game is the player range it supports without loosing its playability. I love this game with 8 and I love it just as much with 2. I also like that as the player number goes down the strategy goes up making for an appropriately luck based game with a large group and an equally appropriately strategy based game with a small one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An amazingly robust strategic design for a whopping seven players, and yet also quite possibly the best THREE-player strategy game EVER devised.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is one of my favorite games. It's not very strategic, since you don't know what cards you'll have next turn, but instead it provides you with an incredibly rewarding tactical game experience where you constantly have to adapt to what's on the table and what's in your hand. Best with 4+ players in my opinion, the 2 and 3 player experiences are still good.

My favorite part is that it is asymetrical, with each player having access to different powers and resources based on their wonder. Each wonder provides a satisfyingly different experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
An excellent filler card game with simple mechanics and a fast pace to it. Very convenient in that it plays a crowd (in about 40 minutes, no matter how many play) and stands well to repeat performances.

The game is tricky to explain and I could see it at times not hitting the table because I can't muster the energy to teach it. "Race for the Galaxy" suffers from the same thing, to a greater degree.

Also worth mentioning: The game has stunning artwork, but the cards aren't very good quality and will start to show wear rather quickly.

Own all of the expansions. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Interesting and very quick, although I've overplayed it at this point. You might get stuck without the resources you need with 6 or 7 players, and getting a neighbour to pay you constantly for resources isn't always something under your control. But has many different things to do, the drafting mechanic is fun, the variation in the wonders is neat, and it's hard to get completely screwed (although earlier decision can come back to haunt you).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Card based civilisation building game. Main mechanic is drafting: keep one card from a hand then pass it to the next player. Can be tricky to learn due to the wide array of different card types and symbols. Once learned however, plays quickly and with decent depth.

Theme: Civilisation building
Mechanic: Card drafting
Ideal players: 3-7
Length: Short
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This game is great. And it is horrible.
The nature of drafting is ok, but the implementation in this game makes it horrible at times. You can be in a situation where you litterally have no way of winning due to the drafting, where no matter how good of a tactitian you are you are still screwed - hence the rating.
When it is good, the game is actually really enjoyable. But when it is bad you wan't to flip the table and play another game instead.

RATING: 9
KEEPER
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game has been such a success at my gaming table.  I put off buying it for a long time, because I was concerned it would be too light.  However, my family and I played it for free at a local pub/game store, and we fell in love with it.  

Yes, it is rather light on rules, but every turn of the game introduced meaningful decisions.  Which card is the best for me versus which card should I deny my opponents (and, if so, how can I capitalize on that denial)? 

I usually prefer long games that are heavier in rules, but I just can't pass up the delight that we all have with this game.  Additionally, every time I play, I try to pursue a different strategy, and I'm impressed by how many different avenues are available for victory.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
El juego tiene 3 eras. En cada era se irán rotando 7 cartas que los jugadores pueden construir para obtener recursos, PV o habilidades especiales. Tu puntuación dependerá de las 2 ciudades que sean tus vecinas ya que puedes comprarles recursos y te enfrentarás a ellas con poder militar al final de cada era.
